I personally don't see my opinion to be unpopular because the game is good as it is now.

Those people who complain are angry because the world has to be explored thoroughly or simply cannot read their stats.

If you do not have the according armor and weapon rating for the enemy or for the area you are in you should ignore it.

Here is a little tip. Talk to NPCs to find important areas, items, artifacts, etc. and avoid areas that are not suited for your equipment:
White/1 star= weakest
Green/2 stars= second weakest
Blue/3 stars= middle
Purple/4 stars= second strongest
Yellow (or gold)/5stars= strongest

Work your way up slowly in each region. You just need to invest some time.
I have had a great time during Alpha and that the EXP is gone is sad but that system isn't necessary to have fun.

Pixxie has also made a tutorial on how to get started with the game. It's in the game's discussions here on Steam. If you need help you should check it out.

The hate on this is extremely odd to me. Sure on release it only has 3 armies. If your only looking at numbers your gonna have a bad time. Devs want to add "all races" from 40k lore given time, and if they are as fleshed out as they are now I cannot wait. With new races comes new multiplayer modes because thats just how they set that up. I have about 12 hours into this game at the time of this review and it is all campaign. Skulls are so thrown around in campaign that i have over 1000 skulls without playing a single multiplayer game and unlocking atleast 3 or 4 heroes to play in campaign cuz i didnt want striking scorpions or whatever. The game is a very refreshing breath to the RTS genre. While i see the comparison to a MOBA I can tell you from having hours into the Beta that it is not. A Moba implies you level up your hero in the arena and get equipment while in the field and whatever. This you do not. Only benefit of leveling up your hero in any mode is more skins and fancy circle under their feet OOOOOO! Play through the campaign and your heroes will atleast be lvl 7 or 8. Unlocked Terminator cuz i didnt want Jonah and it was lvl 4 or 5 by end of 1 yes 1 mission. 
some pros
-Story seems to take quite awhile. Each mission takes me about an hour on Normal but that might just be i like to crush enemies
-All races play vastly different from their DOW1 and DOW2 counterparts. 
-With Devs wanting to add all races from 40k lore and with the polish and uniqueness each races brings now its hard not to get excited
-guaranteed to have new modes as thats how their menu is set up. whether its last stand or annihilation time will tell
-price tag is normal. most sites have for around $45 or less
-if you don't like amount of races at launch guaranteed in a year or two pick up Grand Master version
-some missions have you get very familiar with the race your using, down to what their buildings do.
Cons
-campaign jumping from Races is very daunting at times, goign from space marine to Ork is less jarring than going Ork to Eldar to Ork
-out of the 12 missions ive played 1 was very annoying and if you played the campaign you probably will already know which Eldar one im talking about.
-Interesting story, but kinda cliche
Neither Pro nor Con depends on person
-base building is minimal. Like in DOW 2 you build your buildings to get more units. The difference is there is more buildings to choose. Instead of upgrading your units by clicking on the singular squads you build a building to upgrade all squads, some squads however still have to be clicked singular i.e. tactical squad to get flamers or lascannon
-resource points are still a thing if you didnt like from first game you wont like now.
-Multiplayer Power Core mode just feels like your smacking a big base with the Core being the HQ
So in closing, multiplayer isnt bad if you think of it like a true RTS where turrets are there as base defense and the Core is the HQ you have to destroy to win. the "power generators" are so easy to take down i dont even know why they have them. If after reading this your still undecided know that I havent touched skirmish or multiplayer since Open Beta, all my hours are from campaign(about 12 at time of review) and i could easily get more hours farming skulls to unlock and playing multiplayer matches. I paid $45 for this game and if I can get 45 hours out of it(which i very easily could) my money is considered worth the investment.

I wanted to like Celeste. Really, I did!

And in many ways, the game delivered on many things that I heard. The story was well told, and Madeline is a great protagonist. Seeing her tale unfold as both she and Badeline developed through the story was intriguing. The dialogue can strike a consistent nail on being both serious, funny, or both simultaneously. Theo is great fun, and the other characters are well-written. The soundtrack is great as well, and if for nothing else, I pushed for that.

This all falls apart when, at least for me, the gameplay doesn't hold up. As someone with Super Meat Boy, Cave Story, the four Shovel Knight campaigns, VVVVVV, ect. under their belt, all games I love, Celeste just... doesn't hold up with these titles. Allow me to explain.

If I had to take a shot at what I disliked about this game's gameplay, I would probably say 'the dash'. The climbing mechanic is cumbersome at times, and I've died plenty when I thought I was holding the climb button when my finger twitched, but I had a lot more frustration with the dash. I don't even think it's the dash itself, more the fact that the 8 directions it fires off in feel extremely inconsistent to land. Retracting my first statement, I don't think it's even the dash primarily. Several other features fall to this as well, like the bubble apparatus in [spoiler] Golden Ridge [/spoiler] and [spoiler] Mirror Temple [/spoiler], where you have to aim in 8 directions. Very often did I find myself going diagonally up when I want to go straight forward, or vice versa when I actually needed a diagonal dash.

This is my biggest complaint with the game. The rest of it honestly did go smoothly. As I said, I loved the story and the soundtrack, but ultimately, they're vices to the gameplay. And loathe I am to say it, Celeste unfortunately fails to deliver on the most critical aspect of a brutal platformer like this - the ability to always know that your movement is precise.

I have mixed feelings about this. If this was a movie, it would have been oscar-nominated. But as a game, it is very flawed.

You have to realise getting into this, that what you have before you is a movie interrupted by mediocre gameplay. The gameplay will not keep you entertained for 30 hours. Even though the game interrupts you with notification spam all the time, even though the movement is janky and buggy and frustrating, especially with offroad vehicles, even though there is all this repetetive ridiculously annoying handholding, frustrating enemies, horrible savepoints, and even though the game loves to make you click through menus - 12 clicks for every mission you want to turn in, I enjoyed the first 10 hours or so. But the other 20 were a total and absolute slog. I thought about just watching the rest on youtube many times. There are uneccessarily many missions in the game, and the gameplay just isn't interesting enough for that. Trust me, once you get past the half way point, you want to just get it done. And. it. just. doesn't. end.

In case you don't know anything about the game, and without spoilers: this is quite literally a walking simulator. There are enemies, there is shooting, but it is not very engaging. You will walk, a lot. There are things making walking more interesting, but not for 30 hours.

So then why do I recommend this? Because, as a movie, this game is great. The world is amazing, unique, and something never seen before. The cutscenes are the absolute best I have ever seen in my 26 years of gaming. I believe they were all acted out, by the actual actors, probably with really good facial mocap because the lipsync is flawless. The details and acting in every scene are putting many actual movies to shame. There is just so much going on in the background of every scene, so many little things that all tell a story in of itself. It is one of those movies, where every frame could be a painting. The story is just weird but engaging and definitely something you have never experienced before. I am over 30, I have seen many movies, read many books, played many games. Usually, I know where a story is going from the start. But not here. This is actually so well written or just plain weird that it had me staring in bewilderment at the screen many times.

So there you are. If you are expecting engaging gameplay, cool action, etc. Stay away. If you like weird movies, go for it. I would say this: don't do side missions. Save up your enjoyment of the gameplay to get you as far through the game as possible.

This game has the same faults Doom 2016 had but amplified. 

First of all the sound mixing sucks. People might think this is a nitpick but sound is critical in a game where the entire premise revolves around shooting. Gunshots lack punch and the spatial audio is still terrible. The weapon sounds give the impression you are shooting bbs at your enemies. Go play Insurgency Sandstorm, MW19, Squad or practically any other game then come back to this. You will be amazed at how bad the sound mixing is. Hell, even the original two Doom games had better gun sounds.

The gibbing and weapon feedback feels terrible. Enemies just turn into weightless mush after you shoot them only to disappear moments later. I just don't feel the impact of the guns. Something about the enemy animation is way too floaty. The lack of feedback and weak audio completely ruins the experience and leaves me feeling completely disconnected from the carnage. That's a death sentence for a Doom game!

The flashy item pickups add visual clutter, ruin the aesthetic and are annoying. They take me out of the game. I dislike the weapon upgrade system as well. I think the combat system in general is bloated and over-complicated for a Doom game. Doom has always been known to have simple combat that just worked and this isn't that.

The combat and atmosphere in this game isn't immersive. It feels cartoony, bloated, over-polished. and disconnected. The game in general lacks the visceral experience and atmosphere the previous games had. I don't feel immersed in this world at all. It feels like watered down, Disney Doom.

Excellent survival (as well as a creative mode and freeroam mode) gameplay with an unique map setting where the Ocean plays the main part in it, but also includes islands surrounding the giant map lay-out. If they say 'survival' mode, they really mean surviving on your own.. Leaves the player frightened, surprised, amazed and even frustrated at some point within the gameplay (which is a progress checkpoint scattered all around the map which the player need to find it for himself). 

I recommend this if you dislike pre-chewed nonsense or games that basically play the game for you. The science-fiction setting of the map is what makes the game so unique, this was the sort of thing No Man's Sky was trying to head for but unsucceeded to do so. Subnautica however takes in the place there were NMS failed! The Hardcore mode is what makes the game so interesting, since you're basically surviving a crash of the mothership you came from (no spoiler alert intended, this is literally at the start of the game).  It takes courage, cleverness and patience to proceed further within the gameplay. And as soon as you start discovering things, you keep clustered within the giant map of the Alien underwater world which has deep secrets laying ahead...

Its undeniable that this game has issues. People complain that the maps aren't balanced, that the weapons aren't balanced, that there's glitches here and there, that they want more content, but even if that were true I have two things I want to point out.

1. This game was made by something like 11 people who have never designed a game before.
2. They don't owe you anything.

Everyone forgets what it used to be like buying a game. You bought the game and that was it. End of story. Now you own what you bought, no more, no less. 

This game has no subscriptions, no micro-transactions, and no paid DLC, yet the devs are still providing more content and fixes!

Think about that. How many people do you know that work for free? How can you sit here and complain about a game that costs half the price of a triple A title, competes with some triple A titles, and where the devs are actually listening to the community and providing more content FOR FREE!

They are a small team of developers working on their first project and they knocked it out of the park! The game is beautiful, the music is gorgeous, and the combat is extremely rewarding. I couldn't recommend this game enough. 

It's okay to give constructive criticism, but don't listen to reviewers who complain a game doesn't get updated enough.  The only way that happens is to hire more developers, which means more money, which means . . . lootboxes. If thats what you want, Fortnite pushes out an update every other week.

If you're lookig for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Chocolate Peanut Butter Ice Cream Sandwich Cookies recipe you've come to the right place.

8-10 sandwiches

Ingredients
½ cup butter, softened
½ cup peanut butter
⅔ cup sugar
⅓ cup brown sugar
1 egg
1 teaspoon vanilla
½ teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon baking soda
1¾ cup flour
chocolate ice cream

Instructions
Cream butter, peanut butter, and sugars. Add egg and vanilla and mix well.
Add salt, soda, and flour, and mix until combined.
Form dough into large 2-inch balls, and place on a baking sheet. Use a fork to flatten cookies. Bake at 350F for 12-14 minutes.
Let ice cream soften slightly. Place a generous amount of ice cream between two cookies. Place sandwiches in the freezer for 20-30 minutes before serving.

Oh, geez... do you want to mysteriously teleport into tomorrow? Play this game. Its habit of making you want to take "just one more turn" and "just finish this one thing up" will make tomorrow's morning sun shine through your window when you still thought it was 9pm the previous night. The game is mesmerizing and time wasting in a way that no other game franchise has ever done. All the Civ games have been this way.
I've played a lot of several of the Civ games, and I honestly have to admit that I still am a bit fuzzy on some of the rules and how some of the game mechanics affect what happens in the game. I really don't understand them very well. If I better understood how all the different actions in the game affected what was happening, I'd probably have a better time. As it stands, it's just something to waste my time when I want tomorrow to come faster.

From the one game I played, and the 5 days I survived -

Day 1: Build Cabin off of edge of cliff overlooking ocean so no cannibals can sneak from behind it
- Surround the front with traps
- Try to sleep for the night, but cannibals chillin outside so can't
- Spend the night behind my cabin with a small fire (theres a little spot for my character to hide, but not enough room for the cannibals to reach me, they just fall off the cliff)

Day 2: Time to explore the beach
-Find luggage scattered down the shore, with more energy bars than I know what to do with
-Find boat, on it - flares, new axe, rope, someones mix tape and a skull
-Head back to basecamp, but on the way find some camp with triangular cabins. Creeoy music starts up so I don't hang around too long
-Actually get some decent sleep that night

Day 3: More exploring
-Decide to explore the woods some more
-Find berrys, seeds etc
-Stumble across another one of those camps, this time I look around
-Seems like the cannibals have a fetish for tennis balls since every corpse I find has about 8 shoved in them
-Find a hole leading to a cave with a rope going down, decide against it since I'm probably not ready
-Head back to camp for some sleep

Day 4: Defenses
-Decide I need better defenses around my cabin
-Build walls almost all around my cabin (this takes about the whole day)
-Sleep

Day 5: Death
-Wake up and go to finish my wall
-As I step out side my fortress to gather more logs I see a group of cannibals just walking around not far from me (about 6)
-Stay away from them but don't actually run
-As they get closer I go back into my fortress
-They don't chase me but somehow they all wandered into the one spot I hadn't set up a wall
-They want my blood now
-I hide in my cabin as they all rush to me
-5 of the 6 hit my traps
-He starts attacking, I try to swing my axe and he doesn't swing it
-I die because asshole didn't swing his axe no matter how many times I tried to get him to

I can't say enough good things about this game.  I was hoping this game would be something different from the usual, relaxing, engaging and beautiful and it is all that and more. I purchased the game in a sale bundle which for a bit less than retail for the core game also included for free the DLC's Going East, Scandinavia, High Value cargo and a couple other cosmetic dodads.   Probably the best value of any of the many games and bundles I've purchased on Steam. 

I'm not a hardcore gamer and I'm running this on an older MacBook (which necessitates much lower graphics settings) but playing ET2 is simply a beautiful experience.  It's like spending hours driving through European postcards and yet it provides frequent enough decisions (gas, repairs, job choice,  occasionally difficult driving situations, managing your company, etc...) that 90 hours in I still feel engaged and excited to play more. 


As for the visuals, I have to praise the designers. There's so many ways they could have done less and still had a game that was nearly as good, but it's amazing how much detail they include.  As an example, most driving games have areas with tall highway sound barriers and that's the edge of the world, but in ET2 when using the chase camera suddenly you see that on the other side of the barriers is even more of the world: forests or an industrial zone or a castle or a....  Because of this, and even though it's just s smidge more fiddly to drive, I highly recommend using the chase camera when driving during the day.  It's really ups the beauty factor. 


Lastly, if you don't have a driving rig I highly recommend a PS2 style controller or other pad with 2 joysticks.  Being able to assign one joystick to the steering and the other to provide an incrmental control for the throttle (accelleration and reverse) makes the trucks much easier to control and the game even more fun to play.  If you need one the Logitech F310 (newer version of what I have) is well rated and tends to go for $15-20 on Amazon. I assure you it will be money very well spent.

The Binding of Isaac Rebirth, is an amzing contribution to the franchise. Not only does it reinvent the spooky feeling that The Binding of Isaac gave us, but it gives the player a sense of exploration, With the rooms being larger and the amount of enemies in each room sufficing the space. Visually satisfying and game mechanics are great, unlocking new levels as you play through. At the beginning is may seem quick the game, but as you finish it again and again unlocking more things and donating extra gold to the shop. You will find that you are hooked at playing it. Given that there are 178 achievements, you would be busy for a while to hunt them all down!!
Grinding and grinding to unlock all the characters, all the secrets and all the endings. Easily can sink 5 hours a day into this. As you may see i have not done so with my hours on this but I sure am planing to.
All in all I found Rebirth absolutely brilliant. I recommend it to anyone. Although it can be a rage inducer at times. Beating Mum then dying to a mob, one of the most infuriating moments in a game, but alas. That happens.
I hope all that play it, find as much enjoyment as I have with the game.

What can I say? It's Half-Life. Almost every FPS game released after this game owes something to it.

Unlike many other historically important shooters, such as Doom or Quake, Half-Life's gameplay holds up pretty well in comparison to today's FPS fare, probably because it was so influential that other games since have simply followed its example. The gunfights are an addictive mix of frenzied improvisation and tactical planning, and the game's pacing is excellent (at least up until the unfortunate Xen chapters, which murder the pacing somewhat in its final 20% or so.)

In any case, this game is well worth the $2 it goes down to on sale. The question, then, is which version to buy; the original (as I am reviewing here), the Source port, or Black Mesa. Half-Life: Source is pretty much the same game but with the tradeoff of better box physics in exchange for more bugs and costing five times as much. Black Mesa is a totally different game, and not really my cup of tea; for my money, you should experience the original before deciding whether to try Black Mesa's reimagining.

I'd recommend this game to anyone with an interest in first-person shooters, past or present. It holds up, and for as little as it costs, you're not taking much of a risk on whether you enjoy it or not. Try it out!

It's a mod for mods: It's Counter Strike Souce!

Built around what must be the Half Life 2 source SDK engine? I'm guessing! Counter Stike is filled with guns, knives and you've guessed it mods! So what is this game you ask? Is like Garry's mod except with no gun that will let you spawn anything... well, yes and no...

CounterStrike - a game which involves you countrolling a human and/or alien and/or anything with a skin pack is a game which allows you to modify and host just about anything that involves moving around... racing, shooting, zombie survival the game has it all... However, it can seem a bit dated to those who expect High Def Super Awesome Fun Time Lazer Death with Gorden Freeman and the Orient Express 2! 
But if you can get past the graphics and the "Fire in the hole" noises that tend to happen when someone throws their grenade -.- 

You can enjoy a good chunk of gaming... given it can be a bit quiet at times and makes you nod off thinking nothing is going to happen.

This is one of my favorite platformers/games for many reasons. The controls are very refined and feel amazing to play with. Being able to press a button to rapidly fall adds much more depth than I expected it would, and when mixed with ledge grabbing, it is very simple but lets you express yourself in many ways. Great controls are nothing if you can't put them to good use, and the level design is consistently creative. The End Is Nigh offers 600+ screens, and just about every possibility you could hope for is explored. Falling structures, complex enemies, water sections (better than most), and other mechanics are all mixed together in the main path through the game, side areas, cartridges, and inside Stevens. By far the strongest aspect of The End Is Nigh is its challenge. Every collectible gives a valuable reward, and the game is still satisfying without the extra content. If you just want to beat the game and finish the main objective, you'll be very happy with your experience. If you want to collect every single thing in game, you'll be even happier with your experience. If you want to push yourself to your absolute limits, there are countless challenges that will make you want to pull out your hair and scream, followed by euphoria once you finally do it. The more you play the more you'll love it.

Titan souls purports to challenge the player through bosses that require both reflexion and reflexes. I found myself running out of patience and praying for luck. 
    The game consists in a boss rush where your ennemies, against whom one mistake is fatal, all possess a weakness to which the character's single arrow is deadly. Unfortunately, this nonetheless interesting premise is ruined by a clumsy implementation. Considering how costly are errors, it is necessary for the player to feel responsible for them. However, he may find himself rather blaming the game, and rightly so, for mainly 3 reasons:
[list]
   [*]Aiming with a joystick and without an indicator or aim assist is simply frustrating. Reliably hitting targets outside of a small radius is about impossible. The difficulty of the game is tailored around this characteristic, but why handicap the player with vague aim that could be improved with a simple indicator? Also, keyboard controls are pretty much dysfunctional. I suppose all of this was designed purposefully to balance the difficulty of the one-shot mechanic, but still. 
   [*]Beating bosses requires experimenting, since the winning condition isn't always obvious, but finding answers often requires several walks back to the boss arena, which becomes a bit of an artificial grind. 
   [*]Close calls are frequent, and I felt like hitboxes were sometimes innacurate. 
[/list]
   These flaws don't impair too much the gameplay experience in normal mode since quite a bit of leeway is given, but playing in "no roll no sprint" mode revealed a rotten foundation. 
   Also, the pixel art is pretty ordinary, in my opinion.
   I might have been harsh in this review, but a tighter 3.5 hours of gameplay for 16.99$ isn't asking too much, especially when the harder modes aren't worth playing.

This is one of those cases where Steam needs to put a neutral button. I don't hate the game, they would need to try to mess up borderlands gunplay and I like what they did to change some gun brands(Looking at you Hyperion, with your stupid snipers that can't hit jack in the old games) but the story is just..... painful. The writing is nothing special, a little cringe but nothing that would ruin the game, BL1 had a meh story too and it was just fine. [b] Right up until Ava is introduced. [/b] 

Ava is a little annoying but not unlikable at first, her sidequest to get her diary tells you the kinda stuff she's had to do to survive after her parents were killed and I honestly saw her as a character trying to make the best she could of her new life with Maya. However, the writing for her quickly takes a nosedive once you [spoiler] Open the vault on Promethea. [/spoiler] She almost instantly went from girl trying to make the best of her life, even if she has a little of a rebellious attitude, to a spoiled child that deserves a time out for the rest of the game and the rest of the cast just.... [b] Accepts her bratty nature without question! [/b] I don't think I need to spoiler this but just in case, [spoiler] When Maya is killed, Ava not only seems to move on frighteningly quick, but she actually goes as far to blame Lilith for it! Not to terribly long after, she gets made leader of the crimson raiders! [/spoiler] Ava could be removed from the entire game and it would be a net benefit since they don't have the story culminating with this child taking center stage among the non-player characters in the main story.

If you see this game for a price you can justify, go right ahead and buy it, but for what I got, I actually fell guilty for accepting this from a friend, even if it was half price.

EDIT: Gearbox, are you really trying to kill one of your biggest cash cows? A season pass 2 and new "everything" version, screwing everyone who bought the super deluxe edition out of more content without making them pay more. Borderlands isn't League or Rainbow Six, you aren't a PvP game that has ranked seasons and the fact that you think you can just get away with this shows how garbage your decision makers are

It is a really good game, and it reminds me of silent hunter. There are not so many submarine simulation game recently. So if you are a submarine game fan, and you want to enjoy some bad ass serious mordern submarine tactics and warfare, it is definitly your choice!
For the UI, it is nothing like silent hunter------it is much simpler than the silent hunter series and dangerous waters, no more dazzling buttons, no more complex TMA. In dangerous waters i need more than 20 minutes to attack an enemy vessel. However in this game you need no more than 5 minutes. Generally in this game, things and much more visualised than in Dangerous Waters. You can directly SEE whats going on(if you have enough enmey vessel information) rather than sitting in some omni-control room.
However there are still some parts i dont like. 
First, it kind of lost that feeling of silent hunter series, and I found that it is not because of different submarines. Because I want that RPG feeling from silent hunter series. In silent hunter series, I AM A CAPTAIN! I can walk in your submarine and see what my boys are doing. However, in this game, maybe I am just a artifical intelligent program? It is seems a little bit weird but i just missed the RPG feeling and career feeling from the silent hunter.
Second, it seems that the damage system is not complete. You can sink any enemy vessel with just one torpedo: no matter it is a old November class or the sea behemoth Typhoon. Even the surface ship can be dealt with one torpedo hit. Thats not realistic.
Third, the price is not satisfying, 39$.

10/1 best game

I've been enjoying the game so far. I've played enough TCG such as Pokemon, Hearthstone, Yu-gi-oh and the very recent GWENT (Witcher card game). My first impressions is that Artifact is very polished, high quality and refreshing. I know people are bashing its monetizing model, lets put that aside for now. 

Now the game itself feels like Hearthstone in many ways as are most generic TCG available these days. Obviously Hearthstone being a massive success, many other card games would borrow its concept. But Artifact adds its own twist, it has 3 lanes/ boards. A very unique winning condition, either by taking out 2 towers or focus down the ancient. Those who played Dota 2 might be able to relate! I played thousands of hours of Dota 2 back in the days. Valve converted the MOBA into a card game which is pretty sick. The fact that they kept the Heroes skills and personalities from Dota 2 and made it into Artifact gives me nostalgia, I love it!

One of the interesting mechanics that I like the most is the priority. where you get to initiate first or second. To me this is very fun and strategic, where you could bait your opponent and then counter them once they have expanded their mana. Or to strike first before they could play any cards thus render thier turn useless. While the cards itself feels very Hearthstone like, mechanics such as priority and phases resemblance Yu-gi-oh much. It has been a while since I played a TCG with such complexity. Now when I say Artifact is a complex TCG, please do not be discouraged. Yes, it is more complex than Hearthstone but less complex than Yu-gi-oh IMO. And the tutorial did a decent job of explaining ALMOST everything you need to know. 

Now the monetizing model.... it is not F2P, it has no grind, it can be placed on the market place. I reckoned is okay.... at least these cards have some value?? Unlike Hearthstone which I spent like over $800 but now it is just sitting there since I'm no longer playing. And trust me, Artifact is easier to get the cards you want compare to other TCG. I like the Keeper draft where I could pick the cards I want (sniping for rares). You can straight up buy the cards that you want in the market place, you'd be surprise the cards are relatively cheap compare to other TCGs. 

But if you don't want to spend much, there is always Phantom Draft which is the mode I like the most. You get to play cards that you do not own, so I'd say you don't even need to have a full collection. I would just do Phatom draft all day, I just want to have fun. 

I think most veteran TCG players would like this game.

I've been playing Dead by Daylight for about a year and a half now and have been following it since the following months after its launch. It has been one of the few games that I consistently come back to whenever I want to play something either with friends or by myself. I've bonded and met a lot of great people either by playing this game or just by bringing it up.

I've seen this game through almost every patch, every bug, every chapter, every exploit, and will continue to do so. The game is fantastic, even though it can be very frustrating. But, so can any multiplayer game. Even with the bugs and the occasional toxic survivor or killer, you still have fun on either side of the killer's weapon.

When playing survivor, there's a variety of ways to play it while still achieving the main objective: do the gens, get the doors open, and escape. You can play altruistically and save your fellow survivors, take hits, be a distraction after you save someone from their final hook. You can be objective focused, work generators and work on the escape routes while others do the saving. Along with a lot of other builds that are possible. You can even go into a game just to loot the chests.

While playing the killer, of course your main objective is killing the survivors, but with the variety of the killers and their powers, you can control what type of game this will be. You can be a brutal chainsaw killer, trap survivors, hit them from across the map, or even hunt them down without them noticing. The perks just help with your weaknesses. Be it hunting survivors, maintaining map control, or slowing down the game. 

When it comes to current problems with this game I can name one major issue with Dead by Daylight and that is the Survivor main vs. Killer main mentality. At the end of the day, the developers do intend this game to be a killer biased game, which makes sense! But as you climb in hours and climb the ranks, the game slowly becomes even. And because of that, it causes the big discourse of "oh you're just a survivor/killer main, you don't know what the game needs", etc. etc. The best solution to this? Avoid these types of forums, players, or streamers. I don't mean plug your ears and sing 'lalala' anytime someone says something about balancing because there are so many good points from survivor and killer mains with thousands of hours. Like Hexy, JenDenise, Diatech (back when he used to stream it a lot more), ScottJund, and Hybrid Panda are some great examples of people who play one side more than the other and do have great opinions and ideas for balancing perks and changing up gameplay.

If you had asked me about eight or nine months ago what I had thought was the biggest problem was with this game, my immediate response would be that it feels like the developers don't listen and don't care about this game. But, it has definitely changed since then. Five months ago as of writing and posting this review, the development team posted a schedule that they are following as they continue to evolve and better Dead by Daylight. They have a better reporting system, outlining what they consider needs a permanent or temporary ban. They've added more people to their team and are taking in player feedback and feelings into consideration. It feels like they care about the game and their player base now, which is a large change from before. They stream and explain the changes and their reasoning and play test things to see if changes will be fun and fair and work with the game.

After all of this rambling, would I recommend this game? Yes. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of horror, slashers, and loves to grind. I would recommend anyone who is looking to play something new or has been looking at this for a while just to try it. When you put aside the discourse of survivor vs. killer mains, the community is great and fun. It is a fantastic game, with a great concept, and it has been well done.

**I now have 700 hours and still maintain this opinion.

***New chapters and updates have been added and if anything, I recommend it even more

The only downside is that you'll cry when the game is over ;(

This game is great for the stage it's in, and the fact that it is made by one person. It is fun, innovative and doesn't involve constant killing like most other games. 

As good as this game might be, there is not much implemented, as of yet. I am not complaining, only suggesting things which could be added in the future:

- Wide roads for horses and carts, with stables (similar to pastures).
- Multiplayer. I'm not 100% sure how this would work but I know a lot more people would buy this if it was multiplayer enabled.
- More models for buildings other than houses.
- The ability to research or upgrade technologies.
- Walls to keep out unwanted creatures or people.
- Outwards trade or Exportation. This could be an option from the trading port, that allows us to send out a boat to trade with other towns.
- Day/Night cycle. Again, I'm not exactly sure how this would work but it would be nice to see.
- Parks or recreational areas. At the moment people seem to hang around primarily in graveyards, something like a park would be a nice way to give the citizens a place to relax.
- More indepth citizens. It would be nice if the citizens each had a sort of story that you could follow through until their final days. Also they could become friends or enemies with other people, working better with people they like.
- Advanced job assignment. There should be a way to assign a certain peson to a certain buiding of a job. For example if I wanted Bob to work as a farmer on my orchard instead of on the farm, because it was winter.

This is not a game. This is a story, and a very well-written one at that. As you delve backwards through the memories of Johnny (or should I say Joey?), you begin to feel strange senses of realization each time you activate a memento. His life begins to piece together like a great and complex puzzle. Everything you thought was wrong. There will be tears. To the Moon and its beautiful soundtrack will have you both heart-broken and laughing at the same time.
10/10 would go to the Moon again. 

Also, there are pickled olives. What's not to love?

Shovel Knight is a perfect example of a how a new indie platformer should be made. It uses concepts from some of the best NES platformers (Mega-Man, Castlevania, and Super Mario). You'll get to experience (or re-experience) what it was like to play 8 bit platformers but without the bad controls and overly cheap game mechanics. There will be times when its frustrating but its usually because of a mistake you made or you haven't figured out the pattern to the level. Everything else like the music, level design, and RPG elements are more current but have an 8 bit style to them. Even at full price, Shovel Knight is well worth it!
Needs alot of TLC but even with its failings its a great game that deserves to be supported.

This game serves as a strong lesson on the dangers of vertical power creep.
It has some mechanics and ideas that really expand the series; Having customizable Skills and abilities that truly differ between  different characters lets those characters really shine. Two players playing as the same character can still have very different playstyles. And the differences between different guns by different manufacturers also adds some lovely variety.
But all of this means nothing when every third enemy you kill spews forth a spray of rare weapons.
Seriously, I don't even bother picking up blue or green weapons any more. You don't even need the money you'd get from selling them.
Gold quality weapons are so common and so much stronger than anything else that the entire CONCEPT of having millions of randomly generated guns is totally pointless.
The Mayhem system is a terrible idea. The devs are basically admitting that they CAN'T balance their game and are offering players a crude attempt to balance it themselves. It is an attempt to increase difficulty with blatantly arbitrary addition. Once you unlock Guardian Points, the last vestige of challenge in the game falls apart completely.
And don't bother pointing out that Mayhem and Guardian perks can be turned off: If you have to turn major aspects of a game OFF to make the game better, then it is a poorly made game.
This game is short, as linear as falling down a well, and piss-easy. It's boring to play.
The heart and soul of a good shooter is its choreography: You must carefully balance where the challenge lies, and make sure things are never too easy or too hard. Enemy placement and variety is key.
And this game falls flat in its choreography.
The writing is crap, too. Seriously, Eva is a nasty little monster who did nothing but brood and get characters we DO like killed; and we're supposed to sympathize with her?

It's hard for me to openly and honestly recommend Artiact as it currently stands. The draft mode is probably the most compelling aspect of it, but every time I boot up the game and play a few games I end my session feeling exhausted. Not in the "Ah that was a satisfying battle of wits way" but more of a "There's just a lot of information on screen" kind of way.

I feel like many of the systems in the game aren't there for gameplay, they're there to be similar to Dota 2, and while I appreciate the efforts, they just don't work well together.

The two biggest pains points for me: Imbalance and Randomness.

Card games do not have perfectly balanced cards, it's the nature of the beast and what ends up making draft formats funs. But Artifact is different in that it has Heroes. Unlike "bombs" you draft in, say, Magic: The Gathering, heroes are core to your strategy in the game, and keep coming back the entire game. They sway battles just by existing, sometimes in other lanes. The difference in a good hero and a bad one is GIGANTIC, to the point where having one or two key heroes in your draft can seriously carry you hard.

Randomness is also huge in Artifact. It's built into the core game. Due to how position on units works, you have a 25% chance to attack a target to your left or right, regardless of if your lane is full or empty. This takes away from a lot of the strategy planning ahead can have in combat, but does make combat tricks feel more valuable. Either way, this on top of the three decks in your shop, on top of natural card draw, on top of cards with random effects... It just feels like too much. The series of small random chances do help shake up the game, but sometimes they throw battles into your opponents favor out of seemingly nowhere. It makes for good back and forth gameplay sometimes, but even after 15 hours I can feel it grating on me. 

Artifact is a good game for a certain kind of player, I'm on the fence on whether or not I'm that kind of player. I'm enjoying Casual Phantom Draft for now but each time I run through a draft, I just find myself not wanting to touch the game for a few days. 

Artifact might be for you, but it's certainly not for everyone.
Good Game

I won't lie, usually I don't recommend a game if its good I just won't rip it to pieces.  But this game deserves it.  Let's go through the list: 
1: the graphics are actually surprisingly beautiful, especially if you zoom in on the stone structures its quite easily one of the prettiest games of its kind.
2: The devs are responsive, and not robotic like some developers I've encountered in the past and I appreciate that immensely so I felt they deserved props for it.  From responding to bug reports, to being present and updating people in the community and in discord these guys really are doing a great job.  
3: The systems of the game are, while somewhat complex in some aspects they are very logical and once you get a feel for them it'll come naturally.
4: Designing your own monuments:  This I can't stress enough I love it!  This may be a bias i have because of my field of studies but the fact that I can design and watch as my churches, and monasteries are constructed truly makes me happy.  The scale of the structures too is up to you, you can pick whether or not its a huge, towering cathedral with spirals topped with crosses, or gargoyles  its really that detailed and I love it.  
5: They are updating and working on the game quite often.  The updates do legitimately fix bugs, and the changes are usually fairly noticeable.  For instance, I was experiencing a glitch on one level once I hit ~102 citizens.  I tried that, actually today on the map I'm now making my mega monastery on, and I'm sitting at 150 citizens.  

Personally, I give this one a 10/10, guys great work and keep it up.

Before i get started: this has a good framework, and it's of an overall decent quality - good sound design, nice maps and graphics. However, it suffers A LOT from poor balancing that seems to be focused entirely on players that have all the unlocks in the game. 

If you've ever played Dota or League of Legends you should already be accustomed to this, except in DBD it's actually worse - in Dota and League of Legends, other players do not get inherent advantages over you for having played longer, besides naturally having a better understanding of the game and more experience. In DBD, playtime = unlocking actual gameplay modifiers, meaning that people that have played more than you will ALWAYS have an advantage over you that may in some cases be impossible to outplay. 

It's on the step below pay2winning - that is fortunately impossible in the game, as the only thing you can really buy is DLC characters (that DO however have their own unique abilities that are otherwise inaccessible.). If the game would've had pay2win elements, i would have had nothing but hate for it. As it is, i can respect the idea, despite the execution being extremely flawed.

For new players, Dead by Daylight is a good excuse to hang out with three friends (IF YOU VOICE CHAT), and very little else.

If you are willing to waste roughly 140 hours of your life to be given the opportunity to start playing Dead by Daylight FOR REAL, then you should give the game a try. If you are NOT willing to spend 140 empty hours of your life replaying the exact same maps with the exact same high rank max level killers that has all the unlocks available in the game when you're starting out at level 1 with literally NOTHING available, then steer clear.

I understand that the game may at one time have been fun, but because of endless power creeping (constantly making characters stronger based on the average level and available unlocks of players) this is literally unplayable when you're just starting out. As a survivor, all the killers are designed to be able to handle survivors that has unlocked every single perk in the game, across all the characters available - including DLCs. So when you do NOT have all the unlocks in the game, you're unfortunately still allowed to start matches so you can ruin them for everybody else because unlike them, you haven't already logged over 700 hours in the game and been along for the ride since the closed beta.

As a killer, we're at a reverse dilemma - all the survivors have all the unlocks possible in the game, while you have nothing. So you're pit against 4 players with 700+ hours logged and expected to beat them without a single unlock.

If you play non-stop, you'll typically be able to get your first "good" unlock 5 hours into the game. This amounts to roughly 15-20 defeats / hatch escapes (when you are the last man standing because you couldnt help the other survivors, you can escape instantly if you find a secret hatch in every level.).

Repeat this every single match, usually consisting of killers that can run roughly 30% faster than you and typically see you through walls thanks to their unlocked perks, for a week or so, and you'll unlock your first perk. Congratulations! Now you need to repeat this on AT LEAST 3 other characters one by one, and then you have to play a fifth character to a high enough level that you can use all the four perks from the four first characters you leveled up.

Thought you were good to go, huh?

Nah, you also need to depend on RNG giving you the essential skills and items you require to have even a slight chance against a killer, even if that killer is brand new to the game just like you. The survivors typically need something like 100 hours of experience for every 10 hours the killers have if they are to have so much as a sliver of hope that they can survive them without letting all their ally survivors die so they can bail through the hatch.

Don't waste your money. Wait for AT LEAST a 70% sale before you even think about buying this, or better yet an 80%-90% sale. Lukewarm sewage is more fun to play with than this, and honestly it's a shock this is even out of it's early access stage - never mind multiple seasons in with several DLCs.

Shovel Knight scratches an itch I didn't even know that I had. Its retro graphics combined with chiptune music remind me of the old Mega Man games, which is a franchise I loved as a child. 

The gameplay is quick, and crisp. You don't find yourself blundering because of the controls. The bosses themselves aren't too difficult; it's the levels that are your biggest challenge. The platforming in this game requires some practice. Luckily, the game doesn't run on an extra life system. When you die, you lose gold which you can recover as you restart.

The soundtrack for the game accents it so perfectly that the game seems less bright if you turn the music down. I don't say that a lot about soundtracks, but this one is definitely worth putting on headphones for. 

The story is actually pretty surprising. I thought it would be a cookie cutter hero vs. villains story, but it turns out to be so much more.

Definitely worth your time and money.

(The only spoiler in this review is blacked out, and something early on that you will quickly predict yourself in-game.)

[h1]What You Need To Know[/h1]
If you want the experience of a Souls-like but none of them drew you in, this is the perfect game for that. Same if you feel Metroidvanias just waste your time, but it's far more Souls-like. Personally I'd even call it open world before Metroidvania, even though it has those classic staples, probably because it's executing them so well it barely feels like the rest of the genre.

[b]Go in as blind as you can[/b], every aspect of this game is about discovery in some way. The point of it is the rewarding feeling exploration and relying only on yourself to beat any challenge gives, and don't worry, it will ease you in and doesn't take a god to finish. I mean, Northernlion finished it.

Keyboard works well, Steam Link will get you killed.
I've encountered no bugs. Ironic.

[h1]The Praise[/h1]
It does so many things competently, and trusts you with complete freedom of approach, that it will keep you interested even if you're not seeking out what it has to offer. No game is perfect, but if you are a fan of the things it focuses on (Souls-like, Metroidvania, in that order) it's what you're looking for perfectly executed. Well, at least everywhere that matters.

Because exploration is so at its core and the game is so easily worth recommending to most people I won't go deep into detail, though I could easily say a lot (mostly flattering analysis) on nearly every aspect of it. Vibrant visual presentation, creatively cute character designs, feels 3d due to deep layered backgrounds, both environmental and direct storytelling is wonderful, unique world, combat streamlined yet deep, renewable universal resource for OCD, fun level design, excellent choices for navigation tools, finding new things is incredibly rewarding and the game is mostly that, the feelings of getting stronger and relying on yourself completely... just trust when most people praise this game, everything it does - it does well - and it does a [b]lot[/b].

I paid as much for this game as I did for Witcher 3, which are the 2 biggest game expenses I've ever made (I'm cheap which may be relevant to you), and I'd pay double for Hollow Knight after knowing what it is and does.

[h1]The (Lack Of) Nitpicking[/h1]
I could nitpick the hell out of it as with anything (wasted soundtrack, low fps animations, sometimes [spoiler]wall grab[/spoiler] just doesn't work, Steam Link movement is imprecise), but problems I found were either very rare or so non-essential only I would care about them.

And most things that may seem detrimental are tradeoffs that fit the atmosphere/feeling the game is trying to create very welll. Like multiple functionalities per key on PC, while wasting most of the keyboard, being another contribution towards simple combat with an extremely high skill ceiling. Or being able to never see whole sections of the game if you miss a secret, which gives your freedom so much more weight and respect from the devs.

I could give this game 10/10 and not feel bad about it, even if it hit none of my interests, and I'm that guy who never gives anything over 9. Not even my favorite games or ones made perfectly to fit my interests.
Any issue I've had with the game is buried so deep under the good that even if it was worth mentioning, it shouldn't be, because it does nothing to make the game less enjoyable or less interesting of an experience.

I actually made a list of everything good and bad from the start, it was about equal for the first biome, then the good just kept growing exponentially and the bad got 1 more note total.

[h1]The Bad, If You Insist[/h1]
(The good is about 14x this long and you should just get the game regardless of your tastes.)
•Intro cinematic has jarringly low fps
•Some moves and character animations inherently have jarringly low fps
•Can't aim up/down and attack at the same time, have to aim before attack (even 1ms can matter)
•Foreground stuff sometimes blocks an important part of the screen, like an enemy
•If you have a hard time deciding which of multiple paths to take first, this game has that
•Music is generic, unnoticable in a bad way, though at least it fits the tone
•There's a move that feels missing in the starting set, but personally, after I got it I quickly grew to appreciate how its absence changes my approach to the game. A lot of things in this game made me consider a similar perspective.
•[spoiler]Wall grab[/spoiler] sometimes fails for no reason
•Steam Link joystick shouldn't be the typical joystick circle they use for all mobile games these days, not only because it's always imprecise since you can't feel it, but because this game has 4-directional movement. It's the perfect game to just put a D-pad overlay for.
•It took me hours to find 1 decent quality wallpaper of an NPC, the good wallpapers for this game are either blurry screenshots or for mobile

This is the game that changed FPS games forever.  Before this, the story was a screen of text before a level started.  The storyline was not continued and told solely from the players first person perspective.  The levels were very well designed, the enemies you confronted were smart and varied and required a different approach.  The weapons were varied with secondary abilities.  The sound and music was top notch.  This may not be the prettiest game in the world by today's standard, but the quality of the gameplay from the shooting, to the platforming, to the characters you meet, you will not be disappointed that you got to play the classic game that forever changed the history of gaming and what could be done in a shooter.

Thanks to a couple of my favorite youtubers I found this game while it was still early access and I have been playing it since. I am somehow proud to say this is one of the early access survival games that not only continued development through to full release but also didn't sacrifice the game's quality in an attempt to rush it out to fans. Admittedly there are more bugs than I would like, the most notably obvious being collision issues. Most of the time however, it plays very well. Despite it's beautiful, colorful and almost cartoonish look, this game can be downright terrifying at times, especially if you already don't like the ocean and everything it hides irl. Sonar and soundiin general are your best friends in this game though, as it is not uncommon for a leviathan (huge creature that in most cases thinks you look tasty) to clip into the ground and just "magically" appear directly in front of or behind you, luckily they are very noisy.
The story is sparse yet somehow feels suitably complete for the situation. Besides the clipping the only other thing that really annoys me about this game is the building. It is relatively expansive and that I don't have issues with, my issue is that seemingly basic structures aren't included in your "survival blueprints", you must find them. Logically it would make sense to have a multipurpose room or a water purifier as part of your basic survival blueprints when the datapad claims to provide blueprints based on environmental hazards, yet you have to find them to make them. Hell, you can't even figure out how to make a door without finding one first. However, this seems to be intended as a way to make the player actually explore rather than hide in their lifepod all day.

Tl:DR version: Good game overall
Pros: beautiful, engaging story, solid gameplay, almost never crashes, normally runs well
Cons: can be surprisingly scary, still has some issues mainly with collision, building can be annoyingly tedious at times.

There are many ways to play for free, but if you're a card collector you wont get the cards you want without spending some time on the community market. To be honest, even if you add up the cost of the expensive cards, you're still spending less money than on similar digital cardgames (wont even mention collectable ones). In Artifact the most expensive hero costs about 10 euro, the basic ones costing 10 cents; whereas Hearthstone (the biggest TCG) you wont even get half a legendary for 10 euro worth of packs.  

The need to pay for competitive play does make me want to give it a negative vote.....but still, the game is just so well designed and engaging, and animation and music are simply amazing. 
In view thereof, I simply have to recommend trying it out if you're a fan of the genre.

I've never felt the need to write a review before, but MORDHAU is such a great game, that I feel I need to talk about it.

I can go on and on about all the things everyone else has said, but I won't bore you with the obvious

The combat in this game has been talked about a lot, and I have to say that it is some of the best combat in any game I've played and that's not limited to just medieval fighting games. The combat is smooth, and feels so real and this effect is added onto with all the different ways you're able to utilize the weapons you have available.

The dynamic combat, with the way the swords clash and deflect off each other adds to the whole feel of the world as a whole. You feel like you're in a medieval war and it's an incredibly satisfying feeling.

The customization in the game is also stupendous, with fairly balanced progression and lots and lots of helmets, breastplates, and leg armor. This is also expanded on with what feels like a billion options for neck, shoulder, waist, shoes, etc. Customization to get exactly the type of knight you want.

The game is easy to pick up, easy to learn but very hard to master and I can say that I recommend it to anyone.

A true tabletop experience on the PC. Not nearly close to as clunky as I thought it would have been.

Only downside is that it assumes you know the Pathfinder ruleset. On the upside, it assumes you know the Pathfinder ruleset, and doesn't hold your hand.

In short, if you've played Dark Souls, loved it, and are open to some twists in the combat and movement formula, then you should most definitely love this.

Otherwise, ask yourself if you are tough enough to endure an extremely-hard-but-immensely-gratifying-when-succeeding type of game, with a traditional (but not necessarily historical) Japanese aesthetic and feel.

This game may not be for everyone, but it is, in my humble opinion, a masterpiece.

I've really come to enjoy this game. It is so much more than a delivery boy simulator. It's an almost therapeutic gaming experience and different to anything I have played before. There are so many details that reference different ideas and themes of modern life. It is literally art, the concepts in the story about life and death, human connection, technology and unity are so interesting I constantly find myself delving deeper into the game world to try and understand it. At first it feels as though you have no idea what is going on but the game does a good job of explaining it, you just have to give it time to develop and the dots will connect. I really enjoy the journeys from place to place, figuring out how to traverse a steep rocky mountainside while carrying all of your gear is unexpectedly satisfying and altercations with BT's will have you on the edge of your seat. The landscapes in the game are amazing and make it such a tranquil experience at times. This really is a game that you can sit down and be at peace in, but there are still thrills along the way. Hideo Kojima's story telling and the rich deep world he has created in Death Stranding has blown me away. The game really does keep you wondering all the time. If you get bored of anything that doesn't have you blowing stuff up or shooting something every second then this might not be for you, but there is combat and weaponry that is very fun to get into and gives you the option of different play styles. If you want to take a step into a game world that is genuinely very interesting to discover and explore then, I would recommend Death Stranding.

Gotta say.. The game in essence, is fun. However, I find that it is almost impossible to rank up due to the killer rage quitting and making everybody lose the game and all the blood points and previous rank point that they have aquired. It also annoys me that the wraith can just follow anybody he wants anywhere with the survivor having no hope of losing him simply because of his movement speed. It is impossible to hide from somebody that you can't get out of line of sight from. The hooks are placed way to close together. I have had four three people coordinate a rescue from one teammate that got hooked, The wraith managed to kill everybody and then hook every single one of us nearby and win the game. 

Getting into a match in itself if a task. As a survior I have found myself queing up for a match and entering a loading screen which brings me back to the main menu constantly for at least 3 to four minutes at a time before being placed into a match. As the killed you have to pray to god that nobody leaves the lobby otherwise it will never fill up. I have waited 20 minutes as the killer without a single survivor being placed in my game after the initial four. Matchmaking should be based on who has been waiting the longest. Not whatever system that has been set up in this game.

I find that design flaws such as these unacceptable and so I cannot reccoming this game until changes have been made.

I must add, after further experiencing the game I have come across new issues based off of the killer's (host) connection. I have been rubber-banded from escaping the killer and being pulled right back infront of him or being rubber banded back to the opposite side of a window and also teleporting inside of the killer because of their connection. I have now died and lost my rank multiple times because of this. DEVS DON'T MAKE THE KILLER THE HOST OF THE LOBBY. IF YOU DO, AT LEAST TAKE AWAY SOME OF THE CONSEQUENCES FOR THE SURVIVORS. The game isincredibly unfair at most times and a ranking system does not belong in this game.

On paper, and for probably the first 50 hours, this game is great. But the competitive nature of this 4v1 horror game is what really makes this not recommendable. You can't opt out of it either, the game has one game mode and one game mode only: online ranked. There's a lot of good things to say about Dead by Daylight, but it all goes out the window once your rank starts getting higher and higher, which, by the way, will happen regardless of how good you are- it's all about how much you play. For context, I hit rank 5 survivor before even realizing what ranks were... and hit rank 1 soon after (and I am NOT good). 

One of the main problems with the game is the meta- a thing you will be forced to face whether you like it or not once you've played a couple of hours. I'm not going to pretend like you don't know the basics of the game, but the simple explanation of it is is that there are 'perks', killers and survivors have only a handful of 'relevant' or 'meta' perks, and everyone has to run those perks or risk simply losing the game (yadda yadda yadda, you've played a competitive game before). Many 'meta' perks are locked behind DLC, but that's (somewhat) irrelevant. The issue is every survivor ends up playing the same, and all the killers pick from the same small pool of perks- making even playing against completely different killers usually play out the same way. Which really ain't fun.

Another problem is that killers are over tuned and survivors are like a bunch of evil rats running around cackling to each other. That is to say that killers have certain aspects to their balance and design that make them 'stronger' than the 4 survivors on a micro and macro level- while on the other hand, survivors tend be annoying little idiots that you either stomp into the ground or watch as they run circles around you. There is rarely an in-between, and neither of the two extremes are fun (nor do they award you with many bloodpoints). 

In this game, whether you are playing as a survivor or a killer (and I dare anyone with more hours to deny this), the majority of your time playing this game is spent saying "I'm getting camped.", "This was just a bad game.", "Oh man, there's an afk.", or "That was just anti-fun.". Every time you queue up in this game it's either to quench that satisfaction of getting a whole lot of blood points (I haven't even talked about how there are WAY too many progression systems in this) or hoping, and I mean just HOPING that you get something that could be described as a "Good Game".

There's some good to this game. Characters from multiple horror franchises crossing over? Cool! Some original characters that have good designs? Great! Nonlinear competitive game? Sounds interesting enough. But at the end of the day, it's just not fun.

Now, that isn't to say this game is doomed. Perks and other things COULD be rebalanced, but it wouldn't quite solve the underlying issues (those of which, aren't worth talking about in a face-value review like this). Many of these issues are at the core of the game's mechanics, and would require some major overhauls to get right, but, yeah, they COULD be fixed. Some other game with the same idea COULD come along and pull off the 'nonlinear competitive horror cross-over party' concept perfectly, sure. But I don't know one, and Dead by Daylight isn't it.

Don't sink your time into this. Don't buy unless it's on sale and EVEN THEN only if you're fine with only putting in at most 50 hours.

This game, despite lacking a scripted campaign or story, is the most emotional, intense, and deep game I've ever played. Simply put: it is a masterpiece of emergent storytelling. 

There is nothing like the ups and downs you experience as your best farmer loses his arm to a stray bullet, the tension as a heat wave prevents you from building those crucial defenses, or the horror you experience when your farm catches fire just before winter hits; the joys of seeing your colony through another harsh winter, or the humor of watching a rabid squirrel try to take down a machine gun turret.

I've been playing this game for years now over the course of its development and it only gets better with each update. Definite reccomend.

So let me be clear from the get go, I love this game. It's original, and when ti runs properly it can be wonderful and engaging. There is a reason I have 432 hours on it. 
Now the bad news. This game was unstable form the get go, I have had games where I have built up a sizable settlement, and others where I played for maybe 20 minutes before the game became unstable and I had to scrap that build and start over. While this game has been patched and "improved" over time often times the cost has been reduced performance, frame rate drop, and increased stability. The landscape that was once a barren desert with occasion scrubland has become crowded with mostly useless, often view/click blocking props. Additionally most of the props are non interactive so need iron or steel for a weapon, forget the wreckage right next to you and begin your journey for a shiny rock that is actually mine-able.  The addition of mods took some focus off the slow progress on this game and the sometimes bland tone of things. But this is starting to feel like Bethesda like levels of laziness. The graphics are fine for a game that is around 15 to 20 years old and the controls are simple which is usually good but in this case leaves something to be desired. Along with that, numerous key features still have not manifested.
All of this contributed to my mind being blown when the company announced they are beginning work on Kenshi 2 (the prequel). This game is still far from finished, it's barely a beta if we are being honest and the company is looking for another cash grab. They claim they are still going to be updating Kenshi but let's face it with a new cash grab on the horizon the odds of them doing quality work to finish what started off as an amazing game. 
So, an amazing Idea, a promising start, and a plummet into the pit of cash grabs and failed promises. If you see this for $5 or less on sale maybe grab it, just don't go in with high expectations, you will be disappointed. As for Kenshi 2, Hey Lowfi, maybe finish the first game, running to make another when the first is barely a beta (definitely not a stable one) is just a bad look.

First let me say, I live for the soulsborne series. These games offer me a level of brain training that no other game can for me and the boss fights give me an adrenaline rush akin to one i might only get from something like a real fight. The only thing about Sekiro that i think would be off putting to some soulsborne players, is that the parry system in this game is critical to success, if you cant wrap your head around that system you won't succeed.. kind of like how dodging became so important in Bloodborne due to lack of shield. Spent well over 1000+ hours on this game, starting at B16.  I REALLY want to give this game a thumbs-up, but there is one glaring issue:  performance.  It's to the point where I've stopped playing because late-game just becomes unplayable.  The devs seem disinterested because "it would take too much work to properly address".

DEVS:  I understand there is a big challenge in trying to multi-thread this game, but there ARE ways to do it.  The entire game is not "one system" but a collection of them (weather, events, movement / actions, etc.); and yes, I know they're interdependent.  You've built a fantastic BASE game, but let's be honest, Rimworld wouldn't have such a high rating without its mod-ability / mod scene.  The game needs to remain high-performing, even after mods have been added and we're late in-game with many calculations occurring.  We know you can do it.  Please consider putting effort into such a critical CORE part of the game, instead of slapping on more DLC.
Still not sure if i enjoy it more than 5, but its enjoyable and much better than beyond earth, which was a waste of time and money.

It was a great Platformer from start to finish. The main story does not take it easy on you but never felt completely unfair. It took me 10-15 hours to complete the main story (not including extra 2 chapters after the Main story ends) which I enjoyed from start to finish.

The content that followed afterwards does add a little more to the story but is not for faint of heart. You will die. Alot. It took me an additional 20-25 hours and thousands of deaths to finish the extra chapters that come afterwards.

Overall I thought it was a fun platformer with loads of content while still offering lots of end game activites for those who enjoy a rough challenge. 

For those of you who are going for the 100% completion on Achievements I wish you luck. It took me 47 hours to get all the Achievements and over 11,762 in death count.

If you expect this game to be like Dark Souls or Bloodborne then you'll be surprised because it's much different than those games. It is a hard game, but it feels like some people are over exaggerating a bit.

Also, the graphics and the artstyle is amazing in this game, which is not really a surprise since it's a FromSoftware game. I would give it an 8/10.

No play your favourite earlier Civ title. Steam encountered a problem while posting a more in depth review. TLDR it is not a 4X game it is a poor city management game (or "district management game) where you learn the best or only strategies and watch the game play out. Choice has been restricted through bizarre games design choices.

4X explore, expand, exploit, exterminate. 
Explore: the default map is smaller than civ 5 Huge 128 X 80 _____106 X 66
Expand: A 4X game which penalises expansion by increasing the cost of settlers as you have more cities perhaps at 3500 BC your settlers want more money to leave their condos behind after a single city is founded. Complete nonsense to keep you away from the diminutive map size and terrible faction balance. Note typically expansion is typically what drives forward 4X games by leading to repeated conflict over resources and natural choices over maximising productivity in the short term vs long term. Good news that decision has been eliminated.
Exploit: It is unfortunate your few starting cities did not have iron/horses so you are unable to build many of the starting units but you can exploit by cheesing the ai's stupidity. Trade gypsum for huge amounts of gold at 4000 BC and conquer the AI
Exterminate: War weariness a way to disincentive another core part of 4X games (after making an expansion focus sub optimal) besides making it slow and the AI being dumb. Some factions have large advantages faction starting units 50% better than others one faction available in DLC ignore war weariness (apparently one of the best factions.)

DLC all the best factions come in the DLC and perhaps the game is better with more DLC but it is not a game without it.

** Update ** So I tried it again with a controller per a suggestion. This seems to have worked for the annoying "jumping" bs that you have to do, but does little for the terrible camera angles that accompany the jumping missions. It also helped a bit with some of the other mission types like the spooky mask ones where you have to use the mask to make the floor solid, etc. 

Ultimately you still end up with the same poor battle design for the bosses where they just throw a bunch of crap at you and you end up doing it like 100 times before you either put your controller through the screen or just say f'it and continue the nonsense or call it and uninstall it. I really do think that this had so much potential and its a shame that the developers did not do it better.

Started out LOVING this game, got to a few fairly annoying stages with short timers or having the kitchen sink thrown at you and thought ok... maybe not as good as it started out. Then I got to the Toilet Ghost fight and thought "What a bunch of crap!" Spent about 2-3 hours trying to fight the SOB without any luck at all then gave up on it. Got to a few other good levels, then got to the Mountain and though "WOW! This is AMAZING!!!" Then I got to The Windmill on the mountain, spent about 2 hours falling to my doom got super p***ed and said "F*** this game!" then uninstalled the POS! 
I'm sorry to say but if you have to do something exactly right in a game or start the whole f'ing level over again, you need to rethink your design! It's not 1985 anymore and you aren't doing anything to improve the experience by making that swing angle so if the player is just off a bit they fall to their doom. That s**t was stupid back then and even more so now, the only difference is that now you know you are only agitating the audience (not including those who enjoy sadomasochism, clearly this type of stuff may appeal to you). At this point I'm hitting the uninstall button and leaving this in my "These Games Suck!" category.

It's time to review this game after 90hours later. 

First thing first, this game OVERRATED! Why? Game is build on a strong STORY which is saving this game and enjoyable. But game play is total mess! It's impossible to play without mods. Everything is unbalanced. Monster, Item levels etc. Simple; You are doing a contract for level 24. Your level is level 19 and you get a level 10 relic sword from level 24 boss. This was a basic sample what you face in this game. While you travel in the world for main Quests and sometime sides, monsters over beating your level many times.

I will not hold this thing for a few years old but good story made game. I'm not recommend this game which is not playable if we consider these broken things. You have to play it with some balance mods from NEXUS... ofcourse better control mod for ROACH the Sh...est ever HORSE! Otherwise you will lose your nerve while you are trying to play this good looking game. Also beware about "Chromatic Abbreviation" graphics settings if you don't want to loss your eyes. Turn them off immediately with other few graphics settings in.

Edit: After finishing the game with the Best Ending (Radovid b* dead and Ciri becomes Witcher) I still don't like the gameplay only. And I'm not gonna change my review to positive 'cause of the best story telling. On the other hand, you shouldn't play the game without adding some level/experience balance and horse/combat fix mods.
