This game is weird. I was drawn to tedium the opening hours but the delivery gameplay loop got me hooked. At times, hauling cargo will feel like an insatiable addiction. The landscapes are extraordinary and most of my experience was quite chill. Yet, the climbing mechanics are wack at-times. I'll be honest... and hopefully not spoil the game, this walking simulator will partially transform into the worst third person shooter ever made somewhere in the middle. No lie, THE SHOOTING SUCKS... it is even worse than San Andreas on the PS2.  camera is awful and there is no cover system. The story is actually quite straightforward and that's unusual coming from Kojima. Some characters are well-followed, while others fade into the mix. A couple months down the road, I'm sure the only memories I'll have left are of the scenery and the many examples of awful, corny dialogue. 

Try not to take the game too seriously, because it tends to do that for itself. I expect to continue delivering cargo and rebuilding America.

To The Moon is an experience of beauty both sorrowful and endearing. For the story and emotional experience is well worth the cost and the 3 1/2 hour playtime (which should be finished in one sitting). The characters are bright expressive and realistic, with body language in each sprite that amazed me for what I thought was a techincal limitation of the 32-bit themed setting. What this game is, is an artistic masterpiece of musical composition, rich story telling, wonderful sprite work, and atmospheric architecture the likes of which I personally, have never witnessed. Please play, support, enjoy, and most importantly: remember.

This is the best asymmetrical multiplayer title I have ever played. With a bevy of recognizable characters, as well as wonderfully designed original ones, helps keep each match a unique experience. It is an extremely replayable game that has kept me interested far longer than I thought it would.

There are only a few gripes that I have with this game:
1) As I'm sure you've read in other reviews, the community in this game is by far the most toxic, cringe inducing, sweaty-neckbeards-stuck-in-their-mom's-basement group of degenerates I've ever witnessed in a video game. I highly recommend completely ignoring post game chat at all cost unless you've got thick skin.

2) The game is the first title that Behavior Interactive have developed, and with that status you will notice that this game is riddled with bugs. It has gotten much better with time as the devs have grown, and it is more than playable. However, sometimes glitches and bugs happen that will cause some frustration, but nothing too serious. 

Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone, even if you don't have friends to queue with, because playing the solo role of killer is where the real challenge and fun lies.

The depth to the game is pretty outstanding. I wish we could play on bigger maps with more players but appreciate it wouldn't run as smoothly the more players you add. I played with 30 different AI and makes you very strategic not wanting 30 civilizations turning on you for your actions.

It would be nice to have a bigger variety of leaders or maybe even having the leader change every so many years than one living thousands of years although this doesn't take from the excitment of the game.

The way districts work and building farms/mines is great. in Civ 2 you could build every single wonder in one city but now you have to think of space for your other districts before deciding where you will build them.

I think the AI acts pretty great until the occasion i get a smaller tribe trying to make demands off me but hey, it happens I guess. Making peace after being at war is very interesting because when negotiating, the cities taken during that war are negotiated with too. sometimes they will happily let you have those cities for peace and others they expect a large price to be paid unless you return them.

If you like mods and like playing in the real world like myself, the ynamp huge earth i think (The biggest that loads full size) is such a big and beautiful map to play on.

I also love what taking over an enemy city involves. Having to get through that cities defences is far more realistic than the past where you killed a unit defending it and just moved in. I have not played Civ5 so don't know if this was a feature in it but great progress regardless.

I also have a misses who has no interest in games like this but I got her playing it too. Got me hooked and I'm sure it would anyone who put enough time into the game to see all the features.

To finish off, I was hooked before getting the expansions and I think the base game is great but since getting the expansions, I have to say they are well worth the investment to add so much to the game.

In my opinion, it's like this:

Graphics 10/10: For a game from 2014, for me, It still made to 2017 with excelent graphics, better than those ones in this year from other games.

Audio: 9/10 When you are outside, you hear birds, aligators and animals, you hear them walk and when you are in a cave you hear the water, when you wakl, but I think they need to add more sound to mutants, especialy to the Cowman, or Just ,,Rework'' Them, my opinion

Co-op: The co-op is like the gameplay, but there are still a little bugs, like when you are in a very narrow or just narrow space, and your friend try to come where are you, in that narrow space, someone will fly, and I think there's a 50% chance to take damage or not. and if you take damage you need to use a medicine or medicine from plants.

Price 10/10 The price of this game is  only 15 euro, and for a game like this, this price is an excellent one! But in my opinion, i would pay more for this game, not only 15! :)

If you're looking for a really polished and chaotic action game, behold, I recommend this masterpiece to you. 

My experience of the game was based on the ultra violence difficulty but my words will remain true throughout the review.

I like it how they have really limited ammo and you would actually have to plan strategically with your ammo.  There are a lot of things that have been added to the gameplay like the shoulder flamethrower and new demons that pose more as a challenge. This game also made it feel satisfying with all of the glory kills and with the realistic tear down of a demon as you quickly shoot away its (Quoting doom guy here) "big guts" . As of writing this review I haven't completed the single player and rage quit the game in frustration of not being able to clear out a certain section to at least get this review down. The game can have the casualness and action mixed together with lower difficulties and at least paying attention. Speaking of attention, I absolutely love that this game will make sure you aren't gunning down demons just by just shooting that shotgun at anything, they'll always make sure there's some big factor like the spiderdemon exist, it MAKES you pay attention which basically makes the game less boring. Lets switch over to performance terms. I ran this game on a:

I7 8700k
GTX 1060 3GB
16 gigs of ram

I got the card last year (300$ at the time and now it's like 150$ lol) and I got a I7 since Amazon couldn't deliver my I5 and they gave me a I7 instead.

The game ran 45-60 FPS on the default settings (Most of them high with the texture pool being low.) pretty well. I say it's just me and my graphics card and say it's really optimized for cards better than mine. (Lowering the resolution would greatly help too.)


Also wanted to mention the soundtrack in the background, it's too good. 

I'm not saying this game is for everyone but if you're interested in slaying large of amounts of demons in John Wick form, this is a must buy.

[h1]Insufferable, Sheer Stupidity. Just Don't.[/h1]

Allow me to start by saying that I adore story-heavy games. Love them to death. 

After reading rave reviews about this game's amazing, tear-inducing plotline, I decided to give it a try. 

It failed to suck me in at first, but I nonetheless stuck with it through the slow, horrendous gameplay, and several exceedingly weird scenes (that one zombie scene comes to mind...), in hopes of eventually getting overwheled by an astounding twist or reveal in the story, one way or another. 

But no such thing happened. 

Instead, I was smacked in the face by the game's excuse of a plotline, tear-inducing in all its right, but not at all through emotional depth or significance, but from its sheer incompetency in being able to make sense, much less entertain. 

Perhaps I'm too critical, seeing to how my opinion is vastly different from many of the others who've played this game and fell in love with it, but the way I see it, "To The Moon" is a complete waste of time. 

The game's storyline is convoluted, shallow, and nonsensical at best, and the "plot twist" (if it even merits that title), sorry to say, consists of nothing more than sheer STUPIDITY. Paired with it's lazy gameplay mechanics, this game did nothing but frustrate and annoy me the whole way through. 

Although I got it on sale for only a dollar or so, I still feel cheated. I'm never getting those hours of my life back. 
Do yourself a favor, and don't bother with this game. Just don't.

And we're back in it with the second installment of what is quickly climbing the ranks of my favorite shooters. Now: Half-life, DOOOOOOOOM and Crysis!

GFX: Brighter and less atmospheric than 2016, not that it's a drawback. Polished af.
MSC: This one takes its place right next to 2016 in the best game OST list DOOM 2016 + Eternal, Bastion and Ori.
SFX: Superb... they draw your attention to the things happening around you without taking away from anything... except maybe the headshot noise, that one's a bit out of place (funny though).
STRY: This one took the story to another level through data entries and cut-scenes (most of which are skip-able).
GMPLY: Ultra-fast, in-your-face action! No reloading, no cover... shoot, shoot, punch, chainsaw, shoot! Lots of arena style combat and a quite a bit of platforming, collectibles galore and a bunch of customization for when you decide to give the 2v1 pvp mode a try!

5/5

tl;dr: Just as good, or better than 2016 (going off memory hear)!

Changing to not recommended after finishing up. Could've been a great game, even better than 2016. Yet every mechanic that made 2016 so great has been overhauled. Everything seems to be "more": more platforming, more enemies, more puzzles. There is a point when this becomes "too much", and this is the point Eternal has reached. Who honestly thought DOOM needed underwater sections? A bullet sponge enemy that can teleport between the many alcoves of the map and will summon more demons unless killed? An enemy type that goes against the flow of the gameplay by severely limiting your own play style? Ridiculous Mario Bros style platforming sections complete with rotating fire beams, and puzzles that are often nothing more than a first person pixel hunt? It's as if the thought process behind development went along the lines of "how can we make everything more annoying? Who plays games for fun anyway?".

Mind that I did not have much trouble wrapping up the single player; it's not a particularly hard game, just tedious to the point that it becomes a chore.

Also, seeing that it won best OST: it's great when listening on YT, but the audio mixing is so horrendous you barely hear the music over the background noise, even when all other sound is set to 50%.

While some people will have you think that this game is an improvement in every aspect compared to the original, it isn't.

Firstly, the art style and the music are simply different; they aren't 'better.' I like the former. It's good; it's thorough; it's complete. As for the latter... Well, I'll put it this way: the original's soundtrack is worth buying separately — it's proper enjoyable music. Rebirth's soundtrack as a standalone purchase would be a waste of money. A lot of the tracks are pretty lazy ambiance and nothing else. That is not to say that all of them are below 'good.' For instance, I find the Intro and the Cathedral theme absolutely brilliant.

Secondly, not all new characters seem all that necessary. Azazel, while cool, is completely broken. He's just overpowered and should not have been included. Lazarus seems pretty useless. He doesn't have enough character to warrant his character; as silly as it sounds. Eden is a GLORIOUS addition to the cast though.

This is pretty much it. Those are all the complaints. Everything else is indeed an improvement over the original (dramatic improvements even — in certain areas). The items and combos are fantastic. The reworked boss fights are marvelous. The gameplay at 60 fps is a huge step-up. Bugs are very few and insignificant. I will sink even more hours into this game than into the original. It's THAT good; 9.5/10 good.

Still somewhat buggy, but a fantastically atmospheric survival / exploration game in an alien world.

PROS:
- Immersive enviroment with diverse biomes and creatures
- Great atmospheric music and sound design
- Rewarding sense of progression through unlocking new tools, base components, vehicles and upgrades
- A good balance of fixed biome/POI locations and procedural terrain generation/resource placement adds variety to replays without making everything feel generic

CONS:
- Optimization could be better, lots of graphical pop-ins
- Clunky interface, excessive inventory management (although these can be alleviated somewhat with mods)
- Occasional clipping issues (vehicles falling through the floor, fish swimming through walls into your bases/vehicles)
- No multiplayer

SUBJECTIVE:
- Unlike many sandbox games, has an actual story (told mostly through recordings and data logs) with a defined endpoint
- Emphasizes stealth / running away over combat
- Giant scary roaming leviathans in certain biomes
- Balance-wise, some raw materials / tech options are underutilized given how far into the game they become available, and food/water quickly become irrelevant as long as you remember to bring enough with you on long trips

I never anticipated how claustrophobic this game would make me feel. 

Everything you attempt to build, especially in the early game, is forced into tiny hex-shaped plots of land with resource nodes like berries, stone, or forests taking up space. To buy more land for your housing, you need gold. Which is fair. Except, for some reason, there's a limit to how much gold you can have at any given time.

The actual building aspect of this game, outside of the extraction and residential zoning areas for your population, actually seemed fun, if not entirely pointless. I built a mega-church on a hill that produced all sorts of splendor. Then I realized that splendor was for the clergy portion of my population and did absolutely nothing for my population or immediate needs. 

Shortly after, I discovered that I needed to build tents in my marketplace to achieve enough splendor to have a fishing hub. What one has to do with the other, I have no idea.

I honestly believe this game could be fun. However, unlike other Early Access titles, the problems aren't inherent in the lack of development, but rather its design choices. City building progression can be fun. Forced progression for the sake of progression is not.

This game is exceptional. It's a successor to games like Dance Dance Revolution and Guitar Hero, but in VR. Compared to those games, the controls are much easier to pick up, as they feel more natural. It's still Early Access, but it only gets better from here, and it's already an amazing experience. Also a great workout.

[h1]Overview[/h1]

A Hat in Time is a 3D platforming collect-a-thon that evokes memories of games like Mario Sunshine, whilst also being able to assert an identity all of its own. The game is spread across just four main levels, but each of these is split into numerous lengthy acts and shorter side challenges. The focus of the game is very much old-school platforming, with little emphasis on combat or overarching plot (though each level has its own contained story to contextualise the platforming challenges).

[h1]Good things[/h1]

[list]
[*]Hat kid controls beautifully. She is really responsive, and landing on small platforms is easier in this game than any other platformer I've played. Because I feel so confient moving around, I am able to play much faster and more fluidly than most other platformers.
[*]Every inch of the game is filled with cute details and shows obvious passion from the devs. Hat Kid is easily the most adorable video game character ever - no contest.
[*]It looks gorgeous! The final main level felt like a 3D Rayman Origins - and I can offer no greater praise when it comes to visuals.
[*]The music is consistently excellent. The main theme is a stand-out leitmotif.
[*]Each level has its own unique gimmicks (even on the act-select screen), which keeps things constantly fresh.
[*]Speaking of which, the game does a great job of avoiding platformer level tropes - like 'The Ice Level','The Desert Level'. The first level is an island fishing town populated by Mafia goons who are bad at cooking!
[*]The writing is Undertale-tier excellent, somethimes invoking the likes of Douglas Adams.
[/list]

[h1]Things that could be improved[/h1]

[list]
[*]You can sometimes see the rough around the edges. The odd texture that's not as detailed as the ones around it. The occasional camera clipping through solid objects and breaking the illusion of solid space. Seriously, these aren't things worth worrying about though.
[*]I feel like most of the levels are just a little bit too big. There's generally stuff to collect everywhere, but you don't need all of it to get 100%. In particular, I think the forest level could do with the areas between the landmarks being removed, to make navigation faster and easier.
[*]Final boss spoilers: [spoiler]While the battle was fun, I feel like the whole heartfelt 'everyone pitches in to help you win' was kinda undeserved. With the exception of Cooking Cat, I don't think any named character hasn't tried to kill Hat Kid. So it feels kinda insincere for everyone to suddenly grow some morals, when they've shown themselves to be completely nasty people (without remorse) just hours before. Maybe give them redemption arcs in their chapters if you want to do this.[/spoiler]
[/list]

[h1]Things that you may like or hate[/h1]

[list]
[*]The voice acting...isn't the best. You might find this really distracting, but it reminded me of the cheap UK children's shows I watched when I was younger, and I [i]loved[/i] that feeling.
[/list]

[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]

I think that A Hat in Time is a charming, wonderful game that absolutely deserves to be considered alongside the greats like Mario and Spyro (PS1-era spyro, anyway :P). If you have any interest in platformers, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try. No problems I have with the game are significant enough to actually impact my enjoyment of it, and when it is good, it is simply excellent.
the game is fun and funny, lots of entertainment to be had along with amazing design, still awaiting more content for the game, but right now it is still a 110% worth it.

This game has a flow and rhythym to it that is uniquely its own, which is easily its biggest strength. Gunfights are quick and frantic, but that hardly makes it a game of pure reflex. Playing smarter will always beat playing harder, and the feeling of weaving through enemies and taking objectives with a squad whose consistently on the same page as you grants this sense of accomplishment that few FPS games can rival.

The actual gameplay is a healthy balance of Arma style realism with conventional modern FPS mechanisms. Unlike Arma though, I didn't find Sandstorm's realism to be overbearing or annoying to compensate for. Aim down sights is almost always accurate, but the recoil is heavy and hard to effectively control in automatic fire modes. Movement is weighty and running out of breath will remind you to take things slow at times and to gather you surroundings. Bullets have velocity, but don't feel as if their travel speed greatly affects your shot outside of long ranges (you are firing a GUN, afterall). Probably my favorite part of this games player mechanics is the reload system, which enables you to ditch magazines for a faster reload at the cost of losing those remaining rounds, or cancelling a reload which picks up where you left off if the mag has already been dispensed. It's small stuff like this that makes Insurgency so compelling to play, as your individual skill is equated to more that just a point & click adventure.

Weapons, vehicles and environment sound design in amazing. The crack of the M24 and Mosin sniper rifles is distinctive and punchy, while SMGs like the MP7 and Uzi have intimdating chatters that keep the enemy on their toes. Grenades and mortars have a explosions the resonate and rack the battlefield. Yet, I think the most satisfying sound in the game comes from kicking a door off its hinges for an impromptu breach.

This game suffers in one major category: optimization. Luckily, it's a very fixable issue, but one that shouldn't go unaddressed. My ASUS 560 ran well enough, but textures often fail to pop in and framerate will take a dip time and time again. I've heard stories of friends with much more powerful rigs report that their frames become slideshow-like and textures sometimes never appear all match. The devs have noticed and have taken action to make the optimization better, and given how invested New World seems to be to their fanbase, I doubt any similar issues like this will go unaltered.

In the end, I'm hooked. Insurgency: Sandstorm is a hell of good time. It's been the only multiplayer FPS to break the 12 hour mark on my account in years, and is the only game thats managed to pull away from Siege for a while. It's not for everyone, but I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for immersive and rewarding shooter experience.

[h1] WhErE's My SoN!? [/h1]

The Forest is an exploration-based survival game set on a remote island. The story is pretty much a passenger plane you were in crashed, but you survived the crash and some guy took your son. Therefore, your goal is to survive on this island and find the clues and tools to get your son back. Right of the bat this game is beautiful, with even the models having a decent amount of polish. The game also has a decent tutorial that you can view at any time to get you started, and it is not difficult at all to get the hang of. In fact, you might find yourself having a good grasp of everything by an hour in. As advertised, the main highlight of the game are the cannibals. These weirdos have their own unique AI and tribe mechanics and fluidly react to how you play. For example, hide and keep to yourself and you might rarely come into conflict (at the cost of being unable to progress through the story), but cut down all the trees and kill cannibals and you'll find yourself at the end of their full wrath.

Unlike many survival games, at least in my opinion, the game isn't hard. The cannibals are fair to fight, but it can throw some challenges when you'll find yourself facing the beastly mutants. Your goal in the game is to explore various caves on the island to get new gear to eventually unlock the final area and finish the game. It has a surprising amount of story to it as you pick up pictures, tapes, and other items to discover the island's secrets and lore. Almost every cave has its own unique mechanics and sections that makes exploring feel consistently fun instead of like a chore. Outside of that, building options are limited, but tearing down the forest to make your own fortified base and build a GAZEBO can be incredibly satisfying. The AI will react to this, sometimes even being afraid of you and sending more difficult opponents. Combat is typically a "click to swing" and back up, and the survival mechanics are iffy. I never found myself distilling water and exclusively ate cannibals and nothing bad ever happened. If you want a decent survival game with horror elements, this is probably for you.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Gorgeous environment
[*]Interesting story that can keep you invested and makes you want to learn more; endings are good
[*]Cannibal AI is fun to interact with
[*]Awesome enemy design
[*]Really fun to play with a friend
[*]Simplistic survival mechanics that don't make you out to be a constantly hungry/thirsty monster
[*]You can build a gazebo on a lake
[/list]
[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Enemies can feel "tanky", especially late game and you have no extra weapons to counter this
[*]Mutants can feel a little overpowered at times
[*]Final boss is uninspired and nothing new
[*]Lack of building options
[*]Lack of variety in animals and enemies
[*]You freeze WAY too easily
[/list]

[b] Verdict: 8.5/10 [/b]

This game is fun for about an hour, and then I came to the realisation that it is not really a puzzle game.

In a puzzle game you spend your time figuring out how to solve the puzzle to progress to the next one. In Human Fall Flat, you spend about a minute working out how to do the puzzle, as they are usually extremely simple, and the next hour battling with the controls to make your character perform simple actions such as carrying an item or climbing a ladder.

The controls seem to be intentionally designed so as to result in amusing accidents, similarly to something like QWOP or Surgeon Simulator, but after the first hour or so it just became extremely frustrating.

Game is great so far. Compared to Crusader Kings II I would say the game is easier to use for newer players. Once you get the tutorial down, the world's yours! Playing as any count, duke, king, or emperor and building your Kingdom/Empire! The game has one game mode really, play until your dynasty dies or play until the end year. Usually I quit once I accomplished the goals I set for the character. CK3 is a great new game! Actually good base Paradox game. Definitely gonna hold them to this standard of game from here on out.

I'm really enjoying this game. There is a learning curve. There is a bit of grinding. It takes a while to get what you need. I like how much there is to discover. You can see your progress with the system guides. I've yet to find over 80% of the items. It's crazy how much content there is. There are little to no bugs for me this far, just a few things that bother me. When I first played I was given a sword, and didn't have space for it. I thought it saved itself in an additional slot, and didn't realize until a day later that it wasn't in my inventory. You can really sink some hours in without noticing it. I like the pixel graphics, and I like different systems in place. farming, and harvesting, sales and crafting. Fighting, and relationship building with the towns people.

This is a pretty solid platformer. I hesitate to use the term Metroidvania for this, there's not really much in the way of gear-gating (there's only one item you can get which allows you access to other parts of the map). It's really much more like some of the original Castlevanias, aside from the open map.

I found it to be a pretty easy game; there's a lot to do but I didn't find any of the common enemies to be particularly challenging, and the bosses usually only took a couple of tries, if that. The items you can get are fun but don't make too much of a difference ultimately.

I thought the art style looked really good (in most levels - some of the indoor ones get samey), and I liked the character designs as well. The story was alright - it doesn't seem to require much knowledge of the previous games, which is a bonus. It's not too complex but does give you a context for your actions, which is sometimes all it takes.

Took me about 8 hours to get through but I went though and tried to get everything -  for 10 bucks I'd say this is worth it.

Easily one of my favorite games. It's a blank slate of factory automation that doesn't even attempt to hold your hand. You are only limited by your own creativity and have effectively infinite space to build whatever you desire.

The concept is simple. Gather resources, research the tech tree, try not to die, and launch a rocket. You soon find it's not nearly that straight-forward and your quest to automate, optimize, and grow will never end. Oh, and there's NEVER enough iron.

Factorio also has the best replayability of any other game I've played. You're always trying new things, new layouts, new strategies. As a result, no two factories you build are ever the same. You can make things as easy or as hard as you'd like too.

Finally, this game is supported by an amazing dev team. They fix bugs within HOURS and are constantly listening to, and engaging with, the broader player community for feedback on further improvements. All devs should follow Wube's example.

Portal 2 is a good game worth playing. Let me say that first and foremost. Yes, if you have the money and are considering getting it, you should.

However, if you haven't played Portal 1, play that instead. While Portal 2 has more puzzles and better graphics, I don't think it's a better game. The average puzzle in Portal 1 has 4-8 solutions, and the tutorial puzzles show enough that you learn how to use the mechanics, without making you feel like you're being told how to play. Portal 2 takes the subtle parts that made the first game a masterpiece and sort of hamhandles them. The average puzzle in Portal 2 has 1-3 solutions. The introduction of new mechanics, such as the goop, initially makes for more interesting puzzles, but ultimately creates a need to make the puzzles more restrictive and less intuitive. I didn't finish the game. I am an avid puzzle gamer, but one puzzle near the end of the game required such precision, timing, and execution that I couldn't manage it with the level of awareness I had. 

Of course, being a very social gamer, a friend and I flew through the multiplayer maps with no difficulty. I think I will attribute that to the lack of goop.

TL:DR good game, the first one was better

It's a 100% for me, hands down. This is the most ready of any Paradox game at launch, and I'm already having loads of fun. It improves on the CK2 model in every way, stripping away excess and improving on the best parts of the game. Paradox is a Paradox and there will be countless DLC ranging from cultural clothing and army sprites to full on expansions that add new time periods or revamp interaction with China. The tutorial is much better than in CK2, and I'd recommend going through it to reorient yourself. If you never played CK2, this game is much easier to learn and get into than its predecessor. The map is greatly improved as well. If you've played the Sims or "sim"ilar games, you will have a ton of fun with the RPG elements in CK3.

A Hat in Time is a fantastic homage to the platformers on N64, Gamecube, PS2--namely Banjo, Ty, Sly Cooper, Super Mario. It completely scratches the platformer itch and it does it so well with great level design that never gets dull, a variety of different instances and activities, a rich and colorful world and so much more. I put 7 hours into it the first day I got it just because I was so engrossed in the world, just like when I was a kid exploring 3D platformers for the first time. The game just oozes with character and charm. The controls and the movement throughout the world feel extremely responsive, snappy, and due to dense levels the platforming options are endless. You are doing yourself a disservice not to play one of the best platformers of the year so far...

PvE stands for Player Vs Environment, right?
Ok, play PvE and you'll see players just walk by your buildings and demolish them with no efforts, with no need to fight, just by selecting "demolish" from the menu like they belongs to them.

Just imagine: you spend 10 game hours to build something, then a random guy pass and demolish everything then he talks to you - "I'm the owner of this island, don't build here, go north!" - There is nothing you can do to oppose to his acting-then-talking so you just do it. - "Got it, going to build north".
So you move north and start to build again, then another guy of the same tribe pass by there and destroys everything once again, and then - "I'm the owner of this island, don't build here, go west!".

What the heck do you got between the ears.
That's a shame I had to spend 270+ hours to find out that PvE is just like PvP but worse.

Really well created. Basically your a Monster Hunter (Called a Witcher) for hire in an Open World, fantasy setting. There's a fairly good story line to complete with the main game, but you can go at your own pace and do lots of other mini side quests at the same time. Fight style is easy to command with enough variances in it to make it interesting, as well as how you want to adapt or improve your character.

Both of the expansions are brilliant. Obviously shorter than the main game, but by no means just small add ons. They're pretty full on in their own right with a lot to offer (New monsters, lands, missions and great stories)

Also, and by no means lastly, the humour is brilliant. Your character has a great sense of dry and sarcastic humour, stating obvious facts, which had me in stitches. There's lots of mini, but sneakily placed, film references or quotes which also add to the humour.

All in all. Highly recommended.

First impressions of Civ 6 are overwhelmingly good. It looks amazing and the mechanics are relatively easy to grasp. I haven't had any issues in figuring out concepts for the most part, and it runs smoothly (especially compared to the dreaded Beyond Earth).

Having said that, I have a couple of issues with the game. The lack of a useful in-game editor (or even a mod that provides such) is annoying, for one thing, and the advanced options for game creation are less than robust (the 'no barbarians' and 'raging barbarians' tick boxes are especially missed). But my biggest issue of all with this version of Civilization is the AI. It constantly bombards any civilization I play with barbarians, missionaries, etc. and later on with rival civ's declaring suprise wars with a zillion troops at my doors. And there's no way to mitigate or prepare, even on the easiest setting - and diplomacy is a joke because the actual options for discourse are meaningless and very limited.

I'll keep playing and yes, it's still a fantastic game, but these are all things that have kept me from getting into it more. If it was a bit less all-consumingly challenging I'd think it was a LOT more fun. But please don't let my concerns turn you away from trying it.

It's a good game. The sky (and addons) are the limit to what you can do in the game, it's fun and sandbox shenanigans galore.
Get it, no matter if it's a sale or not, because trust me, it is worth it.

I've played it for 18 hours since buying it, and as soon as i get 28 souls in residence, the food supply vanishes. Two fields, 5 farmers each with an output of 95% and when both are harvested the food vanishes into a black hole. I'm a littler concered about farmers, gatherers, and hunters usually dying first. When this issue gets a patch i'll come back to Banished. Right now, it's not even a slow descent into starvation.

After depending more on hunters gatherers and fishermen, plus reducing the farms and orchards to 7x7 plots with one farmer each, the starvation seems to have ended.

Unfortunately, i was starting to hit 200 plus adults, had 36 gatherers, 30 hunters and 16k of food on hand, all seemed rosy, when 27 nomads show up in my 15th year. within 6 months i was down to 2k of food and despite adding more natural producers the food production cannot keep up with 220 plus Son Goku's. Please please tweak the starvation to a bit slower.

Survivors vs Trapper Killer:
Survivor gets hooked and trapper places bear trap underneath them, then goes off to wait in the distance, so survivor(even high level players) suicide because freedom from the hook ain't happening.

Survivors vs Wraith:
Survivor gets put on hook, wraith goes to wait in stealth in the distance. As long as your other survivors are not hurt, you have a chance to get away as long as your willing survivors want to take a blow to their shoulder or they'll leave you for dead.

Survivors Vs Hillbilly:
Not much to say here because all the hillbillies use chainsaw, so if your being chased, hit a corner and they usually miss.

TL:DR The game basically says camp them until their dead if your the killer, if your a survivor then it's stay off the hooks or your already dead.

So after spending over 400h in this game (and many more in the demo and before i activated it on steam) I think I should write a review.

[h1]First off short answer: Yes, I definitely recommend it![/h1]

The thing that should be addressed first is probably the developers: You're doing amazing work! Six years after the game came out there are still regular update and DLC and for example with the Germany rework you can definitely see that they have improved. Things like the trailer ownership also added "replayablity"

The game might seem like it get's boring after a while, but with the above mentioned regular updates, mod support (defiantly give TMP a shot) and amazing community (like VTC's for example) there's always something new to try

Also you can choose how hard and/or immersive the game is. For example, you could go all out and spend additional money on a wheel, eye tracker, shifter, etc. , but you can also just play with mouse and keyboard. (Ran it with everything from keyboard over a X-BOX 360 controller to a G29. Had no problems with anything) You can have your mirrors and navigation as HUD elements, but you can also look around yourself and follow the road signs

In conclusion: I really don't have anything negative to say about this. Definitely give it a try!

I remember playing these games in 4th grade in my schools computer lab. These games have held up incredibly well and I can't recommend this collection enough. Completing the Mission is the perfect way to end the series and is everything i wanted and more.

A wonderfully crafted metroidvania. Well done 2d animation and an amazing soundtrack that fits perfectly for its immersive world and subtle storytelling. Challenging, but very fair. The combat is simple to understand and the bosses are well designed with no artificial difficulty. Some may find it starts out slow, but the game encourages and rewards exploration with optional upgrades, items, and bosses. The nonlinearity only adds to this. There is no strict set path of progression (go from area A to B, pick up power up then head to C and D, etc), so progression comes naturally as you explore new areas and branch off from there. This game has one of the best interconnected worlds I have seen.

You get an amazing value at 15 dollars. The base game is great as is, and you get 4 additional free content packs which add more bosses, items, and a small bit of additional lore/story. The last content pack "Godmaster" is dedicated to a boss rush that fits nicely into the world of Hollow Knight and it's narrative so it doesn't feel out of placed or tacked onto some side area. 

My only real gripe with this game is that one small section of the endgame content from one of the additional content packs is a brutal step up in difficulty. It is not impossible, but it is an outlier with how Hollow Knight handles difficulty. This is, however, not necessary for completing the base game and it is essentially "post game" content. The other 95% of the game is fair in it's difficulty and will provide you with a very generous amount of game time for the price you pay. My first playthrough of the base game took me roughly 40 hours. Your mileage may vary, but the amount of quality game for this price tag makes it a strong recommendation for any fan of action-adventure/metroidvanias.

Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above:

"Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved."
"I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life.

Again the voice called to her:
"Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins."
"I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in thee," Isaac's mother replied as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world.

One last time Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her:
"You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you."
"Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged.
"To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life as an offering to me, to prove you love me above all else."
"Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butchers knife from the kitchen.

Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch just as his mother burst through his door and threw himself down into the unknown depths below...

This game saved my life.

I am 25.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline broken. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Changing my review due to the removal of denuvo anti cheat. Doom Eternal improves upon every aspect of 2016: performance is better then ever, running at a solid 60 fps despite looking even better then its predecessor, load times are very short, where 2016 would often take at least 60 seconds to load each level, eternal usually has them loaded within 5 seconds of loading a mission, if it even needs to load at all, only had one crash during my 30 hours of playtime, and that was after 5 hours of non stop playing (cant speak for the unholy denuvo times). Gunplay is improved, weapons feel better then in 2016 and have (mostly) better mods, the meathook is so useful I cant even play any previous doom game without feeling like something is missing, some less used mods from the previous game have been changed, for the better too. Having less ammunition has been criticized by some for limiting them from using their favorite weapon, but I think it is a welcome change, letting you think about what weapons work better against different enemies, adding a strategic element to every fight. The soundtrack is still amazing, Mick Gordon never fails to deliver (his presence will be missed in future doom installments). The story is a welcome addition, cutscenes are easy to skip if you dont care, but if you want more of a reason to rip and tear doom eternal gives you some, it also explores the slayers origins, which if you are a hardcore doom fan is welcome content. Overall Doom Eternal is a welcome addition to the doom franchise and if you have even a passing interest in fps games you are doing yourself a disservice but not picking this game up right now, with or without sale.

This game is fun for exactly one playthrough. After that, you are going to find the exact same bland order of events play out no matter which area of the world you choose or which start you play. The only thing to shake things are up when the game decides to be arbitrary and decide to force yourself in to some dumb situation that forces you to get "set back" in order to make you repeat the same thing you just did so you can endlessly play the exact same gameplay loop hundreds of times. People will claim this is the fun of these games, the setbacks are where the fun comes in. But if you realize these aren't really setbacks, it's just a contrived reason to make you backtrack. Your realm arbitrarily exploding isn't hard to piece back together, you have trivial wars against the suicidal AIs that you'll effortlessly win like you did before, over and over and over. Not that it means anything. Having 10 vassals and having 100 vassals doesn't mean much different. Having a stewardship focused ruler vs an intrigue one isn't that different, you make the same types of alliances and come up against the same kinds of events. The game is just half baked, and the core gameplay just isn't there. A lot of comparisons are made that this is so much more "polished" than Imperator: Rome, but this game has the same core gameplay and falls flat in the exact same ways I:R did.

[h1] Great game to unleash your creativity on.

This game is just amazing, you can do almost anything in this game. There's an endless number of addons in the workshop. You can recreate anything! There are many gamemodes in Garry's Mod, from TTT to PropHunt.

Here are some common gamemodes.

[h1] TTT

* Fun and simple to learn
* Waste countless hours in this simple gamemode
* Watch out for Traitors

[h1] DarkRP

* Roleplay as mostly anyone
* Fun and a bit complicated to learn

[h1] PropHunt

* Be a prop and hide from the seekers!
* Find the props to win the game!
* Use taunts to tease your enemies
* Really fun and simple to learn
* Gives that chasing thrill.

[h1] Murder

* Are you a bystander or a murderer?
* Collect clues to obtain a pistol to defend yourself
* Find and eliminate the murderer.
* Fun to play with friends, also easy to learn.

In the end, I seriously recommend this game. As of today, there's a sale on this game, so grab it while on sale! Have fun for those who have purchased the game.

app_name: Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy
review:
I'm gonna be blunt: if you get angry easily, this game suits you about as much as an anime cosplayer in the midst of a basketball convention. You put your effort and time into this game, and after a few hours, have made some progress. Suddenly, you reach an obstacle you've never seen before. Your hands start to sweat (more than they have been from holding the mouse for so long), you feel your heart beat a little harder, and your previous gameplay flashes before your eyes. You finally decide to take the risk, as there's no sense in waiting. You jump, your cauldron sailing through the 2 feet you have to work with, hoping beyond hope that the Foddy Gods will pour their blessing out on you, holding your breath at the time...

But to no avail. With just a little slip of your hammer, you're caught in a downward plummet with no hope of restoration, praying that you won't have landed too near the beginning of the game, where your journey began a mere few hours ago...
Has it really only been that long...?

Just look up on Youtube "Getting Over It Rage Compilation" and you'll find a seemingly endless stream of videos of various people reacting to content in the game, whether it be glitches, loss of progress, or finally...FINALLY...beating the game after so much heartbreak and feelings of hopelessness. 

If you're the kind of person who loses your temper rather easily, this is the game that is on the complete opposite end of the spectrum of games you should play. 

That's looking at it at face value, though. But what if you look deeper?

Getting over it is a game, as Mr. Bennett himself states, where "No amount of forward progress is guaranteed" (okay, maybe that line was meant for a different game, but it's implied that it's also meant for the game at hand). No matter how hard you try, even if you have 20 hours of experience inside your cauldron, you're still, at all times, at risk of "falling and losing everything". That example near the beginning of this already too long review is not something you'll experience only once when playing this game, I promise you that.

But maybe in that reason, Getting Over It is the perfect game if you have difficulty keeping your anger in check. As you toodle along with only your hammer to propel you, Bennett makes philosophical remarks during your trip, and offers encouragement and motivational sayings if you happen to plummet. And it's in those ways the game can offer more insight than you expected in ways you least expect it. In other words, this game could *possibly* be used as an anger management tool and special insight into life, opening up new ways of thinking and looking at things that you'll carry with you for the rest of your life...

But probably not. In all honesty, it's just a silly game where you drag yourself up a mountain with only a hammer and cauldron to keep you company (and Bennett, of course).

Do with the game as you will (unless you want to spend your $8.55 on fast food. Honestly, who wouldn't?).

I rate it 8/10 Minecoins (I would rate 9, but I still haven't forgiven you for that one time, Bennett.....).

There's lots and lots and LOTS of water around, and it's full to the brim with adventure, intrique, twists, turns, terror, and monsters. Yep. Plenty of monsters.

The build and survive gameplay is excellent, combined with great visuals and the soundtrack...oh the Soundtrack! You'll find yourself spending hours fine-tuning the perfect base in no time, and enjoying every bit of it!
The depth is exceptional, always something new to explore or solve.

Actual 10/10 game, a must play for anyone that likes being challenges and having their limits pushed.

Edit: 9/10, if spirit emblems worked like healing gourd it would be 10/10 for me, its annoying having to farm them between boss fights if you are using spirit emblems stuff.

Unlike the other farming simulator in the series, this would be the one with the most content aswell as introducing John Deere as a manufactorer for the first time in the game.
It also features a whole new weather system, where you can predict the weather from looking at the sky.

If you'd like, you can always move your gameplay over to caretaking your animals. Also introducing for the first time, horses!
Now you can also choose the positioning of your animal pens to wherever you like, and you have to buy the land where you want to place it, wich makes it much more realistic.

I also notice that there are some few flaws in the game, but it's nothing that will bother you too much. Also i think it will be fixed in the near future!

Playing DBD is like being in an abusive relationship. There are genuinely good times. You can remember them. They were great fun. But as time continues to tick on, you realize how unhappy playing this game makes not only you, but everyone else around you. It's some sort of weird purgatory where people knowingly hate the game, yet still play it. As if they can't shake DBD out of their system or something. These are people firmly in the loop that DBD provides. It gives you just enough to keep you in, but you're firmly aware of how much you hate it the entire time. Will that stop you? Probably not. Welcome to the abuse.

Reconsider your time before playing this, I promise you there's better expenditures of your time

My writing is terrifying, but...
Celeste is a wonderful game.

where do I even start?
right from the start, I knew this was going to be a good game, the visuals are top notch with attention to the finest detail, at times are colorful enough to make you forget all the darker parts of the game...

and the controls are SO FIRM, the only thing holding me back is my sluggish fingers, no, seriously, I am slow, but that didn't stop me from completing the tough-as-nails C-Sides WITHOUT assist...

Celeste portrays mental illnesses exceptionally well, not your like your run of the mill book, but in a completely realistic and relatable way (just search this up, I will never string up enough words to describe it.)

Despite the sheer difficulty, Celeste has remained an enjoyable game through my playtime, one that actually gives me a sense of pride and accomplishment for completing a brutal level... not like that one company we all hate...

Oh, lastly, the music, most important.
Celeste's music is atmospheric, energetic, and at times dark, it gets power powerful during B-Sides, filling you with the determination needed to press on, despite your never ending deaths.
Yes... the music sure does set a powerful atmosphere...

Would I recommend? I sure will, you don't see a masterpiece like this often.

app_name: Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy
review: Well, I play this to relax if you believe it or not. I've beaten the game over 25 times and my record for beating the game is 6 minuets and 34 seconds, although I have nothing to prove it as I was not recording. I play the game to relax, but if it ever gets frustrating, I stop for a while. For a first time player this is very different however. It is known for being a rage game which is very hard. It's not meant to be frustrating, no matter how much it may seem like it. It's a test of patience and will. Those who have climbed to the top have passed, while those who rage quit have failed. If you just can't climb or pass something no matter how hard you try, it's okay. You tried your hardest, you didn't quit because it was too frustrating. This game isn't for everyone, but if you think you'll give it a try, go for it.

The attempt to recreate Shadow of the Colosseus, but doesn't quite match up.

The pixel art is pretty, the OST is great, and the mechanics are pretty solid.

It's just the gameplay that falls flat on it's face.

The one-shot-kill-or-death thing is pretty overrated.  Half of the bosses feel exactly the same, with only a tiny change in mechanics.  It's waiting for that half-second opening and daring death, as you almost always have to nearly trade your life to score the killing blow.

Some bosses get downright asinine, having "magnetic" attacks (attacks that follow you when you get too close), or even creating deadzones (give me a break; it's sitting there, but if I touch it, INSTANT DEATH!  No, not pushed into it, poke it, INSTANT DEATH!).  It all gets rinse-lather-repeat, and you start to see the same thing in every boss, with a handful of new 'features' over the previous boss of its' type.

By no means does that make this a poor game; I just believe the developers could have done better.  It felt like, "Well, it's WAY too short unless we add a few more titans..."

With no expansion of the player, no new methods of gameplay and approach could be added to the bosses, thus it all becomes stale by the time you reach the end.

The story, itself, while intriguing, is another one of those disingenuously vague ones that reveals and tells almost nothing.  What little bits and pieces are there reveal next-to-nothing of what's going on, or even why you're there.  It's another one of those, "the description of the game tells more about the story than the game itself."  After a certain point, you start to ask yourself, "Why the heck am I even doing this?  What's the point?  Big flashy lights!  Woo!  Okay.  Getting bored, now."

Don't pay full price for this.

I think this game is a great feat in the world of multiplayer cooperation. It has the most balanced skill low to skill cap ratio of player to player I've seen with low tier killers going great against low tier survivors vise versa to high tiers. Sadly no dedicated servers but still holds up nicely. 

Pro's: Developers still working on big updates and bugfixes.
Active community.
Entertaining and great replayability with skill cap always being able to be raised.
A game reliant on player (survivor and killer) error encourages those to become as good as possibile keeping the community vast in it's skill level and abundent in players.
The game can geniuenly cause great fear to the survivors and satisfaction to the killer which creates a thrill in each game.
The soundtrack is great and each song fits perfectly to the situation(to the point where the song playing fits so well you don't even notice it at times{also a con check last con}.

Con's:Many players complaining about balance issues likely due to map design and a perk or two.
Game needs polish when it comes to some of it's core mechanics.(flashlights useless if killer knows to drop survivor instantly after brought to bleeding state)(Killers getting stuck in pallets)The list could go a bit further beyond than just this...sadly.
The soundtrack as said above is great but at times I feel it is playing too quietly for me to appreciate it and for it to do its job of installing fear into me as a survivor and make me feel truly unstoppable as a killer.(Hopefully a feature to increase and decrease the volume within a certain margin without muting it will be added) When listening to the soundtrack on youtube there are so many details shallowed out by other sounds that the real power the soundtrack delivers is missed.

Overview: This game is a 100% worth buying and I don't regret a single hour I have put in. Even with my current 281 hours as of this review I have much to master and learn still. I hope this review helpes you decide wether or not to buy this game

A must have for 2018. Subnautica is one the best games to have come out in the past number of years. 

The game perfectly captures the feeling of being stranded in a giant, open ocean with the minimal needs to survive. The way the story progresses helps you find your way and helps you learn how to survive against the elements, and what lurks beneath. 

The graphics are beautiful, the gameplay is great, it's polished and it's a great experience that I wish I could play over again.

Enjoyable sandbox survival horror with small story elements. Problem is bad things will happen if you don't get people to cooperate and collaborate. My suggestion would be to have a specific group of reliable players you join up with and play through the game on your own save. Hosting with random people can be, in the beginning, challenging as cheaters and spammers will jump in your server and mess with everyone. Overall I enjoy it and see that with future updates it could maintain a positive review. Making an addition of a crafting & creative mode for pure builders might be a decent addition.

I really REALLY want to like this game and my play through has become a sunk cost fallacy at this point even though I want to see it through. Bodies will ragdoll into the stratosphere literally when you place them on the ground. This can result in team deaths, losing prisoners, or even bounties. Speaking of losing bounties-- for no fucking reason at all the game despawned a wounded Gutterhead from my character's arms. So then I had to load a save an hour back or lose the 10K bounty my scout squad had been working towards for over a week since they're either burnt to a crisp by the Eye the instant they leave Gutterhead's tower, or Beakers spawn in front of the building when I try to leave. It's bad enough that I lost all the other Scav prisoners now because of having to abandon them, them launching into space when I put them down, or them dying to "random" Eye blasts hitting my squad.

I'll update this review as I come across new things

You have to really know this is the play style you want to play before purchase, there are almost no RPG elements like the other souls series games, so spoil the first couple of hours watching Youtube to make absolutely sure this is what you want.  Can't recommend for just anyone to buy, have to want this very specific story they are selling.
A little slow, combat is a bit of a bore and the story elements are stretched to far apart.  Lots of check points though so you don't feel railroaded to complete something that has lost its fun by just throwing waves of fodder that you don't want to go through again.
Not a don't buy, just a make sure you know what you are getting into.

Change Note: Seems like there is a lot of fun lore and mystical areas that would make for an interesting world if not for snakes with no-reload shot guns.  Really just sad that at every turn they put another road block you have to smash your head against until you've memorized the pattern.  The game is not worth the work.

6 more hours 2/5 not worth the money, lacks everything that made souls games fun.  No real sense of accomplishment because the next gimmick mini boss will be right around the corner, or worse... another re-skin.
Great game, hundreds of hours worth easy.

A great insight and experience into what it is to drive a large combination vehicle over long distances, although these are flatnose pullers which can only compare to early 90s models in North America. Still a great trainer if you are looking into driving the real thing. Though I would strongly suggest dropping down for a decent steering wheel controller, only because the difficulty of controlling said vehicle on a keyboard only justifies the price of getting a steering wheel and shifter combination. If you want to truly immerse yourself, get an Oculus Rift (they just came out with compatible software for the game) and a pair of headphones. Overall, if you ARE training to be a large vehicle freight driver, all this is still cheaper than a school. Unfortunately, most (current) jobs involving this industry will not substitute this for "real" experience. 

All in all, still a great program to own and there is a lot of push for far more development into of what is already there. 
10/10 would buy for a friend.

In Cube World's released state, you can pet animals! Pretty neat huh? But was the sacrifice for making animals pettable worth it? 

[b] You can pet animals[/b], but you lose the ability to explore and are forced to stay in one area to "proceed" or else you face the wrath of losing everything you gained in that area upon entering a new area.

[b] You can pet animals[/b], but you lose the ability to customize your character's skill trees and instead rely on artifacts that do next to nothing compared to the skill trees.

[b] You can pet animals[/b], but you lose the ability to chat in-game. 

[b] You can pet animals[/b], but you lose all the features of the game's alpha that made most of us love and believe it in the first place.

You can pet animals now, but it cost just about everything else that made the game fun.
You messed up Wollay... If you're planning to bring this game back to its former glory or update it to be better than that, I'd advise you be more communicative with the community instead of your pets at home... I honestly really want this to work out.

I somewhat agree and disagree with the opinons on here. The multiplayer feels absolutely nothing like any of the COD games in the past which I like. I wasn't looking for a copy of BO3 with a new storyline and new guns. I personally have not had any connection issues myself, but a few of my friends have. There are a few maps which are a little small and cramped but once you figured out how to manuever in the game (stop thinking black ops 3) the maps can really be used to your advantage. My one issue is....graphics, I have a 980Ti and the game runs fine, generally around 100-110FPS, but my goodness it looks like crap. I feel like salt and pepper is covering the screen along with some weird blur stuff thrown in as well. Right now I'd rate the gameplay 4/5, graphics 2/5, stability 4/5. So overall, I'd give it somewhere around a 3.5-4 out of 5. Its a good game, and im sure it'll get smoother and better as more patches come out. Many games have had way worse starts than this, so don't be too quick to judge it. Also, the zombies is great,  very confusing so make sure you use the tour guide the first time, helps alot.

One unit per tile was quite controversial, but I do prefer it to the Civ 4 Doomstacks, even if it is a little tragic watching the AI fail to understand it.  From the player's POV it does feel more tactical.

I've played a couple of games of Civ 6 all the way through and while it has its moments, it hasn't engaged me like Civ 5 has.  Civ 5 feels like it offers more freedom and, if anything, is even more sandboxy.

Civ 5 is still well worth going for, especially a package version with all DLCs on sale, and would be a solid and cheaper grounding in Civ vs Civ 6.

The drums of war beat.  The horde descends.  Will you answer the call?

Post Release Review:

This game is beautiful, fun, and occasionally challenging.  The Graphics and design are exceptional.  The gameplay is tight and extremely fun.  The environments are well designed and some offer decent exploration and have no clearly marked paths which is a lovely change of pace. Overall it is a blast and one I highly recommend.

Unfortunately I have seen the steam reviews for this game go down roughly 6 percent in a day.  This largely seems to be due to lots of people finding the game too difficult.

Lets talk about difficulty real fast.  This is designed to be a difficult game.  Even on recruit you can not idly wander about and just spam a single button and win, for the most part. I do not struggle with the difficulty and soloing recruit and now veteran while I wait for my friends is not a problem. That being said I highly recommend playing with friends or finding some like minded individuals in the community to group with regularly.  

The combat is deep.  It is meant to be.  You need to learn how each weapon plays.  Blocking, dodging and pushing are integral in the combat system.  Correct use of melee weapons and ranged weapons depending on situation is a must.  Using things like choke points and crowd control during a horde rush are necessary.

Obviously some things just go wrong sometimes.  For instance I encountered a troll on a narrow cliff, which would have been fine keeping your back away from the edge so you do not get thrown off and so forth, when a chaos patrol came from one direction and a storm vermin patrol came from the other.  It was brutal and we nearly pulled it off but we ended up wiping.  It happens, it was still execptionally fun. 

It is unfortunate that people feel the need to give a negative review on the basis of difficulty in a game that promotes it.  I do not see dark souls games filled with negative reviews claiming it was too hard.

Regardless I wish my fellow Brothers of the Reichland glory and honor on the battlefield. I will see the others who love this game out there amongst the horde.

I would say, you do need a pretty alright PC in order to play on maximum graphics, and still get good FPS. I got a GTX 1050 TI, 12 GB of RAM and a i7 4770k 3.5 GHz, and I get 60 fps.

Wow, I havent been so transfixed by a game since Metroid Prime. It is just perfect - the feeling of isolation, almost endless exploration, and awesome crafting mechanics... I am loving it! Worth every penny at $20; I feel like I am about to [i] SINK [/i] in a few hundred hours into this game!


Edit - One little nitpick is performance - In order to play in 3d vision or vr @ 60 or more fps, you are going to need a hefty gpu - definitely more than my gtx 970!

If you like 4X games then you'll enjoy Civ VI. I've been playing this franchise since the start and each new iteration makes it better and better. With all the dlc over the years the game has seen nothing but improvement and growth. I'm really enjoying the introduction of weather and storms. I find the new modes of play to be interesting, especially the Secret Societies game mode. I do, however, recommend picking the game and it's dlc up on a sale. The base game is fun but the dlcs makes it shine. Thus pick it up on sale so you can get the best play experience. This is also a fun game to play with a friend as the AI makes a horrible partner, but what game has a good AI partner? Not many. 

I've really taken to the Religion part of the game. I think that's my favorite part, creating your own faith and then spreading it across the world. It's fun to create your own faith and pick the tenants and to create warriors of the faith who will go out and do battle in the name of The One True Faith. World Congress is also nice. The ability to trade influence makes interacting with the AI a bit more fun and dynamic. 

Overall, if you like 4X games or if you've been a fan of the Civ franchise then pick it up. You won't regret it.

Highly recommend this game and would recommend checking out the popular mods as they really increase the fun factor.

I've gotta admit, I was scared that the game wouldn't run on my computer and that my money would go to waste. Not only does it run just fine, it plays extremely well. Sure it's a little dated, but I don't think aging hit it very hard. Some glitches (got stuck in a door, alien carcass made it impossible to push boxes out a door to get to the next area), but nothing that can't be solved by loading a previous save (you might want to save often just in case). Great for people who want to find out what Half Life is all about or for people who liked Half Life 2 but couldn't figure out who any of the characters were supposed to be.

Edit: I found out that you can smash dead bodies with your crowbar if they get in the way. Not much I could do about getting stuck in doors, though.

Quick review:
1) Soundtrack is so beautiful. I can hardly believe my ears when the angelic melodies are played.
2) The art style and graphics work very well for the atmosphere. I love the clouds for undiscovered territory.
3) Gameplay can vary between light and awesome moments of exploration to intense combat with countries across the world to desperately trying to scrounge up money to fund your armies. Love it.
4) The controls are amazing. They're almost intuitive. The guides help a bunch if the controls do get confusing.
Verdict: 10/10 game. Will bankrupt country again.

Story for review:
 When my uncle sold me his PC, he bought me this game and told me that it will consume my soul or something like that. XD. The only strategy games I'd played by then were Halo Wars and RUSE. I figured this one might be too complex to play so I didn't for a couple years. I was missing out. 0_0.
He made me try it out and now I've a hard time stopping! It has such tense moments where you can have your own Cold Wars with other countries. I'm in one with Denmark. They have the largest military in the world. They've taken over all of Europe, Africa, the Middle East, Asia, half of Austrailia, and some of the Philippine Islands. They had control of Hawaii but I wrested it from them and turned it into a base that I used to destroy their navy. They attempted to strike behind my battle lines by colonizing some of Canada but I took those cities, too. Despite their overwhelming numbers, they eventually called for a peace treaty. I signed the treaty so fast my pen burned. Be wary, newcomers. Some of the "peace treaties" will suggest you to surrender entire sections of your countries to them. I caught Harold Bluetooth doing just that. He didn't get my cities but we still made a temporary truce. Now we're uneasy again. I've rallied an invasion force and am prepared to press the DECLARE WAR button.
Nothing but the AI and the stats are written by the developers. The game teaches you how to do basic things and after that, your actions are your own! Examples: you can create a peaceful and loving nation that seeks unity and scientific advancements or you can become a tyrant that nukes everybody and takes over the entire planet. It's such an amazing game that's been different every time I play it. Sometimes I'm technologically inferior to larger civs, sometimes my forces are mechanical gods against their peashooters. If you want an addicting game with tons of value, get this. You won't regret it.

Graphics: Visually, a very solid title. The visuals themselves are great, and the environments are quite convincing. Lighting is good, and the overall atmosphere is very fitting of the Warhammer universe: grimy, run-down, and gloomy. Physics are great as well, and in a game with so many bodies falling and flying through the air from the occasional explosion, this is a notable plus. Performance-wise, this game seems to run quite well on Nvidia hardware, but can struggle with equivalent AMD hardware. It's still bearable, but it's not equivalent.

Audio: The soundtrack for this game isn't really noteworthy if you ask me, but it's no bad either. The weapon sounds are great, and many of them feel chunky when hitting an enemy, as they should. This really adds to the satisfaction of the gameplay. Perhaps most importantly in this category, however, are the voice lines and voice acting for all of the playable characters in Vermintide 2. Both the random and scripted lines are well done by the actors and actresses, and they add a surprising amount to the game, as the player gets a lot of backstory and information on the relationships between the characters through their dialogue. Some of it can be rather entertaining as well.

Gameplay: First, take note that I'm a more casual Vermintide player, meaning I don't often touch the higher difficulties, so that may make my review misaligned with many others. It's very fun to play with friends, and can be a bit of a challenge as well. It's satisfying to me both on the direct gameplay level, as well as the over all progression level. It's not exactly my go-to game, but I still play it from time to time many months after release.
As far as balance and difficulty, I think when played on "Veteran" the game is challenging enough to require one or two players at least who are knowledgeable, but it isn't frustratingly difficult, and this difficulty allows the player to access all content in the game and receive the most powerful drops, albeit with a lower drop rate.
Regarding bugs and other negatives, I haven't experienced many as of late, and connection issues are far less of a common occurance than they used to be. In fact, I can't remember the last time I encountered a game-breaking bug. There are physics glitches with corpses rubber-banding or clipping through part of the environment from time to time, but that isn't a surprise with the physics engine.
I know the last two point I've made are the source of most of the controversy surrounding this game, and while they are valid, they haven't at all ruined the experience for me or my friends. I would say this game is worth your money and your time if it looks interesting to you, especially if it is on sale.

TL;DR: Fun Left 4 Dead-esque game, and even better with friends. Gameplay is enjoyable and satisfying, as is the overarching progression. There's also potential for very high-level, high-difficulty play, though I haven't personally experienced it, as I'm not all that interested. Overall a solid buy, especially on sale.
