This review comes as an attempt to offer a clear perspective on the game, in contrast to some of the negative remarks on Steam and on the internet.

Having played extensively all the previous games of the series, i consider DoW3 to be a very good game. The graphics and atmosphere are great, the gameplay and combat mechanics are fun and refreshing, the army customization is the deepest of all the games and it has much much room for future growth.

Let's take it from the top:

1. Campaign
The campaign is fun, much more to the style of DoW2. There is a storyline and every mission moves the storyline forward. You will play equally all factions during the campaign mission, which will allow you to level up some important Elites and gather a lot of skulls to unlock them.
The missions are varied and fun, some of them are typical build you base and eliminate the opponent, other are take your Elites only and bash some heads and they are generally pretty fun! During the campaign you will get to know and utilize all aspects of DoW3 combat and resource mechanics.

2. Multiplayer
If the campaign was the bones of the game, then the multiplayer is definitely the meat of it. You jump into 1v1, 2v2, 3v3 combat with your friends or with AI. 
Now, you will hear a lot of crybabies saying that DoW3 has turned into a MOBA. 
<Insert Darth Vader image with quote "I am your Father">
MOBAs evolved from strategy games but they don't have base building and you can't control the minions. In DoW3 you have base building and you can also fully control your army, along with your powerful Elites. So, yeah.
In strategy games you always had to kill the enemy headquarters to win by elimination, in DoW3 the headquarters have been renamed to Power Cores. So, yeah.
The only thing that has been added are the Turrets and the Shield Generators, which have been added for the sole purpose of avoiding early game rush tactics which end the game in 5 minutes. And it works as intended. 
So, yeah, back to Starcraft with you guys. 

3. Customization
You can choose a roster of 3 Elites with their respective Doctrines, as well as 3 Army Doctrines. Selecting which ones you want to use will vary against your opponent and will alter your gameplay dramatically. There is something for everyone here, and it's very satisfying finding a build that works well together in theory and then verifying that by bashing some heads on the battlefield.

Final Verdict:
9/10
It's a clear 9. The only thing holding this game back is the lack of Chaos, Necrons and Tyranids. But i have a feeling that work is already under way for further expansions, like in Dow1 and 2. Thank you Relic, good job on this one!

-DLC is numerous, and many are just nations

When you picked up this time capsule, I had taken a rocket and left this planet. To be honest, I don't want to leave.
I will miss my cuddle fish, the red moon and the white moon, Seamoth, Prawn, Cyclops, and that "Welcome abroad, Captain."
Since the Aurora crashed, all I did was to survive and find a way to return to Earth, but in the process I found that I prefer life here.
I enjoy life when I grow my own marblemelon, build my own generator, travel in the mushroom forest and say Hi to ampeels.
In here, there's no politics, no country, no war, no lies, no racial discrimination, no ideological conflict.
Is it really a wise choice to return to Earth?


当你捡到这个时间胶囊的时候，我已经乘坐火箭离开了这个星球。说实话我不愿离开，她实在是太缤纷多彩。
我会想念抱抱鱼，想念红月亮和白月亮，想念海蛾号、海虾号、独眼巨人号，想念那句"欢迎回来，船长"。
自从极光号坠毁，我所做的事都是活下来并且想办法回到地球，但过程中我发现我更喜欢这里的生活。
我享受吃自己种的甜瓜，自己造核发电机，开着海蛾号去蘑菇林旅游，跟电鳗打招呼的生活。
这里没有政治，没有国家，没有战争，没有谎言，没有种族歧视，没有意识形态的冲突。
回地球真的是个明智的选择吗...

Crashed, woke up, build shelter, built a fire, cooked stuff on it, killed some animals, got heavily stared at by savages, started logging, got captured, woke up in cave, attempted to expore cave and clipped through rocks into infinite fall of death as I left the known map/universe.

Crashed, woke up, build shelter, built a fire, built some standing fire, started building log cabin, got captured, woke up in cave, found way out, died on return trip.

Crashed, woke up, built shelter, built several fire pits in a ring around my camp site, started building log cabin, got captured,  woke up in cave, found way out, got back to camp, built several traps and more fire pits, camp overrun with savages, discovered I could clip under the plane, held out till dawn, savages discovered they could clip under plane, killed me. 

Despite the hilarity and frustration of all of this, this looks like it could become a really awesome game. Once the savages gain some real survival instinct - like running from fire instead of standing directly in it, burning - this could be the start of something fun. Until savages can actually be disuaded from coming closer, and until traps work, you'll be unlikely to survive more than a few days.

Subnautica is a fun (sometimes frightening) emersive game. As soon as you load in the world your thrown into an alien ocean full of diverse biomes with beautiful plant life and colorful, sometimes, terrifying creatures with beautiful landscape or should I say oceanscape. Along with the great creatures, diverse plant life and oceanscape is the atmosphere. The atmosphere the game provides is amazing, it makes the game come alive even more. Now the biomes, the biomes are very diverse with loads of colorful plantlife and each of there own creatures. And each biome has it own atmosphere, certain biomes have creepy and erie atmospheres while some have ,sometimes, soothing atmospheres that adds to the games emersiveness. And while this game can be relaxing at times, most of the time its terrifying, with an eire atmosphere you'll be swimming to the depths below and then hear the shrieking of an unknown creature praying that it doesn't find you.

So overall this very enjoyable game is emersive and an unintentional horror game with great atmosphere, music, creatures, graphics and much more. 9/10

Storytelling has always been a fickle thing in a game. Sometimes a developer has to ask which is the more important aspect of the game, the story or the gameplay? But then there are games like this that say BUGGA to the gameplay and invite you to a world that is both amazing feels and right at home. This is a (VERY) story driven game about a man who is about to die and is given one wish to change his memories of his life before he passes away. I have to say that I enjoyed the game and wish this type of storytelling will appear in the near future with more tales or new ideas. The only problem I had in it was that sometimes the comedic relief would ruin the critical moments.

In total I give it 8/10 An interesting story that shows that gameplay doesn't always have to be main focus of a game and simple life delimias can be entertaining instead of saving the world from complete and utter disaster.

BEST GAME EVER 

No matter what kind of gamer you are, you'll love this game.

You will enjoy "Vermintide 2" if you have ever had fun with co-op first-person shooters of its ilk, like "Left 4 Dead." The missions can take less than 30 minutes and accommodate a 4-player squad. It's tons of fun with friends or patent pros, but not too punishing with the P(ick)U(p)G(roup)s you might meet via quickplay. The character banter is nearly as good as in "Dragon Age: Inquisition," and the canonically detailed grim-dark fantasy setting will satisfy fans of Warhammer, horror, and eye-candy. The hack & slash melee feels meaty and satisfying.

    If you are a hardcore headshot fetishist like myself, your pituitary gland will hammer your joy-button with a pint of endorphins for every solid *PLINK* you get for demonstrating your skill. You'll also appreciate the reasonably diverse enemy-types, like how the ratties have a hunch that can block headshots from behind unlike their plague-addled human counterparts.

    If you HATE having to pay to unlock the crates you get, and EVEN THEN they're not for the right character ... you will LOVE this game! You can choose which of your five characters does the free unboxing of the 3-items-per box you get for each character level, complete run, and deed/daily/event/book challenge. What you don't need can be instantly smelted down to improve your favorite gear.

This game is utterly terrifying. im currently sitting in my tree house being hunted by at least two cannibals but its night time giving them another advantage. how did i end up here you ask? lets go back a day or two. after waking up i immediately starting gathering necessary materials and constantly listened for any threats. i looked for a break in the tree line and ran for it, knowing i was being hunted. i started learning the basics and worked on building my simple tree house when i noticed the light from the sun fading. i was overcome with fear as my half built house offered no help or advantage. so i make a camp fire, draw my axe and hope to survive the night.
dead quiet..
i scan every direction
i see a black silouette against the white moonlit sand, it dashes left into the tree line 
i hear chittering and giggling, as if i was too easy of prey
i hear rapid foot steps like a bear bounding toward me 
i turn around to see a lean grey skinned beast of a thing staring into my soul as if my eyes would be the first snack, an appetiser
out of fear and panic i close the distance with my axe and land a clean blow to the thing's face
i looked for a moment to see a shell of a person, as if lucifer had a batch of children
i turn away from it and retreat to my small fainting fire
i feed it, only to hear blood freezing maniacal laughter behind me
id been fooled..
the very same creature rose again with its peers circling me
taking no chances this time i struck it. then i hit it again, and again
the others retreated.. this was only the first night
i won this night, but it would only be a fleeting victory

Fantastic Game!

If you love any of the following you will enjoy this game:

- Exploring
- Gathering
- Crafting
- Building
- Unique Story Lines
- Mystery
- Survival
- Beautiful Atmosphere
- Alien Anything

I have been playing on PC. The lag that most people complain about is only really noticeable if you are moving very fast or entering/exiting menus in quick succession. The bugs that I have encountered so far are minimal. There are some things that don't have icons when placed in your bag, and the physics on the moving islands in relation to your character are a bit off, but both of those are to be expected with an Early Access title. Neither of them are game breaking or retract from how lovely the game is. I chose to follow the story line and explore as I go to each of the points of intrest, and I am extremley intrigued and excited to find out what happens next. My friend chose to free roam and he constantly squeals in delight at each new thing he encounters. Different ways to play, but we are both enjoying ourselves immensely. 

I highly reccomend this game to everyone of all ages.

The ideas solid, your group whether that be a spaceship crew crashed, a tribe, or even a sole survivor with a  dog are stranded and against the odds need to survive. After you have procured all your needed resources you start to think a bit bigger. Food is commonly a saught after resource and planning for the next seasons is neccessary but eventually you will grow the ability to explore.

Some people may aim to escape the dreadful planet on a rocket ship, either by building one or traveling to a remote location far away. While others may enjoy anywhere from primitive to advanced ways of peaceful living. 
If you wanted to you could become a colonizer and literally dominate an entire world with your populace.
Or instead you could choose to be a raiding group and do nothing but murder everything in your bloody path. Carful though, those giraff looking things WILL RIP YOUR ARMS OFF! thats ok though, just get a surgeon to sew them back on, or someone elses limbs...Or a a shiny new metal one! But wait, what if you dont want to do any of those things. 
I just want to be a hermit in the woods with a bear as a pet. Well its ok, because you can do that too. 
The vast arrangements of stories to be had here really is considerably limitless. 
I love this game, and you can too. The price is up there a little but realisticly compaired to tripple A games, the gameplay here is worth three of them and their selling at $80 - $90 a pop! 
DO yourself the favour if your looking to buy a great game and even partially considering Rimworld, buy it!

On a side note: 
I just Nominated Rimworld for its rightful "Labour of Love" title. 
This Game was released quite a few years ago and I have done nothing but whatch it become amazing! 
It started that way, and that was the key. Everything since then has just been deliciouse iceing! 
I hope the developers of Rimworld benefit from such nominations.

So first off I have to admit I rarely play this game myself. I know it says 300+ hours on record, most of those hours are my sister-in-law, whom I bought the game for. One day she was talking about how she wanted to get the game. I had heard of the game but had never really looked at it. So I jumped on steam to give it a look, and low and behold it was on sale for ten bucks, I figured why not.

Now for the review.
This is one of the few games that I actually get more enjoyment from watching other people play, as opposed to playing myself. Is the game buggy? Yes, But by looking at my game collection you will see I own a few Bethesda games, so obviously that is not a deal breaker for me. While this game is not my preferred type of game it is enjoyable, I prefer more story driven games. Some of the players can be douchebags, but that is with any online game. Just shrug it off and move to the next match. I play survivor mostly. I am a horrible killer and only play as one when I am feeling generous. So take the extra blood points and you're welcome for the easy escape. The game has room for improvement, quite a bit of room to tell you the truth. However, I still recommend it.
hmm

It's a good game.  It has the best campaign mechanics out of all the most recent Total Wars. 

Diplomacy is actually viable now and you can win campaigns with it alone.  

The battles are fun and look great.  

Units have formations that are both useful and aesthetically pleasing.  

Army composition has been reworked to the retinue system which I like very much.  So armies now can have 3 generals each that can recruit certain types of units that are color coordinated to match each general.  This allows for buffs for said units from said generals.  It's a very pleasant addtion to the game.

Army supplies have been added so enemy armies can't just roam your lands for the entire campaign.   

However, with all that said, they went ahead and sold the blood pack as DLC again which is complete horse sh*t, but that doesn't make the base game bad by any means.

	[td] + Vast amounts of unique loots.
+ Well done gunplay, very much improved from BL2.
+ Overhauled vehicles customization. No more generic presets, and you can now customize every part of your vehicle, affecting both functionality and appearance.
+ Respawning doesn't reset world progress.
- Invisible walls blocking vehicle access to certain paths.
- Can't use vehicle as a platform.
- Why the fuck can't I quit and have my my progress saved in the Circle of Slaughter?

	[td]10[/td]
[td]
+ In-depth progression system. Multiple skill trees, leveling up, increasingly powerful loot, endgame character upgrades and obtaining vehicle parts to customize your vehicles. All these and makes it obvious that you are getting more powerful in many different forms, no matter how long you play.
+ 4 different characters to choose from.
+ High replayability with new difficulties offering new challenges and rewards.
+ Regular new events.
+ Additional challenge arenas provides endgame content.

	[td]8[/td]
	[td] + A lot more natural behaviours with the enemy AIs as they now actually reacts to damage. They fall down, ragdoll, and even explode into a pile of gore when hit by guns or crushed by cars.
- Allies just looks so dead outside of cutscenes.
- While enemies have distinct groups, there aren’t much changes within each group, other than health, size and appearance.
- Fuck the Varkids. They just look so disgusting.

- Can’t sort your guns by the time of acquire, which is detrimental given how much loot you are given.
- Ui sometimes are unresponsive and ammo count and skill cooldown may go missing.
- Tooltips are confusing, you can’t expect me to just read the stats below and know that’s means amp? 
- Why not just say reduce cooldown instead of saying increase action skill cooldown rate? 
- Radius of Nova Blasts missing, something present in BL2.
- Inefficient weapons selling page. Half of the screen is dedicated to the redundant vending machine, and only around 20% of your screen shows your inventory.
- If I haven’t unlocked the area that the mission takes place in, then tell me so. Why do you have to put the marker in such a confusing way?
- Why not put names of locations you’ve discovered in the map?

While I liked the new improvements made to the Gunplay, World Diversity, Progression, AI and Vehicle Customization, I can't help but feel the game's outdated and disappointing, mainly in the UI and the Bugs. However, the core gameplay is still very fun even with these shortcomings, and the game is still constantly being supported. Hands down one of the best games I've ever played. The storyline, even though it's very hard to decipher what is happening sometimes, is very intricate and deep. The bosses were challenging, however never impossible (special thanks to the Weaversong Charm to aid me in the very frustrating Watcher Knights battle) and even the reward of satisfaction was all I needed sometimes in this game, because you will die. A lot (this is still a complete understatement). The bosses would sometimes take me hours on end, but I wouldn't have that patience to sit around and learn the attack patterns of these opponents if it wasn't due to the spectacularly befitting music. Now the NPC's, In my personal experience, a lot of the characters managed to make me grow attached to them, until they inevitably meet their end (in a good or bad way) making me experience a somewhat depressing state of mind for them, as you see their backstory unfold and finish in an instant. All in all, the final boss fight was exciting, however left me thinking 'is that it?' when I did eventually beat the Radiance. Maybe it's because Nightmare King Grimm was exceptionally hard and honed my Hollow Knight skills and made the final boss fight for the main storyline easier, but still satisfied me. Fantastic game, I give it a 9/10 and a solid recommendation.

Great game, probably my third favorite 3d platformer I have played (behind B&K and Mario64). Solid controls and oozes the character that Yooka&Laylee lacked. Probably the only downside is it took my 11 hours to 100%, so its quite short. But all of the 11 hours were great, and I'm super excited about the apparent free dlc worlds they will be adding. 
 
As a sidenote I would like to point out this game is quite a bit more linear than the classics like Mario64 and Banjo & Kazooie. You generally pick a mission and go at it. Depending on the world most of the world should be available to you still, but you can only go after the one time piece(excludingthe last world). I will say the worlds that this apply to the most (2 & 3) are also by far my favorite worlds in the game.

I love this game. Not only for the story or puzzles, but for the witty insults the intercom blares every once and a while. Although the series left on a good note (I.E you leaving the facility after god knows how long) the fan base nearly requires another game. The stipulation was that valve can't count to three- and they have held true to that with all but one series- the half life series. But not only does the fan base's heart ache for even one more comment by GLaDOS; this could be a major money-maker. So it makes serious sense to make another one. This review is not only for the people looking at the community tab for a confirmation that it's worth the money (which it so is) this is also for anyone involved with valve. This says I have only played 44 hours, but I have 135 hours on my old computer. And I have enjoyed every second of it. Although this appears as just another puzzle game- if you take a completionist approach to this game; you will see the major attention to detail. And either it is a long time coming- or the third one hasn't even started. But the amazing shtick that took two entire games to cultivate would simply keep the ball rolling. This is an amazing game with graphics, ominous moments and humor that no modern game that I have seen even gets close to rivaling. And that experience is dirt cheap. This is an older game, but with an amazing team behind it. Buy it- buy it for a friend- and leverage the makers to make another one. That is what I did. This is not an ad. This is simply a candid report on the experience that was (and hopefully still is) the portal series.

P.S I don't consider the lab game a continuation of the the portal series. That game features about 6 different   minigames and only the main menu and one minigame really gets the nostalgia for GLaDOS rolling. Even though it was cool to see her in VR.

This game is incredibly fun and challenging. There is so much content in the game such as tons of different guns and items that your runs can be either really lucky or just really bad, but that's what makes the game challenging at times. It is also precisely why this game has so much replay value. It is unlikely you will have the same exact run as before. This can be a game you sit down and play for hours at a time, or one where you complete a few floors and take a break.

If you're not experienced in games of this genre and this is the first game you play of its type, expect do die a lot when you first start off while you're still learning all the mechanics and enemy patterns.

[ING] Version:

I state that this is not a genre that I play very often but in some cases ... I play it willingly, and in fact the case of Dead by Daylight, personally the simple but effective concept and the difficulty of the game is not too difficult (not too easy, it depends on the players you are playing in the game).

At first glance the game is a lot of fun (at the beginning it is a little scary but the tension even if after some games it fades a bit of anxiety there anyway), you start with the optics but this is a Survival Horror , the goal is to survive before being killed by the killer (5th player), or by the killer killing the survivors (the 4 opposing players) before they escape, either on one side or on the other is not easy but not impossible,

In DbD in addition I am convinced that the rules of "The higher you level the more you are strong" are not in force the player level is a sort of "goal of your progress as a Killer or survived plus level increases the more you have the chance to get special points to buy new Killers or survivors (except for newer additions) to increase your gaming experience.

So I think the game is fun both alone and in company (if you have a close-knit group of 3 other friends playing on discord).

Recommended to buy it with discounts if you want to save something more on some DLC (not strictly necessary to buy them all in my opinion).

Update (11/27/2019):

The game is very nice and fun ... a bit frustrating to code as a killer the search for games is too long, but the new "Battel Pass System" introduced and very nice and allows you to make lots of points and get free cosmetics partly and premium if you buy the battel pass.

[ITA] Version:

Premetto che questo non è un genere che gioco molto spesso ma in alcuni casi...lo gioco volentieri, e il caso infatti di Dead by Daylight, personalmente il concept semplice ma efficace e la difficoltà di gioco non troppo difficile (neanche troppo facile , li dipende dai giocatori con cui ci si trova in partita).

A prima vista il gioco e molto divertente (all' inizio fa un pò paura ma la tensione anche se dopo un pò di partite si affievolisce un pò di ansia c'e comunque), partite con l'ottica che però questo e un Survival Horror, l'obiettivo e di sopravvivere prima che si venga ammazzati dal killer (5° giocatore), oppure dalla parte del killer ammazzare i sopravvissuti ( i 4 giocatori avversari) prima che scappano, sia da una parte che dall'altra giocare non e semplice ma non impossibile,

In DbD in oltre sono convinto che non vige la regole del "Più sei alto di livello più sei forte" no il livello giocatore è una sorta di "traguardo dei tuoi progressi come Killer o sopravvissuto più aumenti di livello più hai possibilità di ottenere punti speciale per comprare nuovi Killer o sopravvissuti (eccetto le nuove aggiunte più recenti) per poter aumentare la tua esperienza di gioco.

Quindi io ritengo il gioco divertente sia da solo che in compagnia (se hai un gruppo affiatato di altri 3 amici che giocano su discord).

Consigliato comprarlo con gli sconti se si vuole risparmiare qualcosa in più su alcuni DLC (non strettamente necessario comprarli tutti a mio parere).

Aggiornamento (27/11/2019):

Il gioco e molto bello e divertente...un pò frustrante codare come killer la ricercha delle partite e troppo lunga, però il nuovo "Sistema di Battel Pass" introdotto e molto bello e permette di fare un sacco di punti e di ottenere cosmetici gratuiti in parte e premium se si compra il battel pass.

I love this game dearly. There's not much more I can say about it. 
As someone who played Harvest Moon a lot as a child, this game really hits a nostalgic spot for me while still introducing new features that has me coming back again and again. Depending on your mood, you can play this as a simple farming sim, a dating sim, or a roguelike (caves, particularly in the desert) - or, of course, all of the above at once. I love how there's a structure and a plot to this game - and the fact that if you're not in the mood for it, you don't have to interact with it. I'm a simple nb that just loves exploring the dungeons, checking up on my farm animals, and giving gifts to my SO, lol. Perhaps it's time for my character to branch out a bit more. :P
Being able to play with friends is also really enjoyable. :)

4. Survival Book is not entirely working as some recipies are misleading, e.g The Log Cabin Says it requires 35 Logs and no. of sticks, but when you place it it says you need 82 logs, I was like dafuq? The book didn't say that.


These are the main things that need to addressed in my opinion, I understand it's in alpha and things are still being carried out, but if you could take these into immediate consideration, that will be most helpful.

Absolutely brilliant! The best game I have ever played. Even though this game is five years old, it is still breathtakingly gorgeous. Between the amazing voice acting, the enthralling and branching storyline, the AMAZING soundtrack, enjoyable combat, incredible RPG aspects, and believable and fascinating characters, I cannot recommend a better game. You can tell that CD PROJEKT RED really put their heart and soul into this game. Not to mention the replayablity. I have played this game all the way through five times, and I am on my sixth playthrough right now. Every time I beat this game, I want to play MORE of The Witcher! The characters seem alive, and after I beat the game for the first time I felt like I had lost a friend, so I started  New Game+ playthrough! Not to mention that both DLCs are WONDERFUL! Over ten hours more of story for both Hearts Of Stone, and Blood and Wine. I cannot recommend this game enough. If you are still skeptical however, it goes on sale pretty regularly, I would pick it up then if I were you. This is the best game ever created in my book, and I cannot wait to see what the amazing devs at CD PROJEKT RED has to offer with Cyberpunk 2077, and all of the future games that they develop.

i would love it if the loot system was a little bit more in-depth and the weeklies gave rewards, other than that this is a great game. If you want a semi-casual co-op loot-light RPG-light dungeon crawler with intense combat mechanics, get it.

Pros: 
+ highly satisfying combat: meat-salad/explosive/fire destructionation of hundreds of hapless enemies with any weapon you desire
+ brutally punishing on higher difficulties if you can't do good mechanics (e.g. dodging, aiming, etc.) and teamwork but
+ fairly forgiving on lower difficulties if you are a bit of a fight potato
+ some hilarious conversations /voicelines /banter /corpse physics
+ pretty decent graphics /sound fx
+ most players are not jerks and will help/show you stuff
+ a very DARK gory theme

Cons:
- loot is RNG but like, really bad RNG. (fuck you Ranald and fuck you reroll button), and so is crafting (also shallow)
- Player skill and attitude varies widely (this is not on the game, but still)
- progression is pretty shallow: after a while you have nothing to get (300 item and 600 character power is max) except skins which are stupidly rare
- not all careers are balanced and not all talents are balanced - you *can* play whatever combination you want and probably still win... or just do zealot and faceroll the same things.

Enemies are incredibly flakey.  Even being as careful as possible you'll still get walloped the second your periscope pokes above the water.  I ended up refunding the game because the AI is obviously playing with perfect knowledge of your location.

Great game made by great developers. 

This game is not for everyone. It's big, it's complicated and it's sometimes comparable to actual work. You start off mining resources by hand, only to create tools which lets you mine resources and craft tools automatically. It has the addictiveness of incremental games with the complication of puzzle games or real life programming. 

It's incredibly polished, very optimized, has online multiplayer and it's a good price compared to the hours you'll get out of it.

I'd recommend playing the demo first to see if this is really your kind of game. Also no need to wait for it to go on sale, the devs confirmed it never will as the price is fair as it is.

Short:
It's a really nice game and in the end i still can recommend it (especially on sales) to everyone who can forgive imperfection in detail.

You can double jump, dodge, charge your spear to increase damage and range, have a flaming sword (with increased damage compared to the standard sword) and, the most amazing thing: you are a viking.

On the other hand:
- you have to press a movement-direction-button (left or right) with your second jump, because you jump straight upward without a direction-button.
- you can't move while crouching, so you have to dodge instead.
- after beating a stage and restarting the game, you have to visit all previous stages and move to the left in order to come to the next stage. There is no way to just choose the stage.
- you have to beat a stage in his normal version again in order to come to the harder versions of the stages. Also means there is no harder version of stage 1.

[Version of the game: 1.36c, just in case some things change in the future]

This is a very very compelling, addictive and challenging rogue like.  

Combining deck building elements, with a system of leveling up certain cards while discarding others if you're able to pay the hefty gold amount.  

 If you've played Hand of Fate, than you'll be quite familiar with the quest lay for the progression of your character.   A limited branch of quests that could be a regular monster fight, a mini-boss fight, a chance to rest where you can either gain health back OR upgrade a card in your deck.  Visiting a merchant to buy various wares all at a steep price.  And finally a random quest where often times you'll be given various options on how to respond which can be painful but profitable.

  And if you're health reaches zero before hitting the boss at the end of the level...well you loose everything.   Every time you die you lose everything.  But that's okay, because you learn your enemies, you learn your characters deck (there are 3 different characters to choose from as of this writing) and hopefully you'll get a bit better RNG.  

If you like Card Crawl, deck builders, or Hand of Fate then you'll feel like you've made a solid purchase (please please please put this on ios!  To be honest I'd probablhy buy it twice).

Possibly the best game I've ever played.  Hats off to the developers and Ludeon.  Have already put 100 hrs in and still much more to explore.  Each person will take away their own unique story from rim world.  Countless different ways to play the game.  Each decision you make stacks.  Some colonies will flourish, others are fated to fail.  Permadeath is a great way to play and makes the stories rich and all your decisions count.  I wasn't expecting this much from a game that looked like stick figures but it just goes to show how much deeper the game is than just animation. Aside from being generally awesome, the game automatically syncs through your steam account so you can easily continue your colony on different machines no matter where you are.  Plays great on laptops.  I waited a while to see if it would go on sale then read a little more about it.  Since it's indie title it won't go on sale.  Regardless, $30 is a steal for this game.  Just buy it.

To get the most important thing sorted right off the bat: This is a good game, you should buy it, you will enjoy it.

In more detail, the enjoyable parts are the fun writing, the great art, the ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE MUSIC, the wonderful boss fights and the platforming which manages to make a platforming casual like myself to not throw his controller while yelling.

Oh wait hang on, that's everything about it that's enjoyable, isn't it? By and large, yes. There are a few parts that could be criticized, though, mostly that the game lacks a bit of polish here and there in the actual platforming that makes up most of the levels. The game sometimes doesn't want to grab ledges, a few jumps are punishingly pixel-perfect(though really only a few) and the game sometimes helps you, sometimes ignores you and lets you plummet to your doom. Conversely, the boss fights are all amazingly well-done.

It's like someone inverted Shantae, which has tons of mood and good writing and art, well-polished actual levels, and then kind of hits its head and waddles around in confusion when you say "boss fight." Hat In Time, on the other hand, could've done with about another 500 boss fights without boring me, while I could see a few places to tighten up the levels themselves.

It's also a bit short on content, about 12 hours of play for me, which involved just toodling around Mafia Town for about an hour because I was enjoying jumping on things, wearing hats and listening to the music. But supposedly we're getting another two acts in the start of 2018, so I think that's a bit of a minor thing to pick on. Besides, 12 hours of very solid entertainment is good value for money considering that it's a game with essentially no random generation at all, everything about it being hand-crafted.

I'd say that the SubCon Forest and Dead Bird Studio both feel like they could've had another couple of stages in there, though. But if I had to choose, I'd rather that they stopped while I wanted more and felt like they could've done more, rather than another eight stages down the road where I groaned every time I saw the Conductor or DJ Grooves(not the Snatcher, though, good luck ever making me tired of him, nerds.).

Ultimately I'd give it a 9 out of 10. It would've been 11 out of 10, but I have to subtract two points for the ending. Very minor spoilers ahoy.

[spoiler]Losing one point because I wanted to sign another contract, and losing one point because I wanted to make another movie![/spoiler]

So if you're still reading this review: BUY THE DAMN GAME ALREADY. OH, AND DON'T BE CHEAP, GET THE SOUNDTRACK, TOO. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT.

Adding an additional comment, I've revisited the game a number of times since my initial comment to see how the updates may have improved performance. While the crashes are a bit less frequent, each save (and autosave) takes 3-5 minutes instead of the previous 10 seconds or so. Since the autosaves are so frequent, I'd say its a net loss in time.  I'll check back periodically to see if performance improves, but until this game is truely finished / functional, I would not recommend another Pathfinder game to anyone.

The game is downright addictive. Build up, build out, make it faster, make it better. If you enjoy puzzles, logical planning, and occasional disaster it'll be the game for you. Just remember when you have your sprawling megafactory that can produce anything you need in seconds with robots to deliver it all to you that you started out scrabbling at rocks with a pickaxe. When you can rain death on your enemies from miles away and wreck the survivors with atomic hate and flamethrowers that you started with a pistol and ten magazines.

Pros:
+Requires you to constantly be thinking several moves ahead to build up your best base.
+Almost limitless creativity to design and improve your factory to build it better and faster.
+Changing map settings can alter the entire experience causing it to take a while for the game to feel stale.
+Largely polished as we approach the 1.0 release; no major bugs in vanilla play.
+The gameplay is very intuitive once you've gotten the hang of basic controls.
+Tech progression is smooth and feels rewarding as you progress.

Cons:
-The combat element is rather bland and can be automated like any other aspect of gameplay.
-While bland, you do not realize you're losing combat until 20 hours in due to the way the enemies advance.
-Some hard stops in tech progression where the thing that would expedite getting tech requires said tech.

Misc:
*Sometimes it can be fun to just watch your factory work. Remember, work smarter not harder.
*Flamethrowers are my favorite weapon. They are also the weapon I've killed myself with the most.
*Learning how to make trains work well is a fine art. Study real rail systems if you need help.
*[spoiler] Heavy Forests make it easier to get hard achievements. Once you have robots they don't impede you. [/spoiler] 
*[spoiler] The devs seem obsessed with complicated belt systems but they aren't really needed. [/spoiler]

This game is like a mix between Gang Beast gameplay and physics-based puzzles.
There are surprisingly few bugs and the puzzles have just the right difficulty.

The enjoyment comes from the funny controls, physics, creative puzzle solving (and cheesing some) ... and playing with at least one friend!

Downsides are: 
Once you know a puzzle, there's little interest in doing it again. 
The early stages seem eerily quiet with zero background noises or music to accompany the gameplay.

I've really enjoyed the game. It's a fun mindless FPS that has some good humor. If you're looking for a tactical FPS experience, this isn't the game for you. I don't play multiplayer much, however, the little I have done (with friends only, no match-making) has been great. As far as the DLC, overall it's good, and I'm happy that I bought the season pass. The best DLC of the bunch is Moxxi's Heist.

The unskippable cutscenes completely ruin the MyCareer mode.  The MyCareer is grindy as fuck already so even when you want to quickly bang out 5 games and get that VC, you're forced to watch cutscenes that sometimes have you waiting 4 minutes watching some shitty dialog you've heard a million times.

Still fun if you like MyTeam and just playing with friends (mostly locally for me).  Also did 5 seasons of MyGM and found it strangely addicting.

Definitely not worth the full price, but I will get likely over 80 hours out of this game.

This game is shaping up to be an absolute favorite of mine.

A game that heavily symbolizes anxiety and depression, makes my mood go up whenever I'm feeling low. A game with soothingly tough difficulty especially with the B side and C side levels, there's far more to do after you finish the story mode. There's a whole lot of game to this, and it feels like the devs just want me to keep playing. Few games have made me want to go back to previous levels and collect all of the items, but luckily, the strawberries you collect tally into how well of an ending you get with the strawberry pie that Madeline makes for everyone at the end, and the hearts you collect allow for more levels until you finish all of the C sides. After you beat the story mode, it becomes a real collectathon. It's like the real game begins, similar to how it is with the 3D platforming Mario games.

In terms of difficulty, this is a tough one for completionists, but I love every second of the greulling climb. It always makes me feel better somehow. I'm not even close to finished, and I keep coming back.

The story is great. The gameplay is rock solid, and there's more to do than what it may lead on around the beginning.

My conclusion: 9/10 An utterly immersive and fantastic game, with some minor issues.

Pros:
-Gameplay is excellent
-Graphics are fantastic
-Sound is used impeccably well
-Music is fitting and helps produce a lot of tension and atmosphere
-Solid atmosphere makes the whole game feel very immersive
-Interesting Story
-Fun base building
-Multiple vehicles with perfect progression
-Beautifully hand-crafted world that is both big enough and detailed enough, with a diverse set of biomes
-An array of awesome mods that can bring the game to yet another level of fun
-Multiple game modes to suite different kinds of players.
-Important loot is mostly randomized, so you can't just cheap out and look it up on a wiki, you have to genuinely explore the world.
-An Early Access game that was successfully finished!

Cons:
-Some aspects of the game are too easy in retrospect. (Mods can make this problem even worse, beware!)
-Sometimes quite buggy, but nothing game-breaking
-Might be too spooky for some people

Death Stranding is an interesting game in that you have to play EXACTLY as Hideo Kojima wants you to play it, there is no room for shenanigans. Figuring out a route, making sure you have the right tools and navigating through BT territories is a lot of fun and quite relaxing and being able to use ladders, ropes and bridges that other players placed throughout the world is great. 

Is this game for everyone? No it is not. But if you're interested in playing and willing to play to give yourself over to the experience I would HIGHLY recommend buying it on sale. As good as this game is, it is a walk sim... a $100 walking sim...

First of all i highly recommend buying this game if you enjoy spending hours and hours exploring and gathering resources .

I am not going to go highly in depth with the game but keeping it short , this is one of the best early access experiences i have had with a game , UWE has done an exemplary job and i will 100% buy into their next early access .

That aside , the game is very well balanced , not too grindy but not too fast as well , i really got caught up in building my base and ended up with something way way way larger than i ever would need , exploring is really fun also from gathering metal salvage in the safe shalows go being stalked  by crazy predators while gathering uranium . Small , funny and also giant creatures populate the waters that you will discover and will definitely enjoy 100% of it . 

Overall i will give this game 9.5/10 , it would be a full 10 /10 if i could play with a friend , in my eyes only that could make Subnautica better . Not full multiplayer but some kind of CO-OP situationwhere i can bring a friend or two along for the ride .

The only thing that i felt passing through into the release was a little bit of lag when the game is loading stuff in , i highly doubt that its my pc but maybe .

The Factory grows.

Enter the Gungeon has the unfortunate honour of being the newest entry into the saturated market of roguelites.

Ahead of its release,Enter the Gungeon was tagged with rather unfair monikers like ‘Binding-of-Isaac-with-guns’ and ‘Nuclear-Throne-clone’. Turns out these descriptions weren’t just unfair, they were inaccurate too.

Quite possibly my most favorite game of the year so far, Hollow Knight is simutaneously a lovely and hideous game that demands no prisoner but only souls. For a game that has the same cryptic writing and story delivering style of From Software's Souls series, it managed to break my heart not once but at least four times thanks to the ugly conclusions of various sidequests that made me feel like a hero at first. If you need to cut deep to open a path, so be it, just don't forget that you're not alone in this hellhole, and always expect the worst if you happen to care about... someone particularly.

Contributing to the emotional impact is the lovely hand drawn artstyle where even the most hideous creatures can look fluffy and cute while the divine ones can turn into monsters in a blink of an eye. Okay that's probably an exaggaration but the diversity and quality here is phenomenal, every single area in Hollow Knight has a distinct theme that makes the game itself a treat to look at and traverse through, from the fascinating greenhouse of death in Greenpath, the cold heart of royal fuckery in City of Tears, the bullshit claustrophobic "WHY IS THIS PLACE SO NARROW AND WHERE'S THE FUCKING LIGHT" feeling in Deepnest, or... yeah, that White Palace. Visual cues make sure you're never lost, from pieces of paper that lead you to the mapmaker, directional signs with an image of a bench or tram on it, or even some paths suddenly have visual distinct from other areas grow near it. Hollow Knight also doesn't lack melancholic tunes that sometimes make you feel hopeless and furious, but my most favorite moments must be that relief feeling when I hear Cornifer's humming across an area: We're heading the right way! We don't need to wander aimlessly anymore!

Smartly interconnected levels make backtracking less a chore and more meaningful, since you can easily pass on any path that you can't quite reach yet and come back later with any mobility ability. Any unexplored path, any unopened door, any dark deep hole can always contain something that's worth risking our lives for, even discovering a shortcut back to previous ares feels like a true accomplishment. Hollow Knight encourages you to explore as much as you want, how quick and far you progress throughout the game really depends on your own pace. Of course, there are some definitive narrative structure that needs you to be in a specific place to trigger and can feel scripted, but the rest of the game allows you to go wherever you want, do what you feel like you want to first, Metroidvania and Souls-style.

Control can be iffy at times with overly sensitive strafing but it doesn't take much time to get used to it. Combat relies on the visceral feel rather than stylish combos, the charms make up for lack of equipments by giving you different utility, defensive or offensive effects. The game's difficulty is on par with your typical Dark Souls game, you don't have heath bar and your "health mask" depletes as the amount of damage taken, every weak monster can kill you if you're not careful, every boss can make you bang your head against wall, but they all have telegraphed moves that can be used against themselves.

I still believe that Radiance was designed by Satan.

Overall if you don't mind a lot of bugs (( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)), don't mind to be heartbroken, don't hate the map system, don't mind backtracking, and deeply a masochist, then you would be foolish to pass on Hollow Knight. Science hasn't proved that playing this game will turn you hollow or not, but I can guarantee that 22 hours into the game made my skin thicker and controller grew some scars that I didn't regret giving it.

If I can put this game into as little words as possible, I'll say this:

Simply amazing.
Amazingly simple.

It's a pretty basic idea for a game. You get cargo, drive to the destination, drop off the cargo, make money, do it again, and again, and again until you have enough money to start your own trucking business. You buy garages, upgrade them, buy more trucks, hire drivers to drive them and do the same thing you do, truck around Europe and make money.

It's one of the few games that, despite being a complete grind, is actually fun. It's repetitive, but that's okay because you are repeating the same fun actions over and over, and they still manage to be fun. Also, you can listen to music on the radio while you truck which is amazing!

I definitely recommend this game to people looking for a relaxing game to play when you just want to listen to music and go trucking around Europe.

I bought this game during the steam lunar sale for 300 rupees ( 4 dollars and 40 cents ) and i am seriously disappointed at myself for not buying it for the full price. I had previously played witcher 1 and 2 on my console and they were okay at best (6.5 for the first one because of somewhat of a unusual combat and a solid 7 for the 2nd one , liked the story but didnt quite like the linearity of the game ) and i absolutely had zero idea what i was going into since it was going to be the first open world RPG developed by CD project RED . I saw many reviews about the game and they all praised it and held it in high regard . unfortunately my pc was garbage at that time when this game came out so i completely let this game slip under my radar. when i actually started playing the game i was seriously shocked (in a good way) and dumbfounded that how can a game have so much content and that too good content. 

All the side missions are excellent and kinda necessary as there will be an epic fight during the final act of the game where you can ask all these characters to join you in the fight. the story is excellent . the soundtrack is excellent. There are absolutely no bugs (none that i have encountered) .the mission design is excellent. Nothing feels out of place here . plus there are 2 outstanding DLC s which open up 2 completely new locations with different enemies and different quests . you can invest 100 hours into this game easily and still you wont be bored and still there will be something in the game for you to do. 

TL;DR overall i really dont think a rating out of 10 will do justice to this masterpiece but if it has to be a rating system i would give it 10/10 . it is really a must have.

Overall The Witcher 3 is an example that development studios exist who dont chase after the green bill and actually love making games for us the gaming community and publishers who dont force developers to rush out a half baked cake (Im looking at you EA)

I first played this game on the Xbox as it was the only platform I could play it on. That was about two years ago and I still love this game. The PC version seems to have more than the console version, which is great as its keeping me well interested. Don't be fooled by the pixelated Art style of this game, its a gem to play, so relaxing and fun to play. 

You start off the game after inheriting your Grandfathers old farm land and, being sick of the city work-a-day life, go live on the farm to make a better life. You start off having a rather ratty looking patch of land and, as you level up in certain areas like farming and foraging, end up being able to turn the ratty land into a beautiful looking farm. You can grow vegetables (make sure you water them daily), go fishing, go mining or even get friendly with the locals, with a view to get married and start a family. You can even have a civil partnership and adopt children, which is great to see being included in games.

I'm finding it hard to fault this game but I do have one or two things to say in a negative direction. Firstly that your game will only save once you go to sleep, not great when you are halfway through a day and you need to stop for any reason. Secondly, I plugged some headphones in to listen to the game whilst the better half was on a phone call and when he was done I unplugged the headphones but the game sound would not come back. I restarted the game and everything was back to normal, but I lost half a days progress as referred to in my first little gripe.

I don't want to put anyone off buying this game, its so worth getting as its adorable style will have you thinking "I'll just play one more day...".

This is a great game to get lost in. It's even better if you love anything to do with Havest Moon or Animal Crossing. The best part about playing this game is that you discover what you have to do as you play it.
200 hours says that I liked it a lot. Maybe another play-through at some point.

A bit of a different experience to other stuff from Fromsoftware, but honestly has so pretty nice and fluid combat once you get going (usually hits you about 25% ish into the first playthrough of the game). It'll take a while to get used to though, especially coming from something like dark souls 3 as I frames are essentially gone, so you go from Rolling through everything to parrying everything. Story is honestly much easier to follow which was nice to see honestly but it didn't hold back on actually checking for story that might be hidden through eavesdropping and NPC interaction. Two complaints i do have however, is firstly that with the way progression and items are setup, if you're not trying to speed run the game, there is virtually no replayability to the game after the second playthrough, assuming you do the first 'Secret' ending on the first playthrough and shura on the second, as by this point you've seen every boss in the game and theres no real new ways to take them on after this, which personally has left me in limbo in actually finishing off this games achievements (requires 4 playthroughs) - Which compared to something like DS3, which i have at least 10 or 11 playthroughs completed of, just because theres so many more ways to tackle each boss. Secondly, theres a lot of mindless grinding to get more ninja arts and skills after even your second playthrough. While this did seem nice for replayability early on, you soon realize that a lot of these skills you missed, you missed because they are generally pretty bad and using the real high tier ones just feels like a waste since they also cost your ninja tool resource and all in all i honestly wish that you could have actually had these earlier in the game cycles, such that their effects might have been more useful. But enough ranting about some kinda minor stuff, especially since these don't even matter on a first playthrough, i'd still rate this game pretty highly for what i did get out of it.

Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare received a lot of negative feedback ever since the first trailer, which made me sceptical about buying it. In the end, as any die hard Call of Duty fan would do, I pre-ordered it anyway.

I have now spent over 70 hours on this game's Singleplayer and Multiplayer and I can safely say that I am very pleased with the game.

The Singleplayer has a great storyline and it is overall just really fun to play. The ending was amazing and off the beaten path compared to the endings in all the previous titles which just made it that much greater.

The Multiplayer has been nothing but a smooth experience. For once the Multiplayer in a Call of Duty game is working smoothly if you have good internet and a good setup to run the game. There are no hitmarker issues and the balancing is a lot better than the last few entries. The movement system has also been refined for the better. The only Multiplayer issue I have found is that sometimes lobbies can take a while to start, however that is not enough to fault the game.

Infinity Ward has done a good job here by trying to learn from the mistakes made by Treyarch in Black Ops 3. I am pleased :)

Though most say it is not newb-friendly, for me it is. Community is nice, VAC works well, Good maps and the gameplay is just overall fun. This game is fun even if your terrible at it, I got the hang of this game in a few hours and became a decent player. There is atleast one weapon that suits your style, thats how good the variety is. 

You can also use this game in GMod for access to some maps and items that are in CS:S, and allow some content from the steam workshop to work correctly. so thats 2 for 1. (if you own gmod that is).

Note: This game requires a decent amount of mechanical skill, so if your a newb to FPS games in general, then you might want to try something easier. I was previously skilled at other FPS games (I was at MLG level in some...), so thats why I found this game quite easy to get in to.

Please dont judge this game because its old or because there is no ADS in it, the game is really fun and I think if ADS was added it would ruin the game completely. No ADS means you actually have to crouch and use mechanical skill to get your gun to hit the target. Instead of this CoD thing where as soon as you ADS your gun becomes super accurate.


So, if your looking for a Challenge or a fun FPS game to play with friends or with others, or you are into the modding then id reccomend it. If your just getting into the FPS Genre of games, id suggest you go for something easier before you jump into CS:S.

And if you want to go eSports, then go for CS:GO. Thats where the eSports are centered around as far as I know. (even though that game requires less skill in general)

The alpha game was great, incredible- even. It wasn't perfect. It had problems- realistically fixable problems.
The game that was there was just too good to pass up, which is the thing that made it special.

The early points of the game weren't great, but once you got your skills and just hit that infinite progression and kept going- it was a great experience. The only roadblock from there was the lack of meaningful content. Factions, unique equipment, stories to tell, gadgets to find. These gadgets and new exploration tools presented in the beta combined with the gameplay loop of the old game is all that it would have taken to blow everyone out of the water.

It's not the case though. What we have is only content- static content that never changes. A whole world with cool things to explore, but with systems in place that do their best to make sure you don't enjoy it. 

Until something is done to unite the best of the Alpha with the best parts of the beta, I don't think my thoughts on the game are changing, and I think a lot of people are starting to realize the game isn't in a good place.

If you are looking for decent graphics and a fun submarine game without all the hassles of a hard core simulator, this is it. The mechanics behind the game such as sonar and torpedo performance approach a hard core simulator's level of detail/accuracy, but this isn't a game where you man a watch station or see what the inside of a submarine looks like. I was a submarine sonar tech on SSN-687 and AGSS-555. I thoroughly enjoy the classes of submarine available in this game. While I served on a Sturgeon class, I love the slightly older and slightly less capable Skipjack class. They were the "sports cars" of US SSNs. They looked sleek and were fast and maneuverable, but had less capable sonar and fire control. This is the best submarine game released in a long time.

If I am playing alone, I can don my bone mask and run around murdering teenagers. Can you think of a better use of your time? I can't. 

There are a lot of people that don't like Dead By Daylight because "____ is so OP", but these people can largely be ignored. They are simply salty because they need more practice (mad cuz bad). The Devs have been working tirelessly on both fixing bugs and creating new content. The Meta of the game is constantly changing and some people get to attached to one way of playing that they can't handle it when it suddenly isn't as good as it used to be. These people who complain on forums and in the comment section of every update are the cancer that is ruining gaming.

Keep up the good work Behaviour Digital, and don't let the vocal minority ruin this gem of a game for the world.

Update: This game is still wonderful, although the devs have a nasty tendency to release paid for content and make it OP, more or less forcing people to buy it to adapt. still great though

The story is mostly generic and unoriginal, with it's own little Borderlands spin, in order to attempt to tie the overall story together. This addition to the series does not excel at story telling, or voice acting, save for a couple of the playable characters, and characters previously featured in the series. However, this addition to the series has by far the best loot system, end game mechanic, and build diversity because of the subsequent better loot. If guns and grinding are your main draws to the Borderlands series, and you can give or take the story, you will likely enjoy this game.
blood

Not really a need for another Positive review on this pile, but I'm going for it anyways.

Let me Preface this by saying that while I owned The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings before this game, The Witcher 3 was still my first real experience with the Series. 

POSITIVES:

>Graphics: This game has great visuals. Monsters are very detailed, from their dirty skin and fur, to their grotesque limbs, the bits of clothing or knicknacks that some of them have made for themselves. Detail is insane. Same goes for character models and armour. Every charcter from the peasants, to guards, to sorceresses, to Geralt and friends, all have wonderfully detailed designs. There are hundreds of different kinds of armour for Geralt too and they're all just as detailed and realistic. Landscapes are very realistic and detailed. Previously, Skyrim was my personal standard for Fantasy RPGs, and while Skyrim is still a fantastic OWRPG, something that distinguishes the Withcer from it is that this world feels so much more believable. Skyrim is very high fantasy - lots of very extreme climates, each very distinct. That's not bad, it's just different from the Witcher. Velen is a great example of what I mean. War-torn countryside dotted with marshes, farmland, and forests, scenes of battle - fields covered in corpses and ruined siege weapons, all being devoured by mud and necrophages. All are huge and expansive but somehow also very real and visceral. Velen FEELS like a medieval countryside in the midst of war. I found the world to be beyond immersive.The point I'm trying to make is that despite being fantasy, the graphics made the world feel incredibly believeable; one can't help but be totally engrossed by it.

>Story: Some argue TW3's story was a bit padded - longer than it needed to be. While not entirely a false claim -there were areas where the story could have progressed quicker- I wouldn't call this is a flaw. The game was long and took some time and effort. You won't have it done in 24 hours, but it's like finishing a good book. You feel refreshed and satisfied. Story itself was good; Not super unique but rewarding and at many points very well written. Characters were very relateable and plot made sense. The Sidequests really shined. A great example being the Family Matters quest you recieve soon after arriving in Velen. Some of the best voice acting and writing I've seen in a game. Many of the smaller npcs in fantasy games often feel forced. There aren't many moments were one is moved by a character's acting. The opposite is true of TW3. There are many times in this game where I found myself agape, near tears, or laughing. The game is good at moving you, not because of out-of-the-box or surprising writing, but mostly because of top-notch character performance.

>Sound/Soundtrack: Authentic, Gritty, Catchy, and Emotional music made this game extremely memorable. Even if you don't buy the game, give the soundtrack a listen. You won't regret it. As far as other in-game sounds, there isn't much else to say, aside from: They're great. The cities, the animals, inns, battle and monsters, weather - all top-notch design.

>Gameplay: I'll argue in a moment that this is probably the game's weakest aspect, but I'd like to comment on a few things CDPR did right. Combat is not NECISSARILY a button-mashing festival. It consits of strong attacks, fast attacks, dodges, rolls, and various other techniques. There are a number of different ways to approach attacking the same enemy. I like what they've tried to accomplish, in that combat has noteable variety to it. Making a tough monster easier by reading a bestiary entry on it for example is an aspect of gameplay I really enjoyed. There's also the whole matter of character skills and progression to account for, but the gist of that is that spending AP to tailor to your preferred play style, sword-fighting, magic focused, using alchemy, etc, is very worth consideration. Travel in general felt Pretty well done. You never felt like you could travel the world in a heartbeat, but you also didn't have to slave for hours to get where you needed to go.

NEGATIVES
<Bugs: While the game isn't super buggy on the whole, there are definitely some issues that were frustrating at times. The horse is a notable example, some of it's AI movements being.. off. Other bugs were few but they were there. Monster AI could be pretty glitchy at times, and quests would sometimes glitch out and a reload was required. A few times I found Geralt walking around on his knees four feet in the airand other misc movement and animation glitches. Again, none were particularily distracting, none were game breaking.

<Gameplay: While I like what CDPR was trying to do with combat, the controls weren't perfect, it could get kind of clunky at times. Controls weren't bad, but especially if you used k&m, they took some getting used to. Not as bad as previous games, but not perfect either. I used an Xbox controller. I highly recommend that to anyone playing this game. It really improved playability. Sometimes certain aspects, while not inheritly bad at all, got a little repetitive. Detective geralt for example (Witcher Senses). 

CONCLUSION: Get this game. I'm a stingy person, but I'd reccommend it even at full price. CDPR have made something to be proud of. TW3 deserves every bit of love it gets, because of the love the devs have given it. A true fantasy epic. 200 hours of genuine entertainment. 9.5/10 at least.

This game is great. When starting a colony, you get to know the colonists. You learn their names and understand their strengths and weaknesses. You get to know which tasks each one should do. You form systems for how to manage your base. You tame animals for their produce, you build workshops, and you start making an excess of supplies to sell. You start to build infrastructure that not only makes your base habitable, but also a rather decent for your colonists. You establish a great colony on the rimworld. 

This game is also brutal. Your colony of ten get raided by a band of fifteen raiders armed to the teeth. You somehow manage to fend them off, but the fight leaves many injured and a few dead. After you start treating to your colonists needs as best you can, another raiding party attacks out of retaliation for their lost. They prepare their siege with sandbags and mortars. You try and meet them head-on but are slowed because of past injuries. You fend them off with what you have left, but the damage to your base and your colonists are done. Your hydroponics system is destroyed and your food supply is engulfed in flames. Because you're in a desert and it's the heat of summer, there is no opportunity to plant anything to eat. The few colonists that you have left have little chance to survive, and eventually succumb to the heat and the hunger. Your colony had a good run, but it eventually is put to an end. ...Either this or your colonists get mauled to death by a bear after shooting it fifteen times.


I highly recommend this game. It's a very approachable base management game. The difficulty is very scalable (you can play it casually or test your luck with a challenge). The scenarios of where to start are very customizable based on the different biomes and planetary features you get to choose and manipulate. And with all of this, there is a strong sense of progression and achievement when building up a colony. All in all, its a great game.

What a masterpiece of gameplay. The story is dark, well paced, and is open to many ways in progressing the story. I get so lost in the side quests I sometimes have to remind myself to do the main quest. And I mean that in the best way possible. Between crafting new armor sets and weapons, fighting different beasts and learning the best strategies to fight them, and exploring the beautiful landscape, this game really has a great scope. 

However, this game does have it's issues. The looting is a pain in the base game (can be fixed with mods, which I did). Also, after a while fighting can become easy as you learn the general approach to different enemies. This can sometimes make the game dull if binged too long, but overall the world is very great that the gameplay isn't a dealbreaker. There's also a decent bit of variety in playstyles in terms of combat, magic, and alchemy. With the addition of NG+ and the DLC, this game can be good investment of time with a very engaging story. and the addition of mods can easy the quality of life issues if you find one aspect particularly annoying.

Pros:

Cons:

If you thought that Episode 1 was great, Episode 2 is arguably the better of the two episodic sequels of Valve's Half Life 2.  This is mostly due to the increased number of assets added to the game, ranging from the new environments of White Forest and its surrounding countryside to the Antlion nest to especially the Hunters (or mini-striders as I once thought of them).  If I remember correctly it was also a period of change for Source as it provided an update to the engine, not to mention the reference to everyone's favorite teleportation-based puzzle game.

I like Episode 2, but I also have a love-hate relationship with it, simply because I, like so many others out there, have been waiting far too long for Episode 3.  I would really like to see an Episode 3...however with all the hype for Half Life 3 I feel like if Valve ever introduced an Episode 3 they'd likely start a World War 3.  In any case, this is a definitely satisfying closure to the current events of Half Life 2.

If you've never played this game before, I recommend it; just so that you can be on the edge of that cliffhanger right along with the rest of us.

TL:DR - fuck this game, if you still want it *DO NOT* buy it for full price.

Pros:
- Good graphics 
- They did try to insert some interesting mechanics for each faction, too bad the game itself sucks.

Cons:
- Took the Unique mechanics of DOW 1 & 2 and threw them to the garbage, and yes, it does feel alot like "Starcraft 2 / MOBA" combination, the only thing though is that Starcraft 2 is actually good.

- Singleplayer is a waste of time, nothing close to the DOW 2 campaign or DOW 1, Multiplayer is LAGGY and unstable.

- Hero Units (OR elites) take a HUGE role like in a MOBA, while they used to be somewhat powerful and help you get advantages over the enemy in previous DOW games, in DOW 3 they can *ERASE* whole units in a second - nothing more fun than spending a few good minutes building units for  just to see them get wiped out immediatly.

- Simplified game mechanics - Say goodbye to Cool looking battlefields and destroyable covers, you now have Lanes, Stealth Zones and Cover "ZONES" that make perfect camping spots

- Building bases is back only for you to build 5 buildings and Boost up units with simple 'More DMG' / 'More HP' upgrades and some unique upgrades that are okay at best.

- A unique feature of DOW - Switching between Melee and Ranged combat, is almost non-existent in DOW 3 + no killing animations.

- Game released with only one mod, compared to the different mods and terms of DOW 1 (in a latest patch they add Destroy Base Mod - which pretty much was the goal in the first mod so... thanks?)

- Reduce the amount of races from 4 to 3 in order to add more units and create a better balance, only to achieve the same amount of units and NO balance, can't wait for the first faction they'll announce as DLC.

- Ridiculous low amount of maps, ONLY 2-3 for each type of match (1vs1, 2vs2, 3vs).

I played DOW since the first game in 2004, the only thing that the fans wanted was a good Balance between DOW 1 and 2, hell even a REMAKE of DOW 1 would be great, and and we all got shitted on by the developers that had a different plan in mind, probably to make DOW a Esports game like Starcraft, they fucked it up and now this game got a shitty score and it deserves that.

If you still want to try it, go for it.
However even if you want to buy it, know that you get way less content than you should get for a full price game, I suggest waiting for a Major disscount before you go ahead and buy it.

This game... it [i]shouldn't[/i] be fun, it's got all of the makings of everything boring. It's a game where you drive on the motorway to deliver stuff to warehouses. But it's [i]fun[/i]... 

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is sort of like being shown a 4D cube as a citizen of the 3D universe. It just baffles you. For starters, I haven't played the other "simulator" games like Train Simulator or Garbage Truck Simulator (seriously?), I bought this because something just compelled me to. Perhaps it appealed to my secret yearning to drive around Liverpool in a giant truck in the rain with my windscreen wipers on. It's a great simulation, the controls work brilliantly (though I had to tweek them a little to fit my preferences) and it recreates the roads of the world quite accurately (I assume, I only know the roads of North England). 

My only real gripe with the game is that it doesn't seem to actually simulate the cities of Europe. When I said you can drive around Liverpool, you can only really drive around the outskirts of the city. It's really a shame, but I suppose the game makers didn't have time to recreate the major cities of Europe.

You'll probably find this game a lot less bewildering than I did if you like boring stuff like driving down the motorway. It practically infuriates me how this game is fun when it shouldn't appeal at all.

I don't think I'd pay the full £15 for this unless I was a real truck/driving fanatic, but in the sales I'd go for it.

So Civilization had just finished installing. I decided I would play it for maybe half an hour just to see what it was like, as I had plans for that day. So I started my game as Rome, and I attempted to be very scientifically progressive and economically sound. I was very peaceful and most civs liked me.

Then the barbarians took my worker. I just payed quite a lot of gold to get that worker, so of course I was angry. I got my archer ready and killed the barbarian. Just as i was about to rescue them the Germans came in and took them for themselves. We had a declaration of friendship up until that point, where I immedietly denounced them. They in turn, built an army and moved it next to my borders.

At this point I realized I had to strike first. So I hit his forces and invaded Hamburg. Doing this made me seem like a warmonger and all other civs were hostile to me. I decided to wait until the atomic era to get atomic weapons to take them on. When I got there I stockpiled around 7-10 atomic weapons in one of my cities. Just as I was about to use them Ghandi invaded me and took my city. Soon he was fighting most of the world.

I had the second most powerful military in the game, so I saw it as my civic duty to stop Ghandi. As soon as I took one of his cities half of the world declared war on me. Fighting on both sides, I barely made it out of that mess, and soon there was no one to stand up to Ghandi.

Within turns Ghandi plowed through our capitals and won the game. This was sixteen hours after I started. Two lessons can be learned from this:
1. Don't get this game if you have and want to continue your social life
2. If Ghandi is in your game, just concede defeat now and prepare for a life as a slave

Overall I give it a Ghandi/10. Don't know what that means? It's up to your interpretation, I don't really care anymore. Now that I have this game.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Old-school pixel art graphics
[*]Cute and at the same time creepy design
[*]Atmospheric music
[*]Good sound design
[*]Easy controls
[*]Infinite replay value
[*]Lots to unlock which creates a feeling of progression
[*]Many diverse gamemodes, floors, rooms, enemies, bosses and items
[*]Mod support (With the second DLC the mod support is even better)
[*]Challenging achievements
[*]Local multiplayer
[*]Ok-Good DLCs
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Not an easy game to get into
[*]Sometimes bad luck can screw you over
[*]Sometimes you get too lucky and become way too overpowered (which can be fun though)
[*]The game doesn't tell you about the effects of items (it doesn't really tell you anything)
[*]Some of the achievements are based on luck moreso than skill
[*]Some room layouts are bad
[*]Certain unlocks are locked behind extremely difficult achievements
[/list]
