An excellent follow up to an already great game, Portal 2 takes everything you love about the first game and gives it an upgrade. Bigger story, bigger mechanics, and bigger replay value. Multiplayer is a fantastic addition and the ability to download custom maps from the workshop means you'll never run out of chambers to explore. Just don't spend money on cosmetics, they aren't worth anything. Non-tradable.

Many ongoing balancing issues (which tend to encourage toxicity), but a solid and fun game at its core with a very high skill cap.

Also Dwelf.

The game is good fun but still has its quirks.

The very weird carry limitations makes no sense you can only carry a small amount of each meat type. Like only 3 small meat max but can also carry 3 rabbits, 3 lizards some medium sized meat chunks and some fish all at once. You can't carry any cooked meat at all. The limitations on non food items were plenty enough that it didn't hinder.

The time flow rate feels off, food goes off way too fast and you can't travel or explore much without becoming hungry and thirsty.

Building is nice and easy but mainly only did so to create a save point and to mark cave entrances. Its annoying destroying structures doesn't give any resources back.

The map once finally found was rather useless as its blank and you get to fill it in as you go. In multiplayer it was very annoying for the map to reset to blank on death. I don't know why it couldn't of been drawn in the survival book you get at the beginning to save either looking up the location or chance upon finding the map.

 I wish there was a face mask as its always so blurry going underwater. The rebreather only gives you air and a light which comes in handy in the dark waters.

The animals are fun to chase after but there is an annoying de-spawn distance. I have seen many deer disappear that I have been chasing and shooting with arrows while having clear sight of them. Would also have been nice for large animals to give bones.

I enjoyed the crafting system but didn't like that every time I wanted to create multiple items I would have to put all ingredients individually together each time and remove the item just created. I did find adding many feathers to a weapon made it look funny.

The main story is rather vague with only some photo's, drawings, notes, tapes and videos that didn't give any hint at all what is going on with this weird area. Only until the very last area of the game does it make it more obvious.

This game is a must have for almost any kind of steam user. Though the fun is starting to die down after 800 hours, that is still saying a lot about how good the game is.

PROS:
-Extremely easy to run (It's running on an engine over 11 years old)
-Though the graphics are showing age, they are high standards if compared to a 7th generation console
-VERY active modding community keeps the game alive (I'll go into more detail on this later. Scroll down if you wish)
-Variety of fun and addicting gamemodes, which are still growing in numbers
-Player hosted servers (Which is a good thing when you have a lot of them)
-A good portion of the community is unserious and goofy, which can be very fun at times
-It allows you to pull some content from other Source games (Half Life series, CSS/CSGO, Portal, TF2, etc.)
-Playable on all the major computer operating systems
-Plenty of servers

CONS:
-Is one of those games that steam won't recognize as closed for a while
-Some of the community is pretty taint, and either hate younger players, or take things way too seriously
-Some bugs after updates, though they get patched within a week, usually
-Without Counter Strike: Source, you'll be missing a lot of content for popular communtiy maps, so you'll get a bright purple checkerboard instead, or an error sign

MODDING:
This is where the game really shines the brightest. The game's modding capabilities seem almost limitless, and with the Steam workshop you can get a mod with the click of your mouse and some download time. Making a map is simple, and familiar to anyone who has made maps for the Source or Goldsource engines. I haven't gotten any deeper in modding than maps, so I have no idea how hard it is to make those.

The biggest part of the modding has to be the gamemodes. Modders can make entire gamemodes from scratch. These include a lot of well known gamemodes (Due to YouTube popularity) such as Trouble in Terrorist Town (An addicting murder mystery game. Make sure you have Counter Strike: Source for this one, unless you choose to play MC themed maps,) prop hunt (You don't always need CSS for this one, but you'll want it,) DarkRP (It's taken seriously by many but when you get a group of unserious people it's a blast,) and many more gamemodes.

Oh, and there's also an easy to use Local Area Network (LAN) system, that works with any gamemode.

This is probably the best survival apocolypse games out there. This game basically entails you starting out with a butter knife, and collecting loot to better equip yourself. You have to manage your food and water so that you can survive. There is an XP system which allows you to level up your character and aquire perks to make your survival easier, or easier to hunt and kill the "zombie" in this game known as nether, or easier to hunt and kill other players. The main types of loot you'll find are sellable items, health recovery items, food/water, ammo, and guns or gun parts to craft your own weapon.

That is the main goal of the game, to survive and thrive. Now the thing that wards players off from these types of games is permadeath. I wasn't a fan of this game for the longest time until I noticed that they added something pretty neat. Along with your character level, there is an account level. This level will not be lost on death, and when it is leveled up, you will get perks that accumulate and are there everytime you play, even if you die. The perks can be very useful, like more cash everytime you spawn, more health, more carry weight, and I'm not very far in the levels yet. I really think this is a great feature, because even when I die I don't feel like I've wasted all those hours on that character just to get shot.

Just a few more features that I would like to add which I appreciate are taunts, from flipping off the world, to dancing on corpses. Character customizations, with different outfits and hats and masks (There's a Deadpool mask too) which all can be bought with real or ingame currency, and stay with you no matter how many times you die. A balanced loot system in which loot isn't impossible, and it isn't around every corner.

This game is updated more often and with more significant updates than any other Early Access game I've seen. If you're interested in this genre of game then I recommend you pick it up.

Honestly, even though this game is short, it's worth every cent.

A game good enough to throw your own cosplay parties around.  There really aren't enough superlatives.  We stream it to the big screen, serve roasted meats, fine cheese, party snacks, wine, and generally have a debaucherous vicarious adventure at Geralt's expense.  There are few games as captivating to audiences as well as for individual play.  After the easy playthrough in group movie-style speed play, I run back through the game in more challenging modes and find just as much enjoyment in completing every conceivable quest, race, brothel, gwent match, storyline choice, and ending I can find.

Short review format:
-Predetermined character RPG at its core, cinematic AAA title in its graphics and story play.
-Excellent story development at the expense of limited character customization (a well implemented, intentional choice by the developer).
-Graphics 10/10
-Sound 10/10
-Gameplay 9/10 (Balance in sword vs. signs is strongly magic biased, strong sword style is draconian, so most swordplay is fast style twirling through mobs, albeit a minor opinion.  )
-Story\Quests 10/10 (really wish there was a better way to highlight the gap between most current game's lackluster writing and the Witcher 3's order of magnitude of improvement in writing... out of scale here to be honest)

I need a button to double-recommend a game.  There are games that I like, and then there are games that I pathologically need other people to play.  I'm not worried whether you'll enjoy it: if you have a soul then you will.  If you don't enjoy it, then I've learned something dark about you.
Stardew Valley is amazing.  It is tremendous.  It fills me with glee and delight.  I have built spreadsheets to calculate maximum crop effeciency not because I need to (it's so easy to get in to you guys) but because I enjoy playing the game even when I am not playing the game.
The graphics are old-school but well done.  The music is lovely.  The characters are excellent and engaging.  The gameplay is FANTASTIC.  Every single part of this game is cleverly thought out, wonderfully done, and almost all of it by a single individual.  And he's still adding stuff to it!  THE GAME IS GREAT AND KEEPS GETTING BETTER.
Do you own it already?  You should probably buy a copy for a friend.  This game is a thing they need in their life.  Do you not have it yet?  Why not?  What's wrong with you?  Do you not like fun?  Do you not wish to feel joy?  Because if so, you are depressed, and may need professional help.  I recommend Stardew Valley for your professional help.  It may not take the place of a trained psychologist, but feeling good about your super-awesome virtual farm is a hell of a lot cheaper.

However, I recommend this game whenever it's on sale because chances are you can also get a pack or two on sale, which in total will equal to the original pricing of the game. I really enjoy how the game has changed in the past two years of playing, and I like that the team does work on aspects that need to be worked on (for the most part). If you have friends, this game is extremely fun to play with them! I enjoy the stories that the devs come up with for each killer/survivor - even if they are not an original character. Overall, highly recommend the game! But wait for a sale because it is MUCH more worth buying it then.

This is a 34 minutes gameplay review. I'm a huge fan of the first Insurgency game and tactical gameplay.

[h1]Sounds[/h1]
So, do you remember the really trash audio when it comes to footsteps and directions that the first Insurgency game had? Well, surprise! It's even worse in this sequel. Even if you are ALL alone in a little grass tile and completely still it'll still be making grass-footsteps noise which then take about 10 seconds to completely vanish. Heard an enemy coming from the right and now you are aiming there? Surprise! He's actually on your middle-left side and now you are dead! Ah just like the good ol' days! 
[i]I have a HyperX Cloud Revolver headset which works amazing in all other games where they have proper sound direction, not a case for this game[/i]

The guns and explosions and everything else have an amazing brand-new sound! So I guess it's a pro?

[h1] Performance [/h1]
Straight up shitty! You'll constantly see textures reloading/loading when you get to a new place fast, but it runs at 60fps with no problem, just the performance regarding texture loading really sucks.

[h1] Bugs [/h1]
This is a unreal engine game and as you can expect it's full of bugs, countless are the times I've seen someone running in T-Pose or getting sucked whilst in T-Pose into the ground (Remember it's only a 34 minutes gameplay, I imagine that once you reach 100 hours on this game you get a Quality Assurance diploma.

[h1] Community [/h1]
Still no one uses VOIP and 'member campers? Yeah, they are back!

I've now played about 20 hours of this game, and I would guess I am maybe 1/3 to 1/2 done with it (maybe not -- hard to say when trying to avoid spoilers).

Overall, there is a lot to like about this game. I've only encountered one (annoying) bug and that could have been fixed if the devs had just given us some more usable console commands to work with (sadly they don't seem ot have done that). But overall the game is extremely fun and engaging as well as challenging and is a top-notch survival game.

Pros
+ incredible graphics even on a mid-high laptop.
+ great sound
+ immersive gameplay
+ surprisnigly interesting story for a survival game
+ very user-friendly UI and game control system
+ realistic underwater physics and alien biology
+ open world

Cons
- waypoints are sometimes buggy (turned off, they sometimes still appear, and vice versa)
- if you get a vehicle stuck on an outrcop/land, it's done -- there's no way to get it off
- resource balance seems a bit off -- I have a glut of some and hardly any of others
- no 3rd person view, no way to zoom in/out w/camera 

Overall the pros far outweigh the cons which are mostly minor annoyances. It's  a great, well-banaced game and reasonably solid. Hours of fun await you if you buy this game. Well worth the asking price.

Umbrella Corps is easy to hate. There's so many little things to it, from the cringy writing, awful camera, lack of any story or context, rage inducing enemies and mechanics, and so many more little things that make this game a game you love to hate. It's so stupid and pointless, that I probably won't bother playing it again.

I never completed it because I got too fed up with it. It's a game I tried to force myself to finish so I can write this review with proper knowledge, but I couldn't bother. It's a bad game, bottom line.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Good customization of your character and weapons.[/b] You can customize nearly everything about your character, from your armor, to your weapon, to the camo of everything.
[*][b]Good graphics.[/b] They won't make you immediately vomit when you see them. They are rather decent graphics.
[/list]

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Horrible camera.[/b] The third person camera sucks. It's right behind your shoulder and the FOV is low, so 1/3 of the screen is your guy, while the rest is your view, but it's so zoomed in that it makes it super annoying to play. You can't see if anything is 2 feet to your left or right. It's so rage inducing.
[*][b]Bad optimization.[/b] Despite good graphics, the optimization sucks. You get lag spikes and stutters, even on the lowest settings. While it isn't as bad as Ark or GTA IV, it's not good either, and you will notice it in game.
[*][b]Rage-inducing enemies.[/b] There's special zombies that swallow an entire clip of headshots or multiple melee hits with your Brainer (scythe-like melee weapon) while they can two hit you. That doesn't mention all the other zombies, dogs, and crows (Yes, crows attack you in this game from above and they're hard to kill with the horrible camera) sprinting towards you and attacking you from all directions!
[*][b]Rage-inducing gameplay.[/b]That also doesn't mention the 5 foot circle you have to stand in for 10 seconds to complete the mission objective, and this circle is so easy to step out of because you're trying to back away from the horde of zombies coming at you, stopping the 10 second timer and wasting time. The Brainer also has a full damage attack, but this attack has a 2-3 second animation to kill one enemy, where enemies can hit you but you can't hit back, and you need to use this attack to kill the special zombies quickly! It's so frustrating!
[*][b]Repetitive singleplayer campaign.[/b] There's literally three kinds of missions in this game: collect DNA samples, stand in the 5 foot circle for 10 seconds 5 times, or collect briefcases laying around the maps. That's it, and the game will repeat the same concept over and over and over. You'll go crazy doing the same mission over and over again.
[*][b]Stupid writing.[/b] It's painfully cliche and unoriginal writing. It's like the guy who wrote everything for this game never wrote anything worthwhile before in his life.
[*][b]Claustrophobic maps.[/b] The maps, both single and multiplayer, are tiny maps with narrow corridors. Couple this with the horrible low FOV shoulder camera, and it's not an enjoyable experience.
[*][b]Dead community.[/b] Even from day one, there's not much of a multiplayer community playing this game. There's a recent influx of new players because the game is $1 on Humble Bundle right now, but that'll die out soon.
[/list]

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Overall, Umbrella Corps is a bad game. It's frustrating, annoying, and easily hateable. I'll be uninstalling this game after I finish this review to make space for more enjoyable games, and I'll likely never return.

Lots of people compare this game with Factorio (which I love), so I thought I'd give it a try.

It has an addictive aspect, because there is always "one more thing" to do, and I binged played it for 20 hours. But my overall impression is still bad.

The graphics are... well, like Prison Architect. Definitely not my favorite.

The difficulty is fine, but some errors punish you long after you do them. Mostly managing quantities (and you can't know what you are going to need until you have played). So it is easy to run out of food, since it takes a long time to grow. You can also run out of components, which are crucial for all mid-late game tech, which may force you to trade.

The game is... well, auto generated... it seems to me like it is always the same... ok, not an enraged rat but an enraged mufalo this time... whatever. Raiders, always raiders. Caravan. Meteorite. Capsule... again, and again, and again.

Sometimes it gets very boring, because everyone is sleeping, and you can't go faster than 3x the speed, so you should probably watch Netflix while you play. I don't think that's a good point for the game.


My main issue though, is that you keep on fighting with the game:

The characters have an AI, but they are dumb as luck, so you have to keep on micro-managing them, "The Sims" like. And sometimes they'll just do what you prioritized once, and go back to their stupid idea. This could be kind of ok if the UI was very simple and intuitive but:

The interface needs a complete rewrite. A few example : 
[list]
[*] If you want to restrict items to store in a zone, you have to select the zone, which shows a panel with nearly nothing, click a small button, which allows you to select the kinds of items, in a tree list organized by category. You can't search for the kind of item. So you spend 5 minutes trying to guess in which category it should be. For example, the plant "Ambrosia", is not in the plants (or something like that), but in the drug category.
[*] Asking to build items is... not complicated, but tedious too. So many clicks for something that should be easy considering how often you are going to do it.
[*] You can deconstruct placeable items, but not clothes and weapons, so you end up with a shit load of "storage" zones filled with useless clutter. Or understand that caravans are your trash and sell everything they will accept to them.
[*] Making caravans to trade... you would think an easy workflow like: select the destination, click go, select your people, their loot, et voila. NO. You have to click on your base. Then click a button "Caravan". Then choose people, and their items. You don't know yet how long it will take, but choose their food. Then click the "Accept" button. Which does nothing but tell you "You have to select a route". So click the "Select a route" button, select the destination... now you are back to the previous panel, so change your food, and click "Accept". And of course, "Accept" is on the left of "Select a route" button, so it's not even in a sensical order.
[*] Trading is non-optional. Some vital items (like components, or medecine), or either too slow to build, or just can't be created.
[*] There is a color code by faction on the world map, a more useful color code would be by friendliness, since you're going to be sending traders to friends, and attackers to ennemies. Using "green" to show ennemy camps is counter-intuitive.
[/list]

Basically, it violates every rule of User experience 101. The things that are going to be done frequently should be very easy to do. Icons should be used whenever possible to identify quickly (items for example, instead of text lists). Search is good to find something in long lists. Relevant info should be shown immediately (like what is required to build an item, what skill it uses, for example).

FPS. but with medieval weaponry. 

The game is tough to get in to. It isn't that the learning curve is steep, but the motions and tactics are way different than every FPS you have played. For the first several hours, you are probably going to hang back a little or rush out and get destroyed either way. Double-teaming or triple-teaming an enemy player is the best way to rack up some kills. I took time and played as an archer for the first several rounds, then made enough to get a rapier and some firebombs. 

After 13 hours so far, I like it a lot. Yes it is really hard, but has many fun moments that cause it to stand out among the FPS games on the market.

The negative reviews for this game are almost 100% wrong, the balance of the game is fine. The servers in the huge majority of the world are fine, progression is amazing, build variety is huge. Combat is fluid and the netcode behind all of this is nothing short of black magic. How many games have realtime sword clashing without cutting into a QTE?

A lot of the reviews cry about how there's no skill in this game, which is a wild assumption. Follow a skilled player around and they will dominate in every single server they go into. If there is no skill, how is that possible? What the people saying "There is no skill" mean, is that they want to control the lobby. In a 24v24/32v32 game, they want to be able to singlehandedly turn the tide. Sure, the best players can carry the weight of 5-6 men all on their own but that's still only 5-6. A team which is overall worse is going to suffer and probably lose, yeah. Every >team< game works this way.

I'm not above shaming, so here's an excerpt of the kind of review I'm trashing with my own commentary in brackets. This one is written by "Ser Matokovich".
______________________________________________________________________________________________

The Executioner's Sword: Hitbox is far too large ... Same issue as was in Chivalry, where players will turn their heads in another direction and the sword will tap your shoulder with the tip and instant kill you as he faces away from you. (PS this was never a sword used in combat anyway, the fact it is in this game is nonsensical)

-[Realism shouldn't be your target here, while we're at it should swords and slashing weapons do 0 damage to plate armor? Should bows deflect off of armor? No, ultra-realism isn't fun but hitting people with a lute sure is. Punching fully armored knights is fun too. Moving on from that, what you're referring to is called "Dragging" and is a mechanic the game's tutorial teaches you about. It's not a mechanic exclusive to the executioner's sword, every single weapon in the game can do it, including weapons with FAR larger hitboxes like spears, zweihanders, and halberds. What you are proposing is to remove a skill based mechanic from the game. No. Also this is the shortest greatsword in the game so if you have a range problem you must be living in a different universe than I am.]

The Maul: same as executioner's sword, but can be rapidly feignted to a far more comical level of abuse.

-[The maul is already weak in many ways, it's a gimmick weapon and you are falling for it by being so unable to adapt. It has a very, very short length of 60cm. It's the only weapon in the game with a 900ms recovery when you miss (Instead of 700ms), it has the slowest windup (725ms) which gives you over an entire full second to back away from the hit and counterattack. It's a VERY exploitable weapon.]

The Longbow: Consistent 2 shot kill on heavy armor, which WOULD be fine as longbows are the heaviest bow in game and cost many class points. However, Longbows only achieve killing power with its immense draw weight. In game, archers can draw longbows VERY quickly and hold their shots for VERY long periods of time, making the longbow extremely easy to abuse.

[Two headshots in a row is "Easy to abuse"? Ranged weapons are currently very "eh" for this exact reason, it's three shots if you miss one of those two headshots, four if you hit the legs too. At any point, all the enemy has to do is hide behind a wall for 5 seconds and heal, starting it all over again. You only get a small pool of ammo and I doubt you can consistently land headshots from a safe distance with how people wildly move about in this game. Arrows take 2.2s to reload which is indeed unrealistic but not by any major amount. Once again I don't understand how realism affects the game in any way, are you saying you want to cap out at 10-12 arrows per minute?]

Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself, drawing pictures, and playing with his toys, as his mom watched christian broadcasts on the television. 
Life was simple, and they were both happy. That was until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above; 
"Your son has become corrupted by sin! He needs to be saved!" 
"I will do my best to save him, my lord" his mother replied, Rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. 
Again, the voice called to her; "Isaac's soul is still corrupt! He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world, and confess his sins!" "I will follow your instructions lord, I have faith in thee" Isaac's mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room, away from the evils of the world. 
One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of god calling to her; "You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you" 
"Yes lord, anything" Isaac's mother begged. "To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice, your son Isaac will be this sacrifice. Go into his room, and end his life as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else" 
"Yes lord" she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. 
Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. 
Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trap door to the basement, hidden under his rug. 
Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down, into the unknown depths below. 
... 




Isaac was cornered. his mother, fueled with the desire to serve her god, was bearing down on Isaac. 
"I will do as I'm told, my lord. I love you above all else" Isaac's mother repeated to herself. 
This was the end of the line for Isaac, his mother was far too strong for him. 
But just as he accepted his fate, god intervened, sending an angel down from above to stop his mother's hand. 
And just like that, it was over.

I know I'm one of the few people right now that is going to write a positive review, but I wanted to get it out there since I think there are reasons you should play Atlas if you like games like Ark (or just like Ark).  However, there are a few caveats to having a good experience, and mine is written from the perspective of someone who runs a private cluster, so the issues on the official servers do not impact me or my review.

The initial biggest source of complaints was the release delay, and after spending time on the Atlas Discord channel when the release was supposed to happen last Friday I immediately decided to write off all of those complaints.  Yes, the devs delayed the game.  Yes, they didn't tell people until after they missed the deadline more than once.  What I don't get is the toxicity in the community on this - no one put down a single penny, yet they were already screaming bloody murder.  As noted, delays happen, and while annoying, I'm not going to knock the game because of this.  If anything I believe the devs deserve a break considering the absolutely disgusting comments I was reading over and over in Discord.  In the end it's a game.

The second complaint once the game went live was issues connecting to the official servers.  I have always played Ark on private servers, and once I found out Atlas would allow private servers, that was the chosen path for me and my friends.  I pre-ordered some servers, and I did log into the official servers while I waited for them to be provisioned.  The servers were admittedly a dumpster fire.  Rubber banding, connection issues, flying mobs, people, you name it.  That is definitely a negative and I know issues have continued, but my private cluster was up and running a day post release, and we've been running non-stop on that cluster for about a week now.  We have experienced bugs of various types, some inherent to the game that have subsequently been  patched over the past week, others related to managing a server that has almost no documentation and is changing under our feet regularly.  However, the servers have been up and stable, and our group has 20-40 hours of game time per person with few issues.

I also have to remind people that this is an Early Access game.  I don't understand why this is lost on people, but when you purchase an Early Access game you sign up for bugs, issues, and all kinds of other problems.  From Steam's documentation "Early Access is a place for games that are in a playable alpha or beta state, are worth the current value of the playable build, and that you plan to continue to develop for release."  I don't know how many of you have done alpha or beta testing before, but games in those stages can be very rough.  I firmly believe this game is somewhere between Alpha and Beta, with the game itself being Beta (mechanics, graphics, etc.) and the server/MMO aspect being more Alpha.  For those playing on official servers that can't access the game at all you should definitely be eligible for a refund and it is a negative of this game.  

The second part of the documentation is an important one, "... are worth the current value of the playable build."  As of this writing I have 48 hours in game, with probably 40 or so actually play.  That calculates to a cost $0.63 / hour for entertainment.  If you can point me at anything that can provide 40 hours of entertainment for 63 cents, let me know and I'm all over it.  Most large AAA games target 40-60 hours of content.  I think the community has seemingly forgot that from a cost perspective, video gaming is completely cheap.  At this point I would say I've absolutely gotten $25 of value out of my experience, and as I continue to play the game the value just increases.  If you have 40-50 hours of gametime and you're complaining about how horrible this game is, you should probably stop spending 40-50 hours doing things you hate.

With all that being said, I absolutely recommend Atlas if you can go the private server route.  When you run your own server it allows you to compensate for some of the bugs.  For example, I read many threads related to ghost ships spawning absolutely everywhere and destroying a brigantine within the first two minutes of its maiden voyage to then find out the devs nerf the spawn rate by 60% because it was a bit much.  Considering it takes probably 100+ total hours of work to build a brigantine on an official server, I can see that causing a lot of cursing.  

On a private server it's a different story because you can spawn the mats and quickly re-build that ship.  Is it cheating?  Technically yes, but the issue that caused you to lose the ship in the first place was a balancing / spawning issue that should've never happened.  I believe correctly that with a few admin commands gets you back to an state where the game is enjoyable, and you can move on with trying out other aspects of the game instead of farming 24/7.

So again, Atlas is definitely rough.  If you are trying to play on official servers I would not recommend this game.  However, if you're willing to spend $13/month for a private server, it's absolutely worth it and can be a ton of fun, especially once you get into the later content.  And yes, there are dragons :)

A fantastic strategy game that will suck you in for hours. It certainly has a steep learning curve, but the in game tutorials are overall pretty decent. Once everything starts to click, you'll never want to stop playing!

Recommend the game to every RPG lover. This game is the pure definition of quality content. As everything else it's not perfect (it has some flaws here and there), but I'm not going to mention them because if you don't know about it you won't find it.

The quests are well structured, no secondary quest is boring. The story too is well done. One important thing to mention is that everything is related to everything in the story, so no plot holes, no missing stuff. If something happened multiple NPCs know about it and this adds to the feeling and atmosphere of the game.

Combat is good, flexible and complex, challenging, but not too hard. Even on harder settings the game is fun and enjoyable.

This game is far the best game in the franchise, but I picked it up after playing with the prequels, and I can say for sure it has a place in the Witcher universe. If you love this game I recommend picking up the first ones too.

A note about the "DLC"s, if you can call them like that. They feel like a separate game, just like in the old days a good expansion was like another game but in the same game (even the devs call them expansion packs not DLCs). I recommend buying the GOTY edition because the Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine will give you a whole new game with new experiences, new story and a good f**ng game. Honestly.

In overall I give it a 7 out of 5.

This is a really great game with only a few annoyances.

First the best parts: Great graphics, amazing combat, like [b]really amazing combat, the best in any ARPG[/b]. A pretty original story. Immersive environment.

This game is great, but it has one annoyance which is enemy placement in a certain few levels. The game is HARD. And I think in an attempt to ramp up difficulty in later stages, the game goes from being genuinely hard, where your skill determines if you win/lose, the game makes the decision to become cheap. It goes down the dark souls/demon souls path of basically laying out traps for your, like no way you can get through no matter how well you can parry/fight when so many ambushes await you. I can understand they want to make the game harder, but I don't think that's a good way to do it. I found it frustrating. It slowed down the action cause I'd have to figure out a way to not get ambushed or something else.

However, most of the game is great. There are some enemies which will force you to really master your combat to proceed. Combat is the best part of this game. Especially the boss battles. It's intense and thrilling, you feel great when you parry and counter, its so tight and rewarding.

I really wish this game was just boss battles cause those are the best. Just 1 on 1 combat that's really intense. Like Shadow of the Colossus style. That would cut out all the stuff in the middle which is not bad, but pales in comparison to the intensity and fun of the boss battles. There's a few bosses in the game I could just go fight for fun over and over.

Are you the kind of person that theorycrafts your world of warcraft character?  Do you create spreadsheets to help determine the optimal way of executing a task?  Do you find it fun picking apart mechanics of a game to optimize your playthroughs?  If any of these apply, you'll enjoy Factorio... If they only kind of applied, you'll also love Factorio.

Factorio is an incredibly well done, niche game that is quite possibly one of the most well done titles I've come across for a multitude of reasons.

On the surface, Factorio is a game about automation, logistics, and optimization.  It doesn't sound like it should be fun at all.  But when you get into the game itself, it ends up being more like a puzzle game, where you're trying to determine the best ways of maximizing yields from your machines.

It's easy to get complacient your first time playing the game through... Sure... One science facility is sufficient to unlock everything... you don't NEED more... but by the end, you'll be in a position where, why not build another couple hundred... a couple thousand.  Why?  Why not?  Each play through, you're astronomically faster at knowing the ideal logistics, you have the foresight for knowing problems that you've run into in the past to plan for the future, and you're more familiar with the game interface/hotkeys/etc to be able to execute your actions in a more timely fashion.

This game is also amazingly optimized as well on the actual programming side.  Multiplayer servers (still in beta), have been recorded, and videos are available to display the server supporting over 150 concurrent users with no lag.  Furthermore, the developers are incredibly engaged, and constantly trying to further develop the game.

It's weird to think of a game built around logistics, automation, factories, etc, would be so entertaining, and maybe that speaks more to me as a person than the game itself, but I recommend watching a video or two, and if it looks even marginally interesting, grabbing the game and giving it a shot.

Truly amazing game, this is one of the best things rpg sandbox genre has to offer. The atmosphere, the soundtrack and, most importantly, the gameplay are just perfect. This is like a dream came true kind of game to me. I love this game a lot, but it has it's numerous issues.

The game is riddled with countless bugs, to the point it significantly affects your playstyle. The visuals leave much to be desired: every character, despite their apparent age looks like some tired drug addict, legendary blades look like pieces of cheap plastic. As for performance... it's horrible to put it mildly. The modding community has their hands tied with that limited toolset (FCS + in-game editor) they were provided with. With pretty much everything hardcoded, there isn't much they can do.

I can recommend this game to anyone who can turn a blind eye on the issues  that I described above. I believe the players  who value gameplay above everything else, will find it exceptional, just as I did. 

PS. Despite my stats in Steam I've spent at least 1 000 hours in this game.

As everyone  has already noted, this game is Left4Dead: Melee edition, but adds a lot more. Game was amazing at launch, but had a bit of a stumble with their Winds of Magic expansion. However, instead of sticking their heads in the sand, they actually pushed some other content back to fix some of the issues/balance problems. The game is also kind enough to allow the host to be the only one that needs to buy the DLC maps for the whole group to play. You do need to get the DLC for their corresponding weapons though (worth it for Back to Ubersreik, but wait for a sale for WoM(which at the time of writing is on sale!)). Hopefully their versus mode gets off the ground at some point to further increase the lifespan of the game and maybe get some new blood. If they ever add a map editor for modders then the game will probably have an even longer future ahead of it.

TL:DR 
Game good, buy game, buy DLC (wait for WoM dlc to go on sale)

Como um grande fã de jogos de cartas eu EVITO jogos de cartas pois sei que é um loop mecânico envolvendo probabilidade, sorte, sinergia e estratégias no qual eu consigo ficar horas preso. Slay the Spire faz tudo o quê eu conheço até então parecer simples como uma partida de jogo de memória e mesmo em partidas em que acabo perdendo sinto que aprendi algo e fico saciado. Não gosto quando tecem críticas a outras obras para valorizar e enaltecer a comparação, mas Slay the Spire é um jogo que qualquer fã de game design em geral deveria tentar, suas influências já reverberam em vários jogos recentes e poder jogar essa versão estável, pós Early-Access e meses após o lançamento (18 na data em que escrevo este texto) é como achar a melhor versão possível de uma obra-prima.

Recomendo para quem se interessa por: card game/deck building, balanceamento, roguelike, game design.

The great german empire settles berlin in 4000 BC. They soon build stonehenge and found protestantism. They settle down some cities in modern day denmark,poland, and latvia. Then russia founds East Orthodox in moscow. The russians convert the city of hamburg, and take the porelian tower. This starts the War of German Agression, which takes the cities of Moscow, St. Petersburg, and Yaroslarv'l. Then Franco-German War is started over a territorial dispute over the city of Orleans. After the cities of Troyes, and Orleans are taken, the French surrender. The Germans choose Order as their ideology, and After england denounced Bismark the Great and Powerful, The Germans amass a force of infantry, and rocket artilery, the British Surrender in 1860. The Second War of British Agression happens, and the British get wiped out in 1945. Then the War of Spanish-German Agression wipes out all spanish traces in Europe, but results in an embargo against Germany. The Germans fall into a depression, and military size decreases. But with a increase in great artists, writers, and musicans, german culture is accepted around the world, and is respected by many

Yes the game came out today, yes I understand there will be some flaws only just being relaesed, but that is why I am here, to hopefully get the attention of the developers or whoever it is that does stuff to this game and can change it up a bit. my complaints(im writing this the day the game came out so if you are reading this as judgement of the game then don't)

 -Districts take a mighty long time to build and once you build them they are clompletely useless( unless your embassies in city states boost the district) till you take another long time to create a building for that district
     
 -Spains Character, like the actual model himself has some minor graphical flaws like an arm and his hand

-Some Ai are just plain ridiculious, for example, i'm later in the game and a while back the Arabs had built a city right underneath my capital. I upgrade one spearman to a pikeman and they freak over the fact that im too powerful and have cities too close to them. Confusing to me.

-More about the Ai, they all love to hate you, all of them. I understand if they dont like you because of different government styles but is that really enough to denounce you over? Or even go to war? Im not sure, maybe it is.

-Also in the tech tree, it is very easy to skip ahead. It's obvious to me while researching things in the tech tree but mainly obvious with the Ai. I'm in the Medieval Era, the Aztecs some how reach the Industrial. Either I suck at the game and the Aztecs are legends or they just skipped ahead greatly. Plus I checked the worldrankings and for science victory i was number 1. Don't quite get that seeing how the Aztecs were in the Industrial Era.

-Another thing about the tech tree are the littler boosters, same goes for the Civil tree. The boosters were a pretty cool idea but kinda force you to play  the game in ways you may not want to. Such as building a military when none is needed and other things like that.. Plus it makes it way easier for some countries to get way ahead in technologies. One last thing about the boosters, they kinda ruin the creativity, i think i kinda said this already but it basically forces you to do things you dont want and thats not really fun.


Now im not sure how useful this review will be, if anything will change, if this'll get seen, but It is out there now to the public so I can feel like i've contributed to the game a little bit now. Of course none of these problems are going to prevent me from playing the game, but i would love it if some of them got changed or modified some way.

I absolutely can't get enough of this game.

Stardew Valley encapsulates everything right with Harvest Moon and takes it up a notch. While the fundamentals are really similar to Harvest Moon/Animal Crossing, there are quite a few overhauls as well as subtle nuances that make Stardew Valley feel more complete in a sense. 

There's a ridiculous amount of depth even in the seemingly basic framework of what the game is focused on.  The game's visuals, whilst catering to the retro style of its predecessors, will still drop your jaw. Just as you're taking time to appreciate that, the game's soundtrack comes and blows you away while still staying very cohesive with how the game's art style feels. 

Mechanically, the game is quite intuitive to play and functions quite well. You're plopped into the setting and expected to find your own way. There's enough instruction to help you get started immediately, but the game is designed so that you're supposed to learn the in and outs as you go through experience. A refreshing taste compared to the overencompassing handholding that comes with many games as of late. 

The one gripe I have is regarding how the combat is fleshed out since you can only look in the 4 cardinal directions and it's sometimes difficult to land hits on mobs coming at you from an angle.

All in all, Stardew Valley feels like a very refined, appealing, and morbidly addicting game (I've literally eaten,slept,and Stardew-Valley-ed the last 2 days) that lives up to the hype and surmounts any negative assertions that it's just a boring rework or farmville on Steam. The epitome of what a farmlife RPG should be, Stardew Valley is surely a game you'll want to have in your library!

I remember playing this game on the PS2 and PC as a kid. Those headcrab zombies scared me, and I felt sorry for the scientists in the elevator who fell to their deaths. I used cheat codes because I sucked at it.

This game was apparently legendary or something. Changed the state of FPSes, I heard. Very atmospheric... in the 90s.

It has not aged well. The textures and level design are very primitive and bare, and its platforming sections have fallen out of favor. The zombies are now just crowbar targets to me, and I've become apathetic towards the scientists and their cheesy deaths.


But I finished it. Legitimately.


It felt good.


I wanted more. 

And that is why I waited for Half-Life 2.

And that is why I'm waiting for Half-Life 3.

Many of the negative reviews have false information.  It seems those people have not actually played the game.

It is a fun game.  It's a solid mix of Dawn of War 1 (2004), Warcraft 3 (2002) Dawn of War 2 (2009), Starcraft 2 (2010). with the "powercore" of a certain Warcraft3 mod.

One of the FEW large scale, high quality RTS games that let you customize your army before a match... You know... AN ACTUAL STRATEGY!  What you do on the battlefield with it are your tactics.

This game will only get better, everyone forgets how much a game changes within a couple months when the patches come out. 

(BTW to all the negative reviews about stripped down features, Dawn of War1 and Dawn of War2 had less to start AND gain most of their modern functionality with expansions)  

Campaign was a well spent 15 hours on Hard.  It has some replayability if you use different Elites or Doctrines during a mission.  Elites gain a ton of Experience from Campaign mode and the player can earn a large amount of skulls, which you use to unlock more Elites for all 3 armies.

Very fun multiplayer RTS/Enjoyable Campaign.

In short, an excellent successor to CK2 with plenty to enjoy already.  My fears that CK3 would feel empty compared to its full-DLC predecessor were - thankfully - unfounded.  As others have said, many DLC-features of CK2 have been incorporated into the CK3 base game, and you can already have a rich gaming experience with the game as is.

That said, the two DLC/Expansions I've been looking forward to the most were/are the ability to play as Republics, and the Ruler Designer.  The latter having just dropped - and for free, no less, which was a smart move by Paradox - I'm very satisfied by how it improves upon the CK2 Ruler Designer in a number of ways.  My minor-ish quibble with the Ruler Designer in it's current state is that you don't seem to be able to manually edit your Dynasty (or primary holding) coat of arms, and have to rely on random CoA generation to get what you want.  (Though, upside is apparently that's a feature that will eventually come, but wasn't ready yet.  Hopefully it will be added in-game as well, so you can edit your titles' CoAs as desired.)  That aside, I'm very satisfied with the quality and smoothness of the new Ruler Designer, and am eagerly awaiting the ability to manually make custom CoA's in the future.  *fingers crossed*

Anyways, if you were/are unsure whether CK3 is worth buying in its current state, only you can make that final call (especially if you have a niche playstyle or love a certain mod that isn't recreated in CK3 yet), but I think there's a lot to enjoy already, and will likely only get better and better with time.

A lighthearted romp through heaven and hell as a good boy gone bad must retrieve all the McDonalds Happy Meal toys from the evil Chads. Watch as he rips and tears through every burger to get those prizes.

I put off playing this for so long - I play a few MMORPGs and didn't really think I had the time to put into it. Then the Steam sale came along and I picked it up anyway (STEAM SALE!! WOOOO!)

Anyway - I'm so glad I took the plunge, I've barely dipped my toe in it and already I'm captivated by it. It really encourages you to learn about the world (where to find certain plants to make into oils, what oils work best against which monsters etc). You rarely see a game that makes you learn the same stuff that the character actually learns.

It all adds up to a world that feels so incredibly alive - victory can be hard fought, but with every victory you really feel like you've done more than button mash/thrown yourself against a wall until you get lucky. 

A smart Witcher lives a long time, a smarter Witcher when to run away ;)

I love it, no doubt. I can't stress that enough because here comes some critisism. 
There's not a lot of songs yet and some of them are kind of samey. Also, the stab blocks are kind of annoying to me. It just doesn't feel as good to stab as a nice slash. Also, it would be nice if there were some different "arena's" or styles of visual you could pick to mix it up.
That said, I like the haptic feedback when the blades touch, and letting my blades slide along the big dodge blocks is fun. 
Hitting a long quick string of slashes without missing feels amazing.
I definitely recomend the game if you like rhythm games at all. It was very much worth the money, and I'm sure most of my critisisms will be addressed as the game continues to develop.

Edit: Most of my critisisms have been addressed. The stab blocks are no more, replaced with "Slash any direction" blocks. The visuals still aren't as varied as I'd like, but there are a few more now. And the 360° levels are really neat.

I've had this game since MAY 2014 - I have enjoyed it everytime I play it. If your into sandbox/openworld/RPG this game should be in your library or on your wish list. Tons of hours worth of gameplay for a game in Alpha.

THE GAME ITSELF: I prefer to start off on hardest mode - with nothing. Start off scrounging for goods off dead bandits after leading them towards guards to kill them fo me. Slowly gathering resources, buildings, hiring teammates, occasionally getting my a$* kicked by dogs or other enemies (quicksave is very useful here) - but the build up and effort delivers reward. 
HOWEVER - the game seriously is in need of some kind of storyline. I like to play towards an end goal, and at presen I am somewhat lacking this.

Development of the game e.g. new enemies, AI, buildings are steadily released along with bug fixes so developers are always active. If you need proof of the work being done just check out recent updates part of page.

Overall its a very good game to play through its development. Definitely worth the money in my opinion.

Ok, so this is my first ever review.

First off, let me say that I am a huge fan of FS series to date.  Particularly FS 17.

But on reflection I now realise that FS17 was great because it created a platform for modders to really up their game.
Now that I'm playing FS19 without mods, I've come to realise that the game is only good with mods. For me anyway.
For me, I like the dynamic of using Courseplay to effectively manage the farm as oppposed to just drive tractors etc.

Why doesnt Giants take ANY advice from its fans? We have been saying for years to add some kind of courseplay replica
to really enhance gameplay. We have also been asking for better ground working physics, more realism. One of the only games I have seen do this is Agriculture Simulator...yes it was an absolute shambolic mess from the get go, but they had the two things FS is missing. A management function AND better ground dynamics.


So heres a few pros and cons:

Pros
-The machinery looks really good. Particularly on High settings.
-There is a real "weight" to driving the bigger machines. This is helped by the new steering system too.
-Finally added John Deere. 
-Really interesting "contracting" model.

Cons
-The gameplay reminds me of the original FS. The monotony of drawing my own grain etc is creeping in.
-The maps are dogshit. Unimaginative. Badly planned. Again, reminds me of a bygone era of FS.
-There is NO useful infrastructure that you can buy. Couple of sheds and a vehicle workshop.
-4/10 times, my games crashes
-Ground dynamics are literally the exact same as FS17.
-Fuck all new machinery.
-WAAAYYY TOOOO DAAYYUMM EXPENSIVE YOOO

My verdict:

This game had real potential. The build up to release alone had me really pumped to get it. But its just a re-skinned version of FS17. I for one, will be going back to FS 17 until the very talented modders out there make this game great.

What did we learn

• Quake Arena: Doom Edition
• Super Mario Brother vs Heck now with more jumping
• Didn't like it at first
• Do like it now that I gave it some more time to grow on me
The loading time is too slow. The time between turns is too slow.  That being said,  You can't help but really like this game, I just wish that it worked better or my computer worked better.

Well... I picked this game up for about 8 bucks. I still feel slightly ripped off for a couple reasons. A VAST majority of the issues are more or less quality of life problems honestly. I still feel the game is worth it on SALE but just want everyone to be aware of the issues.

I'll get the good stuff out of the way first.

Pros
+Game looks gorgeous
+Music is on point
+Sound design is amazing
+Immersion is real
+Story mode has a lot of humorous cutscenes, even though you want to skip them...
+A LOT of options for raising/lowering difficulty and options for game modes

Cons (Basically a list of four gripes that are common in either 2k games or just common amongst everyone who owns it)

First thing is that you can't skip any cut scene which makes the single player career mode a slog. Even just creating a new character with a new build is excruitiatingly painful because you have to watch roughly 20 minutes of cutscenese and are forced to skip out of at least 5 or 6 matches before you're actually playing in the NBA and even then your guy only gets roughly 2 minutes of playtime for like 4 or 5 games after. This mimics what might actually happen in real life with an undrafted rookie but seriously this is a video game. We can do without.

Second issue is the player progression. I've put in about 14 hours into the game in which at least 1/3 of that was cutscenes either watching people interact or watching my character do painfully slow transitions between locker room and court and halftime and time outs etc. So my ACTUAL playtime is probably more like 8 hours. You start out at level 60 and your guy is dog-shit. You won't make any impact on the game whatsoever be it park play or single player until you start jacking that up. Plus you don't have access to any cosmetics or augmentations at all until at least 65 and the ones that make the most impact are locked until post 70+. In order to unlock that level in a meaningful amount of time you need to grind out the in game currency (VC) or pay money for it. Granted, if you bought this on sale then buying a pack of VC for 10 bucks to get you to like 70 or 75 isn't too painful but it's those people who bought this for full price that I feel for. That's just shady and greedy behavior from a triple A title. However without the VC you will be suffering even on rookie difficulty for a while as you struggle to make 3's, dribble past a blocker, run around the court and even just passing the ball around is slow and difficult.

Third issue is the crashing. This happens at least once every time I load the game. I'm not sure what causes it but sometimes during a cutscene the game could just kick right out to desktop and die. It's not gamebreaking for me and I can deal with it but for other folks in the review section its worse. I'm not sure if it's related to a driver or gpu type or a OS issue but just make sure you read a little before you make the purchase.

Fourth issue is the fact that eventually, at some point in time, this game will lock you out of a lot of the features. This happens in every 2k game. Eventually the servers will be shut off and your stuff will be locked out and the only function you'll have is quick play. If you pay full price for this game this late in its life (currently 7/3/2018)  with 2k19 right around the corner you might have a year of time to get some of your single player stuff or custom stuff done before the servers go down for good on it. So ONLY get this on sale right now.

Everything from being just a handful of very highly trained ninjas to a big warband of mercenaries, or perhaps you want to be a merchant, set up shop inside a city ? or build your very own city and bring trade to you!

I have 140 hours on record all played with the same savegame and i consider myself having reached 'end game' if that term even applies to a game such as this :P and what I will say is there are end game features missing, such as proper diplomacy, ways of making your own actual faction/kingdom, waging war + the fact that only half the map is playable. Dead by Daylight or 'DbD' as it is often reffered to by the playerbase is equal parts excellent and total piece of shit at the same time.

Though after playing it for more than 150 hours i'm confident enough that it's 49% excellent and 51% shit so that's where  negative review comes from.

While it has just a superb idea for the game , developers are absolutely incompetent to take care of their own game. By solving one balance issue they make two more, by fixing one bug they make two new ones . In short they are ' fixing and balancing' this game to point of no return ( which in my opinion has already been reached ) .

Amazing ideas are well..amazing but they also need skilled team behind them to realise and maintain them. It's not the case with DbD and they just keep on pilling problems on top of one another .

Only way i see for this game to be any good is to rethink this game alltogether ( mechanics wise  ) and begin new with second installment because at the current state this game is hopeless to get any better.

To The Moon is a wonderful feel good indie that will put a smile on your face when it's all said and done. The story is extremely gripping and will almost force you to continue playing throughout the entire game. Luckily for the busy gamer, the game can be completed within a couple hours, so it can easily be played anytime. The simple graphics work and are absolutely fitting for this type of game that showcases an amazing soundtrack and an even more amazing narrative.

Biggest cons: I experienced a game breaking glitch that wouldn't allow me to move at a certain part of the game. I evetually found a way to bypass this by downloading someone else's save file from a forum and using it to play from the start of that particular level. Also, mouse controls aren't as responsive as they could be, sometimes you feel like your gliding on ice; but you do have the option of using the keyboard arrows in place of the mouse.

All in all, To The Moon does have its share of flaws, but because the soundtrack and storyline are so superbly crafted and performed in the game, its easy to look over. Highly Recommended. 8/10

It's 2020. Is there anything I can write that will add value to the plethora of good reviews for this iconic game? We are in the middle of a pandemic - COVID 19 - and with the release of the new Half Life Alyx, I figured I should see (after all these years) what's up with the hubbab and hype regarding the Half Life universe. This first installment in the series was excellent. Of course it's outdated, I realize that, but playing it brought me some nostalgia of similar games from its time. The story of this first game was bland, but the gameplay was fun and fairly challenging at times if you're typically a casual gamer like I am. For someone whos Terrified of the Open Ocean and the Dark Depths... This game is amazing.

If you like survival-crafting games, something totally unique and new and not done before by video games, with a little bit of mystery and terror mixed in, this might be your game.

For starter, its beautiful, the world itself will instantly draw you right in.
The pacing is perfect. Never do you truely feel rushed, or that you've had to grind very hard. Sure its a Survival Crafting game, but resources are easily found and well spent, and progression is simple... travel farther, travel deeper. You'll be at the edge of your seat exploring the deep, dark, and frightening depths, while trying not to get eaten by one of the leviathans that dwell in the dark. Uncover the mystery of planet 4546B, and finish the job your precursors started.

The game starts off with the Aurora, a megacorp builder ship flying near orbit of plant 4546B, a mysterious and nearly oceananic world. The spacecraft has been struck by something and is crashing down to the surface. You scramble to get to your lifepod and safely make it down to the surface. From here you need to utilize the planets natural resources to survive, and try to establish contact for other survivors and rescue.
As you explore further, you discover you've become infected with a bacteria that appears to be in every lifeform on the planet. Quickly you begin to discover that curing yourself of this bateria, and escaping the planets surface are the same objective. Humans werent the first intelligent lifeform on this planet.

If you're wondering whether or not you should shell out for the cost of this game, especially when it is still in development, the answer is a resounding YES!

Having scrolled through some of the previous reviews about the game, I've heard some mixed things. I was also on the fence about whether or not I would pay for an unfinished game, but I love Firefly and The Sims -- needless to say, I couldn't resist.

While some can be put off by the game's low-res graphics or the somewhat confusing interface and controls, this game will present you with a dynamic and utterly surprising story-telling.

While recent updates have forced me to rebuild a couple of times, the gameplay is so addictive that I honestly don't care.

There is a bit of a learning curve to this game and you'll likely need to watch a YouTube video or two, but once you get going, you'll quickly realize what's behind the price of the game. 

Of course, I can't speak to the tastes of every individual, but I've been a fan of PC strategy games since 1988. This one surprised even me. Maybe you'll be surprised too.

First game, I decided to accept the default colonists without thinking to reroll.

Sergey: Great melee, shooting skills, and dementia.
Jennifer: A love of all-things-animal and absolutely useless at everything else.
Fox: Decent all-round skills, constant state of crippling depression.

The third day is when it all went wrong... 

Jennifer, smitten by a wild fox on the other side of the map, was attacked by a mad tortoise. She later died from tortoise-related injuries.

Sergey, in one of his dementia-infused wanders, ran straight into a group of raiders preparing for attack. He was brutally clubbed around the head until collapse.

Fox, driven mad by the loss of his friends and his habit of constantly mining, went berserk and tried to kill friendly visitors to the colony. He fell under a hail of arrows and was left to bleed out in the kitchen.

10/10 - Most eventful week in any video game on record.

Then, not a turn later, surprise nuclear war by Gandhi. Brazil dies first, before Napoleon flips the switch and fires his nukes at India, and vice versa.

Civilization V, kids. Gandhi is never to be trusted, [i]ever.[/i]

I've played 2 rounds of civ 5 on the one above easiest diffiuclty. I've only managed to put in 36 hours in. Great game, immersive and feels great. Much more to do in the future. I understand how people dump 1000s of hours.

Overall Score: 8/10

tl;dr: An experience that you won't be able to forget easily. Although it has some of the best artistic decisions ever taken, and some brand new ideas, its gameplay always drag around and annoy the player. While THAT is the basic premise of the game, it heavily wounds the storytelling and makes the experience less enjoyable. If you manage to get used to its abysmal controls and gameplay mechanics, you will at least enjoy the story and the scenery.

Death Stranding is... something else. It is the ultimate love/hate experience for me. I can easily say that i disliked a big portion of this game: Gameplay. But no matter what annoying thing the game had thrown at me, i managed to beat it and i'm grateful that i did. I played on Normal and thank god for that. 

What i absolutely enjoyed, is the cinematography of this game. Even when you're not in a cutscene and just... simply walking on vast cliffs and listening to "Don't Be So Serious by Low Roar", game never fails to make you feel that you're in a movie. Camera angles, the overall atmosphere, feeling of solidarity and the little semi-online elements that sometimes make you feel like you're not actually alone and can feel safe here and there.

The another thing i very much liked was the semi-online system implemented into the game. Developers tried this system in a few other games as well but this is the first time i'm seeing this used in an actually good manner. Although it is a single player game, thanks to it's community shaped open world it almost feels like a multiplayer game. Player feels that s/he is a part of a big broad community. This is something very hard for a single player game to accomplish. Kudos to the Kojima Productions team especially on this.

Decima Engine is an absolute miracle. Whenever i've had a PS4 and i played Horizon: Zero Dawn (which will be out on PC soon, yay), i knew how unbelievably great this engine is. Guerilla Games did such a tremendously good job while creating this engine and it really shines on PC at 1440p, ultra details. Scenery feels almost photorealistic. Character models, mimics, animations, everything is visually flawless. And it never pushed my system around. Gave constant 60 frames per second on a system with GTX 1070, i5 6600, 16 gigs of ram and while its on an SSD.

So let's get down to the dirty business and talk about what i didn't like about this game and what made me give it an 8 instead of a perfect 10. Because this game could've had a perfect 10 easily. Gameplay is so, so bad. Like, abysmal bad. Terrible. I know that they tried to go with a more "realistic" approach while designing the gameplay elements but instead of feeling realistic, it felt annoying. Vehicle controls were so annoying, i had to walk for a good part of the game. I can't get myself to drive around easily without crashing on to a small rock every 10 seconds. And it is a small rock, really. A rock that you righftully expect your 4X4 land cruiser to absolutely go over. But it doesn't happen. It's like, the vehicles in this game have magnets attached to them. Magnets that pull your vehicle to rocks and all kinds of obstacles around. I never enjoyed travelling around in this game.

The first 10 or so hours were great. There were no artificial difficulty enhancers. Mules were as dumb as my character, BTs were easy to avoid and were very thrilling-fun at first. But after around 5 or 6 episodes it started getting annoying. Now i knew how to bypass BTs. I knew how to beat them. They were not thrilling anymore. They were just another CHORE i had to deal with. See, when a gameplay mechanic feels like a chore, that's in my opinion, a failure. They could've added some variety at least to the BT encounters just as they did to MULES. They get new weapons and new strategies as the game develops further. But BTs always stay the same. Except maybe towards the end chapters. 

Combat wasn't as good, gunplay wasn't as good, the GAME aspect of this experience just wasn't as good. It is not a walking simulator, no. Do not believe the angry mob that mockingly calls this game a WALKING SIMULATOR. It is not. Although it is terrible, it still has a good chunk of gameplay in it. You constantly micro manage your strategies, your workload, your deliveries, equipment, route, etc. Gameplay is there, really. It's just not as thrilling when you hit the 20 hours mark. It gets old and boring.

The times i most enjoyed this game were the cutscenes and straight-forward story bits. No packages to deliver, no chores to accomplish, no backtracking, just you and the story carrying along together. I wish there were more of these moments in the game. Because the amount of "standard deliveries" is huge and if you try to complete all of them like i did in the first few episodes, you will get a burnout and will rush to end the story. Even the mandatory orders felt like chores. I remember yelling at the game a few times just because it didn't let me progress through the story which i'm very curious about and made me do another mandatory chore. I get the idea behind it but... it is a game after all. It has to be fun.

So yeah. I liked Death Stranding. It was not a pleasant journey sometimes. But overall, it was a great package. Solid story, great cast of characters, absolutely beautiful visuals, great cinematography, mind blowingly flawless sound design, some of the best licensed songs, great optimization and just plain bad gameplay. 

Note: Just as a suggestion, wait until Episode 4 to start with the standard deliveries if you're into completionist stuff.

Great concept and overall great execution!

BUT two issues made me request a refund:
* Playing as killer is way too easy, makes it extremely unforgiving to play as survivor and not very entertaining to play as killer.
* Can't play with friends against/with others online. There's an apparent risk of exploitation in allowing that form of matchmaking the way the character progression is designed right now, but come on devs - there's plenty of ways to design around this issue! For instance:

1. Encourage people to play with strangers by increasing a score multiplier for every stranger in the lobby.
2. Make a separate score for character progression in private matches.
3. Trust your players to play the game the way it's meant to be played, and let sploiters sploit if they must.

Will buy this game again when/if the above is balanced and fixed!

Please Note: I have played nearly 100 hours of Civ III-Civ V, and are going to be comparing these a lot

If you're familiar with the Civilization series, then you're already well aware that they've traditionally been turn-based strategy games that let you play as the political leader of one of the world's nations (such as Gandhi of India or Julius Caesar of Rome) in a fictitious bid to take over the globe, starting from the Stone Age and continuing right on through to the Space Age by having a lone settler unit build your first city on the way to establishing whatever advanced society you choose to design over the course of dozens of turns. The series gives you plenty of ways to do this, such as conquering your neighbors, researching advanced technology, or, in Civilization III (and IV), creating the most cultured society on the planet. It's this great variety that helps give Civ IV the same alarmingly addictive quality its predecessors carried. And thanks to its many improvements, major and minor, and its greater emphasis on strategy over bean-counting, Civ IV isn't just as good as Civ has ever been...it's better.The Civ series' gameplay has several components, and almost every single one of them is improved in Civ IV. For instance, the series' combat system, which pits different military units against one another based on relative unit strength and technology, has been changed to a "strength" system that seems more intuitive. Units that are greatly advanced will have a clear advantage over more-primitive ones (to avoid the commonly cited, though rare, case of a tribal spearman defeating a tank in previous games), and military units in general have many different upgrades they can earn as they receive experience points and gain power levels. In addition, artillery has been tweaked to be much more useful. It can bombard targets, such as enemy cities, to lower defenses and to deal collateral damage to large "stacks" of armies. These improvements don't make battles all that much more complicated , but they do add more depth to combat, since both attackers and defenders have more factors to consider.
This game needs a Steam Award!

The concept is cool, but pacing is extremely slow. Learning the in-battle commands is tedious. For example, just getting your guys to move from point A to point B in the same formation is like 3 different shortcuts (Ctrl+G, Select Group, Left-Alt+Right Click? I'm pretty sure?). Then by the time my dudes show up to the fight, half of them are dead, the others are out of formation that I spent all the time in the world setting up... And this isn't even considering the match-up between units, which gets thrown out of balance anyway due to the Romance playstyle. It's taken me 55 hours and several YouTube videos to try to learn this game. It's my opinion, but any game that literally has multiple several-minute-long videos in the pause menu yet still can't convey the mechanics of the game correctly puts a sour taste in my mouth.

I did like that they give the player the option to play differently. There is a Romance version and Records version. Romance adds an extra layer of variability, and the game centers more around the generals and their unique traits. Records keeps it a little more tactical/logical, and keeps the fights more predictable. I opted for the Records version, as I am interested in learning the basics without the extra variables, but I can see some veterans of the series enjoying the extra unpredictability in the Romance version.

I want to like this game. but to me, it's like reading an excel sheet that looks nicer. And this is coming from a guy that loves XCOM, Gears Tactics, Age of Empires, and Battletech. I've also played every numbered Dynasty Warriors, including the Empires series. I'll continue to play 3K because I spent 60 bucks, and at this point I feel like it's a sunk cost, but given the choice, I'd take a full refund.

If you are a person who relishes the wait and are willing to sink time into learning the mechanics, I think this game could really reward you. For me, the Action-to-Click Ratio is a little too low.

In this review I am going to mention the names of a few other games I like. I dont particularly like to mention others products in a review, it's just bad etiquette. But I feel I have to do this in order for you to understand this review in the right perspective, and dear ChuckleFish and ConcernedApe I'm sorry.

I came to Stardew Valley from games like Terraria, RimWorld and Factorio and outside of steam I have played Cataclysm DDA alot. These are great games who all fits my preference very well. And I tend raise or max the difficulty settings too, when I can.

So as you might already suspect I am the kind of gamer who likes tinkering. And obscure mechanics. And tough gameplay from day one. I WANT a steep learning curve. I WANT to die. I WANT to min/max my characters layers of clothing and arsenal of guns/swords/tentacles/whatever.

But I also want a cookie now and then! Like when I figure out the right meta strategy for a general problem, or find out that the barrel of pure alcohol made with the cooking skill can be attached to the gardenblower. And I use it to MASSIVELY hand out some serious whoopass to those zombies with that stupid grin on their faces, who just before killed me for the oompteenth time. BURN suckers! Feel the pain of a thousand suns! PAYBACK!

I guess you might see where this is going? You're right. Stardew Valley is pretty nice. And it's pretty nice to me aswell. And I just can't take it!!!

I wish eternal darkness would descend on the valley. I wish evil aliens would flood from the mines and I wish the neighboring towns would just INVADE the valley to pillage my farm and do unmentionable things to my dog. And I would have my revenge... I would turn all those thousands of parsnips in my fields into a GREAT weapon of destruction.

But alas. The valley keeps being nice to me. I guess this is great for my wife... She likes it. But I CAN'T have it! So ChuckleFish and CorcernedApe, thanks for having me and thanks for being nice.

I don't recommend the game if you like HARD... If you like to get PAYBACK! I do however recommend it if you like nice, and this is what Stardew Valley tried to be. So I guess it's ultimately going to be a thumbs up from here.

Oh. And goodbye. I will not be back.

I was, in a former life, an average to ok console gamer, when my PS4 died I was pretty gutted I couldn't unwind on BF4.

Used to play some Domination and Defuse in hardcore, I have to say Sandstorm is a GOOD replacement....

Honestly I suck at it right now, transition to keyboard is tough for me, but the game play, the massive increase in graphical fluidity is awesom, but what is best about the game is the game modes and the spawn system, your team has an incentive to take objectives and PTTFO in a way that even hardened console gamers on BF4 would avoid, it ups the realism, as does the TTK, when I actually manage to get the drop on some one its usually over in one or two hits, despite the requirement to play a slower and more concidered game in terms of pushing up to objectives and clearing buildings, the game still feels fast.....or maybe I'm just getting old?!....

I need to put in way more practice on PC to get up to my previous levels of control, strategy and confidence, but I'm realy enjoying the challengs this game sets for me.
