This game is literal cancer and here is why
1. The game has the most bizarre and unreasonable hit detection. "Whats that your sword connected but you got hit as it did, sorry you stopped your swing." "Whats that the enemy missed his thrust with a spear but he was facing you as he pulled back from finishing the thrust, well that hit you and did 100% of your health either though you are in heavy armor"
2. The game suffers the biggest bs exploit with horizontal strikes that everyone called out should be removed from the game that literally inspired this game. The classic whip your mouse as you swing to make it last longer than the action should be based on how its programmed
3. Swing speed is inconsistant. You'll have fights where two people use the same weapon and armor and somehow one can combo attacks off faster than the other with out anything like chambering happen
4. Finally Friendly fire should not exist in this game. You penalize people on accidents( 9/10 its cause a teammate runs in front of you as you are already swinging at the enemy) so you loose out score which matters to the pay out you get at the end of the match on top of that it makes so if you have a group happen someone cant swing in the direction needed to make a hit cause on the swing back the broken hit detection will have it register as a full on blow on a teammate. This issue is even worse for archers and those who use fire bombs. On top of that it forces everyone to waste loadout points just to lower the damage the receive and dish out to teammates
I loved this game starting out but it quickly faded as soon as these issues flooded everything good about it.
Fix these issues and I'll recommend if. If not you are as bad as EA when it comes to caring about your own creations.

This game has the most wonderful story.
It immediately strikes you and never lets go.
If it were ten times longer it would still be too short.

It's more Borderlands, what do you expect?

The story, especially compared to its predecessors, is really bad. Plenty of retcons, inconsistencies and unlikable characters. The villains lack depth and charisma, making it difficult to enjoy their presence in the story as "the bad guys". In other words, the Calypso Twins are no Handsome Jack. The pacing of the story also feels inconsistent. At one point you're on a planet for a grand total of 45 minutes, then you're on another planet for 6 hours. I could go on about other negatives to the story, but that would include spoilers. There's plenty of videos out there critiquing the story already. Suffice it to say, I don't play Borderlands for the story alone, which would limit the enjoyment the game does offer.

Which leads me to the positives! The gameplay is fantastic, probably the best in the series. Every gun feels unique, despite having no red flavor text. Makes you feel as if there's a seemingly endless choice of weapons. There's also a lot of quality of life additions we haven't seen before, such as having access to the Fast Travel network anywhere you're standing, and being able to fill your ammo supply with a press of a button near a vending machine.

Overall, I would wait for a sale and not spend $60 on the game. I breezed through the base game in about 20 hours (and I tried to do every side mission, so it'll take you even less time if you choose to skip most of them). Otherwise, if you're a fan of the series, pick it up.

Return from an adventure of nest smashing with my buddy-pal Mr. Tank.
Processor production dipped because advanced circuit production decreased, advanced circuit production decreased because circuit production went down, and circuit production went down because copper production was low.
While running around figuring this out, I forget where I parked the tank.
Suddenly being attacked where a turret decided it shouldn't defend even though it has ammo. While running across my factory to defend, I find my tank and use it to defend my base.
Forget about copper crisis and use tank's flamethrower to clear forest for future expansion, but run out of flamethrower fuel.
Return to factory to get more flamethrower fuel, remember copper crisis. Decide to move out to the area I was going to expand to for more copper furnaces. Walk there, realize I forgot my tank, and spend the next few minutes trying to find the tank again.
While trying to find my tank, get run over by a train, respawn next to my tank.

11/10 would lose my tank again and still not have enough copper plate.

As someone who has never really played or had an interest in metroidvania style platforming games this is really good for what its doing and i highly suggest it even if you generally just stick to the more basic style of platforming game that's less combat focused. its not without its issues though, however all of the issues i found with this game are extremely minor

for instance creating duplicate bindings can be a little wierd since you have to press both buttons you want to have the single command bound to at the same time which can be kind of tricky if you want to bind inventory right/left for instance to both the bumpers and triggers. also i don't think they even tell you that you could make duplicate bindings, i found out how to do this by just screwing around for a bit in the menus.

initially i thought the game was somewhat challenging but then i quickly found out that the game lets you do the common RPG overleveling tactic where you just play the first few levels a bunch of times to get good gear before the game initially intended on it. luckilly this doesn't apply to everything but there's quite a bit that it does apply to.

also battletoads? really? you could have picked Commander Keen as a PC exclusive reference to a retro platforming game but you pick battletoads for the PC side of the exclusive easter egg stuff based on the platform the game is on in the style of super meat boy... ok then.

outside of those 3 nitpicks the game has been very fun so far and i highly suggest it to anybody who is a fan of 2d platforming games in general. also the music is pretty good too.

Hear me out, I played the open beta and hated this game, I was equally as pissed off as every other review on here.  I've played all DoW games including every expansion and it was something about that MOBA feel that I couldn't get into.  The game had a feeling where every regular unit you create was fodder, and could easily be rekt by even low level hero unit's, regardless of how many you have on the map.

However, after playing the full game I'm getting a better understanding of what they were going for.  There are many different "hero units" to choose from, more than what was in the beta. There are elite units that call in a strong squad like warp spiders or striking scorpians (I play eldar) for an affordable amount of hero points and they have strong abilities that can turn the tide of battle early, or you can save hero points and call up one of the huge walker unit, but by the time you get the hero points for that it might be too late.  

The worst aspect of the multiplayer for me is the cover system, there are random points that just don't make sense strategically, and its easy to wipe out a unit in cover, gone are the days where there is light and heavy cover all over the map.

Last thing, I was also disappointed with a lot of the small things that felt like they were missing from the last game, but it seems like they decided have a lot of skills/perks have to be selected before going into battle.  For example, eldar didn't have a unit to make energy shields, but later saw it could be done a one of the 3 selectable perks before the multiplayer game starts.

It's a pretty game game, the single player is what you'd expect from DoW.  I wasn't going to buy it but I found it on sale for $40, and now that I've played the full game I feel it was worth the full price.

The game worked fine for ages and I had a blast playing it. I made the mistake of having a break and now, with the latest updates, it crashes every time I try to start it. It claims that I now need some kind of anti cheat software, So far I have been unable to find any links to it in chats or the store page. I don't use cheats or mods so from my perspective it is just a pain. I managed to fix the problem by going into the Steam files and reinstalling the anti-cheat software manually after searching for solutions online and getting assistance from Urbisoft.

I have now played another couple of games. While I agree with some reviews that state that the game has become harder, I never managed to do much above veteran level anyway so not much change there for me. It is still as fun as I remember. 

Thanks to Hedge from Fat Shark for trying to assist me in making the game accessible again. If you are having the same issue as me try my fix first and if that doesn't work please see the developer's response below. I can once again recommend this game although you may have to do some annoying trouble shooting to get it going.

First of all I have no idea why this game has so many negative reviews... Mostly people just jumping on the hating band wagon. Now that's not to say the game is perfect, of course it has issues that you would expect from an EA title.

People complain that it's just ark with a pirate skin but let's be real here folks, most of these so called "AAA titles" are just reskinned versions of the previouis title and I don't see the hate for those games....

I bought the game 2 weeks after release so my experiences may not reflect those who played on day 1. 

In my 40+ hours I have not had a single crash or come across any major bugs that have stopped my progress or ruined my experience. The rubber banding was pretty bad the first couple of days I played but after yesterdays update I had an entire evening where the performance was great. No rubber banding and a constant 60 FPS.

The most annoying thing I had an issue with besides the rubber banding was trying to climb ship ladders which can be a bit annoying. I have played a lot of EA games and I'd put this up there as one of the best EA titles I have played, many EA games release with almost no content and major bugs but this game has a lot of content and little bugs (from my experience)

If you like survival/crafting games but want more of an mmo feel then this is a great title and you'll enojoy the game. If you prefer games like rust then you may not enjoy this game.

It's very slow paced and encourages grouping up in to larger groups than your average survival pvp game. Diplomacy is as much of a part of the game as piracy is.

This game does not deserve the hate it's been getting and I'd recommend this to any survival/crafting/building fan that wants a pirate themed mmo

So after 24 hours of gameplay I have decided to give my verdict on relics new venture on the DOW series. For all its flaws ( and there a few) I would give this game a thumbs up and recommend it. Overall the game isnt so bad, the graphics are stunning, the units for all factions are interesting and fun to use which you get to play with across a relatively alright campaign. The multiplayer is challenging and now has an anhilation mode which is very fun to play. 

When it comes to the flaws there are a few that i couldnt help but pick up on. The first one which bugged me was Gabreil Angelos, for whatever reason they have decided to change the voice actor and I miss his booming, authotarian space marine chapter master, hammer swining motherfucker I have come to love from the first and second dawn of war games. The game has overalled alot of mechanics and now heavily leans on how well you can micro manage the abilities of each unit to really get the full use of them. it reminds me much of DOTA except you can have dozens of units and one big skirmish each with their own ability that you need to constantly focus on, especially in the PVP. The cover system as you know it is gone, replaced by these rather strange shield domes which become uselss if your attacked by a melle unit. 

The campaign spans across 17 levels where you flip between the three factions which i disliked. im a big space marine fan boy and would have preferred to have a seperate campaign for all factions but the campaign itself was a fun experience if not very predictable. I also felt that there are not equal amount of missions for each faction and that they are all not the same length, so you could play a big mission with the Eldar that can take around 45 mins and then a quick space marine mission that lasts 20 then your straight back into the eldar again. 

There may seem like a few bad points but the biggest thumbs up for me and this game is that its just plain FUN. I play video games because there challenging and fun and DOW 3 does that pretty well. The Ork scrap mechanic to upgrade units and build vehicles is pretty sweet and watching a whole army of eldar getting chewed up by twin Imperial Knight gattling guns was just seriously fucking cool. 

Yes the game has dumbed down, yes it isnt as big as Dark Crusade or Soulstorm in terms of campaing and invading provinces and planets, yes they removed some good features from previous titles and your correct, it isnt the best DOW title. But its bloody fun to play.

It goes without saying this is exceptionally one of the greatest first-person shooter games that doesn't require real bullets, competitive teamwork, accurate aiming, targets and most other common mechanics that are found in that specific genre to make such a fantastic and charming game. This title demonstrates what it always had shown in the prequel; perfect gameplay and immersive story-telling. Thus, this sequel opens the gateway to the remarkable Portal series.

Now, imagine all of those unanswered questions and obscure mysteries that linger within the first game, and how this sequel answers nearly all those said questions with the utmost scientific explanations through the lines of entertainment from this one. From what I could honestly tell you, this game took the first games mechanics, and widened the story much more bigger and exceptionally better. Portal 2 is by far, worthy of the 'Game of the Year 2011' awards.
Get some friends togheter and play this game. This game is fantastic

-Endless potential
-great soundtrack and performance
-neat graphics
-amazing exploration and beautiful scenery
-high quality audio
These are just some of the things that makes this game great. The graphics are simple but are also very detailed (e.g. the metal in rooms, hallways etc. is mainly just white, but it is high quality and reflective which is cool). The scenery takes a whole new level of awesome when night comes though. Everything lights up and all you can see in the dark is glowing corals and eyes. When I first heard a Reefback, I was both terrified but also in awe because it sounds quite real. Overall, this game can be a bit tedious at times, but the exploration is never bland. This game also has tons of potential since it is still in early access but the developers have tons of ideas for what to add.

I love this game. Great graphics, easy controls, good level increments but not too much, nice story as much to make you laugh as progress the tale. Great audio. Highly recommend, I do like a good puzzle game. This is a standout title.

Perfect game from a simpler time.

One thing that annoyes me the most about modern games, yes I'm looking at you Metro, is the fact that you are basically only watching cutscene after cutscene and you're barely even allowed to do anything yourself. 
Everything that looks remotely like it could be fun happens in cutscenes.

In Half life everything story releated happens while you're playing, without ever being interrupted. Characters talk to you when you run past and if you don't wanna listen to what they have to say you can just run by without caring, it's up to you.

Also the game doesn't bother explaining everything to the point that even a 3 year old would understand it, the leveldesign is so well thought out that you'll never even end up asking yourself what to do. If you can't take the most obvious route (because of a locked door for example), all you have to do is look around and you'll find other paths to take, or at least clues of what you are looking for. That is much better than markers all over the map or an annoying AI running with you telling you the same hint over and over again.

One thing that bothered me a little bit would be how ridiculously inaccurate certain guns are, but overall the gunplay and movement feels very solid and obviously familiar for cs players.

It's a tiny download, you can grab it for under $2 during steam sales, it runs on every toaster and is an absolute pillar in the world of gaming, why are you even reading reviews?

Update to my review:  At this time, 5/16/2020 I can not recommend DoomEternal for PC users.  First patch brought in Denuvo Anti-Cheat, which is a extremely bad thing to have on your PC.  Anti-Cheat installs a kernel on the lost level of your PC.  Meaning it has the ability if abused to collect and do anything on your PC.  If a vulnerability is ever found, which is highly likely given Denuvos track record.  This would leave your PC open for very nasty attacks. 

Besides the HUGE secure issues with this update.  Denuvo also is effecting game performance, corrupting saves and it out right Killed Linux support.  

So with a heavy heart I can't give support to DOOM Eternal on PC.  The update has not effected other platforms yet.  An as long as it doesn't I can  recommend game only on those platforms.

The devs had a vision and they went and did it. The vision is crystal clear throughout the whole game. Though it is a clunky game that needs some polish and doesn't look great to 2021 standards, it's nonetheless a very fun experience if you're the type of gamer that likes games like dwarf fortress, rimworld and fallout 4. 

I love how you can build a settlement almost anywhere (except around towns). The game has a really clever system for entity relationships - not only NPCs can have slaves, but you can also have slaves, and NPCs can enslave you, even. 

The health system is very similar to rimworld, albeit a bit less complex. You can get wounded limbs that will be less effective and even lose limbs altogether.

Difficulty wise I think the game is still insanely hard, it can get easy but you need tons of grinding to get there. I know it's part of the vision of a harsh open world, but I still wish I could defeat some low level enemies when I start playing without having to grind a bunch of attributes first.

When I checked the game description saying you could be anything (a warlord, a trader, a warrior etc) I thought that those features ingame would be a bit watered down, like No Man's Sky, but you can actually be any of those things and the experience will be really fun.

I have been a part of this since Pre-Alpha, It's finally out!!!  I have finish the game and enjoyed it to the end.  This reminds me of Super Mario 64 and I recommend this to anyone who is into platformer games.

If you don't want to read a long spiel of me saying how unarguably awesome game, just read this synopsis. Basically, Subnautica is one of those games that you cannot fault. It is both beautiful and blood curdling. It is a perfect work of pure art. 

I honestly have no words. One of (if not THE) best games I've ever purchased. I cannot begin to tell you how bloody good this is. It has made me both simultaneously left me in utter awe of its stunning visuals, and borderline wet myselfs in my chair at the most terrifying points. Both a horror AND an open world exploration (but mostly a horror), this is a game I cannot reccomend enough. 

But, be warned, for the love of god don't spoil this for yourself. I get it, Jacksepticeye is a great YouTuber and all, but if you have any intention of playing this game, you need to experience it first hand. If not, don't sweat it. I'm sure it will be highly enjoyable, but like many games of its type, you will gain a lot more out of experiencing the surprises for yourself. 

The updates in the developement process were regular and all brought new fodder to the game that I just had to start new saves to play through. Not only that, but I found myself never tiring of the experience. Love to the developers <3

Seriously, thank you so much, developers - I'm proud to say I have owned this sicne its early developement stages, and definitely got my money's worth. If there was a point, I reckon I would buy it again. Phenomenal game. Flawless. 10/10.

I have trouble wrapping my head around why Valve would release such an unpolished and ugly game like this. I mean, how do you make the jump between the gorgeous graphics of Dota 2 and this pile of festering dog shit, squirted out of the quivering anus of Gabe Newell himself? When compared to every other game they're working on now, it looks as though they didn't even try. I understand that they're trying to appeal to the retro boomers who are okay with their boxy, paper mache enemies and crying themselves to bed each and every night. But that doesn't justify shambling together a barely functioning game to leech off of something so near and dear to every gamer's heart. Being Half-Life 2, of course.

A friend of mine went on and on about this game and to be honest, I figured he was kinda making some of the things he said up. Like, literally - he'd describe some situations his colony got in and how the settlers dealt with it and I thought, "Well, that's nice but this is some weird sixteen bit head floating on a tee shirt shooting at another head on a tee shirt I guess you just dropped some acid and decided to invent some weird backstory between these two people about how they made an ongoing friendship and eventually one was captured and joined the colony where they were the best of friends until a love triangle split them up and they ended up hospitalizing each other in a social fight and one died and the other lived on but eventually died of depression."

Turns out no, that was not acid induced. That's just how things come together in this game. A lot. 

And that's not even mentioning the complexity of how the actual settlement mechanics work. 

My sister bought me this game and now I'm all angry that I lost days of my life. But that's fine, this game has some incidental storytelling that outdoes releases from 2018 that intentionally attempt to try and get you emotionally involved, like Far Cry and other rpgs.

Portal 2 is better then its predecessor with a longer campaign and coop.
The campaign is fun but it ain't that hard.
Coop is a great addition to the game.
On the other hand the games workshop is full of hard, challenging maps for single and multiplayer.

Is the game fun? It is very fun to me. Is it perfect? No, however it's one of my favorite asymmetrical games.
Dead by Daylight has lots of good stuff, and I'd definitely recommend it to my friends.  It's one of the most fun games I can enjoy with my friends. That thrill of being either the killer or a survivor is just the perfect kind of rush for games. When the fear goes away, there's still that comical goofy fun players can still have. I'd have to warn them that they need a good computer. It is literally impossible to play it on an average laptop; I speak from experience.

What are the downsides? The top flaw would have to be the matching system. It's such a pain when amateur killers are stuck getting seasoned pros or vice versa, but at the same time it makes the game that much more surprising and thrilling.
Like this flaw, I can view the brightside of all the other problems I find in this game, which are few.

Even after I experience all the content, I plan to keep playing casually every now and then. If it wasn't for the massive download required to play the game, I'd redownload it all the time when I felt in the mood for a month of DbD.

Summary: Great game, worth it. Don't get the DLCs unless you're sure you like the game, and watch out for the toxic players.

While the main game hovers somewhere between "yea, kinda fun" and "why can't I skip this?" the endgame is utterly broken. You can't expect a borderlands game to be balanced. But the abomination that is Mayhem mode is deeply unfun until you reach maxed gear at which point you have no other goals to archive. I'm not saying this as some casual pleb who just wants to mindlessly indulge in pure power fantasy I'm saying this as a dedicated fan of the borderlands franchise who patiently waited for this game for over five years while farming my way through OP8 even on the fucking commando. The "mayhem mode" leaves you without instructions and 10 levels of pain each with its own unique modifiers most of which are either already hated mechanics copied from other games or skills you'd get while leveling up your "common zelot" unit in a strategy game, but you won't see most of these modifiers either as you will be skipping through the tiers as fast as you can because the higher your mayhem level the higher the mayhem level on your loot. Because we have learned absolutely nothing from the common reaction to bl2s op levels and wanted to ReWaRd DeDiCaTeD pLaYeRs with more digital shit they can grind for.
So, if you want a game with endgame content that'll ask you to increase your mastery to extreme extends go play the moba of your choice trust me even those feel better balanced.
If you're just here because you wanna shoot shit go ahead you might have some good fun.

For the people coming to bl3 expecting a borderlads 2 level story go play The Pre Sequel. Because: The story of the main game looks like they fired their writer halfway through and thought "how hard can it be?" then got them back after 3 years of development just, so they can glaze over the shit produced.
You might find enjoyment in the stories of the natives of Eden six and Promethia tho. Some of those use humor in a borderlandsesque way.
The DLCs might just be worth a play as well but I personally wouldn't like to pay for the platform just, so I can buy the actual thing extra.

And for the devs.
1. Head Writer is an important position. And writing in general is more important than you think. Yes even you, the lonely dev who wants to make a narrative adventure, even you underestimate the necessarily of formal training and/or experience (former often coming with a lot of self loathing and/or poverty).
2. Endgame isn't always necessary unless you make it but IF you make it, it should take up a lot of time and be fun for that entire time.

I have a mixed review for this game. So I'm going to list the pros and cons of this game compared to the 17 version. 
Pros-
- 19 has slightly better graphics than 17
- 19 allows you to edit the terrain and reform your land without a mod
- 19 added horses, which is pretty cool
Cons-
- I only have 1 real con, 19 has a different platform making it more difficult for users to create and edit mods, because of this there are far less mods available (only so far hopefully), also because of this, some of the available mods have bugs or just flat out do not work. It's been 4 months so far and no seasons mod yet. All of the great mods from 17 like, seasons, real tire dirt, real ground response, courseplay, follow me, farming tablet, gearbox, more realistic gameplay, proseed, gps, and other great mods, are not available for the 19 version. If these mods start coming out I will upgrade my review to a positive review no doubt, but until then, I say 17 is the best sim so far. I'll still recommend this game though because, hey, farming simulator flat out rocks to begin with.

As a TTRPG fan and having played Pathfinder for quite a while, I can certainly affirm that the system is perfect for a cRPG, since managing all the modifiers and calculations in tabletop can be a chore for Pathfinder, mainly through higher levels. Playing Kingmaker is like playing a TTRPG without having to add modifiers and without combat events lasting for hours, so pretty much a great experience! Lore, world building, game balancing, it all feels Pathfinder and the experience is awesome, mainly now with turn based mode implemented. The game is not perfect though. The kingdom building system is completely flawed and account for pretty much no benefit throughout your adventures in the Stolen Lands. Despite of that, every cRPG fan, mainly those familiar with Pathfinder, should spend their time in the Stolen Lands. The game is great and I cannot wait for Wrath of the Righteous to be released!

I didnt hear a lot about Hollow Knight before i started playing so i wasn't expecting much but after playing the first few hours i already loved the game so much that i didnt play anything else for a week. I even spent ~10h on an optional, hidden jumping puzzle to complete everything the game had to offer back then.

I would consider Hollow Knight a must-play title for every Metroidvania fan.

-Artstyle 10/10: it looks beautiful

-World design 10/10: highly interconnected levels, every section has its own design and feels different, you dont have to follow a certain path

-Music 10/10: Great, atmospheric music

-gameplay 10/10: The movement feels great especially after obtaining Dash, Wings and Claw. 

-difficulty 10/10: Every fight and jumping puzzle feels fair and possible. The difficulty is comparable to Dark Souls and the most difficult things are optional.

-price/performance 10/10: This game is worth every cent.

-Lore/Story 10/10: It's no boring selfexplaining story. You have to discover it by yourself.

In addition: free extensions with great content

This game is fantastic. In comparison to Dark Souls, it removes the stat and build variety that a lot of people may be used to. Because of that, there's really only one viable way to play the game -- through parrying. If you can overcome that initial hurdle, however, there is a lot of depth to the combat, and there are quite a few bosses that will test your knowledge and reaction time. The lack of build variety does mean that this is inherently less replayable than other Souls-like games. Still, there are multiple endings complete with additional bosses. Overall, even playing through it once, I felt the game was well worth the price.

I've played 300+ hours of this game since the DAY it was released. This game used to be very fun! Combat was fast, quick paced, skill oriented. It was awesome! Worked great in one on one fights and in team play. After the latest patch, Patch #17, they've ruined all of it. Movement speed has been reduced greatly. Everything feels like slowmo. Long weapons are no longer viable as they have reduced damage in certain areas and are MUCH slower, to the point that they aren't worth it at all. They removed the "swing through teammates" mechanic, (this mechanic was used so if you swing your weapon and hit a teammate, your sword will go through and hit the enemy you're trying to hit). This mechanic was abused somewhat but kept the combat fast paced and fluid. Now that's gone and if you use a big weapon, you're extremely likely to hit a teammate and instead of going through, now it bounces off. Combat with big weapons was nullified. Do you still want to have fun in this game? Well, you're going to have to play with a small, fast, low damage weapon. That's the only way. Otherwise it's just a game of waiting until you get killed during the super long swing. There used to be two great mechanics, accels and drags! You could look forward during a swing and make your weapon move quicker, or look back to drag out the swing and make it slower! That broke up the pace of combat and kept you on your toes! That was ruined with Patch #17. Accels and drags are completely broken now, you can't do it well like you could before. It's been reduced to a cheap gimmick. 

Okay so what a good part of this game? Team modes. They are incredibly fun and fluid, fighting multiple enemies with your teammates all fighting beside you. It's a dangerous game because not only do you have to worry about hitting enemies and not dying, you also have to be careful and strike properly and carefully so you don't take out a teammate!!!

Sounds great right? Well not anymore. Patch  #17 ruined that too. The game has been turned from team battles to 1v1s. That's what is being pushed hard right now. No one is asking for it, but by God they (devs) are doing it! Now the team battles have turned into duels and nothing more. It's almost impossible to fight in a team battle after this update because the patch has changed the mechanics to suit dueling and nothing else. Now the fun game modes like Invasion and Frontlines have turned into mini duel servers except now you duel with someone and get stabbed in the side by another guy because "hey! you can't fight multiple people anymore!" 

I would not recommend purchasing this game till all of this get's fixed if it ever will. If something isn't done about this terrible update, I'm done playing this game. 

The playerbase is dying off already. Why kill the game more? 

Devs, we ask you to fix bugs, broken mechanics, and OP weapons. Not redo the game. Why fix something that isn't broken? All you do is make it so much worse. The game was amazing before this. I would play literally everyday for hours on end because it was so much fun. Now it's been taken over by a terrible new gamemode. We don't want ranked play pushed down our throats, we want the fun back. 

For people thinking about buying this game: Unless they revert this patch or fix what they broke, don't buy this game. Wait for Chivalry 2 or Mount and Blade or something other than this. Don't waste 30 dollars. 

You're not playing what's advertised anymore. If you want to fight 1v1 against enemies that spin, twirl, and use gimmicks to beat you, this is your game. If you're looking for big multiplayer battles like advertised, stay far, far away and wait for something else to come along. 

Please fix this shit devs. Your already shrinking playerbase will only continue to dwindle if you don't.

Personally I do enjoy this game and while this game certainly does have its ups and downs, I am not here to praise or criticize this game. I am here to offer a phenomenal 4 Cheese Ravioli recipe!

Here are the ingredients you will need!

Ravioli Dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 pinch salt, 1 teaspoon olive oil, 2 eggs, 1 1/2 tablespoons water.

Ravioli Filling: 1 (8 ounce) container ricotta cheese, 1 (4 ounce) package cream cheese, softened, 1/2 cup shredded mozzarella cheese, 1/2 cup provolone cheese, shredded, 1 egg, 1 1/2 teaspoons dried parsley.

Pesto-Alfredo Cream Sauce: 2 tablespoons olive oil, 2 cloves garlic, crushed, 3 tablespoons prepared basil pesto sauce, 2 cups heavy cream, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1 (24 ounce) jar marinara sauce.


1. Mound the flour and salt together on a work surface and form a well. Beat the teaspoon of olive oil, 2 eggs, and water in a bowl. Pour half the egg mixture into the well. Begin mixing the egg with the flour with one hand; use your other hand to keep the flour mound steady. Add the remaining egg mixture and knead to form a dough.

2. Knead the dough until smooth, 8 to 10 minutes; add more flour if the dough is too sticky. Form the dough into a ball and wrap tightly with plastic. Refrigerate for 1 hour.

3. While the dough is resting, prepare the ravioli filling. Combine the ricotta cheese, cream cheese, mozzarella cheese, provolone cheese, egg, and parsley and mix well. Set the filling aside.

4. Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the crushed garlic and pesto sauce and cook for one minute. Pour in the heavy cream, raise the heat to high, and bring the sauce to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the Parmesan cheese and stir until the cheese melts. Remove the pan from the heat and keep warm.

5. Meanwhile, in a separate saucepan, warm the marinara sauce over medium-low heat.

6. Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Beat the egg with the tablespoon of water to make the egg wash.

7. Roll out the pasta dough into thin sheets no thicker than a nickel. To assemble the ravioli, brush the egg wash over a sheet of pasta. Drop the filling mixture on the dough by teaspoonfuls about one inch apart. Cover the filling with the top sheet of pasta, pressing out the air from around each portion of filling. Press firmly around the filling to seal. Cut into individual ravioli with a knife or pizza cutter. Seal the edges.

8. Fill a large pot with lightly salted water and bring to a rolling boil over high heat. Stir in the ravioli, and return to a boil. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, until the ravioli float to the top and the filling is hot, 4 to 8 minutes. Drain well.

9. Grease a baking sheet. Place the cooked ravioli on the sheet pan and bake in the preheated oven until brown, about 4 minutes.

10. To serve the ravioli, divide them among four warmed serving bowls. Drizzle the marinara sauce over the ravioli and then top with the cream sauce.

[b]Note:[/b] As of this writing, I've only beaten the Shovel Knight main story, not Plague of Shadows. I'll update this when I've done that. 

[h1]The Short of it:[/h1] It's a fantastic game. If you like platformers, buy this game. If you grew up playing platformers, buy this game. If you grew up playing Mario, Ducktales, Castlevania, Megaman, or even Karnov, buy this game. This is more than your standard lo-fi retro platformer, it's a genuine love letter to an era of gaming largely gone by; The aesthetic and design of ~1988-1993 with 2015 polish. 

[h1]The Long of It:[/h1] I'll be relatively brief beacuse everyone already reccomends this game. Shovel Knight is a game that oozes old school charm in a way that many similar games have failed to. In an era where retro 2D platformers are a dime a dozen (and frequently worth about that much) Shovel Knight somehow manages to avoid riling the kind of fatigue that's associated with this genre right now. It's hard to put my finger on, but if I had to guess, I'd say it's because Shovel Knight seems to be going for more than just an aesthetic; Yacht Club games pulled not just the art and music from the era, not just even some tropes, they went back to classic sources and distilled the good, designed around or cut out the bad, and from it produced a game which is nearly 100% made of the stuff you remember loving about your old games.

 Gone is the unforgiving opacity of Castlevania, but what remains is the clever design around items that turns every encounter into a live action puzzle. Gone is the "strategic" wrote memorization and sometimes arcane boss weaknesses of Megaman, but what remains is a level design that teaches you how to play from every jump and a feeling of real progression with persistent powerups. It's really hard not to feel good about Shovel Knight.

Is there anything bad about it, then? Sort of, but nothing truly objectively bad. If you're bad, like me, then getting all of the items can be kind of a grind. Yacht Club does their best to mitigate that with bonus treasure levels and replayable stages, but that can be somewhat hamstrung by being awful at the game. While I'm still kind of in love with their checkpoint system, punishing death with money loss (frequently retrievable as it may be) means that players who deathspam their way through levels may find themselves hard up for cash when it comes time to upgrade. 

That's an incredibly minor grievance and having now beaten the game, I genuinely can't think of any others offhand. It's a good game--nay, it's a great game. It's design borders on perfection, it's incredibly easy to pick up and put down as needed, and it is clearly a labour of love in the best of ways. For the love of god, buy this game and support Yacht Club Games. Work like this deserves success.

I bought the game recently from Steam, as it was on holiday discount. After playing few games I do feel like I shouldn't have. So I can't really recommend this to anyone, especially an experienced Civ player, or a strategy game player.

I've played Civ games since the first one and even modded Civ 2 & 3, but Civ V is a true disappointment. I don't recall the AI being so passive and dumb in previous titles. Basically it's just not there. There are fine historical units for each civilization, but because AI is so passive you don't get to see them in action. 

You get to witness how barbarian archers take down AI player's swordsmen, who just sit there while all they need to do is attack them once or twice, as archers are quite defenseless. 

You get to witness how other civilizations create three cities, not more, and leave half of their land undeveloped. 

Also, you will experience crashes because of several reasons. I have very up-to-date gaming laptop and haven't had so many problems with any other game I've played. A crash per hour, I would say. Even after you do what they advice you to do, which is  turn down parts of game to avoid crashes - which is a ridiculous attempt to fix a problem. It's like if a car manufacturer would say "Your car's headlights don't work? Well, just remove them!"

The game is sugarcoated enough, nice graphics, nice unit & leaderhead animations, nice music and nice ambient sounds etc. but it's quite unplayable due to poor AI and crashes.

Let's start with what the game is not:
1: it's not a combat/action/stealth game, forget MGS
2: it's not a RPG with customizable character and choice and consequences, the narrative is completly linear and you are a spectator.

The gameplay is slow paced, requires planning ahead, and the core gameplay is delivering stuff from A to B, but it's not a simple walking simulator, there are many mechanics involved, a lot of tools to build. And the map has many dangers.

The narrative is completly linear, but very interesting and weird. Coupled with the many real life actors involved, the superb motion capture and face animation, and the photorealistic graphics, the experience is between watching an author sci-fi movie and playing a game.

To give it's best it needs a quite powerfull rig, especially an RTX card with DLSS makes its graphics to look stunning and the gameplay to be superfluid.

For anyone beeing in the mood for this kind of gameplay and even being sligthly interested in weird sci-fi distopic settings, Death Stranding is an unique game worthy to experience.

My friends and i played the game mostly all day today and had a great time, just noticed a few things that really stoped us from makeing any progress. for instense once in awhile about every 2 or 3 hours things would really start getting choppy, bad enough so that we would have to quit out and re load our current game. whe we did that the doors would be gliched right out like 10 of them right on top of eachother and we couldnt walk into them. trees would disapear from our tree houses, trees we cut down before we re loaded wouldnt be there on my screen, but on my friends they would be, but he couldnt cut them down. fires sometimes wont stay going and ive never been able to light a bon fire, which is very dissapointing because fire is probably one of the most key points of the game. esspecially at night. bon fires should light the place up nice and bright. 
     another thing i noticed is when i place walls, if it is on a hill it will connect to the previouse wall i placed but it will still be at the angel of the previouse wall. so it will pretty much be floating in the air connected to the walls on the hill. as well as building stuff like log sleds, ive built them and my friend could see it, logs wont come out of the log sled once placed in them ect...

I bought this Game at the Release Date, and jumped into it.

Now I spent about 36.5 Hours in playing this Game, and I have to say, that this Game, it's Content, it's Atmosphere and it's Sounds (which is part of the Atmosphere too, obviously) is by far the most epic experience since a long time. 

Pro:

- Sounds, Music is just nice
- lovely Graphics
- Different Elements, like Farming, Fishing, Mining, Fighting, and the fact that you can have social contacts
- Gameplay is nice, easy to understand the principle
- Storyline is ok, which means how it comes to different things (Don't want to spoiler)
- It's on you how to live your life, and which decisions you make. which influences you life in different ways
- The development is in progress, getting new Content after time

Cons:

Actually, I did not found [u] any [/u] cons which are very considerable. They are still working on the Storyline, and adding new Content to the Game. Yet, i did not experienced any bugs or errors.

------

You have the classic farming experience on a very huge farm area, having animals, while you have social contacts and the Combat/Adventure Feature in the mines.

I think this Game with its features would be much more worth than 15$ (~20 if you buy the Soundtrack DLC too), and I recommend buying this Game if you want to escape your daily routine and having some time where you can lean back, and have a relaxing session of playing this nice game.

And by the way, I guess there is no way raging in that game, exept of dying in mines, which makes it perfect for relaxing.

one of most addictive and fun melee combat games. hard and challenging but fair, engagig and fun. 
even after several new game plus cycles bosses can still give you trouble if you don't pay attention and there's few things one can do to make the playthrough harder if needed. 

combat and boss design is great although there are two or three types of bosses that are repeated several times (although they do have some variation from their previous versions thankfully).
progression, upgrading, leveling, level design, placements of items, enemies, locations and pathways is excellent. there's some sandbox elements such as different routes and several hidden pathways often alongside each route. it rewards exploration with upgrades and story telling. enviormental story telling is spot on. 

story itself is solid and graphics are good. optimization seems pretty okay. 
ran mostly 60fps at 1080p with 1070 and i5 with some framedrops in certain large open areas when for first time takign a look at them to load in the stuff. 
music is great and thank God, finally, a "souls like" game that also has ambient music instead of boring silence. 

controls on kb&m seems okay although the game needs an option to change out combat art usage keys from left click+right click to something else since you can accidentally go into long animation when all you wanted is to press attack quickly after deflect/block but instead, since you didn't release right click fast enough, you do a combat art instead of normal melee (which usually takes longer, leaving you open to damage). 
ofc you can remove the art and not worry about it. 

one thing that may irritate people (besides difficulty) is that there's a good amount of missable quests and sorts. A decent amount of stuff is hidden behind some sort of action like, eavesdropping, talking, obtaining an item, finishing this before that, etc...
replayability is great even if you did everything you could in your first run. since there's 4 endings, upgrades and materials to get via xp from ng+, do stuff you missed, difficulty scaling and best of all, the ability to give away kuro's charm. which you can do after you complete the game once. 
you can give away the charm at any new game or new game plus start and it will make combat even more challenging and fun by mainly making you take some damage when you block instead of deflect.

the boss rush mode is loads of fun and inner version of bosses at end of those rush modes are the greatest thrill (inner versions have new moves, ai, etc...).
as for online, there is only a system that let's you record a recording of your actions and write a message then leave a kunai on floor for someone to activate it and see the message and "hologram" of the other player moving around and stuff. basically to help new players find stuff or such and vice versa. 
it's a singleplayer game. and a damn good one at that too. 

this is, what they call, a souls like game. So be ready to refund after 2 hours when first boss kills you 20+ times in case you don't play reaction time games often. If you are somewhat more then decent at games and enjoy a challenge and a well made game then sekiro is a great choice. 

I have a few hundred hours already on it on my other account I think. It's super addictive when the combat clicks and you get better and better at it.
gameplay overall is awesome, with okay visuals, sound, story, progression and exploration to keep you busy and entertained for a good while. 

I only wish it was a bit longer or had dlc since playtime depends on your skill level. But most will get between 25 and 45 hours if not more. considering you try to do all optional side stuff as mcuh as possible and go for better ending first run.


I still somehow find tiny bits of game I never encountered after replaying it nearly ten times. 
And game keeps up the difficulty with your "powerful-ness" well enough. 
Majority of game is fun to play over and over if you liked the combat. Bugs are few and minor. Loading times seem quick enough. Save function works flawlessly (saving everything you do, even location from where you left off usually). You can have multiple save files. You can play without internet ofc and disable onlin messages thingy or just not watch/read them. There aren't too many keybinds to mess about and enough graphics settings to tweak. player control feels pretty good ofc. textures and animations are also good.

stealth aspect of game is really neat. you can basically go through many non-boss areas sneak playstyle.
the whole health and posture thing with deflecting and coping with perilous attacks is well made and executed. enemy AI seems good in majority of game. voice acting is nice. cinematic/ambient music fits well. 
combat music isn't too repetitive. skills and tools add een more flavour and layers to combat. yeah. all in all a fantastic game.

p.s. sorry for shitty wall of typos text review.

To put it simply:
- If you like Borderlands, this is the best iteration of the Borderlands gameplay yet.
-- It is however, more Borderlands, so don't expect any major changes in gameplay loop.
-- Mayhem 10 is still quite unbalanced, and favors specific builds. That, and a bug-turned-feature-in-testing that made enemies wield Mayhem 10 weapons is also pretty unfair for how bullet spongy they already are.
- If you don't like Borderlands, this game most likely won't convince you to like the series.
- If you're interested in Borderlands' story, forget it (it sucks really bad). If you like Borderlands' lore, this expands the lore further but maybe not in the way you like.

[b]A note in optimization: It is still all over the place. I can't sustain 60 FPS in busy gameplay moments which is 80% of this game.[/b]

However, I can't ignore the many hours I've already spent enjoying this game ever since I purchased it 3 weeks ago, so it is definitely worth the money I've spent. Definitely not a game for everyone, but certainly a game I recommend for the people familiar with the genre and the franchise. The base game is already good enough.

A nice realstic, and fun trucking simulator delivery game, for gamers, and real life truckers to appreicate in all its entiretiy. Very awe inspiring landscapes which may be indentical to the European-German-Italy-Poland regions of the world.  For the single player experince, Deliveries are very time effecttive, and rewarding with respective player leveling, and there are a handful of truck dealer brand selections to interest your liking. A few quirks are the speed traps, the AI traffic is tolerable, although not foolproof, which adds to the challenge of being a safe yet effeict truck driver, and after a few hours, the solo campagin feels too scoiophobia, as it doesnt feature much AI employee interaction or other truck radio chatter conversation along the drive. Other than that, it is a game to enjoy.

Disclaimer: For best experince, you should at least know how to drive in real life to understand trailer movement on a truck, which is minimal experince.

If you want to experience the game on a deeper level, feel free to download the multiplayer mod, by visiting the site here. http://ets2mp.com/index.php

Properly installing ETS2 Multiplayer mod:

1. Make an account on the mod site by A.) Logging in through Steam(Make your profile public before this process, can switch back once fully signed in) or B. make an account without steam (if it will let you do that)

2. Download the mod near the top right of the screen, then click the left box in the center of the next screen

3. Once done, find the file, unpack it, click the icon labled "Install ETS2MP", follow the respective prompts up until it asks for ETS2 directiory.

4. Find your approiate ETS2 game directory (Steam users: In your steamapps / common folder, and Select Euro Trcuk Sim 2.

5. Follow rest of promts on out. Done. Your all set to play ETS 2 Multiplayer. (Steam Users: Keep in mind when you start multiplayer, your game on Steam might keep flashing it is starting up ETS2. If this happens, just relog Steam, and you should be fine then, ths is a recurring problem from time to time.)

When I saw the announcement for this game, I was hoping for another Invisible Inc. It looked like this game would offer a procedurally generated series of tightly-focused, small-scale puzzles that I would then have to solve using a modestly varied set of tools with a pre-determined, RNGless set of capabilities. Once the pieces were in place, I hoped, I could then plan how a turn would play out to the last exact detail.

Turns out? That's EXACTLY what I got, and I highly recommend this game IF that sounds appealing to you. On the other hand, DO NOT buy this game if you want another FTL. If you want that, play the Captain's Edition mod for FTL instead, if you haven't already (if you have, try A Strange New Galaxy or Stations Job, which offer unique appeals of their own even though they're not as polished or feature-complete as CE).

As far as roguelites go, Into the Breach is fairly light on equipment and enemy variety (variance in general really) and on fleshing out the setting, but is VERY similar to Invisible Inc. in that respect. The two games are almost part-and-parcel in that they are both immensely satisfying little brain teasers where the fun and challenge of the game is in racking your brain for the optimal solution to the situation each turn presents, then feeling so very accomplished indeed when you discover and execute a series of moves that leaves the enemy floundering helplessly, doing no damage to either you or your buildings (or in Invisible Inc.'s case, the guards running around like headless chickens with no idea where your agents are).

Beyond that, Into the Breach has a simple but stylish aesthetic, simple but stylish music courtesy of FTL's composer Ben Prunty, and is generally simple and stylish all the way around. It's a very clean, almost clinical sort of game, but that is, I feel, as it should be for a game of its type, another quality it shares with Invisible Inc. It shows you exactly what you need to know to plan your next move and nothing more, leaving your thinking space free of distractions.

Again, the satisfaction of this game is the intellectual satisfaction of a well-executed plan. If you're looking for the visceral satisfaction of giant robots punching giant bugs, you won't really find that here as the combat animations and sound effects are fairly minimalist (though pushing the monsters into water or chasms never stops being funny). If, on the other hand, you're down for a well-realized puzzle game with a fascinating rule set and a helping of giant robotics on the side, you'd be mad not to check out Into the Breach.

Then check out Invisible Inc. once you're done. Not the Contingency Plan DLC, though. It sucks ballz.

Exploring in the dark and building structures to save your life in the nick of time not only puts off a very intensive feel, but reminds you... You're alone without help against both nature and the creatures that hunt you down. Even when there are no enemies around at night, the constant wails and screams of cannibals make you wonder if you really are safe in your own shelter.

You can craft, cook food, make weapons, and explore a vast open peninsula with different environments and biomes. Enemies consist of cannibals and mutants, ranging from weak to very strong. Its not at all recommended to fight if there is more than three enemies since they can easily gang up on you. Mutants are huge, powerful, and very aggressive. Killing them can give you some of the best armor in the game. You can tell if they are nearby by listening for loud footsteps and roars.

Know that if you plan to build a quick shelter at night and a mutant is nearby, they can sense your presence inside the shelter and end up either walking into it or try to destroy it. Try to build protection around your shelter if you are in a mutant heavy area.


Only your wits, drive to survive, and bravery of what awaits you, can save your life. The satisfaction in finding random useful things is just unbeatable. GET THIS GAME. Its fun, its visuals are beautiful for a Unity game, and its very well worth it.

EDIT: With the release of Final 1.0, its even better by far. Congratz to the The Forest team and thank you for your dedication.

I'll try to make this not sound like the generic positive Witcher III review.

Pros:
-2015 game with graphics better than most games out today
-A stock 1050TI paired with an i5-8300H can run this game on ultra 1080P without NVidia hairworks enabled
-Potentially hundreds, if not, thousands of hours of content embedded within the world of Witcher.
-The most perfect combat system. Everything just... works.

Cons:
-You'll hate every other game after beating it, let alone playing it.
-You're going to skip out on homework
-You're going to sit all day playing Witcher, and eventually feel burnt out. Yet you WILL come back and finish the game, either for the story or for completion.

Overall, great game 9.8/10

The game is definitely fun. The biggest problems are with the players who rush through the maps. They should probably be playing something else. This isn't a race, it is a team game experience that should be savored, and played out, not devoured as fast as possible. That ruins the game imo.  Advance, clear buildings and territory along the way, and assault the objective as a team..this is what I believe the game is intended to be. Maybe I'm wrong. I'd like to see a lot more maps and insane coop vs even more AI. Coop mode should be maximized, it's very fun to game with friends in discord or TS in team oriented play.

Torn on this one. It's good, but not great. Maybe my expectations were too high, or maybe I just need to wait a few years until they add enough content and patches to bring it up to par with V. 

Gripes so far: seriously unbalanced, frustrating, and feels very closed-off and limited compared to previous versions. This is a personal opinion but I *hate* the art style. World leaders are rendered as silly, cartoony goofs (who want to nuke you, by the way), the map is an utter visual disaster...it's like a pixel lasagna, layer after layer of graphics that look good on their own, but turn into a melted mush when combined; the net effect is that it's difficult to tell at a glance exactly what or who you're looking at. Music is so-so; probably an odd thing to complain about, but since you're stuck with it for hours and hours at a given time, it'd be nice if it wasn't so grating (seriously, banjos have little place in the real world, let alone in a video game). And worst of all...it's kinda boring. Never before in the series have I felt so robotic in every task I was doing. I feel less like a leader playing this game and more like an overworked shift supervisor at a toy-soldier factory. 

There are good things to say about this game...though at the moment they all escape me. To be fair, I will probably revisit this game in a few years, and either it will have improved, or my tastes will have evolved, but for now, I'm going back to Civ V.

This is a really great game with a ton to do. You play the role of a character whom has moved to the small town of Pellican Town and has begun a life on their now deceased grandfather's farm. It's a game very similar to Harvest Moon/ Rune Factory mixed with a little Animal Crossing from what I understand (haven't actually gotten to play either of those before).

Pros -
 - Very nice art style
 - Nice calming atmosphere, I have yet to run into anything that makes me feel frustrated.
 - A lot of stuff to do
 - Not very grindy (you do repeat tasks often, as you would expect, but nothing really feels like a grind)
 - A lot of interesting characters
 - Four Seasons with a completely different feel to each (different crops to grow, town events, and exploration aspects)
 - You can play as long as you want (The seasons will just keep going, so you can do whatever you want)
 - Doesn't really hold your hand
 - Story can be started whenever you want, or even never (I'm about 20 hours in and haven't progressed the story at all by choice)
 - Replayable (There's two different stories from what I understand and many different ways to run your farm and different characters you can marry in game.)

Cons - 
 - The tasks do get repetitive (although I don't really care some may)
 - The combat is kind of clunky
 - The pets are sorely lacking (can only pet them and fill their water bowl)
 - The general dialogue you can have with people feels lacking at times

All in all it is a very great game that I think is definitely worth the asking price, it seems like it takes about 40 hours to complete your first game and then probably somewhere around 20-30 for your second (assuming you want to see both stories) and the fact that you can play as long as you want is really great.

As a newcomer to this style of game I would highly recommend it to anyone who is interested.

Borderlands 3 is a game which has fun gameplay, but too many downsides to make it worthwhile for now.

First off, the game runs horrid. Low fps for graphics which could easily be ran better. I am struggling to get 60fps on a GTX 1070 on mid settings. Which is above the recommended. Sometimes it dips towards the 40s.

The story itself has potential that is just wasted on every place, the main antagonist barely interact with the player itself, you barely matter in the plot, with moments where you are wondering why your characters aren't doing anything in cutscenes while a character dies. 

Some new characters get added and get pushed hard, giving off a sense that the game wants you to like these characters, which really isn't working. 

The story is about lilith and the sirens, which is doable I suppose. but fails to do anything with it. You go from planet to planet, completing missions of which some really are filler. At the end, something 'heroic' and 'dramatic' happened and the game acts like it was a big moment, but it isn't. As the character which it is about did nothing nearly nothing throughout the story which actually helped the characters.

Gameplay wise, the game is alright. Guns feel good to shoot, character abilities are fun and have more depth compared to the other entries in the franchise. Barring some balance issues between characters, the game is fun.

BUT, the game is also incredibly easy throughout the story. There aren't any moments where it is a challenge to beat it.

Bosses are hit or miss. A handful are fun and have unique attacks which allow for fun gameplay moments which don't simply consist of shooting the bad guy till he dies. Sadly these bosses either die to quickly thanks to the aforementioned lack of challenge. 

Other bosses are just boring. So simple that you can just keep shooting without much effort, after which it goes into a invulnerable phase which is either short or incredibly long. (To keep it vague: The boss which physically transforms between all phases). Which brings me to another point:

There are many, MANY moments in this game where you are gonna be standing still, waiting for the characters to finish talking and allowing you to complete the objective and such. This game kills any fun you have on second playthroughs by forcing you to wait for minutes  at a time between objectives, missions and combat sections. YOU WILL SPEND AT LEAST 3 HOURS WITHOUT ANYTHING HAPPENING. Wether it is driving from A to B without much interesting happening, waiting for lilith to stop talking again, waiting for a animation to finish and more. As said before, this becomes tiring the moment you want to replay the game with another character you like, and more. 

You might ask yourselves why I give it a negative review even after I played 70+ hours, this is because there are other games you can spend your money on which offer more fun for the cash required. Such as Borderlands 2.

So to repeat what I said at the beginning: Buy this on sale.

This game is probably the best game ever made. In terms of the story, graphics (still breathtaking in 2018) and the complexity of the characters that are much beyond good and bad. The End is Nigh is a game by Edmund McMillen and Tyler Glaiel. If you're an indie games fan then you've at least heard about Ed. In my humble opinion this game is a masterpiece and definitely the best of his games. Keep reading if you want to find out why!

The atmosphere is rather gloomy, the Earth is dead and so are you, probably. By "you" I meant Ash, the protagonist black blob missing an eye. His last game cartridge finally breaks and so Ash is forced to go out. I haven't played any other game with that kind of feel. It is dark as I said, but also silly. Ghosts are kinda cute, too!

You explore varied areas, encounter more and more hazards, find secret places and chat with NPCs, including some characters known from Ed's previous games (as always!). Nearly every level, or rather screen has a tumor that you can collect. Secret areas can have mega tumors and/or game cartridges you can later play on your console. Cartridges are just harder levels with retro graphics and music that you can play at any time.

Graphics are really great, I love them. The music is gorgeous, too! I wasn't very pleased with Ridiculon's Isaac: Rebirth soundtrack, but oh boy they absolutely blown my head away with this one. Heavy guitar remixes of classic pieces, originally writen by "buncha dead dudes". Makes you shiver, for real!

Nice things:
+ Varied areas, secrets, NPCs
+ Unique feel
+ Tough as nails, you saw it coming didn't you?
+ Really great soundtrack

Wack things:
- Even though you can disable particle and some additional effects to improve FPS, ingame menu won't let you do all of these. You need to access .ini configuration file in game folder and add several lines. Look it up if you struggle with performance
- If you're more of a casual gamer then this game might not be for you. That's it, really

Okay so extra section. Everyone compares this to Super Meat Boy, so will I. I will start with saying that this is not SMB 2. 
This game is not even close to SMB, really. I'll tell you why.
▪ SMB has sprint, TEiN doesn't
▪ SMB is about picking levels while TEiN is an exploration of game's world
▪ SMB has wall jump, while TEiN uses hook/ledge jumping instead. It's neat!
▪ SMB has slippery controls while TEiN feels way more precise imo. Both of these are cool, of course
▪ More difference you'll notice on the way. Also many similarities. Just play both games, they are good.

Not too much to say, just as everyone in the review section has been stating this game is a masterpiece.
The visuals: graphics, the setting, scenery.
The audio: music, sound effects, voice acting ( dwarves <3) the exception being a bunch of voices in Touissaint, mostly knights, it feels as if they've just hired a bunch of random swedes to voice them.
The story presentation, dialogue.
Gwent!
etc etc etc, all amazing


With that said, here's a few specific things that stood out to me.

The hand crafted camera angles during quests/dialogue add this "cinematic" feeling, they show you some great scenery and backdrops and are just amazing, especially when you compare them to something like fallout where the camera during dialogue is completely static.

Just as many other open world games this game has a lot of side activities. But compared to those other games in which the side activities consist of you collecting a bunch of random shite unusable collectibles with no attached backstory or clearing 100 similarly looking camps of the same 5 generic dudes. (All of which just exist so that companies could say "this game has 200 hours of content!", looking at you Ubisoft :) ) 
Compared to those, most side activities in the Witcher have some storytelling attached to them (especially in the expansions) either through notes on the loot or prop placement around the location. These stories revolve around people in this universe, their lives, a trouble they might've gotten themselves in, a message that they wanted to relay to someone... These narrative bits usually don't have any connection to the main story of the game or Geralt himself but they add a lot towards the feeling that this is a living breathing world and while that might not be interesting to some players, having some context added to murdering a bunch of seemingly random mobs is always better than just having target dummies. Same as how collecting hidden recipes/swords/armor is more interesting than collecting some useless unusable trash that exists just to artifically increase play time.

Plenty of RPGs attempt to give you an illusion of choice but they do it in a lazy way with barely any effort placed into hiding that fact. Usually by showing completely the same dialogue/cutscenes no matter what decisions you've made previously.
Well, even though this game also uses the illusion of choice technique, it's not felt as strongly as in other titles because effort has been put intohiding it. And i think it really contributes to the feeling that your actions actually matter.

No hand holding when it comes to morality.


Cool little details/features

The way Geralt slides downhill is awesome and more games should take this approach.
The dialog skip is not bound to the same button as choosing the next line of dialogue, which prevents you from getting into situations where you accidently select the next line of dialogue when really, you just wanted to skip dialogue.
Dialogue choices which will end the dialogue (or get you to the next stage of dialogue).
The automatic movement of horses along paths where you don't have to steer them constantly along those paths (not perfectly executed but solid implementation and a great idea overall).
I don't think i've seen better implementation of trees and their bending in a game than in the Witcher, especially when you combine it with the amazing sound design.It truly feels special.

DUALSHOCK BUTTON LAYOUT

Small negatives

Too many fighting and racing minigames. They were nice at first but have overstayed their welcome.
Fall damage, Geralt isn't capable of falling from anything higher than 2 meters without dying, what?
The UI is cluttered, finding the exact potion or an item you want unless you remember them by their image is aids and the same applies to your "buff bar".
There were more but i cannot think of any of them of the top of my head right now.

Thankfully most small issues can be fixed with mods and this game has great mod support.

The big "bad" thing 

The combat.
Just as the first 2 games had mediocre combat at best to terrible at worst, i'd have to say this game follows those steps. The main major improvement is definitely the ability to use potions during combat.(which doesn't fit the lore, but in a game, gameplay comes first, right?) It does improves on the previous titles by a bit but it's mostly just from the production quality standpoint. 
The combat stays very spammy with an extremely small variety of moves, fast and slow attacks and rend and whirlwind as your "finishers". And that is really sad considering the amount of ways in which you can modify your character (4 different "talent trees", runeforging, mutations, set bonuses, stats). None of that matters if the base of your combat system is meh. Crossbows are pointless and don't really have a use except for underwater combat and getting flying beasts grounded. Signs are nice and all but they are quite weak (from my experience) and once again, you don't have a lot of options, you've got 2 choices for cc 1 "pure" defensive and 2 offensive ones. So, is combat shit? No. Is it average? Eh...i don't know...maybe it's average or somewhat good? (when you include all the ways in which you can improve/modify your character with talents/sets etc)
But when all the other aspects of your game are amazing, the Witchers combat being average is a letdown. Not to the extent that you can't enjoy it or that there is no variety in it at all, but still a letdown. Especially if you do not forget that at the end of the day, combat is the "heart" of the game.


So yeah, if there's anything at all to complain about in this game it's definitely the combat.

Nevertheless, as stated by so many people this game is a masterpiece. It's a must own if you're into RPGs and we really should commend and support devs such as CD Projekt Red for the work they've put it into this project. The free DLC, the expansions oozing with content... A company being this good to it's customers is really an exception rather than the rule these days.

Celeste is a very hardcore skill platformer with absolutely gorgeous pixel art graphics, I am personally iffy on the story but I know it is excellent for those who have anxiety and other issues. Everything about this game is wonderful, from the gameplay down to the music, but I can't say it's perfect because it really isn't. Despite how highly I recommend this game, I feel some of it's parts aren't that well thought out, some 'sections' or 'rooms' drag on without a checkpoint leaving you high and dry if you don't complete the level in a precise manner, it can be insanely unforgiving at many times and going for 100% really tends to suck the fun out of the game itself as you will find yourself attempting to get a strawberry for several minutes straight in trial and error and suffering if you're not a pixel perfect machine designed to beat every level like a TAS. I feel as though Celeste excels at what it sets out to do when it goes for more self contained rooms that last around 2 minutes to pass through with fairly simple yet challenging platforming, and fails at what it sets out to do when you find yourself in longwinded horizontally scrolling rooms with several obstacles, with one death sending you all the way to the beginning, which can quickly grow infuriating should you be near the end and slip up. I still highly recommend this game to anyone reading, but be prepared for trial and error, and do not go for 100% completion with the intent to have fun, playing casually will provide more than enough enjoyment on that front.

This game will scare you and it will also leave you wanting to know more and more as you progress. Read on if you wish. But TL:DR, its a good game with the occasional bugs here and there, but most can shrugged off if you play with friends. Buy it and play it alone for maximum fear or with friends to experience fear and funny moments together! I recommend this game! Oh and spoilers ahead!  

So we start off 'naked' and afraid. With a sh*t axe and some supplies from the plane, you begin your survival in the harsh island known as Peninsula. As you progress through the story, you'll find vague clues about what happened to the previous people that came there. You gotta explore though, its scary but you gotta do it or else you'll be stuck in the same place until you grow a beard and start talking to to the rocks.

Exploring is really really refreshing. All the caves are well done. Though there were some caves that were meh but they still managed to scare me and my friends. But in terms of exploring the island, that's where it gets fun. It can disorienting trying to find certain places because there's a sh*t load of trees, hence the name right? lel. 

In terms of AI, after awhile, they become smarter or atleast they seem to be, which increases your paranoia and fear. They'll ambush you when you least expect it and if you do things right, you'll get to see the FUN GUYS come to the surface and wreck your stuff. 

Items. Plentiful but, obviously as i mentioned, there are bugs and exploits but I won't need to tell you the exploits because you'll find out what they are on your own. BUGS, items disappearing when you load the game, some clues you can't pickup in caves which hinders your progression and lore knowledge and items sometimes drop out of the world and into the void. Which happened to me once after I killed my first rabbit. But hey, I fell from the sky afterwards, the rabbit? Did not. But meh, forgivable since there are tons of rabbits. Oh and to the devs, this is like the biggest issue I've had throughout my entire almost 60 hour playthrough. FIX THE DAMN LOG SLED! The thing is the most useful yet buggiest piece of shi* in Single and Multi Player.

Storyline? Vague but it manages to keep you wanting more. Like what happened to the people before us? Why are there so many tents? Why are the cannibals scared of The Red God? Oops. You have to find that out yourself. It was unpredictable and a bit sad at the same time. Not too sad though, you'll just feel bad the more you find out.

In terms of gameplay, yeah it does get repetitive but that's why the devs put caves and AI that seems to get smart. Explore and find ways to deal with the cannibals in Peninsula. I wish they added modding support, cause as of now, once you've built all there is to build and experiment with all ways to die, there isn't much to do after you finish the story. Except play it on Hard or Hard Survival, they both arent that different from each other, devs work your magic and make it harder please. Oh and if you plan on playing it again on different difficulties, I suggest you leave the game for a few days, get it off your mind and then play it again. That's how I get to feel the fear rush through me again while playing. Oh and I almost forgot, there are lots of visual bugs in multiplayer. Like imagine fallout face glitch but this happens while climbing the walls in caves, besides that, there's one bug where everyone in the server suddenly has the same face even after they died. Which is hilarious at first but then it gets stale.

All in all, if you stayed with me until here. Thank you for reading. I give this game a 4 out of 5 star rating cause bugs man. PS: This might get edited if there are any changes to the game. 

THANK YOU ENDNIGHT GAMES LTD FOR MAKING A GREAT GAME THAT MANY PEOPLE WILL ENJOY! Psst, it'd be nice if you could fix the bugs I mentioned. Thanks!
