Compared to the previous additions of the franchise, Civ VI is a flop. There are few postitives in this game. Those being the separate research trees, the districts system, and the advanced dialogue. However the negatives far outweigh the positives. First, the AI is terrible. All these bug fixes, and it still hasn't stopped them from being warmongering, religious zealots. Next, the game has yet to be cross compatible, leaving me to play the horribly flawed single player or Civ V instead. The game has been out for a little more than a year now, it's a shame. Finally, the DLC, which is the worst of all. 7 DLC civs that add up to a total of $32.95, not including tax? Absolutely ridiculous. Not to mention the balancing issues some of these civs have like Poland and Australia. Overall, Civ VI is a flop of a game and a bad addition to the Civilization franchise. If you're going to play a Civ game, play Civ V or any of the previous games.

It's a SimCade; it has equal parts of simulation and arcade to please both seasoned and new players. Unlike most "Simulators" on sale, it's very well made and accessible.

You start as a truck driver without a truck; complete some deliveries for others and get some loans and soon you have your own truck (and even your own company); the freights will lead you across the roads of a scaled version of western Europe while carrying a nice variety of goods; from chemical substances to cars. 

The landscape is beautiful but the cities are rather simple (not really a big deal though since you spend most of your time on highways).

Simulation is more on the arcade side, with the possibility of adjusting many parameters to increase the simulation level. With some practice, anyone should be able to drive well. It's highly recommended to play this game with a steering wheel or a controller.

Pacing is very relaxing; you'll spend most of your time managing the truck speed and route. Play your favorite song or podcast and enjoy the travel.

The modding community is awesome; you'll be able to completely overhaul your experience with more realism, cargo variety, truck models and maps, but the vanilla game should provide you many hours of fun.

In conclusion, it's a game for those looking for a different experience where fun does not come from the challenge but the gameplay itself.

You have to be open to this kind of game. It's not filled with action, it has long cutscenes (standard Hideo Kojima), and it's a lot of walking to and from places. There's huge amounts of dialogue, and at the start of the game, you will have absolutely no idea what's going on.

But. If you are open to that kind of stuff, and want to enjoy the game, you absolutely will. This is undoubtedly one of the best video games I have ever played. The world is incredibly unique and immersive, and traversing it always feels like a wonder, never a chore. Norman Reedus as Sam is a very nuanced, interesting, stoic character. Despite the threats of the BTs trying to kill you, the MULEs trying to steal your stuff, and the timefall rain gradually ruining every piece of cargo on your body, the game is actually quite peaceful to play.

I have 38 hours in the game and I'm still only on Chapter 3, as I keep getting sidetracked with side orders and road building. I'm barely even a quarter of the way through the story. 

If you want to enjoy this game, you will. But if slow burning, low action, long cutscene games aren't your thing, you won't like this game.

This game is simply one of the best platformers I've ever played. I'm surprised it took me so long to get this game. At it's core its a fun and fast paced game that will test your skills. Each chapter captivates the player in it's colorful and interesting environment. Each of these levels feels different from the other. New levels come with new mechanics that keep the game fresh as it captures your attention. It's challenging and unique. This game offers an experience to each kind of player. Whether you are a casual, hardcore, or completionist gamer, this game has something for you. 
-For the casual players there's a cute and lovable story as you travel in the boots of Madeline, a girl set out to climb Celeste, a tall and snowy mountain. If you struggle there is an assist mode to help you get through any tough obstacles. You'll never feel like you're missing out of the story! 
-For the hardcore gamers you can enjoy beating each level with a sense of accomplishment as each level gets progressively more challenging. Along the way you can acquire strawberries, a collectable item that displays above each chapter. These strawberries require that you beat certain rooms that are more tricky or challenging than usual offering great hardcore gameplay.
-For the completionists out there you're in for the treat when you discover that each stage has a much more challenging "B-side," 
levels that have the same atmosphere as the original, but task you with technical precision and quick thinking. Every level also contains a secret heart that awards the player with a heart icon on the chapter select screen. Don't even get me started on the true challenge that awaits you after "beating" the game. The extra content towards the end of the game makes it feel like you're not even half way done!
Over all my experience with this game has been phenomenal. I'm so glad that we live in a time where you can find small gems such as Celeste. I'd honestly consider this one of my favorite games of all time. I consider this wonderful game a true masterpiece and hope that you can experience the same feeling that I did at the very start of the prologue. I hope that the words that I've typed in this review help push you towards at least trying this small treasure of a game.

This is the first early access game I have ever purchased and it will definitely be the last. I acknowledge the fact that it is an "un-released" game but to charge this kind of money for something so underwhelming and unbalanced should not be allowed. The survival mechanic is an absolute embarassment when in a mater of a couple of minutes you can die from lack of water or food - it takes twice as many minutes just to reach the ingredients to make food or water. This means it's all you are going to do, make food and water. That's it. It is a shame because it's actually a really nice world to explore but the crafting simply robs you of real exploration. 

There is a mode allowing you to explore without the need to craft things to survive but playing this mode feels like your missing out on part of the experince that costs 20 bucks in the first place.

Also there is no surround sound so this ruins the atmosphere for me. Once again, it's a shame because the audio is actually good quality.

I do look forward to Subnautica's full release and truly hope they balance the survival mechanic as the concept is a really good idea but, I still think I've wasted 20 dollars. I can't recommend this early access game.

Allow me to parrot what everyone else is saying. Yeah. This game gud. Now for a brief breakdown:

Appearance/artstyle/'''graphics''': Basically Tim Burton (Morbid but Cute) meets Studio Ghibli (Gorgeously detailed and fluidly animated). Just look at those screenshots and tell me you can't make a wallpaper out of every single one of them.

Plot: more lore than plot, comes with being a soulslike. You get what you make of it, but if you do choose to engage, you'll find an intriguing world, likeable characters, and a narrative that will make a thought or two pass through your head.

Gameplay: Tight. Tight. Tight! This game just feels good to play. You're always in control in both platforming and combat (And I'm saying that as someone who beat the game with a mouse and keyboard), which is good because they intertwine. Your attacks feel meaty no matter how weak they are. It's simple, but there's a lot of depth to it and a variety of strategies you can use. It's challenging but it's fair, yada yada yada. The one criticism I see is that some isolated parts (ahem Godmaster) are significantly harder than the rest of the game. But I disagree since I managed to beat the Godmaster dlc (even if it took an embarrassingly long time) and I'm utterly garbage at videogames. So get, um... better.

(Also you can break every part of the scenery you pass by and that's always satisfying. Just a bonus)

Since I bought this game as part of a humble bundle, I'm pretty much obligated to buy Silksong at launch now, even if I won't like that game (which is not very likely). I'm in debt now because I DIDN'T spend a lot of money. That's what this game did to me. 

Very tempted to quit my job to become a Hollow Knight evangelist.

Garry's Mod is a fun and enjoyable game for all. Whether you prefer RPing and just playing privately, it usually will fit your needs. You can build houses, or have a blast killing traitors. If you are new and just looking to find a feel for the game there is many noob friendly servers that have lots of fun and enjoyable people that are willing to help you along the way. Although at first this game might seem a bit different and confusing its really actually quite simple. 

There are two main gamemodes that are the most populated and simple out of any, although there is also many others such as Prop-hunt or Stop it Slender. Dark Rp and TTT (Trouble in Terrorist Town) are the two that most people find themselves playing for the majority of there time on Garry's Mod.

Dark Rp is a city like semi-serious rp gamemode enviroment. There are many one of a kind custom servers that always have a twist that the others dont. Some are serious and some are just there to waste time and troll.

TTT (Trouble in Terrorist Town) is more of a first person shooter type game. It consists of three random classes that you are randomly assigned at the beggining of he round. Innocent, Detective, and Traitor
        Innocent: As an innocent you are supposed to just hunt around and try to catch the traitors killing one of your buddies and just being in the wrong ally with the wrong body.
       Detective: You are similar to the innocent but you are given tools to help find the traitors
       Traitor (fun): You are given the role of killing everyone that isnt a traitor (usually there is a few of you working together)             and you are given specal weapons that others dont have like knives crossbows and some others that will help you along the way. Just dont get caught killing.

153 Hours in to the game and I am still loving it...

Civilization V is my first game in the Civilization series and now that I got it I don't Understand why I never played the others.

You start the game off with one group of settlers and a warrior to protect them, from there you start building your civilization.
It's not like other strategy games where you literally build every single building, the map is devided into Hexagonal tiles with different resources, all you have to do is build your settlement and from there on expand to the surrounding tiles, as you play you unlock new buildings to upgrade your settlements, you can found new settlements as freely as you like but you always run risk of attack so make sure you have the proper amount of troops to protect those new found bottom feeding settlements of yours.

There are 5 ways to win the game: Domination victory, Science victory, Cultural victory, Diplomatic victory or a Score Victory.
But this means there are 5 ways for you to get beaten as well so you will need to not only keep an eye on your own civilization but your enemy's aswell, and know exactly when it's time to attack or ally up.

If you get tired of the standard game check out the scenarios, that is where the real fun begins, with scenario's that actually happened like the Boers vs the Zulu's in Africa, the Mayan's who feared the end of the world and all the troubles they faced like the french invading them with weapons they have never even seen before in their lives, the scenario's have it all.

And if that's not enough, Civilization V supports the steam workshop so there are endless mods for you to choose from to spice your game up even more.

The game is very easy to learn with the help of your advisers who even though they can be pretty annoying sometimes, make sure you know what you are doing and what the Consequences will be if you take a certain action. They will take good care of you.

My Rating 9/10 - (-1 the game sometimes feels like it's taking forever to finish, but there are settings to change the game speed which will sort this out for you, but I found that on Standard settings the game takes forever and on quick settings you can't help but feel extremely rushed. It would have been nice to have something in between. )

I just gotta re-review this... thing.

So, initially Rebirth was a really, really well crafted game. Yes, it had it's flaws, but it was still fun to play.
After all of it's "Updates" the game is now in a terrible state. And I'm not talking about bugs.
I'm talking about damn bad game design.
Of course - since it's a rogue-like - it's not supposed to be a walk in the park and I like challenging games even better than walking simulators.
So, what am I talking about?
- There are rooms, you DEFINITELY get damage in. So if you are not lucky(!) enough to have been given the right items to survive (a thing the game decides - not the player), you die.
- By the time many bullet sponge enemies were added. Instead of creating a new challenge / new enemies in a creative way, the developers seem to have "thought", that it's more fun to have enemies that take like 30 hits until they die.
• Talking about enemies... Isaac was never a bullet hell game. Nevertheless the developers "thought" that this would be a great feature to add. No, it's not. Those bullet hell bosses and rooms just don't work with this game.
- Overall (and after 800+ hours in this game) I kinda get the feeling that the game sometimes let's you win - and other times it's like in a troll mode or something. Then there suddenly seem to be no i-Frames, you take damage though not being hit and/or the game won't give you like a single key (but just when it's all you need).

In conclusion nowadays it feels like you only can have fun with this game, if the game wants you to have fun. And that's not my philosophy when it comes to gaming. Also knowing it was different back in the days...

TL,DR: Buy only if you have a time machine to go back to previous builds of the game. Nowadays it's just not that much fun anymore - sadly.

Does the thought of map wide forest fires excite you? How about watching an army of enemy colonist building earthworks and setting up mortars being vaporized by HE and Anti-grain warheads as your colonist call for fire? Or maybe expanding your tunnel base and experiencing absolute horror as mountain dwelling insectoids zerg rush your marble-floored home leaving nothing but blood and vomit as they instantly genocide your friends and family? Then get Rimworld.

If you want to experience: being ambushed my 29 raccoons with rabies, having a murder-bot 10000 land directly into your ornate kitchen and decimate your favorite chef, experience the most nail biting battles (since you actually give a shit about your colonist) as your 96 year old Harvard professor mows down enemy troops with a minigun; then is immediatly killed with an arrow straight to the brain stem all while your japanse K-pop prostitute turned farmer cuts down 5 enemy raiders using a a spear made of solid gold, then get Rimworld.

If you want to fine tune and plan out an elaborate literal concentration camp : harvesting human flesh to make lampshades and using slave labor to harvest cotton, chocolate and weird red mushrooms (which make good clothing somehow), or maybe taming an actual fucking dinosaur, only for said dinosaur to impale you and immediatly kill every single other human on the map, then get Rimworld.
 
And if you want to experience your colonist marry, cheat, intermarry, commit murder, or literally have such a mental breakdown that they unbury recently killed colonist and throw them on the dining room table while your other colonist try to throw a party....then well you get it

Get the game

Its been over 3 years since I aquired this game in its early stage of development and as it was coming to the end of said development I decided I would write a review. 
    
    This developer and game has been amazing. From a development standpoint this is how Indie games should be handled. Every single major update brought major new content to the game and with the content loads of fun. The developer has actively worked with the community and the community has worked hard to improve his game. The game was fun from start to end of the development and well done.

    From a gameplay standpoint, the design and idea behind Rimworld is amazing. The story-teller system and the combat system were the two biggest parts of rimworld that kept it stressfull, fun, and hillarious as other reviews have shown. The colony management has remained a fun task through the whole game working tirelessly to keep your group of fallen rando's alive. 
 
    Unfortuantly I don't have any stories of my past eperiences (Or horrors, which were more common), However I do have a word of advice. BUY THIS GAME.

Overall, awesome game, very immersive, has a great sense of humor and totally worth the money.

app_name: Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy
review:
Super rage - for real.  The reason I wouldn't recommend isn't because it's a rage game; it's because of the *mechanics* of the controls (not the controls themselves).  The mouse is your only control and it's how you move about; the problem is the position you move your mouse to becomes dynamic, in that it doesn't remain in it's intended position - that's why I'm giving a thumbs down.  

Imagine moving your cursor on your desktop then you stop, while your mouse is physically sitting still, your mouse cursor moves back a few inches on screen; that's exactly what happens in-game.  It throws off the cursor location in relation to the physical position of the mouse - so the next thing you know, the mouse is almost off your desk while you're trying to get your guy to move.  

It feels like a hidden mechanic that was intentionally designed to make this a rage game.  Unlike the in-game dialogue which claims getting over the obstacles themselves was the challenge and he left them there because of it.  The obstacles aren't the problem, the mechanics of the controls are; there is no option to tighten up the correlation between mouse and cursor, only to increase mouse sensitivity (which does help a bit, but not nearly enough).

Congratulations to all of you who decided to stick with it and beat the game.

Edit: If you turn on mouse tracking sync (or whatever it's called) then the controls become much more manageable.  Unfortunately, the game still isn't fun.  The jankiness is still in the controls to a much less degree, but still there, and the consequences for making a mistake with these controls is far too dire, which means the game still isn't fun.

I'm just not masochistic enough to continue.  I'm sorry for being such a failure. :(

An extremely well designed, groundbreaking game in a new era of Doom games.
The old classics such as Ultimate Doom and Doom 2 has the ability of "never gets old/boring" and I always enjoy playing them both, now Doom Eternal joined to this tirinity, as it has the (lack of better word) magic too.
The levels are very well designed, the LORE(!) is very fascinating, the enemy categories are very well made, the bosses are unique and challenging especially the Final Iconic One (pun intended).
The weapons have their own roles and the weapon mods are awesome!
The new super weapon -The Crucible- is extremely powerful, while the old king BFG 9000 still wears the crown.
The events, skins and collectibles (and much more for you to explore) also makes it fun and a reason to play!
All in all, I'm really really REALLY critic when it comes to judge a game but this one is flawless in my opinion.
10/10 ---A MUST PLAY--- !!!

Original Review:

I'll start with all the issues I have with the game:

- Smoke is [b]always[/b] bugged. When I started playing this game in spring, smoke would just vanish suddenly. They claimed to have fixed it (they didn't), then when they managed to fix it, they introduced a new bug: At random occasions some players can see silhouettes through the smoke, giving them a huge advantage. This is very frustrating and completely unacceptable in a game which requires you to use smoke.

- The game is terribly optimized. After some fixes I found in the forums and guides I could get it to run well, but at first I had around 100 fps (on medium, with an RTX 2070 Super) with sudden drops to below 30 fps. Then the game would just run at 25-50 fps until I restarted the game.

- The PvP mode Push is the only game mode which is fun for me. Competitive mode only exists for one of the main game modes.

- Cheaters can reach lvl 72 (for reference, I'm lvl 85 or so after 100 h) without getting banned. There's nothing you can do about it either, since they can just rejoin after getting kicked.

- Low player count. In Europe, it can happen that there is only one server with people on a workday. I have never managed to play a round of Competitive, because it is never populated.

- Lvl is purely time-based. No matter how good or bad you are, 99% of your XP gain is determined by the time you spend playing.

- Customization is either ugly, or will lead to you having a disadvantage because you stand out.

- Fun heavily depends on how well your team works together (at least for me). This can make the game incredibly fun, or very frustrating.

- Vaulting is a pain and often doesn't work properly.

- You will frequently get killed by completely random grenade (launcher) and RPG spam.

- Might be hard to get into at first.

(Edit: Almost forgot this:
- There are "restricted zones" in which you cannot shoot (so as to prevent spawnkilling probably), but they're very weirdly placed. Spawnkilling is still possible, however flanking can be hard on some maps due to this. As an example, on one map the zone starts immediately behind the building in which the objective is, which means you cannot enter from behind or briefly go outside to kill incoming defenders.)

Now for the good things:

+ Requires teamwork, and most of the community is willing to work together and to aim for the win, rather than the highest K/D rate.

+ Commander/Observer combo is an amazing idea and feels so...strategic.

+ Great gunplay, nice feeling of recoil and big differences between weapons.

+ Weapons have different customization and make them feel even different.

+ Classes have distinct equipment and roles.

+ The two factions feel different.

+ Sound is great, nice directionality of footsteps etc.

+ Maps are quite nice.

Overall it's a great game and I definitely recommend it, but it is far from perfect. Consider all the negative points before buying this game.
Should buy it with DLC

vermintide 1 was good but classes were limited. Vermintide 2 expanded each for more diverse play styles.
positives:
-the talent tree and class skills. while the number of weapons is a little bigger then vermintide 1, the skills for each class and advanced class will make sure you find the play style that you like. You may have to grind out classes if you like playing a sword and shield character, but worth it for the perks.
-The flow of the game is perfect, linger too long and elite enemies or a swarm will force you forward. 
-Randomness of spawns. Maps are non changing and except for certain mobs, most encounters on replayed maps have differing enemy numbers and types. The elites that chase you at periods never have a set pattern and can be annoying. The bosses can spawn, have had 3 in a map, or not at all. can create a near impossible to survive situation but that adds fun to the game.
Negatives: 
Few maps and once you learn them, you can predict what is going to happen and prepare for it. wish they had more maps or a map creator so players to make their own and upload them to the workshop. not sure how that would work since maps are unique and don't have repeating, cookie-cutter objects but as a player of rift and dimensions, I would welcome a chance to build my own
No save points; maps are large and while it does make sense for a party that dies to start over on normal and higher, the easy levels where you are learning the game should have a few save points. There are a few maps that i spent 5-6 hours trying to clear 1 map multiple times on EASY before beating it.
An extremly good game, really shows what a small team and a BIG dream can do! Just goes to show that even the smallest things can be a big influence.

[spoiler]Cave Johnson, we're done here.[/spoiler]

Bottom Line Up Front:
A Hat in Time is a solid 3D platformer which for the most part, doesn't make a whole lot of waves in the genre. The platforming is good, offering enough wiggle room to allow you to correct any mistakes you may make (if you act quickly enough) and giving you a real sense of wonder as you explore the worlds offered. By no means is this a pixel perfect, difficult platformer. The game feels much more focused on experiencing the world than on creating a difficult and rewarding experience like some other platformers choose to do. The game progresses less linearly than some other platformers with smaller stories contained within the world rather than one larger story that takes you through the game. The game has a great tone, being fun and lighthearted, with a few darker stories that appeal to the adults who grew up with games like these as kids.

The core gameplay loop:
You primarily play levels on a world where you'll earn a timepiece. Most levels you earn the timepiece by exploring and solving small puzzles or platforming challenges until you reach the end. There are a handful of bossbattles in the game that are all unique and fun. And some levels ask you to complete very specific missions to unlock the timepiece. Once you've gotten the timepiece on that level you can go back for collectibles, but I moved quickly from timepiece to timepiece. As you progress, rifts will open on levels you've already completed and you can go back and get another timepiece by finding the rift and completing the short platforming challenge there. As you progress gathering collectibles you can decorate your ship with a handful of relics, decorate your character with new outfits and hat styles, and outfit past levels with new soundtracks. As you progress you also gather yarns which you'll use to stitch new hats, allowing you to interact more and more with the levels you've already completed to unlock collectibles you weren't able to reach when you first went through. You can also purchase badges which affix to your hats giving your character different abilities or gameplay modifications (grappling hook, ability cooldown reducing, changing your sprint mechanic into your character jumping on a solid gold scooter, giving you only one heart, making all words spoken to your character come out as mumbling are just a few).

The Hats:
This games major gimmick is the inclusion of several different hats which each have different functions. You build these up over the course of the game, but I got most of them fairly quickly and easily. The hats are the root of puzzle solving and world exploration and quickly feel like a natural extension of your character. 

The Set Pieces:
The game offers 4 world setpieces (with two planned in future DLC) which are varied and unique. Each world has its own set of characters (the NPCs in this game are an absolute blast), enemies, and themes. Each world has a series of levels with different objectives which reward a time piece. Along the way to getting your time piece, you'll pick up various collectible yarns which you'll use to create new hats, rift tokens which you'll use to unlock outfits and music tracks, and relics which are trophies you'll take back to your ship and decorate it with. These worlds are varied experiences. 3 of the worlds are contained within one map; all of the levels/missions on these worlds are different objectives within that map. 1 world takes you through a variety of very small, linear maps which focus more on telling the specific stories of that level. In between these worlds you can wander around Hat Girl's space ship which is a colorful collection of rooms and (as the game progresses) NPCs. There are three rifts per world you can go back to find and complete. One of those rifts is always a pink rift which is longer and tells a story about that world. There also seem to be hidden diary pages in the game that you can unlock.

Replayability and value of time spent:
Let's face it. This game costs half the price of a AAA title (without a sale it's $30 at time of this review). I bought it at full price and at the time of review I've gotten 10 hours out of it. In these 10 hours I've beaten the entire story and collected all of the time pieces, but not quite all the collectibles or achievements. If I wanted to get the rest of the achievements and collectibles, It'd probably take me another few hours. That's what you're being offered with the core game. However, the developers have enabled in depth modding support allowing you to download from Steam Workshop community levels, new hats, new outfits and characters. I haven't spent too much time wandering around the workshop but I did see a few high quality mods that offer to extend the in game experience significantly. At the time of this review, no additional DLCs have come out and I don't know what their pricing scheme will be, but they also offer to extend the gameplay by about 50%. If you're a person who wants a lot of hours per dollar spent, this game might not be for you (yet! you can always wishlist it and wait for a good sale or wait until there's a lot of high quality workshop content to experience) but if you're a person who's okay with a game offering 10 or 20 fun hours with something like I am, then it's a good option if you like the premise of the game.

Final Note:
This game is fun for what it is. I'd recommend taking the time and money to experience it if you feel like it meets your personal criteria for how much content a game should offer. If you're looking through a lighthearted romp through a series of unique and colorful worlds with hilarious characters to meet along the way, this is the game for you. It's in my opinion, the best so far of the 3D platforming collectathon spiritual successors.

This game has achieved what no game achieved for me in the last two years since I played Gris. I stared at the credit screen after finishing the game completly lost in thoughts. Even a couple of days after the ending I still love listening to the music and keep thinking about the story of the game.

Towards to later half of the game the story starts to become extremely exciting and intriguing. All main characters are written authentic and intresting. 

The gameplay is defintetly different from any other game I've played in the past. This does not mean worse. But its not an action game most of the time. At the beginning of the game you are mostly tasked to bring serveral pakets to their destinations. However more to the end of the game you get many equipments which not only make the transportation easier but also give you the option to be creative on how to get to your destination. I really enjoyed that aspect. 

The combat seems to be a basic third person stealth game. If you like this kind of gameplay, Death Stranding does a great job on that.

I strongyl encourage everyone to atleast give this game a try and see for yourself how you like it.

I've played a lot of Rimworld, and I'm about to tell you a story.

I messed around with my starting crew, made a character based off of me, and two semi-randomized ones that ended up to be female.

The colony started as normal, but very soon after starting, my character formed a relationship with one of the girls. It went well for a while but she eventually broke up with me, because that's just how life is, man. Soon after, another character joined up; another chick. She imediately starts flirting with me and I keep turning her down. And then things started getting a little whack.

A drop pod landed with a wounded survivor. I check their stats and traits. Another girl. A drug addict. No particularly good skills. .... Also, for some strange reason, already my lover. But also not already joined the colony.

So I send someone out to patch her up. She was in REALLY rough shape, in a coma for almost an entire week. The entire time my character suffering from the "I want to sleep with my lover" debuff.

Times were rough.

She then, eventually recovers to full health... but refuses to join the colony. She slowly, very slowly walked off the map, and I never saw her again. But, she forever remained my lover.

I kept playing, and after more and more people joining up, I had 8 or 9 colonists. And every single one other than my character... was female. Constantly they flirted with me, trying to form a relationship, including the girl who dumped me at the start. But my character was very loyal to his lost lover. I would not betray her. I was surrounded by thirsty females and EVERYONE was misserable from being rebuffed time and time again.

And that is how I accidently made an anime harem in Rimworld.

TL:DR 
For the price of €17 "X Rebirth Complete " is really a great game if you are into sandbox, space, and sim.  

Dont mind the overal "Mostly Negative" reviews because they are mostly when the game was in 1.0-ish. Now the devs have made it into 4.0 and the bugs is not to befound and perforamance is good (see speccs below)

2016-06-27:  
With 6 hours into the main story there seems to be tons to do and the space feels endless with many paths to pick. The atmosphere is tick and just slowly fly past a forest/farm on a large space ship is a great audiovisuall experience :). 
The ship control feels right with the mouse/keyboard as well as the handcontroller and the game runs great on a "old" 680 with the resolution 1920x1200. I would recommend a SSD for this game because of the small load times will not be felt such as when an old HDD is used.   


2016-07-28:
20 hours in and the game is becoming better and better. Amazing momement to send the troops to another ship and actually see the swarm of small ships land on the other ship while the rest of the crew is nuking it with laser...

2016-08-11: 
Im at work thinking about how to make the big buck with a new trading strategy that Ive slept on. The game is getting more fun, complex and better looking for each hour... 2016 GOTY for me.

2016-12-19: 
New graphic card (690) and the SLI support is not good at all, you can force SLI by having it set to ALT 2. Works quite ok. But Ive finally having some spare time to roam around. Making my first space station and its really fun to see it built in real time.
Also the the game will get another update with a new X-rebirt in...VR! The devs way to care for their games should be the golden standard for game devs :).

2017-08-06
70 hours and I finally completed the game storyline, built a base with 6/10 parts done and I can say that this game has opend my eyes for space sims. Before X-rebirth I did mostly enjoy fantasy/horror games and now Im sitting with an Oculus rift and are playing Elite dangerous and X-rebirth VR. So great work devs for creating such a fun and atmospheric game.

Base game: 10/10
Heart of Stone DLC: 11/10
Blood and Wine DLC: 12/10

The base game has a full 80-100 hours of content if you're willing to sit down and look through every nook and cranny in this game. On sale, you can get this amount of game for only $12! It's an actual steal! The graphics are amazing, still holds up as one of the most beautiful games in 2019. It's also incredibly well optimized, even people on average computers can enjoy the beauty of this game. 

Both of the DLC's for this game together add another 80-120 hours on content. You can get the Game of the Year Edition for $15 on sale!!! That includes base game AND all the DLC!!! A game worth 300-400 hours of content for only $15? That's not a steal, that's grand theft! Incredible DLC, both of them. Hearts of Stone is an expansive story to the game, add more interesting characters and paths. Blood and Wine adds a whole new map to the game, in which is the most beautiful expansion to a map I've ever seen. The story to Blood and Wine is like a whole 'nother game on its own, its incredibly well done.

CD Projekt Red didn't only knock it out the park with this one, they sent the ball to space. It's a worthy purchase, its a game I'd say every PC on earth should have, along with Garry's Mod. I'd say, buy this game when its not on sale, support the developers. THIS is how an open world RPG should be done, and it's now a game I use the gauge other RPG's. There's a reason this game gets so much positive reviews. Don't sit and wonder if you should buy, just buy it. 

I rate this game (DLC included) a solid 12/10. GG CD Projekt Red

This is the first time I write a review of a game. Though I fell in love with many many games before, this game is simply like never I saw before, so much that I had to post a review! I usually wait for the sale to buy a game, but when I played the demo I just couldn't wait and bought the game right away!
I am fulfilling all my OCDs with this game.. simply euphoric!

Many others explained what the game is, so I won't bother with details, but I will say what I feel about it. It is one of those games where you keep saying five more minutes and end up having played 6 hours. The addictive element in it is that it preys on your completion desires. You want to build a mining machine, aka miner, that harvests iron ore for you, for which you’ll need coal, which you can harvest by another miner, and transport on conveyer belts that will then feed into both machines. How do you get that into the miners? Well you’ll have inserters that will feed the miners, but these miners need energy themselves. Why Yes! That would be coal, inserted into them by other inserters, that in turn need coal for energy. That’s just the first 5 minutes, or the very first 15 as you are still discovering the game.

I could write pages about this game, except that I’d rather be playing it instead, which I will do, every day, for the rest of my days!

Given the hours I've wasted on this game I can hardly criticize it too much given its compeling qualities, but it does have a few minor annoying "glitches" or gameplay/interface issues; small things that get on your nerves after many hours of playing and to be fair they all feel like the result of a lack of people/resources and inadequate quality control. I had a long list of these "glitches" here but deleted them because it would put you to sleep, but if you play this game you have a list of your own and again they are all minor and forgivable. The game is relaxing given its turn-based nature and the music!! - the music is pretty darned beautiful at times. The amount of factors that form a sort of web you have to monitor and manipulate to do well give this game its replay value. 8/10

This is a really fun game that I would recommend to anyone.

That being said, this game has some significant issues. For one, there are some pretty annoying bugs that you can encounter especially when starting up the game. There are also some dubious balancing choices, for example: High attack speed weapons (Rapier, Cleaver, Dagger, etc.) are far too effective because of how difficult they are to block and because of how they can block literally anything you throw at them, even stuff like Battleaxes and Broadswords. Specific weapons such as the Executioner's Sword are also a bit unbalanced (it really needs to cost more to equip). Not to mention the fact that most of the Frontline maps blatantly lean to one side (of course the real meat of the game comes from Deathmatch but that's besides the point). Ranged weapons and cavalry can also be annoying, but I wouldn't consider them broken. Finally, I've heard a lot of talk about dubious cheat protections that has a tendency to ban innocent people more then actual cheaters.

Despite all that I still think this is a great game with some fantastic potential and I'm sure all the issues listed in this review will be fixed in the future.

This game is nothing short of fantastic.

The world, characters, and dialogue create a truly immersive experience. Nearly all quests feel unique, as if each one is telling a different story. And yet, so many of the quests manage to connect and influence the overall narrative. I spent over 100 hours in my first playthrough, and immediately began another so I could see what happens when different decisions are made.

For the amount of content, the number of bugs in this game is surprisingly low, and I've yet to encounter one that is critical in nature (i.e. preventing me from proceeding with the story).

My only gripe with this game is that the skill tree felt very underwhelming. I felt locked into a small subset of all of the skills available to me, and at times didn't even bother spending my skill points since you cannot use all of the skills you learn simultaneously anyway. There are significant portions of the skill tree that I never explored with my first playthrough - and I don't really feel encouraged to in my next playthrough either.

Fortunately, the skills are but a fraction of the content available in this game, and with all things considered, don't detract from the gameplay experience.

If you're looking for a game with a sense of humor, detailed characters, mountains of content, and an immersive story, then you cannot go wrong with this game.

REVIEW EDITED AT BOTTOM

I only have a little more than 100 hours on this game but I've been consistently watching streams of it since it came out and have kept up with it since longgg before I finally picked up my own PC. It used to be pretty balanced, with balance patches here and there mixing up the meta. 

Now, this 1v4, intentionally imbalanced, "survive against all odds", horror game has become a 1v4 "try and get a kill against all odds", surprisingly balanced for a 1v4, bully-the-killer game.

Over the last few months, patches keep coming out that directly address complaints of survivor mains, then either ignore, barely touch on, or outright claim it's not a problem whenever killer mains have any complaints of things in game that had really ought to be changed. This has resulted in the survivors being able to negate things the killers do that take a lot of effort (outplaying a survivor to get two hits on him, hooking someone, etc.)  by just standing in the right spot, equipping one perk forever, or doing one skill check.

Despite the survivors becoming more and more unnecessarily powerful, and the people who play mostly killer continuously and loudly voicing their concerns, the developers release patch after patch after patch and have developer live streams where they announce that they will not be working on things the killers would like changed at any point in the near future, but have many plans to tend to the wishes of the survivors. I used to be a killer main and this was my most played game. Now I sometimes get back on to play survivor, but I've moved onto other games. It's a crying shame. Do not buy this until the devs make an effort to fix it, which, if the last handful of awful patches are any indication, won't be any time soon.

EDIT 1: I definitely purchased this game at full price, I'm not sure why it says I got this for free...

EDIT 2: I've more than doubled my hours since this review, and I can say now that the game is in a better place than it was at the time of the above review. The developer (BHVR) has purchased the full rights of their game from their publisher (can't remember the name), and it has been only great stuff since then. There's been way more communication, way more use of the play test server for big changes, and way more ACTUALLY listening to the community. I'm far happier now with the game than I was before, and I'm happy to change my review to positive.

Obligated to say maybe this more positive experience is because I'm now a survivor main...  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Basically you have to build houses to grow your village. But as it grows, you have to be careful with the amount of children:
- Too many new houses at once: too many new children will be born, the adults may not be able to provide enough food and firewood, resulting in starvation/freezing.
- Too little new houses built: your people may become old and die before they have children, reducing your population.

Once you realize how the game works, you will spend lots of time in the beginning of each game trying to figure out where to put each building to take advantage of the map.

I was surprised in late game when I discovered that the Market (which I thought was useless), is actually the key to build a successful big city.

I'll start with the clear fact that this is an amazing game. You can see just fom trailers hw much love and time was put into this game. The story is incredible, the boss fights (Which are the main part of the game) are incredible, the abilities and animation are incredible. There are not many reasons to not buy this game. Only downside is that it can be slow at some points especially if you're having trouble. But if you push through, the reward is spectacular. It's weird to say, but the most fun part of adventuring through the open world of Hollow Knight is to spend 15 minutes or maybe even 30 minutes trying to beat the next boss, figuring out his/her attack patterns, and the reward of defeating the boss is never underwhelming. If you're waiting for the game to go down in price, then don't, do the devs a favor and buy the game full price. If you really want to wait, it's understandable, and enjoy the game (it's not hard to XD).

One of the best RPG's I've ever played.  Ranked high up there with the other Witcher games, Elder Scrolls, and the Fallout series of games.  The game is HUGE.  I did all the quests until about 2/3 of the way into the story and wanted to see the end, so I hurried up, but then I checked my time and I had played over 120 hrs! lol  A lot more was in store for me, and I wanted to beat the game on the hardest difficulty (1st play was on 2nd hardest), so here I go again!  Story and characters are great.  Dialogues and speech acting is superb.  Graphics are awesome.  The side quests are usually as exciting and adventurous as the main story's quests.  Gwent is one of the best mini-games I've played and I've spent countless hours just playing other players with this card game.  Many ways to play this game, full combat, full sign (mage), full alchemist or a combo of any.  My first run was a combo of combat and sign, mostly sign.  Second time around I'm going to try either a full sign or sign/alchemy.  Did I say this game is huge?  It is.  Just when you think you're getting close to the end, it grips you in for a longer journey.  At no point did I feel the story was too bloated and long.  It's very detailed.  Most of the side quests are very interesting and the choices you make in the game do make a difference in how the story ends.  Without regret, I'd recommend this game to my friends,  anyone that loves the Witcher series, whether you have played the first two or not, or anyone that loves RPGs.

Ja, das gute Dead by Daylight. Oder sollte ich sagen Dead by Buglight? Bzw. Dead by Loadingscreen? Das Spiel hat seine Macken. Teilweise sind Bugs bis heute nicht gefixt,oder es werden einfach Killer zu Tode generft, wie z.B. der Legion. Die Nurse wurde letztens auch generft und sie macht seitdem kein Spaß mehr.
Es kann lustige Momente geben,oder eben “ oft “ Momente in denen man die DbD Logik nicht versteht. Ein Beispiel: Die Hitbox ist auch so eine recht negative Sache, die mal korrigiert werden sollte. Teils wird man noch getroffen, obwohl man schon 5m weiter steht.

An sich macht das Spiel schon Spaß! Mit Freunden noch mehr. Durch die Erneuerung mit dem Archiv,hat man jetzt Aufgaben die belohnt werden, wenn man sie erfüllt. Ich finde dies ist eine gute Sache,weil es das Spiel noch mehr fesselt,was es ohne hin schon tut. (sehe Stunden)! Frustration ist allerdings vorprogrammiert, ebenso wie die Toxische-Community. Wenn man sich zu sehr aufregt, sei es durch die Killer,oder Survivor. Weil aus der Survivor Sicht die Mitspieler z.B. Null Teamwork kennen,oder sonst wie dumm anstellen. Dann sollte man lieber eine Pause machen und später wieder Spielen, oder einfach besser mit Freunden spielen, was meiner Meinung nach  ohnehin mehr Spaß macht und man kann sich absprechen. 

Was ich allerdings nicht verstehe (mal aus der Sicht des Killers), sind die teabaggenden Survivor beim Ausgang. Die denken immer, sie wären total lustig und gut spielend, wenn sie am Ausgang stehen und 1m vor der sicheren Flucht sind. Wenn ihr rausgehen könnt, dann macht es bitte. Aber gammelt nicht Ewigkeiten vor dem Ausgang nur, um zu warten bis irgendwann der Killer kommt um ihn dann zu teabaggen! Ekelhaftes Verhalten!!! Für Anfänger, die komplett neu sind im Spiel ist es sicherlich hart und ich kann mir vorstellen, dass sie schnell gefrustet sind.

Coming from someone who mainly plays open world action games, The Binding of Isaac is still my favorite game. The amount of content, challenge, and resulting feeling of accomplishment makes this game incredibly addictive. At 250 hours I have not seen everything, and I may never see everything due to the amount of challenge. I wouldn't say I am one of the better Isaac players, and even though I am not good I still enjoy every moment of this game. The game runs at a smooth 60fps on just about any computer which is a very reassuring quality in games as it levels out the playing field unlike Isaac 1.0. The Afterbirth DLC is something I would definitely reccomend also. It adds about 100 items, an entirely new and addictive greed mode, new mechanics and features, as well as my favorite, new synergies. 

Even if the game is not on sale, it is worth the $26 for the full game. I have had more fun with this game than any $60 AAA game and hope you do too!

But this is my review of Dead by Daylight and its a good game, and it gets my thumbs up.

While I only played this game shortly, I feel that they lacked creativity and design overall in the game. The setting is small but doesn't make a lot of sense. In fact, I feel this is a knock off of the idea of  the game Damned, except the maps do not change. 
- The graphics are nice but nothing special considering the small size.
- The controls are easy to pick up......extremely simple.
- The sounds are set.
- The characters look is decent.

However the following is all that needs to be fixed/currently broken which is what you are buying now regardless of its current stage.
- The killer's wipe down of the blade after each attack is not only annoying but retarded in the sense that...why? Since it takes multiple hits to hurt someone critically, you are forced to go half speed while wiping down the blade before you are allowed to return to normal speed. It shows lack of creativity/design. 
- Control movements when interacting with the environment(pushing down the numerous crates and barriers) is non fluent and all movements similiar to this are the same. There is no chance for this fail, different style of it, etc.
- Takes you 2 seconds to stick someone up on the spike but takes the people half of a second to get them down regardless of how long they are up on the stick. This again seems to be a lack of creativity not to mention really bad design. Being stabbed multiple times and they are able to get away at half speed. 
- The crashing of this game is about 3/5 chances as the killer. This means the game is over and 0 xp. Way to high!
- No XP for playing with friends.
- Match making is horrific
- Skills? Why?
- Paid beta test of this game with the devs not listening to the community.

It's been over a decade since I first played HL2: Ep2. Replaying it today is a delightful return visit to the greatest FPS saga of all time. The voice-acting, pacing, and in-game cinematics still hold up. The Source engine has aged gracefully over the past 15 years, and while the texture assets look a bit blurry on a large monitor, the Half-Life art style remains timeless.

Episode 2 adds a pair of nasty enemies (the hunter and strider) that are much harder than anything encountered in the earlier chapters of HL2. Veterans will enjoy the added challenge. The gravity gun is as satisfying to use as ever and the vehicle sequences are more varied than the endless driving stages in the original HL2.

Unfortunately, the game ends on a cliffhanger. Will we finish the saga of Gordon Freeman? Is HL3 ever going to come out? Only Gaben knows for sure.

I actually had the OST before I even played the game. The OST is bomb. As a casual gamer who normally doesn't play platformers, I can say that the gameplay on default settings is tough as nails and there are times where it can be downright brutally difficult (although, not impossible). The game requires concentration, problem solving, patience and a whole lotta persistence.

There are assist options that make this a helluva lot easier, and I only used it once, but I realized that the game would be super easy with it on, so I think the game is best played on default (as intended). There's also a thing about my pride.

 I eventually beat the A-side of the game (stopped before doing the core, and B and C side) so I can say its definitely doable. I enjoyed the story for the most part. I would recommend this game for someone who enjoys challenges and has enough persistence to back it up.

Really really good game, and I would recommend it to anyone who likes Doom 2016 or any other Doom game. I love the Doomslayer and how the game plays. Overall it's super solid, the story is somewhat engaging but I have to say I really prefer the Doom 2016 vibes, the animations felt waaaaaaay more curated and alive, the demons and graphics were way more fearsome and overall I think it's a more polished game EXCEPT from the gameplay mechanics. In this Eternal completely beats 2016.

Goods:
-Super good game mechanics
-Greater mobility than 2016
-Hell lot of new demons and finishers to them
-Skins for everything!
-Good story.
-Graphics (I still prefer Doom's 2016, even knowing they wanted to be more faithful to the old doom demons... But they ARE good)
-Rip
-Tear

Improvable:
-Codex entries... God I love the story but I would rather have had a bit more of it explained over voice notes or cutscenes I don't know
-SnapMap. I think Eternal could highly benefit from it, and I'm not a huge fan of battlemode personally
-Battlemode is meh at best

Whole campaign with all unlockables upgrades, etc... took me around 30 hours in Hurt me plenty. So more or less same as 2016, a bit more I would say even. It takes a bit to get used to the gameplay mechanics,  but I think after mission 3 the game just turns waaaaay better for some reason in case you feel the game is not clicking the first 2 missions. 

Also, Marauder is not so bad once you kill a couple of them and know which gun to use, keep moving and take advantage of everything at your disposal!
Its a great game that offers a lot of fun for the price, and no micro transactions that the company try to rinse your bank account with either :)

This is the most accurate and enjoyable possible game version of the profession of PC Building and Repair Person.  Starting a new day and walking into the hallway of your little business to see cardboard boxes lining the walls, containing PCs of new customers and parts you've ordered, then flipping on the lights and getting to work is one of the most addictive game experiences I've had in a long time.  After assembling, disassembling, virus scanning, benchmarking and overclocking, you put the last box away to be delivered, confirm completion in your emails, maybe buy a few good deals off PCBay, then shut down your comp, flip off the light and walk out the door.  The gratification is palpable.  You will love this game.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is quite possibly the greatest RPG I have ever had the pleasure of playing. The world is rich in lore and feels filled with things to do, the dialogue/writing is intelligent and thought provoking, and the general gameplay is continuously enjoyable. The game is visually stunning as well, which is only further improved through the use of mods.

This is not to say TW3 is without faults, for example the UI can be finicky to traverse and the horse which is your main source of transport has a tendency to fight your inputs. There are also some slight balancing issues in terms of combat and merchants however I can confidently say none of these faults seriously detracted from the gameplay experience.

The Witcher 3 is an impressive feat by CDPR and I can only hope their future games maintain the same quality.

I'm not a typical TCG or deck building card game type of person but I greatly enjoy playing Artifact! It hits all the sweet spots that I enjoyed in the following ways:

1. Plays more like a strategic board game where you should be planning your moves in advance along with some backup exit/retaliation strategies.
2. Positional play, such as in poker, is very valuable.
3. Comeback potential huge. I know everyone says the red deck is OP but the game is not as straightforward as that. The right combination of cards can neuter a red deck by the second round.
4. I love dota lore, voice actors and interactions between cards are high quality.
5. Pretty good emphasis on social play / playing among friends. We're really into discussing what cards we have / strats related to it right now.
6. Lastly, teaches you accountability because now you have no one but yourself to blame for your shitty decision making, a self-reflective skill sorely missing in most people.

To address the monetization:
-Packs cost 2.50 CAD, game costs 26.99 CAD and you receive 10 packs with that initial cost. You are effectively paying 1.99 CAD for access to the game.
-Have you ever played a TCG with that one friend who decides to unload thousands of dollars on ultra rare cards and sets that you have no hope of playing against with your $50 deck? Yeah well let's see them try to unload thousands of dollars now, when you can build effective decks for pennies. Literally, pennies. Like, walk around and pick up a few coins off the sidewalk amount of pennies.
-Are you worried that not having access to every single card puts you at an unfair disadvantage to your opponent? Trust me, having all the cards is not going to make you a better player.

Hey here me out, let's put anti-exploration mechanics in a game where a lot of the gameplay is about exploration!

Remember the Alpha? All those neat skill trees and features? Yeah, no, let's get rid of all that.

Every time you change region (A small chunk of land on the map), any equipment you gained from the previous region is basically useless in any other region besides the region you got he equipment in the first place. This is also true for travel equipment such as boats, gliders etc...

What does this mean?

Well what it means is that every time you change region, you have to grind as if you started a new game (except few exceptions such as artifacts, which give near useless buffs such as "+3% sail speed") to be able to properley explore the new region.
There is equipment known as "equipment+", which can be used in the region it was found and some of the surrounding regions, but those bits of equipment are rare as hell most of the time, and by the time you get one to drop, it will probably not even be usable for your class.

This means that if you are bored of the current region for what ever reason, such as the fact that a large chunk of each region is just empty randomly generated space, then you have to think hard on whether or not you want to lose all your progress and move to another region, or try your best to enjoy the region you are currently in.

This release is just a mere shadow of what the alpha was and could have been (with relation to the numerous pictures and chunks of information wollay uploaded on twitter and the actual alpha build).

I didn't even talk about how almost anything can near instant kill you when you start each region, while you do crap damage.

TL;DR

No real sense of progress because your equipment resets to starter equipment the moment you leave your current region. Turning the game into a boring repetitive grindfest that would make games like Runescape blush.

[h1][b]15 second Conclusion[/b][/h1]
At the end of the day you get a game with a solid core loop, fun combat, a bad story, and exhaustingly reused assets. Personally I still think it's a fun game but when compared to how polished and how much money goes into other AAA games at the same price tag I find its entry fee is simply too high for what you're getting.

I'm left with a feeling similar to when your lunch is just a bit too expensive. Service was alright, the meal was nothing to complain about, but paying $30 for lunch just doesn't sit right somehow.

[h1][b]In Depth Review[/b][/h1]
The game is fun and I find myself hooked on it. Somehow and for some reason I find myself overlooking it's many flaws and I'm just having a great time smashing monsters to pieces with my huge anime rocket hammer. This is a grind game. You will fight the same enemies over and over. If that doesn't appeal to you then this game isn't for you straight up.

People seem to get mad when this game is compared to Monster Hunter but it makes sense to compare the most popular Monster Hunting genre game (of which the term originated) for people to grasp the differences.

Combat in God Eater is much, much faster and I find less punishing. Weapons you can pick up and really learn in likely an hour. You unlock various perks that can customize parts of the attack combos to your liking. Even the slowest weapons in this game will feel fast compared to most things in Monster Hunter. 

Combat is also less technical, while there is still break points and weak points depending on your weapon type (slash, pierce, crush) combat doesn't necessarily hinge on lining up that one single good blow that if you miss you're screwed on. However, this title does seem to lack the incredibly satisfying feedback that you get in MHW when you're totally just wailing on a weakpoint kicking the crap out of a monster.

Further, I find the short mission times (about 4 - 5 mins where I'm at now) refreshing. As someone with a job and responsibilities it's nice to be able to jump into a few missions a night instead of looking down the barrel of those 25 - 30 minute slogs you find in MHW. This feels like I game I can actually complete within a reasonable timeframe.

For more differences: mission prep is basically non-existent, and many of the meta systems like in Monster Hunter World are not present - such as eating, the palico caravan, the material farming garden thing, etc. For some this is bad, for me I don't really miss having to deal with a bunch of random chores when I get back from a mission.

For the bad however - this game is simply a much more budget title than MHW yet is priced the same. I would not be surprised if the budget for GE3 was 1/10th of what MHW's was yet it somehow masquarades itself as a full priced title. The quality is more in line with a mid-tier title like Senran Kagura and to me should be priced around 30 - 40 dollars.

The maps in GE3 are all arenas. They're all super small and there aren't that many of them. They are reused CONSTANTLY and is probably my biggest gripe of the game. This means there is none of the free roam exploration present in MHW and even compared to old Mon Hun titles the maps are absolutely tiny. I wager it took less people less time to make every single map in this entire game than it did a single zone in MHW.

The story is frankly kind of bad in my opinion and leaves me with many questions about the world - mainly how the AGEs are even imprisoned. It's said that a single small Ash Aragami could wipe out an entire battalion of humans yet you kill multiple Large Ash Aragami so why, exactly, are the AGEs letting people imprison and control them? Why not just wholesale slaughter everyone who is in your way? Why follow the laws? I'm sure there's deep lore in some manga somewhere that explains everything but IMO you get a cliche, somewhat preposterous shonen story. I'm not very much into it myself and this is coming from someone who is a massive weeb.

So at the end of the day you get a game with a solid core loop, fun combat, a bad story, and exhaustingly reused assets. Personally I still think it's a fun game but when compared to how polished and how much money goes into other AAA games at the same price tag I find it's entry fee is simply too high for what you're getting.

I have played this game over 300 hours trying to decide if I would recommend it or not. Obviously, that means there are many attractive features to the game (also, I was ill and couldn't do anything but play games for awhile...).  I binged, then I moved on to something else, then I came back to give it another a chance, and here's my review:

First, on the purely technical level, the game is a mess, and a lazy mess at that. Who launches a game to a black screen with no indicators that it's loading? And the game takes a LONG time to load, even in vanilla. With a bunch of mods, especially Megamod8, it is interminable. And that's just to get to the screen that lets you start a new game or load an old one. 

If you use Megamod8- which is the easy way for people who don't have a deep knowledge of Banished's peculiarities get a bunch of extra content to make the game more interesting- DO NOT play on an Extra Large Map, unless you are playing on a Cray. I have a new Ryzen7/RTX2060 system, and I finally bailed out of the preparation screen (which at least shows you a pretty picture and updates a fantasy list of things the program is 'doing' (suppressing goblins, forsooth) to let you know it's working. Ironically, or appropriately, your cursor changes into an hourglass for this...)  after twenty minutes. Of course,  this leads to another black screen, but this one never processes through, as far as I can tell, and ctrl-alt-delete just initiates a war between task manager and the black screen which ultimately requires restarting the computer.

From this, you get an idea of the fundamental issues in the game- the tech end is very primitive and restrictive for the kind of game it tries to be, and the developer having abandoned it, many people have tried to fix or extend various aspects, which lead to a host of new problems.

For me, the vanilla game is just not that interesting. It's challenging at first, but too limited- it's the beginning of a good game (though with lots of flaws), that was never completed by the developer. The attempts of the modding community to complete it for him are a glorious example of community support, and some excellent work has been done, but ultimately they all collide with various problems and limitations of the game engine that modders have no ability to touch. The result is a real clusterf*ck. 

Another serious issue is documentation. Because of the limitations of the original game, people WILL use mods, but very few of the mods have decent documentation, if any. Thus it takes a lot of hours to figure out what does or does not work together, and even within Megamod8, which is a compilation of mods by people who know what they are doing, there are sometimes conflicts that don't become apparent until you use an item in mid game and you get a fatal crash. Even elements that play nice together often have supply-chain requirements in-game that depend on completely different sets of ingredients despite apparently doing the same thing. Figuring out which building creates the special resources for a building you've already built can be tedious, requiring you basically go into debug mode and build building for free until you find the one with the right production elements.

I had a great desire to like this game, as many people apparently do to judge by the work they have put into it. As much as I applaud their efforts, though, I think this attachment is futile and the equivalent of Stockholm Syndrome.

As a disclaimer, I haven't played much constructed, so this is more pertinent to draft than constructed. 

This is by far the best draft digital card game i've played. Sure there are some heroes that are better than others, but in draft, the odds of getting those heroes are very unlikely. In general you will have to work with the mediocre heroes and a lot of the times, the default heroes for each color. The game itself in draft mode goes fairly long (often mana turn 10-13), and usually games are very close. Often times games you lose is because of a mistake you've made, and this game has a very high skill ceiling (unlike hearthstone, where the optimal play is fairly easy to read). The frequency of nail-biter game in draft mode is so high that winning a game in phantom draft (casual and free) are often by itself gives you such a triumph feeling that cannot be obtained anywhere else. 

Monetization wise, I found that the game is pretty fair. If you've played magic or yugioh in real life, this is what it entails to. If you want to get into the game, you have to pay to play. Realistically, this game (even for constructed) is far cheaper than hearthstone unless you are willing to committ hundreds of hours each month.  Given that there is a trade market (which I really appreciate), you cannot get free packs, or the packs won't retain any value. This is as realistic as an actual TCG in terms of existence of a market. 

In terms of progression and reward, why do we need reward to play? If you don't derive enjoyment in playing the game itself, you shouldn't be playing this game. Playing for reward is how freemium games these days try to get you hooked, but it doesn't mean you actually have fun playing the game. 

On top of all, you have free draft mode to play. Hearthstone doesn't have that, what more can you ask for? People complaining about the lopsided constructed mode should really give draft mode a shot.

I deleted my original review and decided to give this game another chance.

As before, I'm left asking myself why I even bought this game.

Maybe the story's actually as good as people say, but 90% of what I saw was presented in the form of two adult males speaking to each other in a monotone (Geralt) or a hamfistedly overdone accent (most other characters) about fantasy politics, and I was left tapping my foot wishing they'd shut up already so I could get back to wandering the generic-feeling MMO-style world picking random flowers, tripping over my sword at stock fantasy baddies, ignoring my utterly retarded horse that can't step over anything more than six inches tall, and questioning my decision to drop $30 on Reddit's say-so.

But I'm one lone naysayer against the hundreds of thousands who swear this drivel is the game of the century. If you like fantasy settings, 1000s of craftable items, and finnicky combat systems, this is for you. It certainly wasn't for me.

A lot of times, you buy an early access game based on promise, then they just stop updating and you feel ripped off.  This is not the case with this game.  They could stop updating tomorrow and it's worth it's price.  But they instead have a regular update schedule and a solid vision of what they are making.

Graphics are a little rough if you look closely at things, and sometimes the aiming and hit detection can be al ittle wonky, but those are nitpicks.  Otherwise, this is "The Descent" meets survival game, with enough story sprinkled in to give you direction.

Could be fun (at least for sme time, no real reason for long time playing), but with no grouped MP and ppl joining and leaving all the time to jump into friend lobbies, it takes 3 times the time to start a game as to play one.

Useless to buy for at least 4 weeks.

Edit: On for weeks now, only fixes and no real updates. -> Game dead for Gamers, just remaining tubers and fans.
Not even 18k players at all the time it is live, while "steam topseller for days" -> cashgrab completed

Edit 2: We now have a grouped MP and after some days killers even only dodge 1 out of 3 matches. Player numbers went up a tiny bit, now at least it is playable.
I will still keep it on "don't buy", because after that long time to implement a needed feature and all the exploids and bugs still around, the game is just not worth the money.

Even if i would consider all those bugs getting fixed "soon", i would still be annoyind by teh way the game handles lobbies and games.
e.g.:
- you open a group lobby
- you invite a friend or 2
- everyone clicks ready and you wait 7 seconds
- then you wait some more
- 2/3 of the time you will get "no session found" and everybody has to "ready up" AGAIN
- next round .... or maybe roundS .... oh and btw... while teh game searches, everyone can "unready" by clicking "ready that becomes available while searching (false lable on that oen might get fixt "soon")
- you finaly enter a real game lobby
- killer aka host might be lagging; killer aka might dodge ... problems as ever ... if you somehow not start teh game it all starts all over again
- everyone has to ready up again
- you start the game!!! (it has been a minutes long clickfest but you finaly made it!!!)
- you play the game and after 15 min at the most the game ends
- everyone has to leave the after game lobby and gets put into the pre-solo quee lobby
- you leave that lobby
- you start a grouped lobby again ... and all from the start ...

This is just one example of how annoyingly bad programmed this game is. It just spoils your fun while you play it.

Buy it if you have to, but do not pay more than 5 $, you will regreat it.

Counter-Strike: Source is an FPS video game developed by Valve Corporation. It is a complete remake of Counter-Strike using the Source game engine. As in the original, Counter-Strike: Source pits a team of counter-terrorists against a team of terrorists in a series of rounds. Each round is won either by completing an objective or by eliminating all members of the opposing team.

It's been a couple years now since I first bought this game, and I must say it ages perfectly. Ever since it released it's been building on the base game with new free content from a loving developer year after year and it's good to see that these updates are going to continue. The single player experience sets you up for hours of farming, fishing, mining, and whatever else the game throws your way. Single player may seem a bit boring but it sure is satisfying to make that money. This game just keeps getting better, and after playing it for almost 200+ hours it's safe to say imma continue playing it. 12/10 never gets old.

So I am replaying this game (21 years later) along with the rest of the series before I play Alyx. It's extremely hard to get back into, I first played this game upon near release back in 1999 on my Win98 pc. Which I'm happy I still own the CD. I thought it was one of the most amazing experience I've played then since Mario 64. Fast Forward 21 years later and.......well my memories were nostalgic as is with most old games. Just as many games of yesteryear the controls are very difficult. I think I struggled more with the controls than the actual enemies. I got through  70% of the game until I gave up and activated God mode. You'll want to save before every long jump too as platforming is hard. Still, I give it a recommendation as this is the game that started it all. It's worth a visit if you've never played it. Now that I think about it, I don't honestly know if you NEED to play the game if you can just read up on the synopsis. I've read you need to play it and I had felt the same until I actually replayed the game. It's a trip down memory lane if nothing else. It'll definitely make you appreciate the evolution of gaming, including the sequels. I just wish Steam had a "Yes, BUT" rating.

I've had plenty of game time to decide that Nether is definetly a good game, if it decides to work. For some reason, recently, I was unable to actually play the game and was stuck in spectator mode, flying freely around the map. Then, a minute ago, I open the game and notice that it works just fine. So I'm going to assume that it will continue to switch to spectator mode every so often and revert back to normal, although this hasn't been a problem till recently. When the game works, it is quite fun. 

I always have a sense of unease while playing PvP, for fear not of monsters, but of players. 
Probably because most of them are hackers who have a "Shoot-on-site" mindset and will not hesitate to one shot you if they see you. 

PvE is a much different experience, since it adds an element of cooperation between players, but also makes the game much easier since the Nethers aren't too difficult to evade. PvE also removes the threat of hackers, since they cannot harm you in PvE.

If you want a challenging PvP survival experience that comes with hackers (free of charge!) then I certanly recommend this game. If you are looking for a cooperative, PvE survival experience with little challenge (if you know what you're doing), I also recommend this game. But be warned, hackers are an issue in PvP, and the development team seems to have dropped off the planet, so it's unlikely this will be fixed soon, if ever.

Overall: The development team should be more active, and should be more diligent with anti-cheat. But it looks unlikely they will be back soon, if ever.

For what it is in its current (and probably permanant) state, I like the game a lot, despite it's flaws.

As someone struggling with pretty bad anxiety, I can really appreciate the message this game gets across with its gameplay; life is hard, mental illness is hard, but you can get through it. It's not going to be easy, but if you don't give up, you can and you will. Every chapter is difficult, yet, at no point does it feel like the game is handing you anything you can't handle with some practice and effort. I genuinely feel like I'm more prepared to handle any issues my lack of motivation and moderate anxiety hand me after I've played this game, and I've already noticed that I'm subconsciously treating myself with less scrutiny when I am affected by the issues my mental health causes.
