A challenging yet serene simulator. You drive a truck and get your cargo from A to B. You can contract yourself out to other shipping companies or start your own, buy a fleet of trucks, manage a roster of drivers, and build an empire. The game's ambition scales with yours and you can play as seriously or casually as you wish. Unlike most simulators where you can experiment without consequence, ETS2 makes you want to excel at every task and get through every trip without damaging your equipment or disappointing your customer.

Driving takes a lot of concentration and awareness but is ultimately relaxing. The scenery is beautiful even if it doesn't render cities anything like their real-world geographies. Being able to tune in to local European internet streaming radio stations adds a lot of flavour, making you feel you're right there as you listen to DJ chatter in French or German or Polish while playing local favourites.

Vehicles control well enough on an Xbox gamepad but I've watched people on Twitch with steering wheels and head trackers play the game in all its glory. Mouse and keyboard are viable as well and are superior to the gamepad when it comes to looking around, but it's more precise driving with an analog controller of some sort.

I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this game. I bought it with low expectations but quickly became completely immersed in the moment and in managing my little company. It's an excellent simulator and a fun tycoon game as well.

This game is great. I did a couple illegitimate runs with cheats because I thought it was too hard, but then I realized that it was a mistake to do so. It makes stories for you, you just need to give the game direction. You can be anything (with the exception of a couple things that I will cover later in the review). It's brutal, but every story needs its conflict in order to be entertaining. You can feel truly powerless, as you are weaker than the majority of the characters in the game, creating a merciless environment for you to become immersed in.  There are times of triumph, and times of misery.

The game is great, but there are a few annoyances within it.

1. Slave AI can be super duper janky, making a playthrough as a "slave liberator" very difficult to actually play out. It seems that they forget that they are being freed, making it much less satisfying to actually free slaves.
2. You cannot actually join a faction, whether it be the United Cities or the Holy Nation. I wish you could conscript into one of the nation's armies.
3. Minor bugs, mainly with pathfinding (thankfully just loading the previous autosave will fix most issues)

Overall, Kenshi feels like a more brutal Fallout with swords and much more freedom and roleplay value. Definitely worth the thirty bucks, but do prepare for a learning curve and frustration.

Simply magnificent. I can't stress enough how much it's fantastic to play this game and I'll try to make a very concise list of what's best and worst, though it's very balanced to the good side.

PROS:
- very wide and open World, with many places to explore
- great variety of enemies to face and you won't win just by smashing the hit button. You'll need tactics for each foe
- many quests have different paths and endings, some of which cause impact in subsequent quests
- some of the NPC characters have a good depth 
- tons of well made cutscenes that give ultra-immersion to your character
- you can experiment playing with a different character throughout the game
- the Gwent card game is a very clever and interesting game inside the main game and adds a lot to the immersion
- the alchemy system is excellent, with tons of different recipes
- the crafting system is innovative, with the possibility of dismantling objects to get materials to make other objects
- you have a useful interaction with your horse, though some mods improve it further
- outstanding graphics and sounds (I specially appreciate the medieval style music)
- Full graphics quality with a medium type computer rig


CONS:
- it's an easy game, even in the higher difficulty level
- the prices are too low, so you can get awesome equipment too early in the game
- you often see the same face in the NPCs - not bad though, if the tradeoff was to have more time for better things


NOTE ABOUT MODS:
- a few mods (notably SotR, btw) increase the combat difficulty and change some of the game mechanics above for the better (prices, horse, alchemy, crafting, etc), increasing even more my interest in the game.
This game is good and it needs more work but that's not stopping me from playing and I think this game should win!

It's going to be tough going back to other RPGs after this one. I'm 130 hours deep, haven't even completed the DLC storylines yet, and vast swaths of the early areas remain unexplored. All on my first playthrough. I feel confident that I'll be able to play through the entire game multiple more times, with different impacts from my dialogue choices and different skill builds, and have a very different and equally fun experience. I recommend this to fans of medieval / renaissance settings--Elder Scrolls and Assassin's Creed players especially. 

The expansions are NOT to be missed out on; if you're going to buy, PLEASE get the GOTY / complete / whichever edition gets you all you need to experience the game in its entirety.

What a beautiful story. It's really something compared to the ever-expanding amount of visual novels and story-focused games. The limitations of this game's engine hurt this game in a lot of ways, such as not always seeing exact expression on characters faces, the cheesy animations, and the predictability of some actions the moment as soon as text box comes up. Of course, the game is also riddled with very interesting visual effects and a great score to set the scene for some really touching moments. One time I cried, and I wasn't even close to finishing the game.

On occasions the game gets tedious as you dowse the entirety of the map for the next object to take you to the next area. This is where the immersion breaks (aside from a lot of cheesy, comic relief dialogue), which is a real shame, since many of the characters and areas feel very believable. I often got stuck in areas for these reasons, and I reccomend you keep the internet with you when you're playing through this game.

However, I'm nitpicking. I don't believe you can hate this game, and the DLC minisodes are even better in terms of presentation and writing. It is a really nice story that everybody knows and loves, and if you're missing out, you should join the bandwagon. Maybe it's not a perfect storytelling experience, but it's certainly something made with a lot of love that will undoubtedly, make you cry, too.

BUYER BEWARE!!! 

   As soon as you open your free packs you cannot refund the game. These are the only free cards you get otherwise you have to use actual money to buy more. There is literally zero other ways to get cards despite the game already being $20. This game is nothing but a cash grab from Valve and its sickening. I've been a fan for over a decade but it seems even the best companies fall to this era of microtransactions and shady tactics. 

   The biggest thing is it is a fun game, its unique and different. Its comprised of three lanes complete with random movements, a shop to buy items in, constant effects in lanes, quick spells, and so much more. The game looks fantastic as well, its polished with a bunch of fun animations and voice lines. The board and outer sceanery as a whole envlopes you into the game and makes you not want to put it down. 
 
   All of this effort is wasted however due to the aforementioned issues and lack of refund due to their "policy". The only place this policy is shown, atleast from what Ive seen, is within the games store page under system requirements. Tucked away in small grey font So they can state its clearly stated when its so easily overlooked I thought it to be part of the copyright text under every game. 

   I really wanted to love this game but with Valves underhanded tactics I cannot reccomend or support this game in any way, shape, or form.

Hollow Knight is truly one of the most amazing games ever made. It is a Metroidvania game, and like all games in the genre, it fetures tight controls, exploration, upgrades that allow you to progress where you couldn't before, and challenging but fair combat. The game is also filled with enough lore/atmosphere/mood to be called 2D Dark Souls-ish. What really makes the game stand out is the excellent and unique art design, visuals, and sound track. The world of Hallownest is hauntingly beautiful, filled with inhabitants that are relatable and memorable, endearing even, like the onion kight in the DS series. Even the monsters you encounter are alluring in their own way, often making me wonder what they would be like and how they would live their lives before the fall of Hallownest. 

A game similar to Hollow Knight would be the excellent Salt and Sanctuary. Yet there is no denying that Hollow Knight is more smoother and polished. The combat is less deep than S&S or DS, but I believe it allows the player to focus on other things, such as exploration, lore, and the artwork, which in some ways remind me of the 2009 film Coraline. In sum, Hollow Knight has proven to be one of the most excellent Metroidvania games ever made, and should be on the shopping list of any fan of the genre.

Celeste is a platformer, which isn't scared of getting hard and challenging for the player.

This game has a minimalistic set of actions you can do (Dash, Jump and Climb)
and builds on these as the game progresses.

Every level feels unique in it's design, it's ambience and game mechanics,
which contributes to the feeling of having a true adventure

The music fits perfectly into this world, made by heart with its mix of synths, a piano and percussion.
It gives you the right emotions to the right time.

Even though the games artstyle is pixel-based, the game felt very alive & detailed.
Every animation is fluent and nice to look at.

The character design was pretty good, it felt like everyone was kinda developing over time.
I like the idea of challenge by choice, as demonstrated by the hidden strawberrys across the whole mountain.

Overall, it's definitely the best platformer i've played so far and
I can only recommend to buy this masterpiece.

So if theres anything ive learnt from my recent purchases on steam... its fucking wait... patience is defnitely a virtue. This is my warning here and now many early alpha games are being promoted and released in an attempt to make money quickly with no actual progress being made. I have bought both the stomping land and the forest both of which progress has been nigh on unseen, many of the bugs and suggestions made by the community have gone unheard. This game's got it all: Varied builds, tough enemies, and SALT! Bosses are challenging yet rewarding in this game, some challenge the concepts of the game you've already learned, while others force you to adopt new strategies.

Short version:
Good: movement, combat, graphics, weapons, foes.
Bad: no pause, no save, annoying AI buddy if offline, boring open-world concept.

There are some VERY valid criticisms about this game, but I am enjoying it. The way I would describe it is: All the really important (and hard) things are done right, and they messed up on the easy stuff. Some of this may get improved/fixed in future patches as I know I'm not the only one frustrated by some of these things.

So first the good:
The character movement, and combat in this game is fantastic. That is the #1 reason I buy Id Software games, and in that area, I am not disappointed.  The weapons are good and the bad guys are fun. The graphics are amazing. I think they implemented fire (flame throwers, explosions, etc.) better than I've seen before.  Bottom line, if the primary reason you buy games is for good solid combat, this game you will like. I can’t comment on the co-op because I play games like this single-player only.

Now the bad:
The game is sort-of open world. I think that is a negative in this type of game. I would rather a game like this be “on the rails” because it would be less repetitive (going through the same levels with different missions) and it would not allow you to end up in places you probably shouldn’t go where there are high level bad guys that are just too hard for your current level/build. Also, I think the overall story suffers from this aspect.

Next is the forced co-op. I am fine with an AI helper, but I dislike that if she is stunned, I have to help or die. I would rather just let her die and keep playing. Especially since she puts herself in harms way and doesn’t use cover well (or at all sometimes). This adds frustration and takes away from the fun. Playing offline should allow pausing the game and saving the game. Both of those have been omitted as well. I have had to walk way only to come back and find my mission failed.

Non-Issue:
I did not mention microtransactions and here is why: They don’t matter and anyone mad about them is just being petty. I didn’t even figure out it had microtransactions for a long time. They ONLY affect cosmetic things like skins, and in almost all cases you can use currency you find in the game instead. I think there is only one skin per skinnable thing that can only be bought with real money. The game does not promote it either, you have to find it in the customization menu. I can’t believe the big deal some people are making over this.

TL;DR; The hype around the game is justified. It's a great game all around.

There is probably not much to be said about TW3 that hasn't already been said at this point, but I wanted to add that it's still, and probably will be for a long time, worth playing even if you've no idea about its lore or the previous games. 

The story is probably the main selling point for the game, it's very fleshed out and the characters well written. The world also helps bring it to life with myriads of side quests and stories that don't feel repetitive or templated. The gameplay feels fluid and satisfying, especially in higher difficulty levels. The graphics are beautiful, and even when they become dated, you'll still occasionally find yourself just admiring the view from a high place.

Overall I would recommend this game to anyone wanting an enjoyable RPG experience, without grinding or tactic-heavy combat, just to sit back and have fun in a vast and adventure-filled world.

The series has changed since Civ 4, with a lot of streamlining done (empire-wide culture and happiness) to remove micromanagement of every city.  Some may like this, some may not.  With the recent expansion, religon and espionage have been re-added, though espionage is not as robust as it once was.  Regardless, this version contains the best combat mechanics and tile layout of the series.  Hex tiles allow for better flanking, and offers a much more strategical aspect to the game over the old "tiles of doom".  Overall, the improved combat and map generation (and graphics to boot) ultimately have won me over.  A great multiplayer game (with time investment).

I think this game is getting a lot of hate it doesnt deserve. Having played hundreds of hours in Civ V and having attempted, multiple times, to play through the monstrosity that was Civ Beyond Earth, I think this game is entirely enjoyable and was almost definately what the series needed after such a long hiatus between major releases. It is most definately the most complete, and possibly the most expansive initial release of any Civ game, and it feels (as Civ Beyond Earth failed to do) like a DIFFERENT game, not just a re-skin. It has new elements, good support for multiplayer, and only a few major flaws. One of these is a lack of an easy modding capacity, and secondly a slightly flawed AI. These are most certainly to be addressed soon, and I expect that DLC's which are soon to come will be fantastic.

With a rich world and content, metaphorical story, fun gameplay, disturbing yet charming art style and character designs , this is easily one of the best roguelike games i've ever played.

PS: Keep in mind that you will be playing the same levels over and over again to see most of the content and you may get burnt out after a while like i have but it still is a blast to play through.

Pro's:
-Great mechanics, gameplay, and (usually) graphics and open world.
-Survival mechanics are well thought out, and the story has been well flushed out.
-UI is clean, yet minimalist, making the HUD nonintrusive so you can appreciate the beautiful, alien landscape of the Planet you (Not-Really-Spoilers) crash land on in the start of the game.
-Suprisingly deep storyline, with quite an emotional undertone that can make you feel abject fear and despair, as well as elation and even a deep sorrow.
-Includes surprisingly advanced base-building mechanics, making each base you build (and even most submarines) deeply unique.
-Audio Quality and Music is very well done.

Cons:
-(Not really a Con but a PSA) for those who are agoraphobic or hate the deep ocean, UNDERSTAND THIS GAME WILL FREAK YOU OUT AND MAKE YOUR NIGHTMARES THAT MUCH MORE TERRIFYING. The ocean is filled with deadly super-predators that look like half-breeds of Xenomorphs and the beasts of the 40K Warp, each uniquely and utterly terrifying in their own particular ways. Not only are these beasts terrifying to run into in open ocean (which has a haze liek the real ocean, making visual sighting of immenant death rather difficult past 30 meters) or in the dark, but each has its own unique binary set of Roars, which are
      -Roaming around, which is all echo-ey and has a range of WAY TOO FAR, making it difficult to tell how far away your impending doom is or even what direction its coming from
      -Right in your face, which will ALWAYS sound like its in the room behind the monitor about to defecate on your hopes and dreams no matter what volume you are at.
Combine these factors with the lack of ANY way to defend yourself (the only weapon you have is a semi-rusty butterknife and your own gumption) and the other more frightening fact that rears its ugly head very early on that you are more than likely slower than the thing chasing you most of the time, making you little more than a human Happy Meal. Ending this little PSA, I just want to say most other Horror games, even in their prime, can't compare to some sections of Subnautica... so Purchase wisely.
-Can have rendering issues, since the world seems to load into view range in blocks, although this issue isnt as prevalent due to the water's haze effects.
-Progression can be a bit difficult if you dont consult the wiki, since the most the game gives you to look for certain neccesary components for your needed device, doohickey, building, or sub is a costly scanner room with a very limited range that requires near-end-game materials to sync to your HUD. My advice? This is one of those games you'll need your smartphone ready for.
-Glitches and crashes are uncommon, but have repeated themselves enough with me that I thought it relevant.

Conclusion:
Great game, but YOU HAVE TO KNOW BEFORE PLAYING THIS GAME REQUIRES NERVES OF STEEL BECAUSE ITS ESSENTIALLY 50% HORROR GAME. If you can get past these elements, and enjoy a good survival game with a very well made story, then I can't recommend this game enough.

Civ 6 revolutionizes the civ franchise with unique mechanics. It will not be for everyone, but it is certainly a breath of fresh air.

Arguably the greatest change is the introduction of districts and it is my favorite change as well. For some it will take some getting used to, I came over from Endless Legend so I took to it instantly. The basic idea is to build buildings of any specific type, such as faith or science, you must first build a district, which takes up a hex on the map and gets bonuses to its yields depending on its location. For example, campuses get +1 science from each mountain tile, and +1 science for every 2 districts, they are adjacent to. This makes settling location and city planning far more important. 

Once you have a district built it unlocks the buildings of that type, campuses allow you to build libraries, universities, etc, and holy sites let you build temples, shrines, etc. The amount of districts you can build is limited by population, which means you must specialize your cities. If you are going for a science victory you may build campuses in most of your cities, but you will still need to build theater districts for culture and commercial hubs for trade routes and gold. You cannot build every district in every city, but with the exception of holy sites if you aren't going for religion, you will want to build every district somewhere in your empire. This also means that you can't dabble in multiple types of buildings or make a city that isn't specialized. If you do not have a campus you cannot build a library, so you can't have a city that has a library, amphitheatre, market, workshop, and light house in the same city. You simply won't have the population and/or space to support that many districts.

Wonders also take up tiles just like districts. Wonders and districts prevent those tiles from being worked so unlike civ 5 you can't create a 'wonder city' -- you'll run out of space and tiles to work! Many buildings in districts do add specialist slots to make up for losing the tile yield. Some wonders require very specific locations, such as being adjacent to a specific feature, like a mountain or river, being built on a specific tile, such as hills or tundra, or near a specific district, or even all tree at once. This can be very annoying because some of the restrictions are extreme, locking you out of the wonder completely if you happen to not have the right resource or tile anywhere on your current map, and these restrictions are quite common. However, I believe that these changes to wonders and the additions of districts add a further strategic element are a feature present in very few 4X games (I think only civ 6 and endless legend have districts in the entire genre)

The next major change and arguably the most controversial is the removal of policy trees and the addition of a whole new tech tree, the civics tree. The civics tree is researched using culture and unlocks faith buildings and a large variety of wonders. However it mostly unlocks governments and policy cards. Instead of policy trees, you have an ever growing tree of policies to choose from and a limited number of policies you can have active. While you no longer grow as powerful as you would with policy trees, you have much more flexibility. If someone declares war on you, you can switch out your more economic policies for bonuses to production and military strength to quickly build a strong army. There is a bit of a balancing issue, with certain policies staying relevant for the entire game or getting upgraded, and others quickly being obsolete. Other policies become auto includes and essentially reduce your number if policy slots. Governments determine what policy types you have access to, such as economic or military, and provide a small bonuses such as extra gold or more housing. The fact that there are two tech trees can cause some serious pacing issues as the game is balanced with the idea that you are split between both trees, but if you specialize in just the science tree you can unlock some techs ridiculously early. Ultimately I believe this change is very positive.

The addition of housing is a cool idea as it incentivizes settling near rivers, and limits growth if you don't have enough houses, but It ultimately falls flat. Amenities are far less transparent than happiness was. Housing and amenities simply become arbitrary numbers to keep track of. 

Finally, the ai is absolutely terrible. A serious step back from civ 5, and sadly becomes even worse with the latest expansion. The ai leaders have specific agenda that determine what actions annoy them off or not, one of which is predetermined by leader and one is random. These agendas can conflict making the ai's behavior feel very erratic and out of place. Also the random agenda is hidden to start, meaning that it's not immediately clear why the AI is mad at you and how to keep them happy. Also some of the leader specific agendas are way too specific. For example Victoria gets mad at you if she has no cities on your continent, but it can take her ages to settle on your continent, meaning she can be angry at you for much of the game with out any real way of placating her. Similarly, some empires get mad at you for settling near certain areas, such as the coast or mountains, but sometimes that can't be helped, especially if your first city is near a coast, or your civilization relies heavily on coastal bonuses. Whether the ai likes you or not feels arbitrary, especially early game.

Finally, I've had ai declare war on me for no apparent reason. I've a fully positive relationship, with literally no negative modifiers, settled far away from the ai, they did not covet my lands, and still they went to war.

In sum, I feel that this game is vastly unerappreciated, but you may find some of the new feature jarring and that can turn some people off. Additionally, with an unpredictable ai, the gulf between single and multiplayer means your mileage may vary.

Alright, so this game is definitely interesting.

There are a bunch of aspects I like and dislike about it, as well as general thoughts.

PROS:
The game (with the new DLC) is quite addicting. I found myself saying "Just one more turn" over and over again late into the night.
The cartoonish graphics are actually quite good once you get used to them.
The Music for the game is great.
The new Loyalty feature makes it so forward settling someone far away in the early game is near impossible, and makes late game colonialism diffiult (though not impossible). If you like to build up empires and keep to yourself you'll find you don't notice loyalty much, whereas if you used to like to dominate snowball to victory you're going to have the extra challenge of maintaing loyalty under your belt. Late game the challenge becomes easier to handle, so don't  worry too much about having trouble driving your tanks to Moscow.
Emergencies tend to happen with wars, I almost managed to have 3 emergencies at once, but sadly only had two. Backstabbing people, taking a city state or capital, or using a nuclear device all triggered emergencies against me. It was a bit fun, though I think it would've been better if I wasn't already at war with everyone.
The AI isn't as bad as what it's been made out to be. Whenever the game first came out, sure, everyone hated your guts. Now it's fairly easy to maintain relations with other nations if you so choose, just don't go on massive attempts at conquest and expect people to like you for it. Additionally, The AI actually managed to keep up with me on prince difficulty when I played at the new expansion, so I think the skill has certainly improved.
Governors are interesting. Depending on how many cities you build, you may only need a few of them (and thus you'll have very experienced governors) or if you build wide you'll need a lot (and you'll be shuffling them around a little to optimize your setup). I would say it's a great way to help give big bonuses to certain cities in certain areas, and can really help move things along.

CONS:
No Production Queue. This isn't so bad as it keeps the game moving, but it can be annoying if you want to stop paying so much attention to one place. That said, you can download a mod to fix this, but it hasn't been updated to work with the new DLC yet.
Mods don't work with the DLC yet. That's partially why I think we're seing so many crashes in the reviews, and why I crashed myself when I first started playing this game: I forgot I had mods enabled, and the mods haven't had time to update to work with the new expansion pack.
Free Cities do not turn into city states, you cannot systematically balkanize your fellow players. They will stay free despite outside influences sometimes though.
Map doesn't display my boarders (specifically mine) in game when zooming in and out near other cities, I don't entirely understand why this is. It makes using builders a bit confusing though.
I conquered every city in the game, won a culture victory. Go figure.

All in all, I believe it's worth getting the game with the expansion. Most of the bug issues or graphic errors that people have mentioned will inevitably be fixed with updates. 
I really enjoy playing Civ 6, and I think most people will too.
Just don't be picky and critical all the time, and you'll enjoy a new experience.

I have never written a review before, but feel compelled to do so for this wonderful sim.   

If I had to sum up Euro Truck Simulator 2 in one word it would be "quality."  From the sim engine, the graphics, the attention to detail of the developers, the interaction between the developers and the community and the community itself, quality shines through.

The company is being very well led.  They do what so few game developers these days seem to, they understand their product, the niche it fills in the market and their customers.  They are not afflicted with the relentless drive to grow the company at the expense of their products or customer base, as is so often the case with many companies these days.  They release a great product at a fair price and manage their costs to continue to do so.  No half baked money grabs.  No gimmicks.  Just good gaming value for your money.

I wish Euro Truck 2, this company and all it's employees much continued success in the future and personally thank them for their integrity and commitment to their wonderful products and customer base!

If you want quality, buy this game.

TL;DR: Semi-intuitive, NON-level-scaling (!!!), bit difficult in the beginning, but very nicely designed and developed game for RPG fans, especially those who love playing Baldur's Gate 1-2, Pillars of Eternity 1-2 or the old Fallouts. Needs some fine-tuning from devs, but all in all, a finely crafted RPG gem. Strongly recommended!

This game is long-awaited. There have been "RPG" releases that were a disgrace for the D&D name. Pathfinder: Kingmaker is The Patch to that festering wound.
The story seems good for now - I'm not yet finished with the game, in fact I'm still at the beginning of the good part. After getting your stronghold, you will have 2 (or rather 2.5) ways playing the game: managing your barony through events and decisions and going out with your party, playing the usual party-based RPG, which is also interrupted by some text-based events, where you can choose your path or action from a menu of options, just like old-fashioned interactive novels.
It's pause-with-space, with faily good AI for every character you can control. Enemy AI is acceptable too. [spoiler] Especially the fight with the Stag Lord, where he tends to aim at the main character as much as he can	[/spoiler]

[b] Gameplay settings [/b] For now this is the BEST improvement in RPG history. You can choose how to award XP for skill checks (one member receives XP or everyone), can choose whether all your characters get XP or only those in the party, and several other similar aspects of the game, which was a marvelous idea from the devs!

[b] Tutorials [/b] People, who are used to hand being held throughout a game, beware: here the [b] Tutorial does not cover every little bit [/b] of the GUI/mechanics/class/etc, you will have to learn the game by playing it and trying the buttons yourselves. Requires some intuition, yes. Kids below 12 (in age and/or IQ): ask someone to assist you, don't shout at the screen, it's no use.

[b] Level scaling: [/b] Encounters and areas are not 100% adjusted to party level! Whiners beware, you may find challenge that is too difficult for you on level 2-3, even with low difficulty. Those who complain about Vicomte Smoulderburn [spoiler] that blazing skull who appears when you rest at the camp remains near the Mites [/spoiler] , learn playing non-level-scaling games. Hope people remember Baldur's Gate 2, where you could meet liches even in the starting areas, while on level 8-9, getting killed in like 2 rounds. Go back for the Vicomte later. I myself hate level-scaling. Takes away 50% of the fun.

[b] Pathfinder ruleset compliancy (did I get the right word?): [/b] as much as I know Pathfinder rules, which is zero so I'm mostly comparing the game rules to D&D 3.5, it follows ruleset properly, maybe with some necessary minor modifications. Not so bold kick-in-the-groin blasphemy as merging magic schools illogically (invisibility in Transmutation...guess the game), using cooldown abilities or simplifying rules too much. Nothing of that. If you know any of D&D 3.5 PF 4ht 5th editions, you'll be pretty much familiar with everything.

[b] Character generation: [/b] Many classes and even more subclasses (I think every class has 3 subclasses aside from the vanilla class), some prestige classes, so you can spend a couple of hours creating your character, partly because you want to try more than one class and can't decide. I maybe felt a little overwhelmed by the number of options here...but it's just a very minor issue, not really a problem.
[b]Edit:[/b] I have to agree with many complainers that you need to know D&D 3 or later ruleset to understand everything during creation, the tooltips and clues are not too detailed.

[b] Overall difficulty: [/b] At the beginning there is a certain degree of sh*t hitting the fan all around you, the game is hard, and you need to choose your tactics carefully, sometimes change spell memorization (which means extra resting). Devs admitted the difficulty required some tuning, so the second hotfix addressed that. Maybe there's still some room for improvement concerning difficulty, but it's manageable, and will rather feel like a hard challenge than taking away the fun. Choose your terrain for the battles. You can lure the enemies, use the terrain to your advantage.
For the less patient gamers: buy a spare keyboard, just in case.
[b] Edit:[/b] I have to admit, sometimes I lose it too...game can really be damn hard, even during main missions that you cannot avoid (as they are timed quests). Oh for good fuck's sake.

[b] Graphics: [/b] Beatuiful. I especially like the tone of the coloring. Not too dark-gothic, but not even the swords with sugar-coating and rainbow-ponies kind of high saturation. Nice in-between pastel colors. But you can see the screenshots above LOL 

[b] Party: [/b] Till now I haven't seen any serious banter or fight between party members, even though it is er...quite colorful, concerning alignments. Romance...it will be there as far as I know, but I'm rather curious about the NPC remarks based on some of your decisions, or occasional (or inevitable?) alignment shift( s?). :)  [b]Edit:[/b] There ARE some consequences of not agreeing with your companions, slight quarrel or radical decisions from the companion, but they indeed react to your decisions! Some of these decisions are Barony events-related, not while you're out adventuring. No inter-companion banter though, however. Well, maybe I should let some highly different companions  [spoiler] like Ekundayo and Jaethal  [/spoiler] travel together for a reasonable time.

[b] Bugs: [/b] There are some (even after hotfix 1.0.6). The dev team is busy fixing them, even during weekends! However, I have to agree with those saying it would have been wiser to release the game 2 weeks later instead of releasing 7 patches in 2 weeks (hfix 1.0.7 has just downloaded) It's a little bit of a shame, but well...I am not aware of the background reason for insisting on releasing the game on the promised date. Maybe the press pressed them, maybe pride, maybe some financial reasons (sponsors, anything...hell I know)...not trying to defend them. Actually I did NOT meet too major and game-breaking bugs, even though the hotfix notes mention several bad ones. I was satisfied with the at-release-state of the game, though patching got me even happier.

Well, this game is still full of surprises I feel, so I may extend this review later. But all in all: it worth every penny you spend on this game.

hello, don't remember writting a review so here it is :

This game is simply the concentration of everything that I love in a game. Clearly, it is the best game of 2017 for me so far.

so...

Why the F*** am I rating it like this and why would I strongly recommend that you don't buy it? Simply because this kind of games have to be perfect... Nothing less, nothing more! Symphony of the night is perfect, super metroid is perfect, order of ecclesia is perfect, metroid prime, zero mission, even cave story is perfect etc...
you know why they're perfect for me? BECAUSE YOU CAN ACTUALLY PLAY THE GAME!!!!

I have more than 30 hours on hollow knight and now I'am starting to try everything that is supposed to be hard like I use to in every metroidvania like, it seems that everything is doable to me.

EXCEPT...

UNITY! Unity micro freezes the game every once in a while (every 5 sec I mean...) and when it becomes harder, every fight is like a music sheet that you have to follow BY THE RULE! How can you do it if the game makes you miss every 2 or 3 hits because when you pushed the button... THE GAME WAS FREEZING!!!! HOW? 

I never felt this kind of frustration in any game in my life simply because... the game is fabulous! It is my favorite genre reborn with so much genius in it... But the most challenging parts can't be done... (without luck I mean, I'm guessing everyone is thinking : "git gud noob" ... whatever! I want every fight to be clean and if it wasn't for this b***S*** I wouldn't have spent my entire day on the third level of the arena...).

This kind of game based on precision and decision by the frame can not be released unfinished... It feels like the taj mahal built with white and solid vomit... it's beautiful, but man... IT SMELLS!!!


edit, a year later : I decided to do it another time. 0 micro freezes during 30 hours of gameplay!! Thank you team cherry for this absolute work of art. 15 out of 10 ^^ 

but next time, you know what to avoid ;)

[h1]ATLAS[/h1]

[i]Review constructed as follow:
[list]
[*] Intro; Why did it look interesting to me.
[*] Positive things; explaining the good things in the game.
[*] Neutral things; things that aren't necessarily bad, but could've been better.
[*] Negative things; explaining the things that somewhat ruined (my) experience playing this game and/or things in general that need work.
[*] Ratings; giving a grade to some core concepts of the game.
[*] Verdict; Final grade and some explanation.
[/list][/i]

[u]Intro[/u]
I just couldnt get into the ARK setting, however i did follow it's development closely. I was really hyped when i noticed they were releasing a ''Pirate theme'' version of it. 

[u]Positive[/u]
[list]
[*] Alot of things to craft.
[*] Sailing the map with a home made ship and friends is alot of fun.
[*] You can almost build every where.
[*] Water graphics/physics are well done.
[*] The way they implemented ship building is really cool, you have a to build all parts necessary for the ship, after that you can alter it's complete design and decide where you want to build cannons for example.

[/list]


[u]Neutral[/u] 
[list]
[*] Optimization, game not running very smooth.
[*] The seas feel a bit empty.
[*] Islands are too small.
[*] Getting a decent base is a fairly big grind if alone.
[*] Messy skill tree.
[*] Performance issues on starting islands.
[*] Switching and especially reloading weapons is buggy sometimes. (No shot chambered after reloading) 
[*] Foundations are too small, constructions like forge, loom etc. are too big.  
[*] Sometimes get stuck between rocks.
[/list]


[u]Negative[/u]
[list]
[*] Animals, holy shit what a mess are the animals and their AI. first, there are too many, every area is covered in way too many species. Second, their AI is just horrible, aggro is bad and when animals are fleeing they tend to get stuck or they just wander off only to run back at you 2 minutes later.
[*] The games rocky start, will explain below.
[*] Graphics are not bad, but i put it at negative because it's not even close to what they revealed at first.
[*] Alot of space on islands are already claimed due to the amount of claim flags people can place. This made us eventually leave the official server.
[/list]

[h1]Verdict: 6.4[/h1]
Oh man i've seen games with a rocky start, but this one is on the top, luckily things are getting calmer and the devs are trying their best to make it better day by day.
Sadly, this does not changed the fact that they delayed their release day several times without communication, besides that, their extended gameplay trailer that they showed us half December looked way too good than the actual gameplay.

At the moment of writing i played around 30 hours, mostly on a server where there were higher xp rates and get more resources from gathering just to get to know what this game offers late game aswell. We had alot of fun despite the issues the game has.

So far it's been fun and frustrating. I gave it thumbs up because i enjoyed those hours venturing around despite the plentiful bugs and server side issues.
If this game will get the same attention as they did with Ark then i'm pretty sure that the developers are able to make something very nice of ATLAS.

To be honest, this is one of the best games I ever played. I've never played any so-called "metroidvania" games before Hollow Knight, but I absolutely fell in love with the hand-drawn level design & art and the exploration of a mysterious dark world, accompanied with a soothing soundtrack when just exploring, and a solid soundtrack when in combat.
It isn't as hard as Dark Souls, but nevertheless a bit challenging from time to time.
What makes this game so great, is the advance of combat throughout the game, together with the developer's passion for design which put together many different unique areas to explore.
Since I first played the game when it was brand new, I experienced the addition of a few updates. They were never boring, always filled with interesting additional bosses and other stuff.

I do not regret any second I spent with this game, and I am really looking forward to seeing the release of Hollow Knight: Silksong. Hopefully it'll be a great successor.

Both a relaxing break from the action and adrenaline-pounding moments of nearly every other game, and a challenge of scraping by, working from nothing to something. And it's not just a farming game, either. You can farm, mine, fight, explore, socialise, fish...there's always something you can be doing. Also, the only thing that's needed is money (taught me a fair amount of money management, which can be quite handy irl as well). Don't like talking to people? Don't talk. Hate the fishing minigame with a passion? Don't fish. Think the mines are too scary? Don't mine. Yes, there are drawbacks to not doing these things, but its more of a lack of rewards that you would get from doing those things. While the story only goes as far as "repair this building in one of 2 ways", there's a good amount of lore if you want to get digging into certain characters. Also, with multiplayer now a thing, why not get some friends together and just chill together instead of tryharding your way through online matches?
So, all things considered, don't buy for any kind of  awesome fight scenes or bosses, buy for a breath of fresh air and a change from the fast-paced action of the shooters and the MMOs.

In the current state of this game, the games are much too unbalanced, repetitive or just overall not fun. In most of the five maps you have available to you, if you pick Blue, you have a strategic advantage over the opposition. If you use certain weapons or loadouts, you are more likely to score kills or survive for much longer. Of course, it's all for the sake of realism. A shield should be able to block majority of damage because it's a shield, but it gets to a point where, in Frontline, you're just ganging up on a bunch of people over and over and over again. There's not enough in this game to warrant it's pricetag. Especially since it feels like an Early Access game, which is sad enough as is. Wait until either this game actually gets enough content to warrant it's current price tag, or don't bother.

[h1]Cuteness to die for[/h1] [strike]Heh, get it?[/strike]
Don't be fooled by the silly faces and funnyfuns, the hearts of the Gundead are filled with pure evil! Don't think that will let you to [b]THE GUN[/b] that easily! 
Prepare to fight hundreds and hundreds of derpy yet deadly enemies, with the most unthinkable weapons! 
Really, [u]anything[/u] can be a gun in the Gungeon, from bananas, to cacti, to a sweaty T-Shirt launcher! 
(Mashine gun wash only.)
Be ready to die countless ti- actually, scrap that, the game counts the deaths for you, making you feel bitter regret every time as you look at that growing number of failed attempts. 

But don't loose hope! You [u]can[/u] dodge their bullets! You [u]can[/u] kill the past!
[b]"And if you don't, you can always... try again... heh heh..." ~Drunk Gungeon Man[/b]

Anyway, on a more serious note, this game is fun, a great Rougelike Bullet Hell with much variety, pixel perfect graphics, and most imporantly [b]a LOT of heart.[/b]
Kind of, as if Isaac and Nuclear Throne had a baby. So if you are a fan of these games, or of the ganre, or just like silly and challenging stuff in general, [b]GET THIS GAME![/b]

First things first, it's in alpha so theres some glitches and some bs occurences my character got stuck not eating for a few days because of a glitch where I couldn't cook food. Shit happens, honestly I am completely and utterly blown away by this game, right now my longest survival time is 10 days I built a small fortress by the beach complete with warning signs to attempt to deter the enemy. Each time they would attack a few would perish and a few would retreat and the next night they came in bigger numbers. The A.I. is intuitive, with the characters acting differently based on a wide range of various parameters you feel the anxiety as you look at them watching you, circling you, probing you for weakness to determine if youre a threat. This game for all it's alpha flaws is amazingly fun and I can honestly say that this is the only game i've ever played where I was legitimately unnerved and on edge. Completely worth it.

TLDR: Left 4 Dead comparisons are fair, but in my opinion its a lot more fun.    More weapons, leveling system, beautiful world, and greater enemy variety to name a few things.   Game does have loot boxes but no cash shop so there is no concern there.   And the game gives them generously so it isn't grindy. 

Edit: game time is inflated due to strange bug where launcher remains open and has to be closed manually otherwise it thinks the game is running.   If you have an error where it says "app is running" when you try to start it even though it isn't open you need to end the Vermintide launcher in taskmaster.   So if I get up to thousands of hours, and you call BS you're probably right. 

Longform Review:
So Left 4 Dead but with Warhammer.   You've heard it, I've heard it, your mum has heard it.   That's what everyone has heard about it.   And... they're correct... to an extent.   However, that really shouldn't be a problem as long as the game builds on the premise of Left 4 Dead.   I mean I'm primarily an RTS player and the amount of similar mechanics across those games is substantial, but you don't see people saying "Ooh another Command and Conquer Clone"   And I'm happy to say that Vermintide absolutely adds a good number of features along with the Warhammer reskin of Left 4 Dead.

For starters there's a sense of progression of your characters.  Left 4 Dead you're one of 3 admittedly very charismatic dudes and one equally enjoyable dudette that starts the first round with the same damn pistol and the same choice of shotgun or automatic weapon every... single... time.   Whereas with Warhammer, you have the option of being Victor Saltzpyre, the Pokey, wielding your rapier and impaling your enemies with far reaching forward thrusts, or Victor Saltzpyre the Headsmasher, wielding a flail and washing yourself clean in the blood of the heretics you smash in a wide arc right in front of you.  And there's a lot of weapons more outlandish then that like repeater pistols and flamethrowers and various other pest exterminating tools.   Adding on to that are various different ultimate skills that you can unlock for characters, and then skill points you unlock to alter your characters playstyle further.   So all in all there's a lot of alteration you can do so whatever character you pick like Victor Saltzpyre or... the other slightly less awesome ones... you can make it feel like you.

But I hear you say.  That just gives you an excuse to grind the shit out of the game like a Skavenslave on a treadmill.  And depending on if you're a masochistic looter shooter enthusiast or someone like me who likes not having gaming as a second job, you may be either excited by this prospect or reluctant.   For me as someone who wards away grindy games like Destiny with a crucifix, I feel no obligation to grind.   I've been able to accrue a massive amount of loot boxes just from leveling and have been able to try different weapons as I please.    An important thing to know is once you unlock weapons you can craft them.   So if you want that flamethrower for your dwarf because "Holy crap it's a FLAMETHROWER" the good news is you can dissassemble things for scrap to get one and the conversion rate isn't bad.  You get three items in a loot box that you can melt down each round you finish, and honestly like two boxes worth or less is usually enough.   You might not get great stats on it but until you get into really high level endgame, the extra stats are gravy and you don't really need them.   You can also use scrap to upgrade weapons too so if you really care, there you go.  

Honestly though for me as a filthy casual, who looks on at actual good players game play with a near erotic longing, I mainly care about story and environment.   And Vermintide.... mainly delivers on environment with the story being told in snippets and exchanges between characters.   Essentially the Skaven have collapsed a big ass city, and have a green stargate in the ruins beneath that they'll use to march Norsca chaos soldiers through.   And you have to stop it.  And you do.  The end...

 But the world.... oh my god it's beautiful.   And I mean it, it really is beautiful despite also being an apocalyptic craphole.   And honestly that really captures the essence of Warhammer.   Even as the world burns and falls into ruin it's magnificent and beautiful, and that makes the tragedy all the more enjoyable and also impactful.   I wish so much that other apocalyptic landscapes took this to heart but too often it's brown, dead, and horrible to be in and look at.   And I think that's a mistake.  I genuinely do.   

It's all these additions and the love and care put into the game that honestly make "Left 4 Dead with Rats" a bit of a double edged sword.   On one hand it does sum up the basic experience so people know what they're getting into but it does a bit of a disservice to what I think the game accomplishes.   But I suppose "Left 4 Dead with Lovingly Crafted Environments, More Weapons, More Enemy Types, And Overall Yet Another Fantastic Addition to the Warhammer Game Canon...... with Rats" doesn't roll off the tongue.    Oh well.   "Left 4 Dead with Rats" it is.

Greatest game ever

Genre: Retro 2D 16-bit Platformer
Sub-genre: Hardcore Platformer

Presentation: 10/10 - Each pixel is beautifully rendered and lovingly placed to burn a hole directly through your skull with enduring love.

Gameplay: 10/10 - With simplistic yet unforgiving controls, this game will have you high fiving your best friend one minute, and smashing your face into your desk for sweet release the next. 
*Keyboard and mouse compatible, as well as Gamepad compatible.

Sound: 10/10- With a soundtrack that feels like it was ripped right out of the 90's, it fits right in sync with the mind-numbing sound effects that will have your ears bleeding from extreme brutality.

Replay Value 10/10: What exactly is "Replay Value"? If it's in the sense of playing the game over again, then I can tell you I am almost 100% positive once you complete this game fully you will never want to play it again, unless to show someone else or submit yourself to more torture. That being said, you are going to put so many hours into this game that it justifies the $12 price tag ten times over. You are going to die so many times that technically you can consider that your "replay value". If you beat the game and feel like it's not hard enough for you, then you can go back through the first level and not die. At all. Do not die, get to the end of the level, and defeat the boss. In one sweep. You will then exit off of the stage and be taken to a seperate set of levels that are called the "Path of the Valkyrie". These levels are much more challenging and give you all of the migraines you crave. Enjoy!

Review Summary:

Never have I played a game for four hours straight to still be on the first level.

I am on the fourth level now and I have put 23 hours into this game.

It teaches you how to play by spanking you like a little school girl.

You will yell. You will cry. You will never laugh. You will step by step memorize enemy locations, level traps and upgrades to the point of madness...and then you'll continue to the next level and do it all over again.

There is one checkpoint in between each level, splitting them into two for each world. There are six worlds in total, making it twelve levels total. If you do not make it to the checkpoint then you will start at the very beginning upon death.There is a boss fight at the end of each world.

You have two weapons the entire game: a sword and a spear. Use these to navigate and decimate your way through each uniquely designed world. There are upgrades. If you can manage not to take any damage, each upgrade you get builds on top of the last one. It starts with a wooden shield, next upgrade is a metal shield and you can charge your spear throw. After that comes a viking helmet, then a flame sword. Only once you have claimed all of these upgrades can you truly claim you are still only mediocre at this game. There is also a bonus item you can find called Mjolnir, that gives you temporary invulnerability.

BEWARE: This game instills hope just as fast as it takes it from you.

If that's not your cup of tea, then you are a sissy.

I'm having a wonderful time generating a massive dynasty and plopping down kids everywhere I can. The learning curve is a bit steep, like most Paradox grand strategy games, but it's similar enough to CK2 that I was able to figure stuff out pretty quickly, and a number of features are gated behind techs I don't have unlocked yet, so I don't have to worry about those yet.

The game still has some flaws but the devs really do their best to fix bugs asap, I think. All in all I like the game. I never made it past chapter 2 or level 8 with a character, I'm having way too much fun creating new chars and testing/learning the rules in this game to really get to know the mechanics for all classes before playing through. And there are just tons of possibilities considering that! 
The other reason is that I want to wait for all the bugs in the end game being fixed, I heard there are a lot.

But It's a good game, I already spend a lot of time in it and it still catches me. Just be informed that it's still somewhat in development and you might need some patience before it's polished.

Pros:
-Immersive and interesting world
-Fun characters

-Great sound design

Cons:
-A few bugs (but nothing gamebreaking)
-Almost "too" much content: the game feels unfinishable to me (is surely a good thing for most people)
-Some music is repetitive (the Gwent one particularily)
-The crafting and item durability mechanics that plague just about every AAA adventure game bog them down without adding anything meaningful

Overall: potentially the best game ever made, most likely the best rpg

Rainbow Six Siege is a tactical 5v5 shooter loosely based off the Tom Clancy novel. But this game is much more than that. Compared to FPS games of the past, what makes Siege so much different? First-Person shooters may be the most over saturated game genre. Siege is a breathe of fresh air. The best 3D platformer on PC, no question. Probably the best 3d platformer I've played as well. Some of the design is clearly inspired Super Mario Sunshine, and out-does it in every single aspect.

It's funny, it's surprisingly well-written (for both kids and adults), the voice acting is actually quite good, the levels are well designed and fun, the art style is great, and it's probably the cutest game I've played yet, with unlockable hats and colour schemes for Hat Girl.

Oh, and the soundrack is wonderful! There's a huge variety of songs, most of which change slightly depending on what you are doing. It's just a delight to listen to while playing, sets the tone really well and gives off a really great positive and happy vibe overall.

It is very clear that the team at Gears for Breakfast put a whole lot of love into this game. It shows in every aspect, from the big things, like the level design and characters, to the little things like a dedicated blow-kisses button. Cute as puppies.

It took me 16 hours to collect all 40 Time Pieces, and it was worth it and totally achievable for the average player, I'm happy they decided not to have something ridiculous like 800 like in Super Mario Odyssey, sometimes less is more.

Also as a bonus, this is probably the first 3d platformer with official mod support. Great stuff.  

If there were any criticisms I have of the game, it would be that the way you get new hats with different abilities is a little weirdly paced (I unlocked a hat long before I actually got to the level where it is actually useful) and that some hats are a little underutilized. Also, sometimes there was a bit too much dialogue and not enough platforming in one or two levels, but that's about it.

If you love 3d platformers like Mario and Banjo-Kazooie, then look no further. This is probably the best one.

Cool concept, very poor execution. A buggy mess, not even worth playing during free weekend. In my ~2-3 hours of playtime, here are some of the issues and bugs I saw:

-Totally broken matchmaking, as noted by other reviewers; takes 5-15 minutes to find a game (which usually lasts about that long).
-Clipping and teleporting issues, including the killer scoring the final blow from the other side of a wall
-A player dc'd while healing me and I was stuck unable to move or interact with anything - even the killer couldn't attack me, and I had no choice but to DC myself, earning no XP for the match
-The new "nurse" character seems ridiculously overpowered, although this could just be because I'm a noob
-Poor optimization - my computer runs most games on ultra but I had to drop down to medium to get a steady FPS
-The "skill checks" are horribly desynced between when you press space bar and when it actually stops, causing me to fail many that I was sure I pressed on time

Wait until deeply discounted or until the multitude of bugs get some attention.

Overrated grabage. Anything that has (metroidmania) (souls like) in their bio should be avoided, for it is a clear sign of being devoid of creativity and a red flag for, "We dont know what we're doing but we played Mario and DS1 once so I think we can make a game." Story is another vague too deep for you bore. I hope you like reading walls of text for hours. Idk, maybe if you're thirteen you'll find the story interesting but even so its nothing you have'nt seen before but with bugs this time. The Ai is below a Ps1 game level of intelligence, enemies will jump off cliffs and attack through walls. Enemies and bosses will spam the same abilites which will lead to guranteed damage, completly unfair. Would'nt mind the unfair spam as much but the walk back to where you died takes far too long. You'd think the level design team would know how to make a shortcut but nope. The most "souls like" thing in this game is the bad camera and input delay (not often but still present) which will lead to a bunch of damage and deaths. An upgraded weapon doesn't make you feel more powerfull it's just one or two enemies take one less hit sometimes. Idk if this is a glitch but enemies take a random amount of hits to kill sometimes. Upgrades and buying items cost so much you'd think this is an Ubisoft game. The map is the worst, it doesn't come with a compass and you have to buy a new one for every area "usually for too much money", from some guy in a random spot which you can't find because you don't have a map. A poor map and a vauge story will leave you wandering for hours through places you've seen six or seven times and it sucks. When other games do this they get flamed and Hallow Knight should be no exception. I could go on about how revisiting the same areas so many times makes them lose their charm and how alot of the level design is bad but I've gone on too long. This game is worth five bucks ten tops if you interested in a mediocre platformer with a boring story.

Super Meat Boy is a fun and frustrating high-speed platformer with really responsive controls, so you'll need the kind of dexterity that is unreasonable to expect from keyboard control.  There are a ton of very short levels, and a tremendously fast interface lets you zip between those levels—or respawn after deaths—at ludicrous speed.  This is good, because you're going to die a lot.

I have four suggestions, these are just throwaways, and I doubt they'll get any attention, but here they are.

1. Item Trading.
The ability to hold out an item to trade during a trial, where both can see the others item, and both can press the secondary action button to accept, or walk away to decline. This could let survivors know before they drop their item what they're getting, or to see what item their teammate has.

2. Chest Skill Checks
Survivors will have skill checks (not affected by Killer skill check perks) to determine the durability, tier, and possibly, if running Ace in the Hole, add-on's. This would help change the courses of games, and depending on how well you do, your life. Perks like Plunderers could be used to affect Skill Checks on chest as well.

3. Community Made Run/Walk Cycles
Competitions for new (dev approved) animations for certain effects could be held, where the winner's could be implemented as a buy-able swap-out for the normal (normal running and walking being most costly, rarely seen ones (such as Tier 3 Insanity Doctor's) being the cheapest. This would allow more diversity, yet still no insane or unrealistic qualities, to how Survivors or Killers look.

4. Secondary Items
These would be one use items, separate in key bind and use, from main items. These could be used much like firecrackers, having a single use while still bringing a dramatic new amount of possibility to synergies and overall gameplay. This is the biggest stretch of all these suggestions, but still could be something to look at.

So other than that, incredible game, despite the memes everything works great, yadayadayada hitboxes, something something entitled player. Thanks for making an incredible game, look forward to what comes next.

I haven't completed a single game halfway through and I've seen how messed up and boring this game is. Even during the Steam Summer sale the full game, DLC's and expansions, was way too expensive, ~$90.00 overall. 
The movement system is flawed, not allowing my units to evade from hostile units and make awkward costly decisions, even if I skip turns. Workers alone cannot build roads anymore, making things seem more slower. AI is awkward and cannot defend their own cities, maybe because cities can no longer hurt units defensively. I was worried about the workers being temporary, and rightly so, which makes it more tedious to choose workers over other things to produce. 
As a veteran of Civ 5 games I completed, these new features just increase micromanagement and distracts the player from their own goals. 
Wonders are limited because of their restrictive requirements as well as needing to literally delete a tile so that one can be built, why???? 
Overall, I wish I didn't buy this game in the first place knowing Steam's joke of a refund policy.
I sincerely do not recommend this game to anyone who likes civ 5.

This game is without a doubt a huge creative blast for the gaming industry. An example of out-of-the-box thinking that has grown like ivy throughout the game world. An example of how to create something that will be imprinted in memory and will pass through the years with its head held high. An example of how you can create something without the numbers "6-7-8" in the name, creating a whole new universe with such manic pedantry and attention to detail that many can only envy this. Hideo Kojima in this game acts as either a desperate prophet, or a chaotic demiurge of lonely spaces of art, or a creator who personally detonates the very Big Bang that is so important for this game. It is difficult to deny the influence that this game has had by the mere fact of its appearance, just as it is now difficult to deny the undoubted influence of Hideo Kojima on the development trends of the modern gaming world.

A lot in «DEATH STRANDING» is aimed at the idea of unification. In the role of a courier, plowing the endless lonely expanses of America, having survived a massive catastrophe, you feel so lonely that something is shrinking inside. But you are always aware of your goal, your highest destiny - to be the thread that sews the scattered scraps of a surviving society. And therefore the main character - Sam Bridges very quickly moves from the screen into you, and the problems of this world become your problems. The plot is so complex that it is almost impossible to tell it without spoiling the impression of the future game. We will limit ourselves only to the fact that it is as crazy as possible, incredibly perfected in its aesthetics, but at the same time it does not cross the border of good taste.

The most important thing here is not even the perfection of the visual, not the impeccably created scenery of the dying world, not even the incredible main plot, filmed with the participation of world cinema stars. The main thing is the feeling of the game world, the feeling of one's unity with other players, the pure emotion that this game gives. It is impossible to convey the feeling when you make routes that no one has walked, leaving help for future players, feeling the pride of a pioneer. Or, when you suddenly discover that through a gorge that would have to go around for a long time, one of the players carefully threw a ladder, leaving it for the future, simply because you have one goal. It is not just that many jokingly say that "why are you interrupting my wonderful courier adventures with some kind of plot." And this is an incredible gaming experience that is difficult to overestimate, infinitely far from the falsity of the "open" world of many multiplayer games. This is not just a game, but something more, and no more words are needed.

So after 520 hours I will make a short review:
Many people complain about bugs and yes they exist, but the only one that is a little problem actually is that it is difficult to get a lobby in Survive with friends. 
BUT: after a learning curve (you rather won't be a master after some hours: after about 100 hourse you start to get good and know the maps, clever hiding spots etc.
It is indeed very addictive, as a Survivor your heart will pump wildly while being chased especially at the beginning. As a Killer you will feel adrenalon in your veins and be uncalm sitting on your chair, holding your face close to the screen and trying to catch Survivors.
The best and worst thing in this game is that there is no AI: every player is a real life person. The community can be great and on the other side really salty, but the fun moments will be more often. 
All in all this game is absolutely amazing for it's money and I never ever have played a game this much before (and I played many great games)

This game is off the hook! It has a feel of NovaLogic's Delta Force series and Joint Operations. The map style is especially reminiscent of that genre. It also reminds me of a more grown up version of the infantry combat in BFBC2 without all the neon junk, hit markers, and poor hit registration issues. When all you can do is use the words "feel" and "remind" it means this game obviously is its own unique qualities! 

There is good 3D positional sound and the weapons and explosives sounds  (while maybe not surpassing Post Scriptum) immerse you into the game. I am cutting my teeth in Coop and it is hard to tell the difference between AI and human players. Highly recommend!

I'll keep you posted!

10/02/2019 Here is  some follow-up. I now have 500 hours of play time in the game. The developers are very active in their support and continuing development of the game. 

I wish to leave some very subjective thoughts on the multiplayer PvP aspect of the game. The weapons are very lethal and the time to kill is very low. It is unforgiving if someone cannot camp. I always favored objective style game play and I never had much interest in team death match. There is one objective mode they call "Push". One side attacks and captures the enemies positions and the other defends. The other is called "Frontline" and each side has a base to defend and in the middle is a neutral base to capture.

In the Frontline game mode, both sides are pushing to capture the same base at the same time. So goes the theory. In practice, most of  the players on both teams are no where near the objective and they are simply sniping or they are not attempting to capture but are simply looking to ambush. It works that way because because of the time to kill (ttk). I say it is very frustrating to have to suffer the poor team death match players who find their way into the objective game mode only to continue to play tdm against the objective cappers. Many never attempt to capture a point even as the last man on their team.

This is an old gaming problem made worse by the weapons. The game scoring DOES reward the captures, so it's not uncommon for the top scorer having a barely 1 to 1 or negative K/D ratio. Some may say that is "tactical realism"game play. This is like Arma without the awkward clunky character movement or overly involved game mechanics.

That is why I can't thumb down the game. I would prefer "Tactical Arcade" where there is more to the gun play. Gun play where you can be ambushed by a camper, but with a slower TTK, through clever character movement, a cool head, and steady aim and weapons control you can still prevail. Especially in close quarter combat. That is opposed to the gun game experience here: "I'm camping and ready to open fire, you are on the move to the objective, I see you first, PEW PEW you're dead, death simulator".

There are times that you happen to fall in with some good tactical minded players on a public server who are interested in smartly working the objective. It is those times that are HIGHLY gratifying and FUN! They're not interested in going off alone to hide in some shadow to just ambush players for 10 seconds of gun firing in a round. If you can team up with friends on a server you will derive the most amount of satisfaction from this game. I share these thoughts to help someone make the best buying decision for their gaming fix.
Ever since changed to official server, my ping is always ard ms, anyone know how to fix this>?

I played the alpha version back in 2013, I had fun with the game for awhile but it felt really shallow and lacking in content, it was also poorly balanced. However it just needed to be expanded upon and it would have been a fantastic game. Unfortunately that isn't what happened. Six years later and the game has changed on a fundamental level, and not for the better. I'm not even sure you could call this game an RPG anymore.

[b]Just a few things of note:[/b]
[list]
[*]Skill trees have been removed from the game, with nothing to replace them.
[*]Levels and experience have been removed from the game.
[*]No skills to unlock.
[*]None of the gear is interesting, it's all simple stat upgrades, there are no passive abilities, hit effects, or anything like that.
[*]Every time you leave your region all of your gear gets taken away.
[*]There is no reason to fight 95% of enemies.
[*]The strength level of all the enemies in every region is the same, the game never gets any harder than your first region.
[/list]

You can also collect things like hang gliders and boats but the moment you leave an area it all gets taken away for no reason and you have to find it all again. There is no in game justification for any of this either. It's completely baffling. If I collect a boat in one region and try to sail into a neighboring ocean the boat will [b]DISAPPEAR WHILE I'M RIDING IT. [/b] The game is chock full of things like this where it feels like the developer is just trying to waste your time.

There are zero progression mechanics beyond tiny upgrades to your movement ability that take hours to get. I'm talking about things like sailing 2% faster, swimming 2% faster, etc.
[i][b]I'm not kidding, this is the only form of permanent character progression in the game.[/b][/i]

Once you've played for a few hours you've seen everything the game has to offer, there is no reason to go to different regions, the gameplay is fundamentally the same thing over and over. There is no real progression or variety.

I could keep going on about every single confusing design decision in this game but that wouldn't really add anything, the game just isn't fun. Consider it a cautionary tale for why developing a game in complete isolation with no outside feedback for 6 years may be a bad idea.

Subnautica should have been a favorite game of mine. It's has everything I like: Single player, non-shooter, openworld exploration, alien tech to figure out, stuff to build, and so on. But it doesn't work for me.

I've had this game since beta preview, and have started a new game every update. Some things have greatly improved, but others, not so much, at least in my opionion.

I think it might be the lack of any guidance, and the randomness of the resources, which would be the case if this was IRL, but this is a game. For example, at the beginning of the game, there's this one resource that is needed to make one of the *basic* survival tools, but no info on where it might be found. I had to Google it. Likewise, I shouldn't have to spend 20 minutes plus pounding open every random limestone outcropping I see, in my case an ultimately futile attempt, to find the ore needed to make another tool. I gave up. Again.

It's probably just me. The game probably follows certain tropes that I'm just not familar with, or otherwise can't see, or understand, but in the end, left me bored and frustrated. YMMV, after all, a lot of others have loved it.

I am a fan of the civ series, since the first one. This one has added more in-depth layers to the game than any of the previous titles. However, it needs serious balancing—which I believe will achieve thanks to the community feedback. I have only played with China so far, and thus I must restrict my suggestions to that nation alone. 
China suggestions: 
-The wall takes forever, not because of the factors you would imagine but because it uses tiles that are acquired very slow.
-Could you imagine what would have been like if the Great Wall had ladders on both sides? Yes, it would have defeated the purpose of the defense—well, that is how it works in the game; the enemy has the same access to the Great Wall that China has. So it is just a football game to see who gets to jump on the wall first. You can't occupy every single tile of the wall with units, so they jump on it and attack you—with all the full defense benefits of the wall on their side. In other words, you built a platform for your enemy. 

Please, let's make China Great Again and fix that wall.

* Feels like a table top experience. If you played tabletop kingmaker even better.
* It doesn't hold your hand. You have to think once in a while. It is refreshing. 
* Visually it is very beautiful.
* Red Panda! 

BUT...

* It doesn't hold your hand it doesnt tell whats going on properly. quest log is desastrous. you have to check the internet for solutions multiple times. 
* It is not unforgiving it if unfair. Almost cheating at times. Shelyn paladin bossfight, enraged owlbears. 
* Sometimes makes you feel like you are playing d&d with a DM that hates you. Unfair fights. Having to save (and load multiple times) before every lock and trap. At the first levels healing is a problem too. 
* Annoying companions and annoying npcs. DM definitely hates you. Ridicules you at every opportunity. You are supposed to feel like a baron but noo. 
* Has some silly design decisions like - carrying around 50 kilos of food but the game tells you that you don't have enough rations and have to hunt but cannot hunt indoors.-  
* Production quality is meeh. 
* Voice acting is amateurish. A lot of the Player character voices are annoying 
* Assumes you are very familiar with the tabletop pathfinder rules. 
* Plot seems nice. Well they have Chris! it has to be. (Well after playing for 80 hours, plot is very mediocre after all so moving this to negatives. Chris has disappointed me big time.)
* And after sooo many patches it still has annoying bugs that cripple your gameplay. 
* Loading times are ridiculous even when installed on a ssd. 
* While music has its moments once in a while, it got old very quickly and i turned it down at one point. 
* I would have refunded if i understood what the game really is at the first 2 hours. It starts relatively bug free and balanced then it loses its nuts. 

Do i recommend it? For tabletop rpg fans maybe..
For others? No. Stay away. Wait for the devs to fix bugs and change wrong game design decisions. 

One little advice to the Devs. Please find a proper Game Designer. This is not the way to make computer games. Seriously I feel like Game Cheates multiple times. What was that ridiculous fight with valeries mentor guy the paladin. 

Come on...
