After 153 hours of playing and finishing the main story, the expansions, and a majority of the secondary quests/treasure hunts, I can honestly say... I feel empty inside. I feel, quiet literally, depressed that the adventure is over.  That is an epic indication that the game was amazing.  Now I have to pick up the pieces of my life and figure out what to do with them!  For the escapist at heart, this game is for you.  It is a truly emotional game. For those who have played it, let's admit it that you got hit in the feels during the Baron quest. It probably has one of the richest stories I have ever played in an RPG with Dragon Age Origins/Awakening being up there with it.  Yes, there are bugs here and there, graphical ones mostly, but overall it is a real work of art with some great attention to detail.  If I could ask one wish of CD PROJEKT RED, it is to do the trilogy honor by going back and refreshing 1 & 2.  I'd have trouble going back and playing them after the eye candy of 3; although 2 isn't too dated yet.  Anyways, to summarize, this game is well worth the cost -- even at full price. Say goodbye to your friends and your family and DO IT.  It is the best hit of fisstech you'll ever take.

Celeste is one of my favourite games, even if I haven't completed it yet. I love the pixel graphics mixed in with the beautiful soundtrack, which is one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. 

Celeste is game which takes part with a young girl by the name of Madeline, trying for some reason to climb Celeste mountain. During the intro Madeline discovers she has a unique ability which allows her to dash in any direction quickly. This dash ability creates for some challenging tasks which requires accurate button presses.

There are 8 chapters which have multiple levels in each, (with over 700 levels in the whole game!) and each chapter a new game mechanic is added. For example: In the first chapter there are platforms which move when you touch them, and then stop giving you momentum in order to cross a large gap in the level, the 5th chapter when you dash some platforms with move instantly and slowly return. Which can lead to some interesting level designs. 

Celeste rewards exploration. In each chapter there are multiple strawberries you can collect which don't really do anything and are usually far off the main story but it is nice collecting all the strawberries and feeling like you have beat that chapter 100%. In each chapter there is a cassette tape you can pick up called a B-Side which unlocks a far far significantly more difficult level, which can keep you trying, and trying again, and again until you give up and come back tomorrow and then smash that piece of impossibleness trash away with you're super amazing skillzzzzz you got.

Overall the game is worth the $19.99 USD.


You get:
-Amazing soundtrack
-Beautiful pixel graphics
-Unique chapter design keeping the game from going stale
-Far far far difficult B-Side levels
-And you get... STRAWBERRIES!

This game seems fine to people who haven't really played or invested any time into past paradox games, but people who have share very similar sentiments involving the serious lack of features and for good reason. The game often might as well play itself as you have very little in the way of choice. There is basically no depth to any of the systems and mechanics in the game. You should not be able to learn the ins and outs of a grand strategy game in less than an hour. This game really feels like a cash grab to lure more casual players into sinking as much money as they can squeeze out of them and farm good reviews from those dog dookie websites. I have no problem with CK3 being a simpler game than its predecessor as hell, my monkey brain could never get a hold of being able to play it but what I do have a problem with is the abhorrent lack of features that will be pushed out in future DLC and for a 30 DOLLAR price tag, I wonder how much its actually going to cost before you can play the true base game before it was chopped up and locked behind future paywalls. I didnt have as much problems with them milking the ever loving hell out of ck2 and eu4 because those were great games that you would likely get some return on investment on, but I am very doubtful of how much future dlc can actually add to this experience. I highly recommend anyone who purchased this game and is still eligible for a refund to do so immediately as the 1-3hrs you spend so far is about the true extent of the depth of gameplay you will likely ever experience.

A bit disappointing.  As a big fan of the first two games, I had high hopes for this one.  I feel like I should enjoy it too, but ultimately I found the game kind of boring.  I finished the game with one character, got 2/3 with two others before I got bored and quit, and only did two-and-a-half of the DLCs with the max-level character before I was bored out of my brain and uninstalled.

Visually the game is very similar to BL2, with some enhancements along the way.  The usual iterative improvements you would expect.  Similarly, the gameplay is improved over BL2.  In this area I feel the improvements were more significant.  The enemies, locations, gun-generation, drop-rates, fundamental combat gameplay, etc, are all significantly improved.  In terms of pure gameplay, I would consider this the best game in the series.  All the more reason why I find it bewildering that I ultimately got bored.

The writing is perhaps the game's weakest area.  Many of the characters are badly written, and many returning characters feel like the writer did not understand them.  The jokes often fall flat, which is bad in a game that lays them on pretty thick.  The main villains are terrible, as is the Mary Sue in the supporting cast, but both of these complaints are well-documented all over the internet.

The quest writing is also quite frustrating, with most quests taking the "Haha, you thought that was the end?  No, we just changed the rules!" approach.  I think this was one of the things that most impacted my enjoyment of the game, as quests tended to drag-out and get boring/frustrating long before I finished them.  I was bored and wanted to do something else, but the conditions just got changed again.  Level design also conflated this.  While the levels were interesting, they tended to feel too long.  That size with lots of alternate paths for different side-quests would not have been so bad, but instead they tended to be one main path and if you did not do the side-quest on the first pass... well, you just added an extra 30 minutes travel-time when you go back for it.

[h1] Preface:	[/h1]
As a child, I grew up with platformers, hell, I had never played an FPS until a year and a half ago. Platformers have been the main games I have been playing for years, until I bought my mega-pc 2 years ago. So when I heard that a [u] brand new Mario game was coming out	[/u] on the Switch, I was joyed to come back to my childhood. I played the game, and was crippingly dissapointed. The game was 90% filler, 5% dull tasks and 5% fun. The game offered no challenge at all and treated basic movement patterns as a rewards. To be sure it wasn't just my skill, I went back and played Galaxy, Galaxy 2 and 64, it is just odyessy being trash. I wanted something [u] new, fresh, fun and at least somewhat challenging.	[/u] The main games I had heard about being a platformer similar was Yooka-Yaylee. Bad game. And I have been hampering after what Mario odyessy should have been. Then I found a small little indie game: A Hat In Time.

[h1] Gameplay:	[/h1]
The most important part of a platformer. The gameplay. Does it feel good? Answer: Hell yes. The control scheme was so damn tight it is completely playable on keyboard and mouse. The way Hat Kid controls is great. Combine this with badges which change gameplay, levels which can offer challenge and most importantly variety. Just like the amazing platformers you rememeber. With mod support now added for free [spoiler] (take notes Edward Mcmillan, you hack fraud) [/spoiler] even more opportunities were added. The hats start off basic, but do a good job of creating an almost metroidvania of going back to levels to test and try out new things, it could be argued that they are not too creative, but they do a great job of streamlining the experience. No complaints in the gameplay department. 

[h1] Graphics:	[/h1]
The cell-shaded department here really carries this particular part. I can imagine in a few years this looking rather out-dated, as the graphics are fine, but only just, hence the style preventing a completely awful write-up. That's not saying the game looks bad however, as the colour pallete not only changes in level, but in sub-sections of the level (called Acts within the game.) Don't get the wrong impression this style and combo of graphics will do until HIT2. Just.

[h1] Atmosphere:	[/h1]
This game oozes charm. From an old western train with an amusing over the top scottish owl from a haunting forest and an old woman gone mad from her lover leaving her chasing you. The voice actors completely annihalate here, each one with great writing and unique character design. A huge shoutout to Yungtown as a ghost 'Snatcher' (He is a youtuber apparently, never watched him.) and Xander Mobus  as the Conductor, absolutely clean house with some amazing voice acting, as well as Jontron really showing his worth in a few lines, would have liked to see a little more from him. And the soundtrack, my word. Absolutely stellar, both the OST and the remixes are great, you can tell the composers really had fun with these tracks, if you look up the OST, songs which should only really play for about 30 seconds max, like the classic pokemon 'you win' tracks, go on for several miniutes and aren't used, presumbly because they are jsut so damn fun to record. And hell, I love them too,

[h1] Longevity:	[/h1]
Free DLC will be added, and Gears for Time have taken a poll asking if people want even MORE content in paid DLC form. Sticking to your original Kickstarter promises AND THEN still giving content to those who pay for it is a great move, and I fully expect to buy DLC for this. Modding support has been added as previously mentioned, as well as extended and remixed tracks in the B-Sides soundtrack DLC. Beautiful. Looking over forums and so on, not only are the devs fairly active, but kind too. This game has the opportunity to really push out some damn good content, and to keep sales fairly high for the next couple of years, and these guys deserve it. 

[h1] TL:DR	[/h1]
Despite costing less than Mario Odyessy, and Yooka-laylee for the devs AND ourselves this game surpasses them easily, becoming an instant classic, up there with the best of them.

-Thanks for reading
-Cain

To be fair, I love the Souls games and Bloodborne is one of my top 5s. I loved this game before I even began to play it. Then I started the game...and I hated it. I wrote my review for this game when I was young. I couldn't even write a grammatically correct sentence back then, so lets fix that and make a new review for Rimworld.

            So, Rimworld is a game that truly speaks for itself. It has so much to offer, and numerous different stories to tell. Tynan Sylvester did a wonderful job making this game. I'm not one to write a lengthy review with pros and cons, so I'll just tell you outright what I think of the game.

            Buy it, full price. The amount of fun I've had with my friends playing this game was amazing. The multiplayer mod really boosts the experience and just makes it fun to live through triumph and tragedy with friends. Singleplayer is great to by the way. So, buy it, coax your friends to buy it, get EDB prepare carefully, make your best pal's character fat and bald, and never talk to them again. Have fun out there and remember, don't let your colonists take drugs or they'll probably kill your favorite dog after they come off the high.
Great all-around experience without the burden of unnecessary online components or fluff and is priced competetively for what it provides.  Highly recommended.

Half life 2 was always a great game. This game puts more emphasis on difficult battles in the first half, and vehicle exploration in the second half. The most memorable part has to be the finale, though I wont spoil anything. 
This game also continues Episode One's feature of teaming up with Alyx throughout most of the game, who makes a great companion and is a proficient fighter. 
Except this, the game is exactly like the previous two games. If you liked those games, this is more than a must-buy. If you didn't, buy it anyway. It is a great game from beginning to end (even if the plot leaves on an unresolved cliffhanger)

Overall, a brilliant game for both half life fans and the first person shooter community. Definitely recommended.
Also, keep a tally of how many real garden gnomes you smashed when going for the Little Rocket Man achievement. I hate that Gnome...

GOOD GAME - HOWEVER, IT SHOULDN'T HAVE LEFT EARLY ACCESS WHEN IT DID

I got this game when it left early access, and when I tried to play it, it would crash every 10 minutes.  That now seems to be corrected in the latest beta patch (so would expect it to be ok next full patch).  It seems to me that it's a recurring theme in all early-access titles (that make it to full release) that they test and develop the game over years with the community, but then release their full-release patch without first testing with the community.  

The game is still littered with bugs:

1. Items and plants respawn on reloading game.  This is touted as a "Feature", but if you've got to rely on exploits to make the world in your game sustainable, that's a bug.

2. When cooking in a cooking pot, instead of cooked food/broth, it spawns another empty pot (really)

3. You can't remove/change armour (really).

The fact that the game can still be seen as "Good" despite these things is quite remarkable, but also a huge disappointment.

I got it for free and beat it last year thanks to the Epic Store, but I had to buy it on Steam just because it's a masterpiece of a game. A journey in which you can choose how to approach it.

[b]Technical bit[/b]
I played this game with my friend, in fact, I bought him a copy too (even though I didn't need to), because it was easier to set up. I have two other friends who have played the whole game through on some third-party software on only one PC, but it didn't work for me and my other friends as much as we liked to. Therefore we opted for connecting trough Origins friend invite (yes, this game requires Origin launcher even on though it’s sold on Steam ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ ). That's as much as is needed to be said about the technical oddity of this game. (The oddity being a co-op only, split screen gameplay). 

[h1]Now to the verdict: [/h1]
[b]Story and Gameplay[/b]
As we played the game, we greatly enjoyed the story, pacing and the mélange of different ideas. Some scenes a very fun, well thought out and cunning camera cuts between the two-character perspectives - I especially loved the Street Fighter -esque gameplay my friend got in one of the levels - which helps the game to always keep things fresh, which made the whole experience feel just right and action packed at the right moments. 

There are some minor plot holes in the story, and there are some things which seem as plot holes when in reality, they are actually great plot twist, as long as you can connect the dots :P Way easier to spot on a second playthrough, yet I can't imagine playing this game once more, when you've seen it, you've seen it all. 

Well okay, there are some points, in which the story differentiates. It's often a difference between choosing one characters ideas/plans over the other ones, which lead to different gameplays (often stealth vs action), yet after having tried some of them out, they did feel a little underwhelming, compared to what we both had envisioned would be happening.

Gameplay, although it had all of the above going for it, still had some... minor inconveniences. Maybe it was because we were playing on a keyboard, but the movement and actions felt sometimes unresponsive and clunky. We also encountered 1 or 2 bugs, after which we were forced to restart. Happily, the checkpoints are frequent, so it didn't matter that much in the long run. 

[b]Graphics[/b]
There were also a couple of different graphical issues. Saying that, I don’t mean bugs in graphics (which although were on highest settings, didn’t match my expectations. Looks good enough, but could be better), but in the motion capture cut scenes, like both characters forgetting a gun on the table in one of the cutscenes, yet in next cutscene, one of them is holding the exact same gun in his hand. That's either magic, or a bug. I opt for the latter :P 

[b]Price[/b]
I would definitely recommend the game, but price of 30 euro is a bit too much. I bought it on a sale where it costed 10 euro, and that a price is way more adequate for this game, in our both humble opinions. (I remind you, I bought the game twice, so the total is 20 euro instead of 60 euro, a terrific difference. And I did it simply for the my and my friend’s convenience). 

There you have it! The good, the bad, and the pricing. 

PS: Friends not included in the price, those you gotta find those yourself.

I have played this game and other CS games for years together now and am pleased to say the developers didn't disappoint at all.. I needed to play on my 3 yr old laptop so I bought this game along with Global Offensive as a package which was well worth the price.

I recommend this game to anyone who:
1. Has a kinda old system which doesn't support the latest games
2. Has bought a PC recently but only for general purposes (PC which only has onboard graphics)

4. Have friends who have any of the above machines and want to play CS with decent graphics

Figured i could spend a few hundred on the gym, or i could just get Beat Saber. Spend hours just moving around already. I try and get an hour or two in every day and i feel really fit now.

Can´t help myself but this feels like "Generic survival game No 214" 

Pros: 

+Cool "Backpack" menu
+Well done crafting book
+Your Char is using "BIC" lighters
+Throwing spears

Cons:

-Story feels like its made in a 5 min rush cause they needed a story
-Bugs
-Graphics only OKish
-Wood chopping simulator

In its core The Forest is just your Generic Survival game. Collect food, build shelters, go to bed and kill Zombies ... Sorry meant Cannibals....

Sure the Developer added some Ideas of their own like the cool Backpack menu or the good looking Survivalbook, but after all... its just another Survival-game.
Besides this "gimmicks" and the fact that there are Cannibals rather then generic overused Zombies...  there is nothing that makes this game different to that 100 other Survivals that flooded Steam.

The Story is told in a 1 min cutscene at the beginning of the game, basicly "save that child wich u seen in that 10 seconds before your Plane crashed"  i guess its the son of the Mainchar, after that there are just a few collectable pictures wich... are supposed to... what exacly?  There is no emotional binding to that child, you dont know if it is even your son. Nothing that makes you actually wanna save it...  and tbh i didn`t, still discovered pretty much all of the Map and only missed out 2-3 caves...

There are no other Roleplay elements, your Char is just a Nameless guy who got the power of Craftmanship...  He/She must be a Master Carpenter. You can (as soon as you got the ressources) craft Spears, Bows, huge buildings and so on. 
No advancing in skills, no learning....  Your Earlygame Bow is as Deadly as a Bow can be, ignoring the fact that making a wooden Bow (that can be used for Hunting/Killing) in RL (especially without any Tools beside a Stoneaxe) is a damn hard and require years of training. Same goes for lit everything else.
You also dont need actuall tools to build anything, just your axe to chop trees...   If you wanna build something just place the blueprint and fill it with the needed things, usually logs...

Graphics are running on max with my 1060Ti and... mmmh they´re ok, no Frostbite engine but who needs it... Only the lighing is sometimes really immersion breaking. Shaddows for example feel especially by night pretty cheap.

I had quite some goodwill with Steam Greenlight games but after the 200st survival game.... nah...
There are just not enough things that make this game feel different. 
Nothing that makes this Uniqe.
Its another generic Survival game.

Tbh i don´t like Survival games anyways, never bought a single one (even tho i got a lot of them for free to play with the one or other Survival infected friend) and got even this for free from a pal...
So maybe a Survival fan will see this as "the choosen one" but for me...  
Its one of hundred others.

Maybe with some really Unique Ideas besides the Menu... or the BIC lighter...
Maybe with a small story, building up emotions so you actually care about that child...

Let's start with the positives, the gunplay is fun, it feels responsive and i like some of the new weapon manufacturer gimmicks. I won't talk too much about gameplay because it's more or less what you would expect. The story is very lackluster and the Calypso twins are not compelling villans in the slightest, it felt like they were trying to make another villain like Handosome Jack with the way they mock you calling you a vault thief (opposed to Jack calling you a bandit) throughout the campaign but it just doesn't work the way it did in BL2. The biggest issue I have with this game, and the reason I just cannot recommend this game are the bugs, from minor inconveniences like the countdown timer for fast travel in a multiplayer lobby only showing up on the first fast travel of the session, to crashes to desktop, a common one many people encounter is crashing to desktop when they try to load into the Guts of Carnivora, however the ones I experienced were not consistent nor did they ever occur in the same location twice. If you are fine with potentially dealing with these bugs (and more) go ahead and get the game, but overall I would still say the best Borderlands experience would be BL2.

I like this game, but at the same time I don't like this game.

Why I like it:
- very colorful and the environment feels so alive.
- map is HUGE

- armors look cool

Why I don't like it:
- the game is way too tactical for me to play (you seriously need potions or food by your side)
- you can't block monster attacks
- counter attacking isn't very great (You're a witcher! how do you not counter enemy attacks as fluidly? Even assassins can do it better!)
- It consumed most of my time.

Overall, it was a good game; however, I wouldn't recommend it to people who don't like tactical combat.

Although to my knowledge the developer left the game shortly after its release, it was also a 1 man team, and this is quite a strong game. I'm sure the brand-new at the time of writing steam workshop will only make it better.

This game is all about strategy, and learning by doing. I suggest you do not look up guides, at least not detailed ones, until you have played around a bit and can sustain ~200 person maps. You lose some of the magic if you learn all the math.

The game gives you access to every building right off the bat, but many won't be used until pretty deep in.  Don't think that just because it's available it's needed.

There are many ways to play this game, and the different setups might be the most fun. Do I want to make an uneducated mob? How about live in the mountains and sustain an educated populace on berries?

It's also one of the most brutal games I've played, finishing me off after hours of trying to save it from a single problem. Completely unforgiving.

I can't say enough good things about this game, it's worth it if you like simulation / strategy games. It's about even with Sim City for me, and thats a AAA release.

Good luck, and may your first town last longer than 10 years.

I only returned this for the sole purpose that the Deluxe edition is a joke, the skin packs add skins no different from their base skin, only different colored. They do  come with helmets but none that are unique to the different hunters and you get some weapon skin packs. I played this game up until i could refund it and i can say i have already experienced the lack of invigorating story the first two had, Claptrap is...Claptrap and that may sound okay at first but it just seems like they copy and pasted him in with no changes, at least in 2 there was an interesting event that unfolds in this one...you just step off the bus and meet him? 

The meat and potatos;
The gunplay is great, everything is smooth and the weapons plentiful. The replay ability is there but if you do not play with friends i feel it may become too bland and uninspired after your first few hours. Characters return and conveniently after the Crimson Raiders had eliminated Jack and brought 'peace' to Pandora and while Lilith was looking for a Map they just go to the dumps and are eradicated? Im sorry i dont understand, the newly united superpower from 2 is just gone...hard to get behind. I love the sliding mechanic and the attachment to guns are great i will be looking forward to Borderlands 4 should it release on Steam in a timely manner. 

The base game is not worth $60, pick it up for $30 while you can or $40-$45 if you can. If you want to get even so much as a good deal when its not on sale you will be spending $100 to get the game and the Season Pass, without it you will miss out on a ton of content that was probably stripped right out to serve as a separate product. And if you were unlucky enough to get just Borderlands 3 getting all the content for a decent price (I.E getting the game and the pass for DLC) youll be looking at $90 to procure all the dlc for a good deal. 

I might repurchase Borderlands 3 base edition before it goes off sale, i will have to make the decision based on if my friends also get it.

Right now there are three big RPGs out there: 1) Pathfinder: Kingmaker, 2) Divinity Original Sin 2, and 3) Pillars of Eternity 2: Deadfire. How does Kingmaker fit? Here is a list of the pros and cons.

Pros:
1. Great character customization.  More races, classes, and subclasses than I've ever seen in a game. 
2. Tons of content for your dollar.  Usually I'm left wanting more but here I was often wondering how much more of the game there was until it ended. 
3. Good creature and level design.
4. Many awesome female characters and villains. 
5. Ruling a kingdom is great fun at first.  Decisions feel important and weighty at the beginning. 

Cons:
1. Not enough character portraits when creating a character.  You can import your own if you're willing to take the time but many of the default ones are mediocre at best.
2. Too much waiting! I've played almost 200 hours of this game and much of it was resting or marching my party back and forth across the map.  The former can be shortened by hitting space-bar during rest to skip the part banter. 
3. Bugs and bad design. My game crashed many times and when it did I always had to restart my entire computer. Some bosses were unfairly difficult and could hardly be touched even with a super buffed party.  Near the end of the game I had to switch to story mode because some bosses were so challenging they made me want to rage quit.  I got nearly all the way to the final boss and then a bug prevented the story from advancing. 
4. Ruling a kingdom eventually becomes a boring game of micromanagement that distracts from the games action.You'd do well to turn on kingdom development to auto after you get your fill.
5. The overarching story is mediocre in my opinion. 

Overall Pathfinder Kingmaker has better character creation than Pillars of Eternity 2 or Divinity Original Sin 2.  Divinity Original Sin 2 has better graphics and (in my opinion) a better story. I can't recommend Pathfinder at this time; I had heard it was bugged and waited quite a while to play it but it seems that it currently is still too buggy to play.

This is a game that scratches a very particular itch, but does it so exceedingly well that it's hard to put down. The process of discovering new technology, logistics and automation options, and problem solving to automate more and more of your production is deeply satisfying. The world you build in is relatively basic, more of a canvas than an exciting environment to explore, but the local fauna are lively enough to keep you on your toes. 

The game is also very well optimized. I expected my CPU to buckle as my first factory began to grow to a ridiculous scale (a la Dwarf Fortress) but everything runs silky smooth even when you're producing tens of thousands of components per minute. Even with multiple players.

Best experience I've ever had playing a video game, ever. It is my favorite game of all time for sure. There are times in this game where you can feel the tension while adrenaline is running through you, all while amazing music plays in the background. I remember facing off with genichiro on the rooftop while the peak of the song was playing, literally gave me goosebumps, nothing can touch you in that moment. No other game has ever made me feel that way. Its almost like a drug, I replay it upping the difficulty to experience that feeling again. If your new to games, I'd stay away until your more comfortable. If your a huge gamer that enjoys a challenge and feel that games are always easy and too forgiving then this is definitely your game. Not for everyone, but damn is it a good game. Rushing in like a madman spamming attack and parry won't get you anywhere. Study enemies moves and learn what works, what prothstetic tool is effective etc (Spamming parry isnt that bad, recommended if your still learning that timing for certain attacks and patterns). You'll eventually click and master the game. Then you have the time of your life and whoop the games ass. I have just one complaint: the soundtrack is SO fucking epic, that I wish music tracks would trigger more often, and not just in certain situation when you, lets say "reach a goal". But hats off to Kojima for handpicking these tracks/bands and the moments in which to play them, I totally see why it's done the way it's done.
As for the real complaint: the ingame menus interface is simply not intuitive. It's not a tragedy, but it takes some getting used to.

Anyway - best game I've played in years! A true revelation for me - I was expecting to be disappointed. In the end, I haven't had so much fun exploring and discovering at my own pace since Subnautica.
Took me about 40h of gameplay just to find the common denominator through out the game that made the biggest impression on me: attention to detail. And I don't mean visual details, graphics.. I mean everything.
When you walk across uneven terrain, your char spreads his legs a bit in order to gain more balance while hopping forwards.
When you climb down a rope, around a tiny stone bump, if you tense the rope just right, it will wedge over that bumb which will in turn give you momentum that will push you and your cargo accordingly.
It is possible to have a separate audio source for sounds that come from BB (that baby in a tank) when it communicates with you, just to make it more immersive - I mean when have you ever heard of a game where it's possible to use 2 different audio sources? And it even makes sense.
Entire physics engine that takes care of walking and driving, and ragdoll interaction with objects and NPCs - too much to describe here but, like I said, a lot of details.
Jumping over anything is done amazingly! Try walking over a water stream/river that is too deep, you will be swept away in the most realistic manner. 
You can sit on a bike sideways, the regular way... but if you approach it from rear -> that is also covered with the appropriate animation.
Wanna unload hand carried luggae into a "cargo space" (avoiding spoilers here).. you can do it through the primary cargo managment interface just like anything else (which you will be using A LOT).. but in this particular situation it's enough to simply "release" the cargo from your hands (let go of the mouse button), if you are next to the "cargo space", and it will automatically be placed where it needs to be. It's small things like this that show you how it's one of those rare games that was released when it was actually finished! So this literally means you don't even have to click a button to perform an action.. you have to make "half a click" :)))

I won't go further into detail because it's almost impossible without spoilers. I don't want to reveal "what is possible" to future players, discovering everything is what makes this journey so worth it. At least to me.

Those people who keep saying it's a "walking simulator" and that it's boring because of too much walking? Total crap.
Ofc walking is a huge part of it.. but it's done in the perfect manner just like everything else. Every quest/route is just short enough not to become tedious or boring, and yet just long enough to make it interesting and intense, especially if there are "bad guys" in between. And as you play you constantly keep unlocking more and more new stuff and expand on the basic "walking" experience. So don't dare listening to anyone that has less than at least 20h of gameplay because they haven't seen shit yet. Even me with my 40h at the moment is honestly not enoguh to make a proper review.

Just buy the game and play it.. don't bother reading too much about it. It's not neccessary. The game is fantastic, and you only won't enjoy it if your head is pre-filled with negative trash from simple minded idiots who can't enjoy a good game.

I bought this game in Alpha 0.98.31, it is an awesome game for an alpha stage.
The game play is extremely difficult even on the default start. But with great risks come great rewards.
In the 30 hours I put in, I have lost almost every battle that my characters engaged in so far. But every loss makes them stronger and tougher since they gain experience by taking damage. My aim is to keep all of them alive, I don't care if I lose the battle.
One strategy I like to do is make the city guards kill my enemies by luring them close to the city. After they are dead, I loot their bodies and keep the good equipment and sell the rest.
One faction that that strategy does not work on is the Black Dragons. They sent a war party of 30 elite to my base of six veteran warriors. I thought I could make them detour from their current path (you get a notification on screen when an enemy is moving toward your base. You can follow their movements in real-time on the map). I sent one of my fastest warriors in a preemptive strike to try to get them to follow him. He shot a shot a few with a crossbow but they did not deviate. He charged them from behind, that made half of them turn around and fight, but running away is difficult when you are outnumbered and surrounded by at least 5 warriors with superior equipment and training. My guy got cut down in less than 5 seconds but unconscious. They just caught up with the rest and continued. I had to send my second fastest runner to heal the first one.
After that I realized I could not fight them as I was, so I ordered my squad to wait it out in a nearby town while they ransacked my base.
Not to worry, the buildings will still stand and my squad is alive, I will get them back for that later when I can match their strength and numbers.

As the game is right now is how I want it to stay. A few things that I think could make combat easier for the player to control would be some squad command buttons and individual command buttons (or the same buttons but it depends on how many are selected). Something that gives them orders to retreat from a fight, because I keep clicking an area away from the fight but the character takes too long to obey. Or there should be a technique they can train that allows them to perform a maneuver to get out of the brawl when the player orders a retreat. It shouldn't be known at the start but learned, is my thought. Either from a training dummy or a skill learned after several lost fights.

With so many early access games available these days it's nice to find a game which is actually finished. 

Euro Truck Sim 2 was an impulse buy, but it didn't take me very long to realise that I'd got lucky and had found a great game.

As a simulator it's great. You need to know the basic road rules but you don't get bogged down spending lots of time stuck on inane tasks. 

It has a lot of options for how realistic you want your gameplay to be too. You can choose the type of gearbox, whether auto or manual, and there's a further couple of modes for the choice of automatic or manual gear change modes. 

The career is also full of options. Early on you start out drving other people's vehicles, but you get a choice for whether you want to just slog it out and keep doing jobs until you can afford to buy your own vehicle, or you can borrow money from the bank and purchase your first rig. 

When you do buy a truck there are plenty of customisation options available, some of which are practical and others which are aesthetic. But you do end up feeling like you've bought a vehicle with an element of personalisation. Of course, you can opt to just buy an off-the-shelf rig and save a little money.

So far, I haven't spent a huge amount of time in ETS2, but this is definitely a game which I find myself looking forward to playing. The jobs I've done are long enough to make you feel like you've spent a decent amount of time driving, but they're not overly long and tedious. But that could all change: I assume there's a sleeper cab on my truck for a reason.

I'm currently playing with a joystick which seems fine. There's enough control over the truck in all situations. But I definitely think my experience would benefit from having a proper steering wheel and pedals. 

If you're into fast action and explosions, this probably isn't the game for you. But if you like simulations with a strong element of strategically building up a business, I really recommend this game.

This game, is a mix of adrenaline, and a mix of relaxation while you spread your culture, religion, or your power. You can win the game by science, domination, culture, and a few more, but those are the most common, and most enjoyable. I personally love playing science and domination. You get a nice mix of everything in those games, and i mean, come on, war is fun, and so is science! From worrying about your happiness to keep Revelation at bay, to worrying about Russia assembling units around your borders, this game is sure to give you a gratifying, and amazing experience. Many of which you will find yourself telling your friends about. This game is addicting as hell, you will find yourself slugging along at 4 in the morning "Just....One.....More....Turn" and so on. The combat is brilliant, the game is pretty balanced, only a few issues with that, but hard to notice, and rare to come across, and it's a blast to play with friends, and by yourself. Now, if you are a civ4 player coming to 5, the new diplomacy will take some getting used to. ALWAYS and i mean ALWAYS have a good defense, or civs who are bigger, and better than you will walk all over you to expand, but if your military is a threat, they will back off. Also, your actions can affect your relations with the other civs. If you were to make a proposal in the world congress a civ docent like, it will make then VERY angry with you, deepening on the proposal, it could be a war on your hands. Overall, the game is worth every penny, and it one of my favorite games of all time, a MUST HAVE!!!

EtG is simply awesome.  An intense twin stick shooter mixed with some bullet hell located within the dark and dangerous dungeons of NES Zelda.  Well, that is my initial impression at least! lol!  A+++...I can't believe how well it looks, sounds, and plays. Definitely chasing the dragon with this one...and I can't stop.  

EDIT:  A lot of folks are saying EtG is much too hard.  For me it is very hard as well but I realize everytime I play I seem to get just a little bit better.  That is a great feeling in and of itself.  It takes practice and patience (something sorely lacking in todays instant gratification society) and there is no instant win button with this game.  Kudus to the dev for not dumbing down the difficulty and giving an actual challenge. 

P.S. A big help for me gameplay wise was switching from KB&M and going with a gamepad.  It made a world of difference and is in my opinion the only way to experiece this game.  There is way too much dodging and weaving in and out of bullets to be fiddling around with a clickity clackity keyboard.

Having played DOS2 and POE1/2, this is the current modern crpg that has captured my heart. Harkening back to Baldur's Gate, this is one of the few games that really captures the feel of D&D or (cough) Pathfinder in a video game. No longer bugged plagued as it was originally, this game is amazingly indepth with hundreds of hours of content and replayability.

In fact, as of this review with 272 hours, I've only managed to complete about 1/3rd (I believe) or perhaps less of the entire game's main storyline.

Hundreds of hours of customization, replayability, and a fun campaign makes this a perfect game for any gamers looking for a true to heart RPGTabletop experience or seeking D&D/Pathfinder in a video game. (Also this game has mods <3, most enjoyable is the turn based mod to truly turn this into a D&D/Pathfinder game)

MODS--
Recommended mods in order to streamline portions of the game that some people will find tedious (such as myself). 

If you're fickle with your character choices and often reroll get the Respec mod.

If you dislike the kingdom management or feel stressed by it (me) get Kingdom Management.

If you like fashion (like me) get Visual Adjustments for better player control of appearances.

If you want traditional tabletop feel (sort of) or a slower paced game get Turnbased (works suprisingly well despite not being designed for game balance.

This game is a masterpeice. It is a *steal* at $20. It's a steal at twice the price. Assuming they fix some of the more annoying bugs (shadows are pretty terrible, and game does occasionally crash) it'd easily be worth a full AAA price of $60, in my opinion.

This game showed up in my steam queue one day and I - never having heard of it before - dismissed it within seconds after seeing it in Early Access still after initial release in 2013.

Later, and I don't even remember why at this point, I found myself watching some youtube videos of Kenshi gameplay. That was when I realized my mistake. After looking more into the ongoing active development I bought it right away.

And I am so very glad I did. :)

That said, even I have to admit it's not for everyone.

There are no quests. There is no "main storyline" to play through. There is no main bad guy. You're not special in any way whatsoever. It's literally just a world sim sandbox and you decide how you want your guy(s) to live their life in this world. You HAVE to enjoy coming up with your own "quests"/goals.

One thing i wanted to highlight that i don't think gets pointed out enough in the reviews is the combat system. Animations improve with your characters' skill, and new types of attacks open up as well. At the start you fight like a bar-room brawler with no training, but as you skill up your character fights with much more competence and style.

Heavy weapons and polearms tend to get more AE attacks, and light weapons tend to get more single-target attacks, but there's a fair amount of overlap. Martial Arts (unarmed fighting) is particularly interesting, you start with basic punching and shin-kicking and evolve into a stance-holding matrix-dodging flying-kicking kung fu bruce lee badass. Ok, i know nothing whatsoever about martial arts IRL, but it's impressive to see your character evolve over time.

Pros:
-Once you're in game, there's no loading screens anywhere. Interiors/exteriors it's all one seemless world.
-The world is GIGANTIC, and 1/4 of it isn't even out yet, as of the time of this writing.
-Very immersive, easy to suspend your disbelief.
-Awesome combat system built around a *lot* of excellent animations, very satisfying to watch.
-Truely open sandbox, there's precious little you can't do (or have DONE to you...) with more capability coming from the devs (such as being able to truely take over territory - or aid allies in doing the same - and rewrite the geopolitical map).
-Supports just about any playstyle from lone wanderer (not recommended for newbs, though) to expansive empire-builder.
-If you get into the crafting and/or base building elements there's a lot that can be automated once you have the people to assign, it's a very nice system overall.
-Workshop support with a lot of excellent mods out there. In particular i recommend the Dark UI mod, or the Dark Vanilla UI mod if you want a less clean/modern look but still the same (much improved) color scheme as Dark UI. But "Dark UI" (not Dark Vanilla UI) makes text a LOT easier to read, i love it.

Cons:
-No loading screens, but the constant streaming of data as you move through terrain can result in serious FPS drop. This gets worse the faster you can move (high Athletics skill and Athletics-boosting prosthetics). *STRONGLY* advise installing this game to an SSD if you can, it helps a *LOT* (but still doesn't cure the issue).
-Occasional crashes, which is pretty frustrating. Only happened during gameplay twice for me so far in 80+ hours so not the end of the world. Quicksave often, and failing that there's Autosave to fall back on.
-Shadows are a buggy mess. Flickering, LoD issues, what appears to be vis issues in some areas where the shadows aren't calculated correctly. After trying for a while i just turned 'em off. Seems like the problems get worse the longer your session is, but maybe that's my imagination.
-Default UI is pretty ugly and text is blurry and hard to read. This is a super easy fix with the Dark UI mod in the workshop, but still, the UI the game ships with is unpleasent, imo.

I suck at it so far, I don't optimise very well but I am learning, my colony is shit but it's MINE. The story so far is pretty epic/sad/brutal. Basically I named one of the old ladies I started with "Mum" she is the character that kinda does everything pretty well, and now she is REALLY good at a lot because she is the only one that has survived the whole 20 hours this last colony has been around.

Kind of sad that all of her "children" have come and gone before her, she has buried 8 colonists so far, no Mum should have to endure such hardship.The funny thing, however, is that she has a serious case of Alzheimer's so she probably does not remember any of them, lol.

I nearly had A total party wipe of 4 colonists when a pack of animals wanted their revenge, Mum was bleeding to death, and went into a confused state , forgetting to tend to herself...Luckily the man in black came and managed to save her with 2 hours to live, the other 3 perished... The man in black, BTW, His name is Vladimir and he is a politician...I'm not making this shit up.

After Vlad saved Mum, he tended to her then proceeded to binge on the last of my smoke-weed joints...Honestly I couldn't be mad at him as he smoked up in my kitchen. Since then, a lone wanderer name "Lawman" joined us out of nowhere, and again, Mum lives on...she lost a  pinky toe though, I truly wonder what her fate and that of the colony is from here on..

Did not really mean to write all of this, just wanted to say "Game Gud" but this is the effect it has, when you look to create stories, it is fantastic at helping you do that.

Lastly out of all the colonists (8 or so) that have died so far there seems to be a marriage curse, half of them were couples (this also happened with my first colony). Every time a couple in my game gets engaged, either one gets kidnapped and the other dies, or they both die horribly before wedding day.

That's me. I'm done

For those of you who are wondering if this is just another card game, well YOU'RE WRONG!
Haha Just kidding, it's pretty similar to other card games.
But, what really makes a difference are the developers. They cater toward the community and take advice and critiques very well. Because of so, I am extremely excited to see how this game does on it's official release.

A couple of things you might want to consider before buying the game:
-Yes, it is "another" card game, but you have to understand that you are playing as one character and the card are actually the skills for your character. (For those of you who played Kingdom Hearts: Chain of Memories, the combat system of using different cards are similar, well I think they are haha)
-No, this is not Hearthstone OR Elder Scroll's: Legend.
-This game is a "die and go back to the beginning" type game (This will happen often if you are like me XD )
-Takes time to learn the different strategies.

Well, that is all I have, but the biggest take away is that the Developers are working to make this game better and that they cater toward us the Community. It's fun, but not for everyone and that is important to remember.

app_name: Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy
review: Pain and misery. That is all

The positives.
The whole atmosphere in the game, from its narrative to the way how it expresses the story, how it let you feel  through your character, how you accept an hour long traversing the mountains, which is not making you bored but rather curious what new horizons you will see IS ABSOLUTELY STUNNING. From this perspective, this game is unbelievably original and its own kind of experience. This experience was finally the reason to finish the game.

---

The negatives.
AMERICA FIRST. Why the he11 the whole story is about absurd American exceptionalism? Time to time the characters talk about the world but the whole story is that the "world" you have to save is actually America. It's boring and it's what is exactly not cool on America. 

YOU ARE A HERO. All the dialogues you have after all deliveries need to ensure you that you are absolutetly the best porter on this world. The NPCs are surprised in what condition you have delivered the cargo. Why? Do we really need to be ensured that we are the best all the time? It's annoying.

GUI. The game interface and its animations is so annoying that I had to close my eyes time to time. I had to go through unbelievable senseless statistics that have nothing to do with RPG-kind of a game. You need to see all the shining glowing graphics and texts with final statistics after delivery that have little sense for your progress through the game. In the end, everytime you take an order you cannot make the decision what equipment you want to take with your. E.g. you can't recycle in this moment, so you must finish this part of preparations and go back to the terminal. This is something every player must experienced but such a bug was kept in the game not by mistake but by game design.

---

Finally I was able to ignore these parts of the game and pursue the story and the whole experince was fantastic. Yes, I do recomend you to play it.
My current favourite game

This is a redone review. I did one around 10 hours into the game. 

TD;LR: I really like it but it's a game not for everyone. 

Anyways, the best way to describe Death Stranding is walking simulator with lore. I know that may not sound interesting at first but most things in the game are super super well done. It's an aquired taste kind of game, you may not like it all or you very well may love it. This review says yes so that means yeah I really like this game. 

Death Stranding is another almost masterpiece made by Kojima with his new studio. It's a game that doesn't fit any genres, calling it a "Strand" type game. It's a one of a kind experience. 

The game isn't about combat rather planning ahead for a long journey ahead of you, plotting routes, things to take with you on top of the deliveries you already need to make, rebuilding America while doing, and uncovering mysteries about the Death Stranding. All while walking point A to point B. 

Death Stranding does have combat however, I found it to be more tedious than anything. The boss fights with the BTs are boring throw gernade or shoot blood bullets, boom easy. The MULE camps are hard to stealth because there are so many people to take down without killing them. 

The story is complicated as all hell and I needed to turn to outside recources to fully understand it. I don't really like doing that for story driven games but I make an exception. The story is super weird and something you've never seen before, I guarantee - Yet, somehow it's a phenomenal story all about connections. The story is also emphasized more by the fantastic motion capture and voice acting as well, it's surprisingly very immersive. 

I would explain the plot however I don't want to go accidentally into spoiler territory and i'm still trying to figure out everything for myself. It's basically an apoclyptic world where people are too scared to go outside because of invisible monsters from the dead that you can't see so brave porters who deliver stuff like the protagonist, Sam Bridges come to be essential. 

From a technical standpoint with this port: A+. The issues I first had got patched where DLSS didn't work and I got stuttering while streaming but DLSS is integrated so well into the game you'll get a pleasant and smooth experience. 

If this sounds at all interesting to you, read some more reviews and no harm in at least trying it out! 

It's not a game for everyone but I thoroughly enjoyed my experience and I know this review is structured pretty badly but eh.

If you have really bad wifi, this game is for you. It favors those with shitty wifi, as killer you can hit people from a mile away and as survivor you can teleport across the map and not get hit. Overall DOG SHIT GAME

My reccomendation for playing this game is to stop around rank 15 and put it down until season restart. It's fun, but the asshole meta that the game itself encourages at later ranks kills all enjoyment.

I can only speak from the perspective of the killer as my main, but past rank fifteen, expect survivors to teabag you, body block you, swarm you when carrying people to hooks in an attempt to slow you, blind you with kitted out torches that send your screen white for five seconds straight and never run out, bum rush hooks to save their freinds as quickly as possible so they can sprint burst away, decisive strike you everytime you pick them up (a perk that allows a free escape from the killer, which -always- feels so fun after the work you put in to chase them down) - and much more scumbaggery that's completely antithetical to the idea of the theme driving the game: survivors fearing the killer.

It's not necessarily impossible to counter all of this, it's simply not fun. I'm still ending most games with 3+ survivor kills but there's no enjoyment at all in being rushed down and hampered by survivors who don't concern themselves with stealth or tactics beyond what i've listed above. And why should they? The game doesn't reward you at all in terms of bloodpoints (the rescource for the ranking system) for a slow and carefull approach - i'm not tilted so much by the players doing these things, there's no secret code of honor and players -should- do what the game encourages, more that the game has allowed itself to go on in this state for so long now despite the constant feedback from the community complaining about all these issues.

tl;dr : It's fun initially and it really is something special when a good game happens, but when the meta kicks in at later ranks, expect those games to be few and far between.

Also, why doesn't the killer just fucking close his eyes?

Very cheap for the content that it offers and very fun to play with your friends.

The sense of progression makes the game very addictive. From swimming around without proper gear to getting scuba equipment to building a submarine, the game has it all. Not too much grinding either.

The only three gripes I have with the game are the following: NO autosaves, NO co-op, crashes.

The game has crashed at least 5 times now during my +20 hours of playing it. It is escpecially frustrating, since there are no autosaves, which is why you might lose a lot of progression after a crash.

The game is a blast though, and I do recommend trying it out. Hopefully they will add a co-op option in the near future.

I don't play multiplayer, so it would be nice if this game went in another direction, and instead of catering to twitch streamers, or coop players, I could get the same level of value and gameplay from a solo, or singleplayer experience, instead of having to derive what little nourishment I can from something that just seems like a copy and paste job from gamesworkshop's creative assets archive. However, because it IS a gamesworkshop sponsored piece of art, I will purchase it, if only to enhance my Total Warhammer experience, if nothing more than seeing the universe through a different perspective. If you can appreciate that, then you can appreciate this title. Other than that, it seems to be going in a more mainstream type direction in an attempt to appeal to a greater base of players, than to what they perceive as a niche group of mature individuals who expect an enriched story, player freedom, as well as an in depth atmosphere. Instead of something that seems to be riding on the coattails of a greater company just to garner a few dollars. I get it, its part of the society we live in today, how to make the greatest number of dollar signs. But have some pride, this is a message to all developers, or would be contributors to the gaming community. Its a wonder modders and those who gain little to no financial support create the most elaborate and grand designs to ever be experienced in a digital format.

i have played this game for nearly 20 hours and streamed about 90% of it. This is the first rhythm game that i've ever bought for myself as i don't have much talent in that department. the sabers sold me, i gave it a shot and have been having a CRAZY FUN time ever since. i got fairly decent at most songs on the hard mode, can complete a few songs on expert but even when i fail, i always feel like a champion because of the amount of fun i am having. 

the game itself is a workout, even just while just playing for fun. the songs are excellent and i am not tired of hearing the same 10 songs yet, myself. there's a standard mode, a no arrows mode that i like to refer to as a free-style mode and a party mode. 

the arrows mode on hard is my comfort zone for a good time playing this game and i am perfectly happy with that. over the past few days i have been experimenting with the dual bladed saber staff similar to that wielded by Darth Maul and it has made the game a brand new experience with completely new challenges and different ways to have fun! the community of fans of the game have already begun making mods to add to the longevity of the game for themselves and the devs seem VERY active in continuing to improve the quality of the experince in Beat Saber. i think it's amazing that so much fun can be had in such a small game.

TL;DR: Great game for sandbox survival fans, even at full price. Some bugs degrade but do not ruin the experience. 9/10

First and foremost, Subnautica is a really great game. If you like games where you explore, harvest resources, and build bases, this game is for you. The story is fairly good as well, but some of the most interesting content in the game comes from finding abandoned PDAs. That being said, if you miss one you may be missing out on a huge part of what helps this game immerse you. One thing that this game does really well is the visuals. It's honestly amazing coming from an indy dev. Additionally, from the moment you touch down in game, there's an air of anxiety and horror in the sense that you don't know what's waiting for you in the deepest reaches of the ocean.

That all being said, there's some bad with the good. This game is a buggy mess even years after its official release. Honestly though, it's within acceptable ranges given the amount of people that put up with the AAA titles that are still buggy as all hell like Bethesda's games. Some elements of the game were also implemented fairly poorly causing certain parts to become more frustrating than fun. For instance, the last quarter of the game is literally one big fetch quest. You travel to and from places multiple times and really the only way to avoid it is to look up a guide of the items you need, but honestly that ruins fun of it all.

Let's start this off with a little background: it's December 31, 2016. I'm a High School student currently taking all Honors courses which has really stressed me out. This is one of the first reviews I've ever written.

When I first heard of this game from a small Youtuber named paulsoaresjr, it looked intruging. Games like these catch my eye, which is quite unusual, as my primary tastes lie in games such as XCOM 2 and Battlefield 1. So I bought it for Christmas. It.. may have been the best purchase of 2016 for me. You look at my other major 'best" purchase of 2016, XCOM 2, and you are comparing 213 hours... to 93. IN 5 DAYS. At that pace, all I need is 6 more days, and I have basically caught up with XCOM. This game has been the best way to end 2016 for me, which wasn't a particularly good year for me. I've never felt this good in awhile. I have realized some things about my life from the game I wish I would have realized ealier in the year. For the first 3 nights, I stayed up until 3 in the morning playing, which is unusual, because I have trouble staying up past 11:30 recently. This game has helped me pull away from the reality of life, which as I said, hasn't been the best. Enough of me though, you want to know the game stuff!

PROS:
-Simplistic
-Developed by one person (which is pretty impressive)
-Runs smooth, have not run into any glitches aside from minor graphical ones
-Developer continues to work on and improve the game
-AWESOME soundtrack (If anybody happens to know the EPCOT music played around Innovations, a particular summer theme heavily reminds me of it)
-Plenty to do in the first year

CONS:
-Developed by one person (huh? Yes it is also a con, as he can only do so much work)
-Starts to get a bit repetitive around the end of the second year (EDIT 1/4/17: This isn't as severe as I realized, I just had taken it a bit too fast. I still enjoy it and can easily nail 2-3 hours per day on it)
-NPCs use mostly the same conversations/say things they have said already (which isn't terrible, but sometimes it gets a little bland)
-From what I've seen and read, children don't do much besides becoming a new set of conversations for your spouse and a new relationship to build (I want my children to toil in the fields with me!)

All in all, I highly recommend this game. Only 5 days, and it's done great things for me. It may not be for everyone, but if you are on the fence, buy it. Stardew Valley has a nice charm to it. A simple life, when things in the modern world today is so interconnected and quite crazy. It's one of my best purchases. Ever. 
Now if only Co-op play could be developed sooner..

The scope of the game is incredible. The amount of true unique content on display is ridiculous. Most side quests here get more attention to detail than main quests in other games. Emptying a chamber pot for someone in Witcher 3 would get you a full voiced cutscene and a chase sequence. If there is one consistent flaw with the Witcher 3, it would be that the parts are stronger than the whole. It's side quests, and especially the excellent DLC releases, are in many ways better stories than the main arc.
There are moments atop a mountain when you can happily leave Geralt poised, listen to the excellent jingle-jangle lute-based soundtrack, and watch the time and weather change - typically resulting in a brewing storm and rain. Need to shift forward in time, then simply meditate to restore energy and potions, or grab a bit more sunlight.
Some of the small things stand out in particular: the way the wind catches the trees, how sunlight breaks through the branches as a forest thins out, the flow of characters' hair, even wet skin after a bath. Of course there's better to be had out there, because the gaming world moves fast, and five years is a long time in any game's life.
Its shockingly cohesive world is as beautiful as it is demanding, and it's packed full of mature content that throws you from one emotional response to the next. Its storytelling is superb, its combat is grippingly refined, and its often unforgiving nature only lends itself to a brilliantly rewarding experience

I can't believe I haven't reviewed Into the Breach yet. As far as logic based, puzzle games go, this is going to be one of the best you will ever play. A sudoko or chess player will quickly see and analyze the factors they are given to work with as each new board is tiled and enemies set. It's a wonderful logic game that can be set down and picked back up at your leisure, even while playing a round. The gameplay itself is simple, but the strategy you use will depend on the player. I have found many ways to finish boards giving it very high replay value. An absolute blast, definitely get it.

An excellent game, if a bit short. Lovingly crafted with a main character that, although almost entirely mute, displays an immense amount of personality. Quirky and original without falling into the pitfall of being 'random', the game bounds from one genre to another, yet without losing a central tone and theme.

Perhaps the main flaw is a lack of an appropriate antagonist, given that the villain disappears from the game and re-appears only as the final boss. Nevertheless, the area and story changes so frequently that this isn't a major concern. 

Definitely worth purchasing, even if not on sale.

My late, and final verdict. Like Civ 4, Civ 5 became a complete experience with all the expansions. AI battles really didnt become exciting until the very last patches. But when all the expansions were there it became a great civ-game...with all the flaws you are used to if you have played this series since it started in the early 90´s. What the complete Civ 5 failed to achieve was interesting diplomacy, leaders with really unique personalities, proactive AI (you can play an entire deity game with only 3-4 cities and no one will attack you, even though they have literally hundreds of units just ready to be used) and many more things that would have made the game more immersive. One could also wish for a less linear system when it comes to research and social policies. But with the obscene amount of hours played, i clearly loved Civ 5:)

Now when we all know about Civ6 coming in october, lets keep our fingers crossed that they will bring better immersion and basically more fun into the game. The last expansion to Civ5 brought, for the first time in the Civ series, a good late game. I would like to see more things that makes the entire gameplay, from start to finish, more fun and immersive....and all the stuff i said that Civ5 failed to deliver. And lastly i want a better turnbased multiplayer experience, because that is something that has never existed in the Civ series. That would open up an entire new feature in the game, because lets face it: the overwhelming majority of us havent felt that much love for multiplay in this game.

Ok. Here is my in-depth analysis of Dead by Daylight. I have about 2,000+ hours as of right now and I play both sides and I would like to describe my full experience playing this game, start to finish.

The first time I heard of this game was, ironically, a Jacksepticeye video (i know). I thought the game looked awesome, but that was in 2016. I had only Nintendo consoles only and Dead by Daylight was only on PC at the time. However, in late 2016 I got an X-Box, and then in 2017 when DBD launched on consoles, I played a free weekend with my friend. And I LOVED THE SHIT OUT OF IT. I played it non-stop that weekend and was heartbroken when it ended. The fun that I had seen only from Jack and his friends was finally in my grasp; and it was just as great as I imagined it would be. The chaos when you're screaming when you first pallet slam the killer, or you kobe for the first time and escape. When Myers jumpscares you from around the corner and you scream like a little girl. However, after the free weekend, I forgot about the game. It fell into the past...

Flash forward to March 2018, I have a computer. Granted, a pretty shit computer, but one nonetheless. I'm sitting in discord browsing Steam, looking for something to play, and I see Dead by Daylight and my friend who is in discord with me announces he had has Dbd for a long time and loved it. In that moment, the great memories flooded back to me, and I without second thought bought the game. A lot of new killer had come out since 2017, which was weird but I was excited to learn how to play against them. My friend was like a god compared to me. I died all the time when I started, but that drive to get as good as my friend pushed me. No, not as good as my friend: Better. I wanted to be the best Dead by Daylight player in the world.

The next few months were a blur. I started to stop performing well at school. I would get home and all I would to is play Dead by Daylight from 4 to midnight every night for months. My skill increased, and so did my knowledge. In May I started to watch No0b3 more regularly, which increased my skill. In July I had finally mastered the 360. I had become a walnut to this game. No scare would even make me jump. However, one gamemode I had never touched was killer. I occasionally touched it, but for the most part I played survivor. But there was no way I could master survivor and not be somewhat good at killer. There was a night in June where I just sat down and played killer, and in that moment I had found my new calling. No longer was I just a survivor main. I was now... both. Survivor in itself is always a rush. Killer is hit or miss. Either you feel immense fucking pain our you can feel like a killing machine. It can go either way. Another thing that pushed killer gameplay for me was the rank achievements on steam. No way i could be a Dbd pro and not have all the achievements. So I had to start practicing and in May and June I mained Myers for the most part. I had a moment where I mained doctor for bloodpoints, but that was short lived. However, when 2.1.0 dropped and Hag got a buff. I had found a new favorite. No killer was like Hag to me. And ever since then I have been a Hag main. 

Now I'll cover the DLC and patches and how they turned me on or off form the game. 

I believe the game was most blanced in 2.1.0, however my personal favorite was 1.9.4 since that's when I started. While vacuum pallets was a skill I ever utilized since I was still a baby, I know how other people felt about them. The feel was just so...nice. It felt rich. Nothing will ever top that in my mind.

Once 2.0.0 dropped, I moved a way from the game a bit because the new pallets took a learning curve, as well as the new killer. But playing the game while a new killer was announced for the first time was really exciting. However I came back after a while and came back harder for 2.1.0 and throughout the rest of the summer. The spirit was fun at first, but in the end on her final nerf it turned me off a little, but I still played pretty much every day. Legion killed this game for me, I played nothing of the Winter Solstice and January. I came back in the end of January and I was probably playing the second most ever this Febuary. March, this month, has been great. I'm excited for dedicated servers, Plague looks really good so far, and I'm excited for the future of this game.

Final thing to take away from this game: It is beyond worth the 20 dollar price tag. Hell, even with all the DLC it still not even coming close to this game's worth to me. There is so much content in this game. The grind is long as hell but not incredibly unforgiving. You're hooked at the start, and the drive to increase you're skill is what pushes you further into addiction. Its replayable and constantly getting new content. The bugs and unbalanced nature doesn't affect it too much, but I feel one big bug fixing update would be greatly appreciated instead of other things. 

it is a great, but flawed game. Buy it now.
(sorry if I dwelled too much on my personal life, but I just wanted to capture how a new played might feel diving into this game for the first time. Big departure from the standard review, but it's mine nonetheless)

I wrote a review for this game earlier and it was far too jokey.

Stardew Valley came to me at a weird time in my life. My grandpa passed away last June, and my dog left us last December. I also quit my job last December, stupidly, trying my hardest to get by on selling my music, and I've been struggling with death anxiety for a while now, trying to find a point in life, to the point of even breaking down in more than a few anxiety attacks, which have singlehandedly been the scariest thing I've ever experienced.

So I see a few of my friends playing this game and fondly recall all the hours I've put into Harvest Moon games in the past and decide to give it a shot. I don't really know what I was expecting. Definitely not to find any answers, nor to find something worthwhile, maybe just a distraction from the existential dread hanging over my shoulders. But Stardew gave me more than that.

Maybe it was something I would have come to eventually, but I believe Stardew really helped me out. Something calm and relaxing. Something I can play for hours and hours and not have to worry quite so much. Something to help me breathe. I've described it to other friends as "like Harvest Moon but better", but I don't really think that's fair. It IS very similar to Harvest Moon, yes, but there's absolutely no rush, no reason to worry, nothing to fear. If you don't get it right the first time, there'll always be tomorrow. Maybe you won't perform exceptionally at the start, but you'll eventually get the hang of things. You just have to keep trying. You just have to keep putting in the effort. You can't get hung up on mistakes, but rather, you have to keep pushing forward.

I'm still trying to pick myself up off the ground. It's hard, but I'm still trying. I'm learning every day how to better handle things. And as corny as it sounds, I owe a bit of that to Stardew Valley.

If you're struggling like I am, please, give Stardew Valley a shot. It won't fix things, but it's a nice place to relax and it's got more than a few lessons to be learned.

I love this game, this is a game about relaxing and taking your own pace to accomplish goals that you set on your own for your farm. The game is literally about you not wanting to work a 9 to 5 job and taking your time off in the countryside. I highly recommend this game to people who want to relax after a hard day's work. Amazing job to the creator of this game!!!

In a game that seems is largely about discovery I had to keep looking things up online to get the early most basic stuff done.  

I figured out how to make water from a bladderfish on my own on the first start attempt. I did a lot wrong. Couldn't find more bladderfish, Die of thirst. No problem, I expect that kind of thing in a game like this. On the second and third start I found exactly one bladderfish between them. Looked up other ways to make water. The only one that seemed viable in the early game was to use coral and salt. I had to look up how to harvest coral. I had to look up how to find the rubber to make a knife so I could harvest coral. (rubber knife?)  Then it was time to look for salt. Advice online = it is everywhere. My experience = the game has no such thing as salt. Have not ever seen salt in my entire attempt to play the game.

Three restarts. Can't find any bladderfish, can't find any salt. No water. Dying of thirst. Yay???

I suppose I could play one of the easy modes where food and water are not required, but a game that is this badly designed isn't worth putting more time into.

Ugh. This is a neutral review.

It is a nice game, but it feels like someone made an anime, then transitioned it into game engine, then padded it with battles at every 2 minutes mark - battles you ahve to beat so you can continue watching.

In this game there's significant discrepancy between production values in cutscenes and the movies and actual gameplay.

Character editors are nice, there are nice maps as well, but EVERYTHING is heavily reused, and you'll see the same time dozens of times, over and over again. Same applies to enemies, there are reskins, retextures, there are a lot of similarities and so on. At the same time every cutscene is voiced, and apparently plenty of them used mocap (or animators were very talented). This doesn't qutie make much sense to me.

The amount of missions you have to complete is quite large, but they're similar, they're mostly filler that you have to beat in order to continue watching the story. Typically the game introduces a monster, then several chapters later you'll see its reskin, then it'll be on another map, then it'll be paired with another monster, and so on. It is kinda similar to Monster Hunter World, but Monster Hunter World had gorgeous environments which were huge and open for exploration. In this case environments are nice, but they're heavily reused, and nobody really lets you ever explore anything.

I found combat to be quite dull, although there's a great degree of optimization, customization, tons of apperances for your character and multiplayer. 

I barely managed to beat the game, not because it is hard, but because after several dozens missions tedium caused by repetition becomes nearly unberable.

Still, the ending wasn't bad.

So there you have it.

A fairly odd game, that feels like an anime with combat engine bolted onto it for some reason. If you're interested in story line, you'll have to grind through the annoyingly similar story missions to see the rest of the content, which is definitely not for everyone. 

Can't say a lot about multipler, though, as I haven't played much of it.
