Now I might be jumping the gun a bit here as I'm reviewing this slightly before finishing my 1st full season in Career. Finished the 82 regular game season but still in Play-offs but I think i've played enough of the game at this point to comment. Which I'll be doing about the Career, GM mode and MyLeague as the rest I don't care about and therefore haven't touched.

Overall, the career mode is a step up in my opinion over last year's game. Some people may prefer doing the whole college thing and then going into the draft not knowing which team you'll be on for the first season, and I'll admit I do miss the draft process (not the college part). But 2k18 gives you the choice to join any team at the start. Giving you the choice of joining an already good team if you want a good chance at play-off success, your favourite team or a bad team and trying to drag them to a decent season. Beyond the inital start, you'll met a variety of different characters from your best friend, to your agent, the Vet player who takes you under his wing (same person regardless of team), brand agents etc. Most of these characters I have enjoyed meeting and the interactions you'll have with them. Although you can't trade yourself to a another team like last year's game, you do notice that teams do trade with one another. So its possible that you'll see new players on your team part-way through the season and new players on other teams as well.

But the career isn't without its down sides. You can't ask to get traded to a different team, but you do choose which team you do start on to off-set this. Contract negotiations often feel quite pointless. You get an offer, you decide a part of the offer isn't good enough and ask for a better deal on that part and a few games later you get a completely new contract. Not just on what you asked on, but everything else as well meaning it was pointless to ask to get a bit of a better deal on just the 1 thing. The whole street neighbour thing for the career mode is a good idea, but why does it have to be online and get filled with other players? Makes no sense for a single player element to have that. Plus you have loading time between any building you go in or out of as well. If the neighbour thing wasn't online you could have all of that load at once so you could easily walk in and out of different buildings without having to load them up everytime. Beyond that there are bugs as well. An example I'll give is that near the start of your career you'll get the chance to talk to all the different Shoe companies and get offers. But for me I ended up getting the same Shoe company cutscene 3 times out of 5. Even though I was already re-negotiating with them after the first time they sent an offer my way. Also had bugs during a match as well, such as an opposing player glitching/passing though my player to get to a rebound (and not going around my player), even though my player was between them and the ball but its very rare thing to happen.   

As for MyGM and MyLeague. To use a phrase from Top Gear "Ambitious, but rubbish" for the MyGM story mode. In 2k17 it was my favourite mode as you could start it up and sim the whole season time after time, and get to the fun part for me which was trades, Scouting and the Draft. As well as adding in fake/fantasy teams. This year you can't do that. I don't know why but they created a story for MyGM which means you can't do any of that. The story overall, isn't good. The cutscenes were often out of sequence with the events of the story. Meaning you be making a decision in a cutscene not knowing what it is about, as it comes too early while the story hasn't got to that part yet. Unless you happen to have played through the story once already. I don't know if the story continues beyond the first season of the GM mode because I lost my enthusium for the mode after doing the full first season with a couple of teams. The MyLeague mode is more along the lines of what MyGM mode was last year except you can control more than 1 team, and overturn decisions made like rule changes for the NBA, the All-Star city location etc. Some people may simply move over to this mode instead of the MyGM story, but looking to play as mulitple teams and being able to over-turn decisions isn't what I want to do. 

Overall, this is where Steam should have a 3rd button beyond just saying yes or no to recommending the game. Like buy on discount only. Since the game has a bit too many bugs for me to recommend and the MyGM story is bad in my opinion which took away my favourite thing from the 2k17 version. But the Career mode, even with minor bugs, is better than 2k17 to me. So I guess I can't recommend the game at full price, but I will if the game is on sale for at least 75% or better. Since I don't think you can get the longevity out of the 2k18 version more than the 2k17 version of the game. The career is the sole highlight of the game to me and I will say that I hope that 2k brings back the agent character in future games because I believe he is too good to not use in future games.

So I've heard about the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt for years and when it finally came down to $19.99 I felt I had to grab it. After finally doing so within the first few hours and be playing it this is one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen in my entire life. I don't know if it's because I'm on a PC with just regular settings but oh my goodness from each blade of grass moving the way it does, to the clouds, the rays of the sun this game looks absolutely gorgeously perfect.

Cons: while the game is beautiful indeed there are some flaws with the combat system that I felt. I don't know if it's because I'm using a PlayStation 4 controller on a PC or not but the way they combat and design it's very specific but hard to remember. It does take a lot of getting used to in order to be able to fight efficiently. But once you get used to the battle system you see why the battle system is designed the way it was. So my main complaint is that it does have a high learning curve as far as the controls are concerned. Also there does seem to be at certain points and glitches which I've seen happen in this game a lot more than I would like to but that's probably based on due to the settings that I have currently for the game. Also the beginning story I feel kind of drags on is very very slow in the beginning. I've heard that it picks up in Act 2 but Act 1 seems to be very very slow

Also the story is engaging I feel that I'm very invested in the story within the first 9 hours but then you so much content that this game can easily you can put over at least a hundred hours to 150 hours into.

I really want to like it. But I dont. I'd still rather play Civ V. The AI is so annoying, production is so slow, I miss the little things like game setup saving the settings when creating a game or a proper icon of a garrisoned unit in a city instead of it obscuring housing/amenity icons, general scarcity of natural resources, unit movement across tiles does not make sense to me sometimes, the look of the fogged out tiles, resource icons and descriptions for land tiles could communicate information much better (Civ V gave me the info I need at a glance even without icons), little bugs like discovering new continents when you approach a river sometimes (wot?) or repeating status messages from other civs from decades ago and the music is not as well chosen as Civ V. I also preferred the old narrator with gravitas in his voice. Sean is cool but he will always be the amateur from the movie Ronin to me, or the dude who lost his head on season 1 of GoT or the dude who got killed in the first LoTR. So TL:DR, I'd rather play Civ V with the visuals from Civ VI. Sorry Firaxis! Xcom is great though!

A quick text review:
Pros:
1) more gameplay then other nearly released rollercoaster 3d games (ok so there is only one but hay, and yes i own both, will review the other on my channel later)
2) nice selection of content for a first alpha
3) awesome coaster designer, very easy to use and a lot of fun.
4) will mature into a good game with time (and tlc from the dev's)
5) stable enough to play...sort of
6) fun to play as is (isnt that one of the main things to look for in an early access?)
cons:
1) no autosave (really essential in a game that is not 100% stable)
2) a lot of customization options that should be a doddle for them to add are missing (wheres my £ symbol lol)
3) no feedback from dev's as to schedule of updates (or any feedback really)
4) some optimization issues (that is pretty common with early access but is a bad point none the less)

So i recommend the game? yes but only if you understand that its alpha/early access and has bugs, crashes, etc. See it as investing in a game down the line, a game that i have every hope will be very good and that you get to play as it matures (and with luck influence its development) 

I do not recommend it if your expecting a fully working optimized game right now.

An absolutely magnificent game in terms of depth and content within the gameplay elements. It really is a lot like a puzzle game mixed with sandbox, as you're always trying to come up with ways to fully automate the crafting systems so that machines can pump out materials and items for you rather than doing it by hand. Once you can safely walk away from your base and have it operate without your own input, you know you've achieved something amazing.

There are lots of options to tweak the experience, from richness of resources to enemy spawns.

Frankly it gives me a good sense of nostalgia, giving my glimpses of my Dwarf Fortress days where the building system was just as intricate as Factorio.

For 30 bucks it may seem a bit steep, but it is an extremely addicting and rewarding game and is quite easy to learn; well worth the price.

Into the Breach is a hard and addicting strategy game by the devs that brought us FTL.

[h1] Video Review [/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yU02D3zC21k

[h1] Written Review [/h1]
You play as a squad of time-travelers tasked with the mission to stop humanity's demise. Earth is being attacked by giant alien bug creatures, and you pilot mechs to combat them.

The main gameplay objective is to maintain your "Power Grid" health. Bugs will constantly target buildings. Each successful hit will drain your Power Grid by one bar. Once it gets to zero, it's game over, and you will get very few chances to regenerate those bars throughout your playthrough, so it's very important to protect your buildings.

This forces you to play in very clever ways, sometimes even placing your mechs in front of projectiles to protect buildings from getting hit, since they will heal after every battle anyway.

The gameplay is turn-based. For every round, bugs will set up their attacks. Then it's your turn. All enemy attacks are telegraphed, and the game will show you exactly where all projectiles and such will land, allowing you to properly plan. You have infinite time to make your decision, which is good because you'll really need it.

A mechanic I find very interesting is that a lot of your attacks do not simply damage enemies, but also push them. This way, if a bug is about to attack a building, you can simply get a good angle and push them out of the way of the building. They will follow through with their previously planned attack, however it will be wherever you pushed them to, instead.

This allows you to sometimes get enemies to attack each other.

The game does a good job at keeping the game fresh, as well as multiple playthroughs. This is because the levels are randomly generated, and the enemies are varied. 

Each level will have optional missions that you definitely want to try accomplish, because you will need them to help your playthrough last. You'll be able to heal your power grid, or purchase upgrades for your mech depending on the optional mission.

Enemies also have unique skills, and behave differently with the environment, which keeps you on your toes.

There are a lot of small details that allow you to really plan your moves nicely. Such as special tiles like a forest, which if attacked will cause it to ignite. If any one steps on it will then catch fire. Your attacks can also throw enemies onto their friends, causing them to both be damaged.

If you fail your playthrough, the planet will be overrun by bugs and you are given the choice to choose one of your mech pilots to save. This will transport them back to the future, and then back again to the past on your next playthrough. This allows you to really make them powerful over playthroughs, however it's also more horrible if you get them killed.

Overall, although I've explained the basics, there are so many fun aspects to this game that can't properly be explained through text, so if you're interested I'd invite you to watch my video review at the top. 

It's a great game, that really captures that simple-to-learn-but-hard-to-master fun that FTL had. The music is also done by the same artist behind the FTL soundtrack, so it's still great. I highly recommend the game!

Good: 
-Best controls so far
-Best combat system so far (it's amazing!!)
-Bosses have consistent high quality
-Story is interesting and characters are really cool
-Very colourful by FromSoft's standards (which I like)
-Feels more open than older games (not fully open world or nothing but still nice)
-Music plays outside of boss battles
-Very streamlined (no potential levelling trouble, tutorial guy etc)
-Prosthetic tools are very reminiscent of zelda tools
-Finally a difficult final boss!!
-Eavesdropping is sick

Bad: 
-Maybe a bit short
-Not crazy replayable 
-Overworld music can get annoying 
-Boss music isn't very memorable (it is nice to listen to though)
-Story is more like a zelda than a dark souls, it's not that cryptic (but I dont hate that)
-No weapon variety (some people hate this, I dont though)
-No different outfits (made me a little sad)
-Some areas don't feel like they were used enough or were very small / linear (abandoned dungeon, poison swamp)
-Some areas are reused (outskirts like 3 times!!)
-Dragonrot is SO easy to bypass (it's so not that bad, doesnt even kill NPCs)
-Some of the prosthetic weapons are SO irrelevant youll never use them
-Terror is mental

Overall:

I really do still recommend this game to Dark souls fans, maybe more so Bloodborne fans, and definitely new people looking to play a souls game. Definitely start with this one as it is the most streamlined and probably the shortest :)

You need to know what you're getting into before hitting that purchase button....

This game is a Kojima unchained. It's like Konami was the filter between some of the most crazy and over the top ideas - and we still got the events in the MGS titles. 

That's not to say that it's a bad thing - the story is deep, rich, and convoluted. You'll most likely visit a couple forums to see what people thought. It's unfair to say it's a fetch quest game or Euro Truck Simulator, it's more than that - but some of the basic "mechanics" are there.

You're always going to be deliverying things in this game. No matter what - that is the core. Whether it's a peaceful drive, a shit show with enemies or just "terrorists" trying to take your shit. That's the underlying gameplay. 

However, the terrain that you must navigate is pretty unforgiving. It makes the building/rebuilding element of the game much more of a relief of not having to travel such dangerous paths. I played on "Hard" and it wasn't too bad at all - I almost would recommend that difficulty level.

The menus system I see pop up in reviews all the time - it's not great but it's not a deal breaker in my opinion. Once you get the hang of it it's not too bad, there for sure could be some QOL improvements on the UI, but overall it's overblown in reviews in my opinion. 

Bottom Line - If you're a fan of Kojima like you would be a musician or director - you'll probably enjoy this game like I did in all the weirdness of Kojima. If you're on the fence and don't really know what a Kojima-flavored game is. You're going to probably not enjoy this as much.

Sometimes, a game comes along which completely turns a genre on its side, that changes the way you look at video games. Enter the Gungeon (PC, PS4) is not one of them, but it's a damned good game. In the game, you look for a gun that can kill a mysterious entity known as "The Past" by going into the titular Gungeon and shooting your way through birds, books, sorcerers, and anthropomorphic bullets with guns. To fight them, you use your trusty sidearm (which varies from character to character) but as most roguelikes go, you can find and unlock different guns. This is where the game gets interesting. All the guns are unique and fun to use, ranging from a M1911 to an exploding banana. As you progress, you unlock more guns to use in different games. You're not the only one with an arsenal; your enemies have plenty of guns, and will use them like crazy. You'll constantly find yourself being barraged by a swarm of bullets, which you can shield by flipping a table, dodge roll away from, or use a devastating Blank to get rid of. However, eventually, you WILL die. This game is hard as a rock, and twice as fun to throw at your buddies. Like most roguelikes, you lose your progress when you die, but you keep your unlockables. This is rewarding, because it makes you feel as if, even though you died, you made progress anyways. However, like all games, there are flaws. The soundtrack isn't stellar, and some of the characters are objectively better than others. However, these flaws don't detract from the fact that Enter the Gungeon is a great game, and I would recommend it to any hardcore gamer who want's a challenge.

Overall, I give Enter the Gungeon... a 9/10!

disclosure: I am one of the many Kickstarter backers for Shovel Knight, at a low tier. I invested in what looked like a good concept at the time, but otherwise ignored it until publishing time. Here's my take on the fruits of the project:

Shovel Knight is a modern day "de-make" style platformer. With physics and maps that adhere strictly to their limitations, and a soundtrack that sounds just as at home on an old NES as on your PC. Aesthetically, the game absolutely succeeds in achieving the retro tone and feel it was going for.

Gameplay-wise is even more impressive. Shovel Knight delivers an *incredibly* solid 2D platforming experience, with good character art, and a nicely themed story to keep the pace moving. There are eight very unique feeling bosses that round out the world in Shovel Knight, each feeling very distinct from the others both in design and in their difficult and technique. Environments are also expertly designed, with just the right amount of difficulty to have you give it a few solid attempts before you could clear it. Special mention needs to be given to their penalty system. The lost money bags are a fantastic way to make the game only slightly penalize you for deaths, but enough that there is still a real risk in trying a tricky jump. This works to keep things tense while still feeling fair, and works mainly because of how balanced the in-game economy is. There is plenty of money to let you afford all the major upgrades in the game by the end.

The story is simple, but one I really enjoyed, as it was told with colorful characters and really good art to carry it along. The gameplay almost puts Megaman to shame with how fresh it feels. I would highly recommend this title to anyone.

Portal 2.
Ein Puzzlespiel in der Ego Perspektive. Der Spieler bekommt eine Portal Kanone, mit der man 2 Portale erzeugen kann, durch die man entweder selbst gehen kann oder Dinge werfen kann. Im Gegensatz zu Talos Principle, wo man oft durch Anwendung von Geometrie die Aufgaben löst, nutzt man in Portal 2 die Kräfte der Physik zu seinem Vorteil. 
Es hat leider keine so interessante Story wie Talos Principle, aber GLaDOS ist eine großartige KI. Leider sind die Aufgaben zu einfach. Ich hatte das Hauptspiel an einem Tag durchgespielt. Zum Glück gibt es eine großartige Community, die weitere Kammern erstellt.

Overall pretty good game, though some elements need touching up as they feel unrefined as of 1.0.0.7.

8/10

The game is very well done and very much Dark Souls esque, though the bosses are a bit more forgiving as you can warp out of the fight if you need to.

The combat is very well done, the majority of the bosses are fun, and the game does a good job at keeping a consistent feel and pace.

The rules are constant, there are very few creatures who have specialty rules to them, which contributes to the consistent pacing and it makes the gameplay much smoother (there is no creature that you have to arrow to death, or magic to death or whatever just for the sake of forcing the player to play that style).

The draw style is unique and effective, the armors look nice, the NPCs and Characters look different from eachother underneath the helmets anyways and overall it makes the game rather pretty.

what needs touching up:
-The tree of men boss is just terrible, he's not fun, he's not hard, he just has alot of HP and inconsistencies which make him a pain (I.E. when he hits 2/3rds hp he doesn't return your salt like every other boss before him does, sometimes his head and torso count as solid other times you can pass through them, when he stomps he seems to get a tad bit glitchy with his movements as his torso will become part of his gut and hips, it looks terribly done).  

-Some creatures can phase through walls which is just a pain, especially when they can attack while phasing through them (I.E. Fire skulls, clay men, the flying archers in the dome though they cant shoot through the walls which makes it seem more awkwards).

-Light armor is all just clothes, none of it provides any protection that is worth a damn, might as well run around with the tier 1 stuff on, it provides roughly the same amount of protection.

-Sometimes i would hold "up" and then jump which should be how to jump from a platform that you can fall through, and the character would fall through it even though i was holding up.

-Some of the smaller creatures seem to have way to much HP for thier size while other bigger creatures should have more HP for thier size  (I.E. Flaming skulls take more abuse then the chargers in the cage hallway level even though the charger guys are three times thier size and look like brutes while the skulls are litterlly just floating skulls on fire),
Fix the matchmaking!

Y'all remember back in like 2002 when everyone was askin when the F are we gonna get ourselves a Baldur's Gate game that uses Third Edition. Turns out they never did that because video games got stupid right around 2004 (you can infer fer yerself what exactly happened that year) and we ended up never getting the tradish D&D quest that all of us fanbois and fansquirrlz were lusting after. Jump forward almost 20 years and LAZY GREEDY GAMING DEVS finally decided that we as starving video game consumers are worthy of an actual, honest-to-God D&D game. Except you can't call it D&D bc of the law (A.C.A.B.). So what we get is this, and my dude if you were me and fourteen back in 2002 this is p. much exactly what you wanted.

This game is a PC adaptation of a tabletop campaign and you can tell. That means it doesn't suck like some streamlined, made for console action RPG. Instead it sucks a lot like doing homework, and if I am going to play a D&D game that's exactly what I want. Luckily the difficulty settings are robust and provide lots of options for masochists--and gentle, sensitive souls--to tweak in both directions just like my dirty daddy nips. 

People who say this game sucks are silly. It sounds like it was a mess when it first came out but at this point there's literally nothing that negative I can say about it. It's like Pillars of Eternity except the ambition lies along the path of the tabletop-style adventure over building an intensely multi-faceted world. What I'm saying is it FEELS LIKE BALDURS GATE IF YOU LIKE BAULDURS GADE BUY IT

Personaly, I took an evening to sit down, play and complete the game. It was a late night sit and just ejoy it as I'm slowly getting sleepy type of game.

It is enjoyable. 
Simple.
And thats what makes it shine. A decent story from start to finish with a few plot twists and moments where you might find yourself surprised or able to piece everything together and be content with that.

One thing to note, there are puzzles/minigames. At first I was worried these might affect the game or have some impact, but they do not. I really didnt like them, at first this ruined the experience, but after I realized I dont need to try on them, all was good.

I'd give this game a 6/10.

At the same time, the game provides exciting gunplay and an interesting pep-system, making you more dependable on your co-player in tough situations.

Overall, play with with someone in co-op, or do not bother.

It's surprising to think back and realise that I first dipped a toe into the first iteration of the Civilization universe some twenty-six years ago. Since then, the game has grown in complexity, scope, ambition and clearly in terms of visual effects and audio.

Civ VI is the latest release of the de facto empire building genre. The game shouldn't appeal on the scale that it does - yet so well-crafted is the presentation of the game, that newcomers along with veterans to the series can find their own space within it and progress how they see fit.

As such, Civ VI is one of those titles that occupies that rare talent for catering to the needs of the many - without alienating any group in particular. Players who have previously ignored such a game can pick it up in no time - whilst experienced players will actively search for the fresh nuances and capabilities within it.

There's a well-used phrase that perfectly sums up Civ VI - that of "Just one more turn". I've done that recently myself where a game started at 8.30pm, soon saw the clock reach 1.30am - without any obvious passing of time. It’s a time-sink - making you think of more elaborate plans to match your ever-expanding empire. It starts off with you casually clicking 'Next Turn' having kickstarted the building of a new granary and moving your singular warrior unit towards that unexplored section of the map. The game then processes the moves carried out by the other players and back you go to your own choices.

You send your warrior unit further into the unknown, the granary ticks off another small section of completion and now your advisors are requesting what should be researched next. Do you choose irrigation to further your farming, or maybe select animal husbandry to gain the benefits of retaining cattle? Of the several options that usually appear, an advisor preference is assigned to what they deem to be a priority. Such advice can be taken onboard and agreed with by the new player or completely ignored and overridden by seasoned players.

More events appear. You fend off the occasional barbarian scout unit and make contact with your first civilisation. Initial greetings soon grow into trading routes and the spread of religion. You might find that a desperately needed resource suddenly appears within a new stretch of land that you've just explored. Getting a builder unit over there is imperative - though now you've got several units and buildings in a build queue - and that builder will have to wait.

For the player, the game does an amazing job at containerising essential information turn after turn. It's difficult to let important updates to slip by, yet rather than bombard you with useless and repetitive feedback - Civ VI cherry-picks the most vital. Due to this, you never feel like the game is overwhelming you - rather it's a helping hand on events that could really do with your intervention.

Civ VI is not a swept board of accolades however. In purest core form, it's easy to feel that it lacks substance. The mechanics and structure are all there - but the content is thin on the ground and lacks variation. As is common these days, expansions and DLCs are seen as a method of extracting extra income from the players - often with mixed success. The expansions of Civ VI are not exactly cheap and added to the core game price itself, the overall cost can appear prohibitive. However, with the Rise and Fall expansion, you add the concept of loyalty, along with Great Ages and a new governor system. As expected, several new units, civilisations and wonders can also be built. The most recent add-on of Gathering Storm features Mother Nature getting her own back with erupting volcanoes, floods and tornados. A new World Congress that focuses on the leaders of each civilisation discussing and voting upon different matters - from applying bonuses to certain resources to sending aid for a struggling faction, can occur. Perhaps most topically relevant is the inclusion of climate change - which although influential, is far from the train-wreck that Civilization IV had when it featured the concept of pollution.

Civ VI is a superb heavyweight of a game - yet remarkably easy and friendly to get into. Being turn based, you get to take as long as you require to carry out your sequence of moves. I could argue that if played on a large screen like a TV, it would make for an involving game featuring the suggestions and input from several people sat on the sofa. You struggle to make a particularly bad decision, but by the same token, there's rarely a perfect choice either. Balancing the need to expand whilst consolidating and supporting your homeland is key to success within Civ VI. And as with nearly every option within the game - you can configure it to be as straight forward or ruthless as you like.

Overall and without wanting to sound like a sales pitch - I would highly recommend Civ VI in its Platinum Edition form. All the expansions and features crammed into the core engine make the title shine - enticing you in for that next turn that you told yourself you wouldn't have...... 32 minutes ago. Yet in standalone form, I'd be more wary of flying the flag for this game. It's not that it does anything wrong specifically - but compared to the rich content of the Platinum Edition, it feels like a hollow experience and mildly underwhelming. Therefore:-

Civ VI core edition			        - 6/10
Civ VI with bells & whistles edition 	- 9/10

Ive played about 16 hours so far of The Forest and i can honestly say that i would recommend this to anyone who likes survival games such as ARK and Minecraft. 
The game itself is very immersive, you find yourself sneaking about a lot to avoid being detected by cannibals/mutants and to effectively hunt down your dinner.
The storyline is very immersive also, you slowly start to figure out what has happened and the lore of the game as you go along and find various items and documents throughout the game that point you in the right direction of what you are supposed to be doing. 
There is always something to do in The Forest so you are never bored and there is a lot of exploring to do. 
for the small amount of money i paid for the game it was worth every penny.

If I were to steal Eurogamer's review scale of Avoid - No Verdict - Recommended - Essential, I would rate this [b]Recommended[/b].

If you like collectible card games (CCGs) and Roguelikes, this is a no-brainer. It combines what makes those fun.

One thing I particularly enjoy is that I don't have the deckbuilding paralysis of a traditional CCG. Everything gets thrown out, win or loss, every hour or so, so I spend much less time in menus and more time playing the game.

Runs can get really samey at the beginning after you get a feel for the game, and I feel like it is simultaneously too easy and too difficult. I rarely have those "well this is terrible luck but I can scrape through" runs, instead most runs are EZ stomps, it's just a question of whether that's from my POV or the computer's.

The devs are tweaking and updating constantly - once a week to be exact. The new character has seriously spiced the game up and alleviated the "Samey early run" complaint, but that is of course temporary until we get used to the guy, and we can't expect there to be an unending flood of new characters. I would like to see starting decks be randomly drawn from a limited pool (of only the "weaker" cards) to keep it fresh.

It is worth noting that I have never experienced a bug that I noticed, and the game has more than enough content to justify the price. As far as Early Access goes, on a scale of Ark to Factorio, this is a Factorio situation.

Worth the asking price for its target audience, but if you aren't a fan of CCGs or roguelikes, it's hard for me to say if you will like it.

People from SCS Software Studio in 2008 decided to recreate the hard life of a truck driver, traveling about on the roads of Europe. So there was a Euro Truck Simulator. Admittedly, the first attempt did not go lumpy. Players got a big world, sane physics and nice graphics, considering that while Rig 3 just going to the "gold" in 2009 from the competitors at the creation SCS was just boring and ugly 18 Wheel of Steel, which is competitive, to put it mildly, did not maintain . In 2010, the studio came from German Truck Simulator, in which, as the name suggests, had to ride on the roads of Germany. The summer of 2012 saw the light of Scania Truck Driving Simulator, which was a kind of "breakdown of the pen" modernized and completed up to the standards of modern graphics. And this fall in sale Euro Truck Simulator 2.

Loved RCT franchise and was so excited when I heards RCTW was coming out.  I am tisht and don't normally pre-order games and usually wait until they are in a good sale, however I preordered this as soon as I heard it was being developed.  I will say that I also bought Planet Coster too and have been playing the alpha of that.  I have no bias and I actually want to have two great theme park games.  I will continue to edit this as the game develops.

I've been playing theme park games for decades (yes, I am that old!!) and it's one of my favourite style of games.

The pre-realease weekend they did last year was a disaster and I was worried what game I would actually get for my money.  I anxiously waited for the next pre-release weekend until I saw that it was now released on "Early Access".   I guess they felt pressured to actually release something now that Planet Coaster was starting to do releases.

About the game.  The game does have a lot of features in it already to enable you  to actually build and manage a theme park.  This is definately in Early Access as there are issues that need to be addressed and features that need to be tweaked, but I have not experienced so many issues like other players.

Pros
Lots of feature to enable you to buld and manage the park.
A wide number of flat rides, coasters and shops to choose from.
The user content feature is amazing

Issues to be addressed (in my humble opinion)
Improved coaster building since pre-Early Access, but still is very fiddly and cumbersome to actually build a rollercoaster.  I'm sure with a lot of practice it will become easier, but even using the RCT like buttons to lay the track, it still isn't as easy and straight forward as RCT3.
Path building needs to be worked on
Needs the ability to demolish in a draggable area.  This maybe there, but I can't get it to work.  Its a pain in the ass to delete every tree and bush to be able to put a ride down.
It's not so clear the benefit of the different size staff buildings.  Is there a coverage radius that they cover?
I personally don't like being fored to have the entrances/exits fixed to the rides.

Should you buy this game?  I would still say yes.  I know there are problems with it, some people have experienced lag which I haven't.  I have faith that Atari are listiening to the community and will be implementing the changes, requests and fixes as the game develops.  Since release they have already done a couple of updates and I hope that they continue the pace and release frequent updates and changes rather than waiting months.

Yes, there are features in Planet Coaster that this game doesn't have and there's no arguing that the Planet Coaster videos look amazing.  Like I said earlier, I'd like to have two great rollercoaster games as I'm sure they'll both have their strengths and weaknesses.  Time will tell how both games will be developed.  For now, I will be spending far more time plating Roller Coaster Tycoon World than I will Planet Coaster.

The good: old first-person shooter game that accomplishes with not boring the player. Wide variety of weapons, pretty well dubbing (at least in Spanish), and easy to access and understand weapon menu and stuff. 
The plot is very interesting, now it is a cliche if we think of Stranger Things series for instance, but it is a cliche that hooks us, at least I find this stuff pretty interesting both in movies and series, and in videogames. 
The bad: even having chosen the easiest mode at the beginning of the game, I've been killed over and over again throughout the entire game, and I've had to reach many points and areas repeatedly unless I save the game constantly, thing that I did when I reached the final chapters of the game. It's not about the checkpoints what sort of annoys me or better said gets me done, but the fact of been killed that easily (taking apart that I may be a bit clumsy).
Finally, the controls are kinda clumsy or difficult, or that's my opinion. Though I know it's an old game. Quite many times I was bugged in the game, like, my character was bugged and I couldn't even move, so I would have to load the last checkpoint.
Overall, it is immersive, saving some parts that are quite the same and others that you have to be extremely an observer to figure out how to move on.
Game is really fun to play with friends. Hopefully soon more game modes will be added though.

Best small company studio game ever!
+Modding; modding community grow stronger everyday, there are a lot of mods, for different versions of game.
+Replay value; doing same thing over and over in this game, won't bore you as fast as it would in other games.
+Difficulty; from peaceful builder, to random planetary 200x bandits annihilation at day 3...everyone will find something for themselves;
+Many mechanics; temperature; hunger; beautifullnes; sturdiness; flammability; trading; crafting; diplomacy; building and many many more;
+Developer who actually care about game, and what community has to say
+Optimalisation; should run even on lower end PC's (not like those unreal 4 games...)
+Done and done; It's development is roughly done, so modders can flourish now with mods on newest version of game.

-Genre; not everyone must likes colony/city/country/planet simulator games, but i have to say it's best of it's kind (i played few of them).
-Price may not seem the lowest, but taking to consideration how much time Tynan (Developer) spent time and effort creating this game, will make it more resonable.

I've played it for more than 1000h and it's my favourite game alongside with Nier:Automata.

Shattering game. In the end you lose, no matter how good your deck is. And then you lose your affectionately built deck, too - every time. 
Additionally, somehow the enemies do not seem to attack like announced. If its a 1x5 or 5x1 attack, its just one 5 attack; or just one 10 attack, when it says 5x2 or 2x5; not always, but annoyingly often.
Also, if there is a 25% chance to wake an enemy, you _always_ wake the enemy, but when there ist a 25% chance to obtain a relic etc in the first of a series of attemps, you nearly _never_ get the relic with the first attempt. 
The description of the cards could be more precise, too. When it says "chose one card" it does not say "from your hand", but thats exactly what the card means.
And the last rant: at some point of the game, there are so many relics and effects active, that its _impossible_ to predict/ overlook the exact outcome of your or the enemy's actions, without studying every turn for minutes.

So, in the end this is a roguelike deck-building game for people who do not care about what roguelike and deck-building games are or how these games really work or are played.

PS: Addition: As stated by others, this is a RNG game, but the number(s) for your game is (are) rolled _before_ the game starts, not for each turn seperately. So, if the numbers are against you, you _CANNOT_ win a combat, no matter what you try.
PPS: Ok, this game needs some serious debugging! Had three enemies, two were'nt attacking, the third was just applying a non-harming /-damaging buff. I had no health stealing / damaging buffs etc. - and I died! Is this game still maintained???

This has to be one of the best games ever made. I have never played a story as intense and insane as this one. The dlc's were so good, they could have made a whole new game out of them. Many of the side quests where so deep that sometimes I actually thought I was playing the main quest. The game has awesome graphics, beautiful landscapes, amazing soundtracks, insane cutscenes and I really loved the design and detail of all the characters. This was the best adventure I have ever experienced and if it was possible, I would love to play this game again for the first time. A rating of 10/10 wouldn't be high enough for this game.

Overall is very similar to Civ 4 and 5 in terms of gameplay, so if you were fans of those you should like this. There are a few new mechanics which either feel pointless, don't make sense or are just straight up confusing, however the additions of diplomacy, road building, religion overhaul, new leaders, climate change (DLC), new maps, etc are a key reason why Civ 6 is worth the money and in my opinion is on par with both Civ 4 and 5.

The game designers did an impressive job of creating many classes that play uniquely and accommodate a wide range of stylistic preferences. There's not really a "healer" class, but there are certainly roles for tank, melee dps, ranged dps, support, and hybrids. The 13 maps from the base game are varied enough to keep the game interesting while playing through the scenarios. The crafting system, which at first seemed overly simplistic, actually turned out to be one of the most useful crafting mechanics in a game of this type. You can craft gear that is the equal of 98% of the gear you can receive from loot chests. Lots of opportunities for customization. The only downside of the game is the often hostile and toxic player base, but I guess that's inescapable in 2020. The game can be played very easily (and beaten) even in the hardest modes with AI bots filling out your party, although I recommend reading the very helpful bot guides in the Community section. Some of the AI behavior is not intuitive and requires a bit of adjustment on the part of the player, but nothing is insurmountable. The Keep (or home base) is unique to each player and can be built out and spruced up if you're into that sort of thing. If your an achievement hunter, the game has a robust reward system in place for those who enjoy such mechanics. After 350+ hours, and purchase of all the DLC, I'm extremely satisfied with the game, the quality, and my time invested. Gold medal. Five Stars. 9 out of 10.

This game is a lovely casual exploration experience, in the same vein as Untitled Goose Game or Costume Quest. It know exactly what it's hoping to provide, and it delivers in spades. I had always kept an eye on it, and now that it's on sale I decided to give it a try. 

I was absolutely not disappointed. The atmosphere and ambiance are adorable, and everything is cute, but not overly simplified. I found myself stopping to explore every possible nook and cranny I could find, and almost always stopped to chat with NPCs. The game is constantly rewarding you, giving you coins and shells to collect, and often letting you have quest items simply for talking to the world's characters. 

The main character, Claire, Is a nice enough person, and isn't written to be so "nice" that she comes across as generic or outwardly obnoxiously nice. Rather, she feels pleasant yet easygoing, and most interactions feel believable as a result.

Throughout the game, you direct Claire as she jumps, flaps, glides, dashes, and climbs her way up to the highest point of Hawk Peak on Hawk Peak Island on a quest for cellphone reception. Along the way you can stop to chat with and help NPCs. Or not. 

It's entirely optional to interact with all the NPCs, and you only really need to find about 6 collectibles (in the form of golden feathers) to climb your way up to the top. I would highly recommend talking to everyone you meet, however, as you can find many more items to help you on your journey by helping the island's other inhabitants. You can get an item to help you run faster, purchase more feathers, collect a few pieces of cosmetic headwear, and more, simply by talking to people. The map is small enough that you aren't likely to be lost for more than a minute or two, and the landscape is easy enough to learn your way around. 

If climbing the mountain has you beat, you can take a break from your quest and do various other activities, such as fishing, volleyball (but with sticks), running races, and treasure hunting, along with multiple short sidequests to help get various things for various people. Even though I was not required to do any of it, I ended up doing most all of it, and feeling pleased with just how much content there was.

The soundtrack is mostly comprised of a few orchestral pieces, but in my time playing it, I never felt any track was overused or overstayed its welcome. The mixing makes the instrument selection mix together quite well, and wouldn't be out of place on iTunes/Bandcamp/whatever the heck else is popular.

If all you want is a pleasant, relaxing little island adventure/exploration game on the cheap that fells great to play, and is equally pleasant to look at, you really can't go wrong with A Short Hike.

Civ been around forever... still a great game.

Three colonists crash land in a forest. "Young" and "Walsh" hit it off immediately and get engaged. "Hun" is a hard worker that gets things done.

Compound slowly expands over time, including steel buildings completely surrounded by a steel wall. We are invincible.

Get a distress call from an old woman running from some angry tribals. We save her and kill/capture the tribals (their bow and arrows are no match for our rifle and pistol). She joins us and becomes our charismatic chef.

Get another distress call from a big geologist. Prepare to fight tribals, instead put up against trained soldiers in nano armor and energy weapons. Find out that we are, in fact, not invincible. Hun is killed, Walsh is downed (but rescued by Young), and the old woman disappears without a trace (seriously no idea what happened to her, no corpse or anything).

We managed to down one of the soldiers. Young equipped his armor/weapon and killed a second soldier causing them all to flee. Walsh gets better and both he and Young are fully equipped in nano armor with energy weapons. Now we are definitely invincible.

Another group of tribals attack. They are pathetic and quickly killed outside the walls by my new energy weapons.

Wait, what is this? The energy weapons set the corpses on fire? Wow that fire is spreading quickly...

**5 minutes later**

The entire compound is lost and half the map burnt down before it finally started to rain. Apparently those weapons run on jet fuel because my steel walls and buildings were no match for that blaze. George W Bush would be proud. RIP trapped prisoners and that group of visitors from the other colony sleeping on my floor.

I guess sleeping on the floor in the ruins of the compound was bad for morale and the geologist we saved earlier snaps and starts stabbing Young. We put him down with energy weapons. Thank god there is nothing left to burn.

Young eventually snaps too and starts attacking her fiancee. She is downed but survives and is healed up by Walsh (thankfully he is a doctor).

Deciding that staying in the compound ruins is probably a bad idea, we move on to find some shelter elsewhere. What's this? Some kind of ancient structure? Well we have nothing to lose so maybe it will make a good temporary shelter.

Break through a spot in the wall, get attacked by giant bug robots. Run around the back and draw them out, then swing back around to enter the structure. Hah, stupid robots. There is something on the ground, looks like it does something to animals...maybe it will tame the ones nearby, I could really use the help.

Activate device, animals go into a man-killing rage. Every single animal on the map rushes to the structure. Young and Walsh go down in a literal blaze of glory as the swarms of animals attacking them are set on fire by the energy weapons.

10/10. Now I understand why the alien races in movies never trust humans with advanced technology.

A sad disappointment. I won't speak about the hype this game had, nor the graphics, nor anything like that. As that isn't what makes this game un-fun for me. Its the gameplay.

I had the privilege to play the early version of this game way back in 2013, and while it was basic, the game was a fun ride with days’ worth of content. I can appreciate why the developer wanted to make a new exploration and leveling system to help make the game stand out, but the execution somehow makes it pointless to progress. No levels, gear becoming useless outside of the equivalent of your neighborhood, and items vanishing into thin air the moment you leave that neighborhood makes your progression hardly worth it. 

What’s the point of a game where your reward for hours of work is half of a percent total increase to your movement speed?

I lost interest in this game fast, which is funny because the game itself is very polished and well-tuned around its core system. (A broken system minds you,) but well-tuned regardless.

If I were to make a suggestion for the developer who won’t look at this reply because I hardly doubt, they would, I would make it so that as you explore new areas, your weapons lose their strength gradually. So, if you leave your area, your 5 Star loot might become a 4 Star, and so on. That way your progress isn’t too hampered by leaving to explore that neat ice biome. Another idea is to have, instead of the items like gliders or bells in special locations, lock those stat buffs across the land so that their small powers will lead to something. You can have those buffs be locked behind na enemy encounter or a boss fight, but if you want all of them you need to explore to different biomes because each area only has one key item. Lets say you start off in a grass land and you unlock the glider, ok cool, but now you have to find the bell for that one dungeon in the ice area to the north, or the whistle in the lava land down south. You get the idea.

I know there are countless other ways of improving the game but seeing as its been months since that point, I don’t think they will. I wouldn't recommend this game in its current state, only pick it up if its updated or if the reviews change.

But if they could just add XP back I would be a happy camper. God, I miss it so.

First off if you're even reading this, and still haven't even decided to buy this game... Just fucking buy it, it's like $5, and it's not even that big of a game. I got this game back in 2013 with my shit ass internet, and was able to download this game and that's when it was a whopping $15. But if you do decide to get this game make sure you get Counter-Strike: Source (CS:S). Trust me, it makes everything easier. But any who, lets get started.

First off the game is only like $5, if you don't have $5 then how the fuck did you afford to get a PC? It literally cost less that a Little Caesars Pizza.

Second you can literally do anything you want in this game, you can download anything, make it look like anything, and do whatever you want. If you want to be a fat fucking bumble bee blasting zombies with a sawed off with a x40 scope on it, by all means. If you want to building a giant building out of wood and set that son of a bitch on fire, by all means, if you want to race cars in this game, by all means. This game is like Minecraft after Minecraft. You can download addons (if you don't know what addons are for, just go to the Garry's Mod workshop and just look at everything to get an idea.) so for example you're looking for a particular map, BOOM in the workshop. If you're looking for a specific car, BOOM in the workshop. If you're looking for a unique playermodel, BOOM in the workshop. If you're looking for a type of gamemode to play, BOOM in the workshop. I don't get how by now you don't understand how that you can literally do whatever you want in this game.

Third you don't have to play online or multiplayer, you can just play by yourself if you're a lame ass introvert. This game is honestly perfect for anytype of player. If you want to play solo, sandbox is where it's at, if you want to play multiplayer, literally there's anything you want to play on there from StarWars RP (for all you nerds out there) and a bunch of other RP servers out there, there's Gun Game, Prop Hunt, Speed Runs, TTT, like I mean anything you want to play.

Fourth... honestly I've done said enough, just buy the game and quit being a broke bitch and spend the outrageous $5's and just try it, worst thing that could happen is that you don't like it, and if that's the case just sell your PC you uncultured swine.
You can do whatever you want, think about it, and... JUST DO IT.

Everyone wants to hop on the hate train for this game without even playing it. I normally don't even write reviews, but due to all of the hate, I feel the need to. 

I'll start with the negatives. 

Cons - Low quality net code compared to other PC shooters. Games like Overwatch and BF1 outperform COD by a large margin. BUT, this game has BETTER net code than BO3, so keep that in mind. 

91 FPS cap. This doesn't particularly bother me, but there is no reason to make an FPS cap.

Occasional stuttering in Multiplayer matches. Happens maybe once every other game, where i get zero FPS for about a half second. 

People who aren't already into COD multiplayer probably won't like the COD multiplayer. The game keeps getting more complex and I don't think it is very inviting for new players. 

Okay, negatives aside, what are the Pros?

I have 700+ hours in the BO3 Multiplayer, and hundreds of more hours spread across other COD multiplayers, and i find this multiplayer to be particularly enjoyable so far. I went into the multiplayer with no enthusiasm, but after 20 hours of gameplay or so, i realized that i was genuinely enjoying the game. I think that the multiplayer is well balanced and well done overall. 

The creators of the Multiplayer probably had a lot of fun with the game, adding in a few classic weapons from MW2 and MW3 that look and feel just like their old versions. 

Optimization - For my PC personally, this game runs smoother than BO3 and AW. I have it on max settings at 60+ FPS, and i could not do that on the previous 2 CODs. The game looks graphically amazing, compared to the cartoony look of BO3. 

Zombies mode - SO MUCH FUN. I enjoy Trayarch zombies, but they always had a more serious tone, and with the way that the zombies maps were made, there was a lot of grinding involved to get set up. You ALWAYS had to spend 30 minutes to an hour watching youtube videos before you could even attempt to do well at all in a Treyarch zombies map. 

In the new zombies, it's so relaxed and fun. Everything is goofy and laid back. It isn't supposed to be taken seriously, and on top of that, it is probably one of the most fleshed out Zombies experiences i've ever had. There is so much more to do in this zombies mode than there ever was in any treyarch zombies, and it is all fun and easy to pick up on. 

The Campaign - I don't like playing COD campaigns. The last Campaign i enjoyed was World at War. The cinematic experience in that game was bar none. The last three Campaigns that i at least tried (BO2, Ghosts, and BO3) I ended up not finishing. 

IW's campaign, however, is an experience that drove me to finish it and pulled emotion out of me. And it was not the same linear experience that I was used to. It involved side missions and other decisions, giving it a never before seen felxability. That's all that i can say about it, you have to experience it first hand. 

TL;DR - If you liked BO3, get this game. It's a good one. It recieved a lot of hate for no reason other than falling into an unfortunate downward trend that the internet all got in on. 

Multiplayer - 8/10  (On par with BO3, with better net code/hit detection)

Zombies - 9/10  (I am a treyarch zombies nerd, and I actually enjoy this zombies more than treyarch zombies)

Campaign - 8/10  (This is coming from someone who generally HATES COD campaigns)

I first played through this game on the Switch, I love it so much I am playing through again on Steam. This world is absolutely massive, immersive and a perfect fit for the Metroid-vania genre. Hollow Knight is a 10/10. A masterpiece. From the tight controls, to the level design and music, there is nothing wrong about this game. It is worth far more than its $15 price tag. It is a work of passion and you can tell as soon as you load in. The sound track a perfect fit and so well orchestrated. The soundtrack coupled with the enviorment makes some of the best scenes I have ever seen in any one game. I found myself literally overwhelmed with beauty. This game doesn't hand-hold or give much direction in the form of actual instructions. You learn to play from playing the game. Fighting enemies is coordinated and tight, if you die it was your own mistake, nothing is ever felt cheap. You may come to a pass that you cannot get through, so you go to a different area and get stronger, get another power up and then you can do what you were originally trying to do. There is a ton of back-tracking and it is impossible to do an entire area in one run. That may turn some people off but that is a classic Metroid-vania staple. This game will have you begging for more if you manage to get to one of the many endings. I cannot recommend this game enough, it is well worth your money and your time. I will continue to play through this game every couple of years. It is timeless. 10/10 Team Cherry.

I've got 19 hours here on Steam but I've got a couple of hundred on Xbox. I've played every killer and almost every survivor. My killer rank was 4 and Survivor rank was 2. My point in this is I know the game very well despite my hours on Steam not being very high.

This game has a lot of potential, but currently it is literally hot garbage. So the number 1 problem is how fast the objectives can be completed, for the longest time there was a perk that helped slow the objectives down making it at least managable for the killer. That perk is now nerfed into being useless, so there is absolutely no way to win as a killer unless you play as a few different characters (which wouldn't be as much of a problem if you didn't have to pay for all these killers that have almost no chance). What this effectively means is that if you play as killer and do everything right you're still probably going to lose, and if you play as Survivor and don't have a team full of morons, you're probably going to win. It's hot garbage and not in the least bit fun.

The problem is actually because the maps are so God awfully big, you can't properly pressure the objectives as a killer. People have done the math on this and it's physicially impossible unless the survivors just decide to not work on Generators. 

I uninstalled this game on my xbox and on PC, I won't be playing it anymore until they fix the objective speeds in some way (which really means making the maps smaller, NOT actually slowing down the gen speeds themselves).

This is one of the few times I wish I had a middle option for recommendation. I’m not a huge fan myself, but I don’t think it’s a bad game.

If you liked Doom 2016, you may or may not like Doom Eternal. It’s a different type of game built out of the same bits. Much more chaotic and much less focused. It’s Doom 2016 cranked up to 11, and not in a good way. 

They added a bunch of new mechanics but none of them do anything interesting.  Now you can press a button to get armor just like the way you can press a button to get health. You can punch things when your punch things meter is full. Certain enemies have weaknesses where you shoot a particular weapon at them or shoot them in a particular place, but exploiting those weaknesses ends up feeling like a chore. It all just ends up feeling pretty hollow.

The bad story in the first game was easy to ignore. The bad story in this game is so bad that I can’t help but be irritated any time anyone is talking. 

It’s still pretty fun sometimes, but it’s one of those games I sit down to play and an hour later I realize I’ve just been zoned out and bored for most of that time.

That’s just me though. I can see the appeal for people who aren’t me. It’s fast paced and challenging, and the act of shooting things is as much fun as ever. The guns are still great. It’s just too messy for my tastes.

Inspired by a number of NES classics (Mega Man, DuckTales and Zelda 2 especially), Shovel Knight takes on Retro 2D platforming and does it justice.

I found the difficulty of the main game to be just right personally, not quite as unforgiving as some NES games due to checkpoints and being able to take more hits, but not pathetically easy like many modern games. One nice addition I found to the levels is the ability to destroy checkpoints, a simple 'higher risk/reward' mechanic. The level design takes similar ideas from Mega Man, with each stage having its own unique theme. The hazards, the boss and the stage item are all tied together with a general mechanic exclusive to the level. Some levels are more smartly designed than others, but are all overall well crafted. All of these are nicely complimented with great, tight controls.

The length of the main game isn't too long, probably stretching a bit longer than a typical Mega Man game. That said, with New Game Plus, and achievements which promotes other ways of playing (speed runs, no death runs, etc), there's a ton of replayability to be found in Shovel Knight.

The game has a decent mixture of chiptunes, some being more forgettable than others but the soundtrack isn't short of catchy tunes. The story is simple and straight to the point, with some funny dialogue here and there.

I've honestly had more fun with Shovel Knight than I've had with most of the 'AAA cinematic' games that have come out in recent years. Anyone who enjoys platformers and any of the NES games that Shovel Knight takes inspiration from will absolutely love this. Highly recommended.

TL;DR, 8/10. Solid game. Get the Super Deluxe on sale so you don't have to spend more on the DLC's later. 

I'd say it's a solid 8/10. By far the best [i]feeling[/i] Borderlands game I've played. The new movement systems with grapple and sliding as well as the overall shooting and gun play are great. The game looks good and runs fairly well on my system but there are stutters every once in a while when a lot is going on. Nothing really out of the ordinary in that regard. 

I think the only place I can knock points off is the story. As I'm sure you've already heard, the main villains aren't the best or most interesting. As of writing, I've completed the main quest line and Moxxi's Heist DLC. I would say the DLC is better than the main quest. It felt more like the older BL games in my opinion. 

Just as a tip if you do decide to buy, wait for a sale and get the Super Deluxe. It comes with the first "season" of DLC's (Only 2 are released at time of writing) and ends up being $20 cheaper than buying the game and the season pass separate. I learned that the hard way.

I still remember how I felt when I finished this game. I was lost for words, thinking: "What the f*** did just happen?"

To the Moon. Perhaps one of the greatest love stories crafted into a simple point-and-click pixel video game. Don't expect a lot of interaction. You will be an observer, learning about the lifes of Johnny and River.

The writing and story telling is exceptional. Have you seen the movie The Neverending Story? If so, I suppose you remember the scene when Bastian hides in the school's attic to read about the adventures of Atreyu in Fantasia? Try and picture this scene with you sitting at your computer. To the Moon will take possession of you and take you on a journey.

I suggest you play through the game in one session. Takes approximately 5-6 hours. Lock the doors, pull the curtains, mute the phone, get same snacks and be in for a ride (to the moon)!

Dead by Daylight is a terrifying and exhilarating game, that allows players to either play as a neglectful and mindful survivor, or as a murderous and fearful killer. Personally, I really enjoy this game, especially as the survivor, as the sensation of fear and having to be aware makes me feel excited. However, this does not mean that I despise to play as the killer, but it does give me pressure and anxiety. This only allows me to play as the killer for couple of matches, but the pressure can be also felt when I play as one of the survivors, since everyone is depending and relying on you (when they are hooked or knocked down). There are many positive aspects to this game that makes it so great, but I also believe there are few features that the developers have to improve on.

Firstly, I have to say that the matchmaking system is just terrible. Most of the time, I have to wait about 10 to 15 minutes, continuously joining and leaving to find a server that has a decent ping. These servers are usually around 200 to 400 ping and it takes even longer to find a good ping match when I am trying to play with my friend. Obviously, people can play with these pings but it would be so much more disadvantageous for the survivors. Therefore, I think the game should construct a setting, where the survivors will be able to adjust the maximum search ping. This way, I would not have to constantly join and leave. I know that this is not the game’s fault and the killer’s server, but still no one would like to play on match where they know that they have a high chance of losing.

Despite the matchmaking system, I really do like the game itself. The idea of silently and carefully fixing generators, juking and trying to escape the killer makes the whole game really thrilling and fun. The maps are also random (unless someone uses an offering), which makes the game more interesting. That moment when you 360 a killer and escape, or when you knock down a survivor as the killer can be really satisfying and exciting. The perks are also really interesting, as players can build their survivors so that it matches their play-style. I really like the idea of teachable perks, because a player might want to only have the perk from another survivor, and use it on a different survivor. For example, my favourite survivor to play is Meg Thomas, and not surprisingly, my favourite perk is “Sprint Burst”. However, I do not like all of Meg’s perks (e.g. Quick and Quiet), and I also really like Claudette Morel’s “Self Care”. This allows me to build up a set up the way I want to, so that I can have different perks on one survivor, and play as it. I do think that every items or perks can be countered with different perks or items. For example, if the survivors have powerful items that gives them an advantage (e.g. Brand New Part), they can be countered by the killer with the perk “Franklin’s Demise”, which makes the survivors drop their items. In other words, I think the game concept is great and everything does fit in a way. 

Recently, I admitted that Dead by Daylight is not a pay to win game, as players cannot buy bloodpoints to upgrade their survivors or collect more items (from the blood web). They have to actually play the game to earn it, and players can collect more by using offerings or completing daily rituals. However, the recent DLCs (Leatherface and Freddy Krueger) has made me consider if this game is a pay to win game or not. Leatherface’s perks, such as “Barbecue and Chilli” can give a huge advantage to the killers and Freddy had to even be nerfed because there were many complaints from the survivors. In other words, the more DLCs a player obtains, the more option and advantage they could possibly have in this game.

Lastly, I have to mention the killers that makes this games absolutely insufferable. The killers that camp and patrol are makes the game extremely difficult for the survivors. I know that the other survivors could simply work on the generators while the killer is camping, but this makes the game for the person hooked unenjoyable and bias. In addition, the players could possibly not complete working on the generators in time (by the time the hooked survivor dies), in which the killer will again hunt. If another survivor is knocked down, this decreases the chance of the other survivors escaping. I should say that the best perk to go against a camping killer would be “Borrowed Time”, but it would not be that difficult for the killer to chase and knock down the survivor again.

In conclusion, I think Dead by Daylight is an incredible game. Despite the horrible matchmaking system and the killers that are “cancerous”, the game provides a sensation of thrill and excitement.

The definitive underwater exploration game. Delivers on all aspects.

What I loved:
-Deep sea monsters
-Surprisingly varied biomes to explore

-The feeling of dread when surrounded by empty black sea in all directions

This game is hard and it makes me hard. But fun! This has got to go in my list of top games of all time. I'm not a 90s kid, so I can't really say from frist hand experience how it felt to play this game back in the day, but I am playing at an age at which probably most started playing back in the day, so I guess it count's. This game shares my #1 spot for favorite game alongside with Fallout 2 (ESPECIALLY with the Restoration Project!).

This game came bundled with the RPG Maker VX Ace Humble Bundle, and that is how I got it. So when I loaded the game up, I can't say I was expecting much. I was sure it'd be enjoyable, but I didn't expect it to be one of the best games I've played in recent memory. The story is absolutely engaging. It's an emotional journey about granting the last wish of an old man, and the way the story is told is remarkable. I can't go too far into detail without spoilers, but I cannot recommend this game enough.

The graphics are done in the old SNES style, with more polish, and look quite nice. The music is beautiful, and is perfect for the scenes that it sets. The game sprinkles humour into the story quite well to add some chuckles to what is a rather sad story. The story itself if beautiful and very well written. There is no other way to put it. I'm a dude, and even then, it was emotionally moving.

So buy To the Moon! It is worth every cent.

I love how realistic this game is. The controls and physics behind this game are incredible. The one thing that I have a serious problem with is the constant crashing. Throughout a 2-4 hour gaming session, my game will crash, on average, ~7 times. This is getting extremely frustrating. I have checked my file integrity, updated my drivers, and done everything I've read about on the forums, but the crashing still persists. All in all, it really is a great game and I've had a lot of fun learning how to play it. I will still recommend this game to friends and other gamers. Just keep in mind that you may have to deal with multiple crashes during a short period of time.

[h1] Amazing game that attracted possibly the shittiest community of players I've ever seen. [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
[*] Satisfying gunplay with a satisfactory level of weapons/attachments. It's not Tarkov, but it's servicable.
[*] Good graphics and audio.
[*] Emphasis on tactics. Run and gun won't cut it most of the time.
[*] No hand-holding. This game is very unforgiving and for hardcore shooter fans, this should be a huge positive.

[b] Cons: [/b]
[list]
[*] The community is fucking garbage. Get ready for a non-stop stream of everything offensive that these dude-bros and neckbeards can think of between matches.
[*] A lot of chinese players abusing 500+ ping and then also using thier limited knowledge of english to indulge themselves in some racial slurs between matches.
[*] "Firefight" is just a bad game-mode.

[b] TLDR: [/b] If you mute-all and take firefight off your matchmaking list, the game is great. I wavered on whether or not to give this game a recommend. I tentatively give it a thumbs up because the actual game is really great. The people that play it, however, should probably go dig holes in a desert for the rest of their lives.

Oh this is SO frustrating! I have well over 1,400 hours sunk into Civ V – that’s 58 days, nonstop playing. That’s not counting the countless hundred of hours on Civilization 1-4. I love the series, so it pains me to say this: Civilization VI sucks.

The AI is schizophrenic. Settle a city? Denouncement. Don't settle cities? Denouncement. Don't expand your borders? Denouncement. Expand too much? Denouncement. Grow your army to prevent the IA from attacking? Denouncement. Leave your army small? Denouncement.

All this Denouncement eventually leads to the AI to flip out and march to war against you. But if you build a strong military to repel this attack? The AI will focus Science or Religion and win that way.

We'll put it this way - I'm 14 hours deep into Civ VI, playing on the easiest level, the "I am a Wussie Man Baby! Please don’t hurt me!" and I have YET TO WIN. This should be a cake walk. I should be curb stomping everyone and everything in arms reach. I should be Brock Lesnar beating up a pack of handicapped preschoolers. And for some reason I just cant make ground.

And the worst part? It took me 14 hours to figure this out. Refund for a fundamentally broken game? Hah. hah, hah. Good luck with that kid.

Ah well,  Back to Civ V I guess. . . .

****EDIT****
After trying the new patch, the AI is still broken and the game is still terrible. Go play Civ 5.

Around 30 hours in, Subnautica is easily a new favorite of mine. It's an excellent example a survival-crafting game with a huge space to explore, a wide variety of materials and recipes to locate, and ties everything together with a sci-fi narrative with a touch of horror.

The sound design of Subnautica is excellent. For better or worse, the controls and graphics are reminiscent of Portal 2...which is to say, not bad at all! (But don't expect things to be hyper-detailed either.)

There are a few difficulty levels if you hate the survival mechanics, enjoy the struggle, or like something between. One thing that'll likely be love-it-or-hate-it is how little the game holds your hand. My first death was from not finding water fast enough - I just hadn't learned how to find the supplies yet. If you're aiming to craft certain items, you could have to wait a while - until you stumble across the right blueprint or resource. You can get stuck sometimes, and your only option (without cheating and using a guide) is exploration! I LOVE this approach, but your mileage may vary.

Overall, I HIGHLY recommend this game if you're into adventure/exploration games. I'm mad at myself for sitting on this one for so long. It's easily a new personal favorite.

I have finished the game twice the second time being only a few days ago. Ultimately, I do think that Half-Life 2 is a little overrated. It is a lot of fun and the story, character, and atmosphere are absolutely great, but the gunplay itself is not nearly as satisfying as a lot of other games. It's heavy focus on physics puzzles highlighting the Source engine's abilities also stick out as a dated mechanic. It's great to go back and have a look at what was for its time one of the most innovative games and it is still an enjoyable game to play, but I don't think it is quite as utterly amazing as most of us perhaps think it was. Also, buyer beware, Half-Life 2: Ep. 2 does have something of a cliffhanger ending that has been left hanging since 2007 and in my personal opinion is very unlikely to ever be resolved by any official Valve release. 

However, Project Borealis, which is based on Mark Laidlaw's Epistle 3, may offer some measure of closure to long time Half-Life fans once it does release. 

Also, only go for the neighborhood watch achievement on hard difficulty  if you're a compulsive masochist like myself. Otherwise, spare yourself the pain.
