It's been 5~6 years since the release of this masterpiece and chances are that you probably already heard how good this game is. And I have to say that all of those comments about the amazing graphics, breathtaking world design, fantastic storytelling with memorable events and exceptional characters are all true. This game is one of the best games ever made and the only excuse you have for not playing it is either not having the time or money. It doesn't matter if you are not a fan of RPG or medieval games, you probably will like this game anyway.

So, since there are literally hundreds of thousands of reviews about this game, with most of them basically saying what I just wrote, I would like to present some other points that I haven't seen in what I've read so far:

First, let's just pause for a second and try to gasp the fact that Geralt was the protagonist of 7 books and 2 games before this one, and this game might be the end of the road for the witcher series.  Do you know how amazing is that? You are not playing with some mediocre protagonist who is just learning his way around the world. You are playing with a professional monster slayer whose story and character have been building up for decades now, and you will define its ending! And don't worry if this is your first contact with the series, because you will be able to catch up with the story and characters fairly easy.

Secondly I want to address the bestiary and the whole monster design/lore. This game has easily the most diversified list of enemies and creatures, with each and every having a well written entry on the bestiary. They bring you not only a detailed niche of the creature, like the way it behaves, how it preys and devours its victims, but also the lore and interesting facts about it. And the game actually follow this information in such a way that you can possibly guess which creature you are hunting before the game tells you. This was the only game that made the extra reading something cool and rewarding. 

Now, this game is not perfect. There are some flaws like the pretty bad UI or the main quest being mostly about finding people and doing favors (seriously, sometimes you have to help a guy for him to help you help another guy for him to tell you where the person you are looking for is - this would be a deal breaker in some games but those persons that you help have such well written backstories and personalities that the whole thing turns out to be exciting.) but for me the worst flaw is the combat and difficulty. 
There's a ton of different bombs, potions and crossbow bolts,  5 signs (magic spells) with a lot of customization and still the most optimal way to fight is to keep pressing B to dodge and spam fast attacks whenever possible. Remember the amazing monster variety that I've just talked about? They are all very similar when fighting and can be killed with the same simple strategy. 

Fortunately the DLCs fixes all of those problems (with the exception of the UI), bringing amazing and fun quests, new character customization that makes other combat strategies more viable and new enemies with different mechanics that force you to use new strategies. 

It's nice to see that CDProjectRED were aware of the game's problems when they made the DLCs. 

Like I said before this game is a must, and if you like the base game (which, let's be honest, you will) then you will enjoy the DLCs even more.

At first this seems like a great party game, and it is. But once you play for many hours, you realise there are so many Quality of Life issues that aren't addressed. The dev team is more focused on making more $$ with new DLC content rather than updating the current game to it's best. Bringing me to my next topic.

This is a great little arcade game, but not for the price. I recommend only ever purchasing the base game and the DLC's when it's ON SALE. There is little to no replayability on this game at all. Once you beat the levels, it's done, it's finished. And honestly, it's not a lot of content for the amount of $$ that you spend. Because keep in mind, this game is meant to be played with friends. So they all have to purchase a copy for themselves.

There are no endless stages. It's all about replaying the same exact stage over and over and over again until you get a better score. What do I mean? Well for the base game, there are 6 stages. And in each stage there are about 5-6 levels. That's it. no more. So what do you do now? You've completed the game in like 20 hours. Why can't they just add in 1 Stage, that has infinite levels? I don't know. Oh, I guess you have to spend more money for more levels. Time to buy the DLC.

There are no weekly or even monthly updates to improve or enhance the game.
Okay, IMAGINE THIS: Once you've unlocked all the Chefs/Characters, there are OVER 50! Great! But here's the catch, the ONLY WAY for you to choose which chef to play is by clicking LEFT or RIGHT. So in order to scroll through ALL the chefs that you own, you'll need to click in one direction FIFTY TIMES. There are NO character selection screen where ALL the chefs are displayed on one screen, and you can see all their profile pictures. "Hey I feel like playing as the green alien today, let me just click right 25 times until I reach it"
Like, that's just one quality of life issue.

This is one of the best games Ive ever played, across every category. 

Graphics are off the charts, super well optimized and runs like butter at 4k. The story is interesting and engaging and keeps you wanting to learn more, the world is huge and filled with gorgeous organic textures and forms, and the exploration/porter game is 80% better than I expected any game with these mechanics to be. The increasing challenge of traversing while carrying 100s of kg of deliveries actually turns out to be deep and fun, your abilities to do with carrying and balancing have actual interesting progression, and somehow Kojima has made a totally original masterpiece out of this concept. 

 I really didnt understand how Kojima would pull off a non-PvP oriented game where people support one another and succeed together, but on release day...I got it.

Stardew Valley is the spiritual successor to Harvest Moon. Arguably even better than its inspiration.

Essentially what the game is about is that you just moved to a rural town called Pelican Town. There, you live the farmer's life, you farm vegetables, you water your plants, grow fruits, take care of barn and coop animals, you fish, you mine, you fight monsters while you mine, you cook, you make money, and you make friends (maybe even life partners)! 

Playing this game will give you a zen and peace that you never thought you had.

This game can be insanely fun, or frustrating. After some hours the panic feeling of being chased or the thrill of the hunt kind of goes away and it starts to get that "playing a game" feeling though. DBD has events pretty regularly, is always being updated, and also having things added to it. Also, with the connection of the console versions, the game has seen a pretty large boost in players overall. I would recommend it, and if its on sale, you would be silly not to pick it up.

One thing to keep in mind is that the community seems to play predominately survivor or killer in waves. Time zones also seem to affect this. So for instance, if you are having a long cue time as a survivor, hop over to killer and you will get almost instant games, and vice versa. So if you want to "main" as one and only one, that might be a downside for you.

Bought it during the 2019 Summer Sale. Any bugs or weird balancing that was apparently in at release seems to be fixed now.
The gameplay/system "feels" better than f.e. Pillars 2 (which i also like) but the story/tone seems less super serious (but not silly like Divinity 2). Kingdom mechanic is stressful since you never seem to have time to do everything (or even most things), but I don't know if it matters much.

Subnautica is an interesting game with very many neat and realistic mechanics dealing with water based exploration. There are islands in the area but the world is more or less completely covered in water as far as the eye can see. Which isn't a bad thing, infact it makes it all the more challenging.

If you are into base building, like I am, this game has a great time with it. Same with resource gathering, survival and vehicles construction.

Ocean exploration involves going to the very depths of dark abyss or burning lava zones to find the resources you need to make the various objects in your base. Creating a on hand recipe book will make gathering easier but nontheless the system is quick so long as you pay attention and set beacons in the appropriateareas to mark places of interest. 

Major resources you will want is Titanium and Quartz as they provide the items that are the basis for base building/shelter creation.

It is imperative you adapt quickly and if you use the survival mode, securing a source of food and fresh water (normally through technological blueprints and fish) is a must if you wish to survive.)

My first play through put me in a rather safe and docile location, no biters, realtively fewStalkers (metal grabbing and aggressive fish almost like a barracuda) and lots of metal and quartz deposits. Along with crash sites with plenty of starter blueprints.

I cannot wait to see what else they add to this game in regards to additional vehicles and base designs.

Though it is in early testing phase, it is a load of fun and well worth the money spent!

So I've not been in Stardew Valley very long but I'm already growing to love this place...although the first few days here were slightly odd. 

I found a letter in my mailbox from a man called WIllie who wanted me to go and meet him at the beach.  

So I set off trying to find the beach, only to bump into a very attractive lady called Haley.  I accidently wacked her a few times with my sickle before saying hello.  We talked a little and then I followed her into her house...which she didn't seem to object to but apparently I didn't know her well enough to go into her bedroom.  Fair enough.  I left.  I continued my journey to try and find the beach which was sadly unsuccesful.  It was getting late and darkness fell.   By 1am I still hadn't managed to find my way home and had somehow ended up in the childrens playground! I ran away as fast as I could as I didn't want to residents of Stardew Valley thinking their new neighbour enjoyed hanging out in playgrounds in the middle of the night.  Thankfully I DID find my way back home again and had a long sleep. 

The next morning I decided to head out to try and find this elusive beach....only to end up at the local Joja Supermarket.  I wandered around the isles and then for some unknown reason I held a rock above my head and looked as if I was walking up to people wanting to stone them.  I eventually found how to make the rock go away and left. 

I *still* couldn't find the beach and night fell once more....I purely by accident found myself at the bottom of my garden but needed to hack my way through the undergrowth to get to my house.  By 2am I fell to the ground from exhaustion and passed out.  

The next morning I woke up - NOT in my garden....but in my own bed....which was great...the bad news however was that I appeared to have less money than I did yesterday.  Bugger! I found a hand written letter in my mailbox from a man called Lewis who said he found me on the ground and someone ran off as he approached.  He had carried me to my bed and said he hoped the thief hadn't taken too much money.  Lewis warned that I should be more careful in the future.....(Careful? I was in MY garden! How do I know that YOU 'Lewis' didn't steal my money? And more to the point, why exactly were you wandering around MY garden in the middle of the night? Hmmmm?).  

So this time I decided not to try and find the beach.....and would you believe it, it was the FIRST thing I found (typical).  I met the infamous Willie who gave me a rather nifty fishing rod.  I tested it out.  I caught some seaweed and ate it.  It tasted terrible but game me energy.  Hurrah. 

After an afternoon of fishing I headed home....somehow I ended up back in the playground AGAIN (I know, twice is a little harder to explain...) but thank God I made it back to the farm before night time.  

I watered my vegetables and hit the sack. 

A bloody brilliant game.  10/10.
A deep, engrossing adventure with at least 200 hours of A+ content if you buy the DLC

Everything about the game could be fixed by buffing some of the gag guns, making them drop far less frequently, and/or picking up the overall pace of the game. If just one of those three things were tweaked, I'd happily give it another chance. I really wanted to like this, but it just drags its ass so hard. I'd keep at it because there's legitimate challenge to be found later in the game but it just doesn't consistently reward successful gameplay enjoyably, interestingly, or often enough to feel worth it. It's also hard for me to call it a real bullet hell. Sure, there's lots of stuff to dodge, but the pace just feels too slow for it to really qualify for me. It's a real shame; On the whole, they crafted one hell of a likeable universe here and every aesthetic touch from the art to the soundtrack are very nice. I just couldn't get hooked by the poorly tuned gameplay.

Edit: I'm leaving this review up for posterity, but the game improved so much through content updates that it ended up as one of my favorite roguelites of all time. This may seem unforgiving, but once it clicks it's good to the very last boss.

To help people who have NOT yet played Witcher 3 and are considering to buy it, while wondering what sort of game it is, I will list the things Witcher 3 is NOT about, the things Witcher 3 does NOT included and the things you can NOT do in Witcher 3. If some or many of the things listed here are important for you to enjoy any game, maybe Witcher 3 is not the game for you.


[b]The Combat[/b]

While Witcher 3 is action RPG, some people expect a lot more action from the game. Witcher 3 has no complicated key sequences to memorize so you can pull of really cool combos. While the game provides some extra options to improve the combat (oils, bombs, signs, light or heavy attack, parry, counterattack, dodge) most of these are completely optional. Even on highest difficulty whole game can be played using just simple left mouse click for fast attack, Quen sign for shield and dodging or rolling away when enemy attacks. Everything else can be ignored. You can use all or many of these combat techniques if you want to but you do not have to use them.

The Witcher 3 has no wide variety of weapon types for you to choose from - no guns, poleaxes, two-handed swords, clubs, shields or throwing daggers. You can use crossbow. And you always, ALWAYS, use just one sword, steel sword on humans and silver sword on monsters. That is it.

The combat in general is fairly easy. You should not really die in Witcher 3 if you keep following the quests around your own level, keep upgrading your Witcher gear and do not try to blindly run into fights against enemies much higher level then you. 


[b]Customisation[/b]

In Witcher 3 you play as witcher called Geralt. You can not change the name. You can not pick another profession like mage or barbarion. You can not change your race or gender. Even changing the way Geralt looks is limited to wearing different armors (which WILL change the looks while you run around), having haircut and some optional looks for the beard.

While many side quests in Witcher 3 have several optional endings depending what options you pick, and even main quest have few branching plots where some character may live or die, in the end, the story you follow is set. No matter how many times you play the game, most of the quests and dialogues and events remain same. 

While you find multitude of weapons and armors in Witcher 3, witcher sets are always best so pretty everything else can be sold to the merchants. You are never required to farm some boss for the slight hope of legendary piece.


[b]Grinding[/b]

Witcher 3 has no grinding. If you enjoy killing same random monsters for hours to gather enough xp and gold and eventually level up and unlock new area, this is not the game for you. Monsters you kill provide very little xp and even less when you outlevel them. You get most of xp from doing quests around your current level and finishing main quest line. You can basically ONLY finish main quest and you still level up fast enough. You should do side quests and witcher contracts because they are fun but you are not really forced to finish any of them.

You never need to grind for gold if you explore the world and pick up items hidden in the bags, crates and dead bodies. 

No quest is repeatable. Once finished, they are done. No boss is farmable. Once dead, they do not reappear.


[b]Story and the World[/b]

The world in Witcher 3 is torned by war. In this war there are no good or evil. Most of the people are just trying to survive during this difficult time. There is a lot of mud and dead bodies and monsters eating dead bodies. The world is not happy place full of unicorns (expect 1) and rainbows.

People around you cough, sneeze and fart. If you find these actions revolting and disgusting, you will suffer. A lot. You can not avoid coughing and sneezing and farting around you.

For many quests there are no right or wrong answers. You are given options but none of the options is clearly better or worse. If you pick one path, you will have to kill someone who does not deserve it but if you choose other way someone else will eventually die. 

Young players do not enjoy the story, do not understand the witty remarks and have difficulty understanding pain and suffering some of the actions may cause. This is not the game for kids.

Game of the year. I find reading negative reviews interesting for this game because there are a couple common threads in those--they rate the game poorly and call it "walking simulator", but there's a catch: their time played is low. I have a friend who tagged this as walking simulator very early on, but he admitted he never even got far enough to get the first vehicle. I think the only main criticism I would give is that that should have happened sooner because I also found myself wondering what I had gotten into until I got to that point.

Sometimes I like open world games where your actions change things. But I also love when games have a coherent, thoughtful story like this. 

I love some of the ideas behind this and how it's a meaningful story that's about real life, too.

Keep on keeping on.

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is “Great”

Important: The game is for people with high patience and people who seeks a challenging game to finish. The game is not for the faint of heart. If you want a challenge, then go buy the game. 


If you are familiar with the fromsoftware games, then this would remind you of the thrill you feel of chilling anxiety or frustration fighting a boss that can repeatedly beat you.

The game is beautiful, the art work is really unique in its design comparing it to darksouls or bloodborne. The world is so mesmerizing, the colors bloom every time you get to a new location. When you explore more and more through the game, you will experience the obscure conditions of the characters or things revolving around the world. The game is really difficult if you are not good with the controller or the souls game mechanics, though the game utilizes new features like jumping or the grappling hook. The game still feels like its old predecessors but with new welcomed traits. 

The combat is very strategic, you cannot just attack and dodge or roll like dark souls. There are less instances where I felt like I could cheat my way into situations. I couldn't really spam arrows or magic, etc. You need to learn how to time your deflections/parry and destroy your enemy's posture to win an engagement. The fights become so intense sometimes, and it feels so good. One mistake can lead you dying, even with a resurrection, I was hesitant to die because of maybe some consequences. Stealth feature is also welcomed in the game, it is fairly new in the fromsoftware games, but it does help a lot in some cases. I could not stress enough how being smart in an engagement saved me a lot of times from dying. I have to add that, there are instances where I felt like I had an edge against the game because of my knowledge of the darksouls and bloorborne games, there are times where I knew things like a hidden wall, or a hidden object, I was really thorough in playing the game because of my history with this franchise. I would like to advise people to just read a lot of the hints, and inventory items to completely grasp the whole game.

The story is okay, I wouldn't say it is the best, but it did keep me interested, it is much easier to understand compared to the story of its predecessors. You are a shinobi tasked to help the divine heir, it's pretty straight forward before you progress the game. The more you progress, the more the story becomes complex and interesting. You will need to read a lot of notes, or talk and listen carefully to the NPC's to have a better understanding of everything. It is easy to miss a few side stories or quests if you make mistakes. In the end I didn't feel that much for the story itself,I only felt a lot of relief that I managed to beat the game. That is not because the story is bad, but because the game punished me so much with the boss fights, and by the end of the game I just wanted to finish it so I could feel satisfied. The game rewards the player for their dedication of getting better in the game and outsmarting it to have an advantage. I would like to add that there are annoying boss fights that are super difficult to defeat, some took me hours to complete. Even so, at the end, I felt the joy of success after finally beating them. 

The sound and music is pretty solid like the rest of fromsoftware games, the sound is pretty grounded. The swords clashing feels so impactful everytime it deflects, the blood splatters everytime I slice an enemy. I can feel the thrill of just trying to not be hit, desperately trying to break the enemy's posture then doing the final death blow. The music does its job, it is not over the top, but it does the job. The voice acting is mysterious and a bit like the darksouls or bloodborne games, but the NPC's doesn't feel like they are crazy or looney. The more the player listens to the characters, the more the player gets an idea of who they are and who they were. Again, the game doesn't spoon feed the player all the information, the player needs to find it for themselves. 

The AI felt a little stupid sometimes, the guards are sometimes literally stupid. Let me explain, once you kill a guard, the corpse will remain on the ground, but the other guards wouldn't care if there are piles of bodies laying on the ground. They would only react if they see you, and if the other guards alert them as well. The AI is good, when you start fighting against them, they have different set of moves to counter what you do. There are bosses where if you side step on their first attack, they would do a sweep, but if you stay in front of them, they would go for a thrust attack. Little things like that should be taken into account. It is important to mention that, some of the bosses were so creative. Some were really nerve wracking because of their appearance, backstory or just the uncanny sound they mark. Those little things made the game so special every different boss encounter.

SUMMING IT UP: If you like challenging, gritty action packed games, then go buy. Who doesn't wanna be a ninja assassin? In the end I did enjoy the time. I had a very stressful time handling some of the bosses, but after successfully beating them after my 45 hours of playthrough, I felt so accomplished as if I received an award at the oscars. It was a fun time for me, but in the end, “git gud” is the key to finish the game. 

Note: If you like character creation or varied build types or races. Then you wouldn't find that here, this may not be for you. Its variation is how you handle your enemies, your strategy and critical thinking.

[b]Bottom Line Review[/b]

Filled to the brim with content and story, this complicated isometric RPG adaptation of the Pathfinder ruleset is worth to experience... if you can play by its rules, handle its bugs, and accept some pretty severe difficulty spikes. Keep multiple saves.

Call of Duty Infinite Warafe, worst CoD ever, right? No, not at all.


Singleplayer

War between Mars and Earth, Humans vs Humans in a war for territory and resources. Missions take place at beautiful places and landscapes. All the characters are likable and enjoyable. Story and the plot are gripping and amusing. It's well told and presented. 10/10
Apart from the regular missions there are also Jackal side missions. You get to fly your own spaceship and battle others. It's fun and refreshing. 
There is a new difficulty called Specialist, it's simular to Veteran with just one difference, no auto healing. You have to find healing items and use them carefully because there is a limited amount of them. It's a nice challenge I recommend to everyone. 

Multiplayer

It feels like Black Ops 3 with different maps, guns and operators. It is fun and if you enjoyed BO3 you'll enjoy this one too.

Zombies

I didn't really play this mode that much. Just wasn't that interesting to me, so I won't write anything about it.

The developers missed what made each of the previous titles great and instead filled it with things that just make you ask "why?". I will not deny the combat is the best it has been in the series but the rest of the game gives you no reason to do anything. The story is one of the absolute worst I have ever seen. Without spoiling anything the story takes such a weird turn from previous titles that focus on the team rising above the odds to defeat the boss. This game focuses on one individual that barely anyone liked to begin with. The best characters in this game don't have more than 20 lines and the main characters are so shit, it just erases the great performances put out by them. While I will continue to play this game because of friends, I cannot justify saying that it is worth the $ I put down.

Ignoring my biased against the From Software sub-genre they have created. 

I had zero technical issues.

The last nail in the coffin: Most games increase difficulty by simply adding HP and not adding capabilities to the enemies. Sekiro tries to side step this by giving the player more capabilities to deal with tougher enemies. This is unfortunately all undermined by the non-linear "exploration" the game "offers". I put quotes there because none of the "exploration" is opt-in. In other words, you never know you are exploring until you find yourself against three bosses that you have no chance to defeat because you went left instead of right three hours ago. There is also no indication that you are participating in optional content.

Some might say "google it", but this isn't a min/max loot shooter or complex simulation game. This is an experience game, and as soon as you have to "google" something in an experience game, the experience is broken.

I play killer. I'm done.
I'm so sad that I have to leave this game, but it's just frustrating. Many other reviews have gone over the ridiculous broken balance of this game towards op survivors (read them if you want the technical aspect), so I'll just make a metaphor so you can understand how it feels.

Remember school? Remember that group of kids who used to pick on the "different" kid, physically abuse him and/or name-call him? Remember he couldn't defend himself because they were more and he was weaker than any of them? Remember how the one time he defended himself he got caught by the teachers and got suspended by the principal and the kids that picked on him didn't suffer any consequences?

School is the game. The group of kids are the survivors. The "different" kid is the killer. The abuse is just the broken gameplay that always favours survivors. The name-calling is the end of the match chat whenever you have to use cheap strategies because you have no other choice if you want to rank up. The killer is weaker than just one of the survivors, and there are 4. The time they defended was when they asked for better balances. The suspension were buffs to survivors and nerfs to the killers. The principal is the devs.

TLDR: If you like winning easy, buy the game and play survivor.
Otherwise, don't bother. The game is not and will probably never be fun again for killers.

After playing this game for a fair amount of time today being it's launch, Ive found some good and some bad to bring out. I'll list some of the things that may need adressing aswell as some of the good features about this game. Alongside that I will make a few suggestions towards the game.
Pros:
- Large amount of selection for cases, brands and types of parts available
- Career mode to work at
- Realistic steps (while starting out the game) to build and change parts of a PC
- Very good for people getting into building PC's, goes through a well formatted tutorial
- Good for people looking to learn more about PC's in general
- Realistic looking parts, good modelling 

Cons (Aswell as bugs):
- Obvious visual bugs that need addressing
- Interior cables come through the outside of cases in some cases
- Parts of a PC may become glitched outside of the case (such as fans)
- (Might be just me) The refresh rate is not changeable from 59Hz
- No anti-aliasing to the game so some things look quite choppy
- Lack of certain realistic sounds (such as walking, box opening)
- Annoying fan sound from PC
- Lack of cable managing customization
- Movement is very slow and field of view is not changeable

Recommendations:
I would recommend for the developers to put a bit more emphasis into graphics. I understand the game is a simulator and not really meant for graphics and visuals, yet I think it would benefit very muh and would be a step in the right direction for being worth is price of $20 (CAD) currently. Another thing would be more customizeability for the game itself, possibly such as the field of view in game. I would like to see (and most likely along with alot of other people) more animations. These could possibly include a box opening animation for the PCs, a delivery animation, maybe for even placing items on the workbench. Also adding a few more smooth animations for the operating system within the game would boost the overall smoothness of the game, I believe. Another aspect that could be improved upon is the cable management within the computers. If there was more customizeability for where the cables will route through it would add ALOT to the game itself with attention to detail. Also, a big recommendation would be possibly the addition of a mode or option to have a more advanced experience, for users who know about building computers with much knowledge. Possibly getting rid of guidelines in this mode and to maybe also require the user to select the correct headers for each cable connecting to the motherboard (or PSU). Another big aspect that could be improved upon is water cooling. I very strongly believe if watercooling was added that this itself would make the game worth its price. Adding AIOs to the game would make it much more customizeable and alot more interesting. Maybe even in the long run adding custom loops too! Overall, there is much to be said about the game and I do believe there is alot of potential for upgrading this game as it is of course in early access right now. At the moment, I am recommending the game for beginners to PC building and because it is in early access and there is still alot to be improved upon.

I've played a couple rounds with friends smashing the starter decks together, a few casual drafts and a keeper draft. That put me at the ~9 hour mark and so far, so good. I've really been enjoying myself. Been quite some time since a new CCGs mechanical systems have given me stiff nips. I think the last two that have made me sit up and take notice would be Shadowfist and Middle Earth: The Wizards back in 1995. Now, I am definetly still in the honeymoon phase; whether this one will be as deep and maintain the same long lasting interest as the former two I mentioned (I still play 'em) remains to be seen and too early for me to objectively tell. I have no issues with the monitization model because it comes the closest to the real world model while allowing me to break the rules in one signifigant regard. I see a card I want for a deck I buy it. That's it. I don't want to churn daily quests or grind games for hours to get my cards "for free." I already have a job. I sold a rare from my keeper draft for ~$5 and bought a couple dozen cards to modify my starter decks with for a about nickle to a dime, each. Other games where you bust up your cards into cookie dust or fairy sprinkles or whatever the return rate is booty sweat. Finally, I can play phantom drafts (no retention of drafted cards) for _free_. I'm about to make my $20 bucks sit up and dance for me in a way that cannot be equalled by nearly all competitors, to date. Magic: The Gathering Online has a singles market but no free draft so nuts to that.

That being said, I can recommend a purchase for aficionados of the genre and an encouragement for the curious with spare holiday dukats to step on board. If you think your in the later camp make damn sure to not accept the event tickets and boosters that come with the account or no within-two-hours return is possible (to quote Surly Joe, "You seen 'em; you play 'em.") I'll probably make an update middle of December when formats may or may not rotate.

app_name: Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy
review: I got over it.

Subnautica, Subnautica - what should I say? I've never played a game with that much [b]joy and love[/b]! [i](.. and sometimes a good portion of fear)[/i]

[h1]First of all: 10/10! Recommended![/h1]
(Have I ever rated a game that high?) ^^

Nevertheless - this game has done so many things in the right way during the development like with the game design that it's hard to find something they have done in a wrong way.

The feeling during the gameplay is gorgeous at all. (At least you need a PC that has a sound grasp of contemporary developments.) You get that fast hooked on this game, that's unbelievable.

Pros:
+ you'll never encounter any moment where you are NOT feeling to be on or in a water world
+ learning curve is smooth
+ exploration everywhere
+ all that more you go further into the deep or progress in the story, all that more fear you'll get
+ great concept of crafting and upgrading (every station that crafs or upgrades fits in its role)
+ no resource or recipe is useless
+ sea life - they are all well planned and placed (I mean they have even elaborated the evolution of certain species.)
+ the world is HUGE!- well designed biomes, caves, rifts, wracks
+ animations - they are all smoothed rendered that you are always have a flow
+ sounds - music is calm and not very present (thats's good), the sfxs' are superb
+ story - consists of fragments of voice logs you find during your progress through the game (This is by far not Witcher 3 story telling, but the way they've chosen it suits the game.)
+ it will leave early acces this quarter and gives the players exactly what the devs promised at the beginning of the development
+ free saving (no autosave)
+ high replayability

Cons:
- Sometimes you encounter some [i]little[/i] "bugs" like:
- getting stuck with the Prawn Suit (Getting stuck with my Prawn Suit was more or less my failure, I wanted to walk through a hole which was obviously to small for me. ^^ So never try this on your own. ;) It was just at the beginning of a new exploration so I reload the save and everything was fine. :D So make a save everytime you start a new exploration.)
- a locker won't display its inventory but the opening animation started. (That only happens if you are "to far away" from the locker - there is some miscalculation between the hitboxes.)
- from time to time your base is flooded, but only as animation - the hull is still intact. (Just save and reload and your base is fine again.)
(- no autosave: you have to remind youself to back you up )

[i]After 20h+ ingame I encountered no other bugs in the lastest version of Subnautica.[/i] The bugs I encountered in the previous 40h+ ingame of the old versions are all fixed now. Like the overall performance of the game - there is [u]no[/u] stuttering during biome loads [u]anymore[/u], there are [u]no[/u] game closing errors [u]anymore[/u], etc.

Why not 9/10 although there are stll bugs? 10/10, BECAUSE you can condone this little scratches, they are drowned between all other pros! Recommended!

Where to start? 
This game is nigh flawless. The story told is out-of-this-world and is filled with more than one plot twist.
The gameplay is smooth, and focusing on transitioning across land has never felt more engaging, and adds an active thing to be doing as you're sneaking around. 
Great elements of Kojima-style stealth, albeit (obviously) more limited than an MGS entry, with enough of it's own weird quirks to make it feel unique to this game. Pacing and integration of new equipment is well phased, would be great to see a replay option where you can skip the opening a bit more as it gets a bit dull to go back to basics so aggressively.
